abstract: To-day the force of United States marines which has been accumulating here for some time, will leave the Brooklyn Navy-yard, bound for Charleston, to strengthen that portion of the corps now attached to the Blockading squadron. Some years have elapsed since so formidable a body of regular troops left this neighborhood. The men are all in excellent condition, and perfectly disciplined. Officers who came on from the different stations will accompany them. They are all well supplied with ammunition, and are eager to have a hand in the attack on Charleston. Capt. LAWSON and Lieut. MEADE are among the officers ordered with the men. More than one-third of the entire marines in the service are now attached to Admiral DAHLGREN's fleet.
lead_paragraph: To-day the force of United States marines which has been accumulating here for some time, will leave the Brooklyn Navy-yard, bound for Charleston, to strengthen that portion of the corps now attached to the Blockading squadron. abstract: Caesarism in America
lead_paragraph: The performances of the Copperhead politicians during the last year will furnish a curious and instructive chapter to the history of this war. Being most of them born and bred in Free States, with every possible reason in blood, training and association, to love Liberty and hate Slavery, they have set themselves with a bitterness of which there are but few examples, even in the story of intestine strife, to aid a band of unscrupulous conspirators, who loathe and revile them while accepting their help, in their nefarious attempts to make the Slave Code a part of our common law, and place slaveholding on the footing in every part of the Union with properly and family. Being Americans, too, and most of them unblest with a single claim to anybody's respect, except their possession of American citizenship, they have endeavored by all means legal and illegal to promote the dismemberment of the Republic, for the purpose of establishing on its ruins two new States, one of them an armed oligarchy, avowedly based on "Slavery, subordination and government." in lieu of "liberty, equality and fraternity," and the other a shattered, broken-down Democracy, betrayed by its own citizens, and scorned and reviled by foreigners. They have, moreover, come out in the face of day and informed the world in set terms that twenty millions of Americans engaged in a war with five millions of rebels, have, after two campaigns, been "whipped" so thoroughly, as to make peace and submission not simply expedient but necessary. We believe that modern history does not contain any record of similar degradation.
headline: {'main': 'Caesarism in America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Caesarism in America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The proprietors of the Long Island race courses, have determined to give a week's rest to the ???otters, and in the meantime, about every one connected with the trotting end racing turf, will go in a body to Saratoga, where the running races will commence on Monday and last four days, under the management of Mr. JOHN MORRISSEY. Besides all the horses which run at the Paterson, Philadelphia and Centreville races, quite a number of other celebrated fast ones will contend, some of which have been brought from Canada and the Southwest. The Sunday evening boat Francis Skiddy, for Troy, will take up a large company of the leading turfmen, and the racing meeting will be one of the greatest events which has taken place at Saratoga in some years.

The Sunday evening boat Francis Skiddy, for Troy, will take up a large company of the leading turfmen, and the racing meeting will be one of the greatest events which has taken place at Saratoga in some years.

abstract: The August Term of the Court of General Sessions will commence on Monday next, before Recorder HOFFMAN. The Recorder, the District-Attorney and the Clerks of the Court, were anticipating a light month's work, and had made arrangements for spending a pleasant time in the country, but the riot in this City has upset their calculations, and furnished them with the largest criminal calendar of any month during the year. The District-Attorney intends to bring up the chief rioters for immediate trial, and with the well-known character of Recorder HOFFMAN for dispatching business, the community may rest assured that before the end of the Term a good number of the vagabonds will be doing the State service within the walls of a prison.
lead_paragraph: The August Term of the Court of General Sessions will commence on Monday next, before Recorder HOFFMAN. abstract: A rebel newspaper draws comfort (such as it is) from the loss of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson by declaring that far more consequence has always been attached to their retention than was deserved.
lead_paragraph: A rebel newspaper draws comfort (such as it is) from the loss of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson by declaring that far more consequence has always been attached to their retention than was deserved. The true way to have blockaded the Mississippi River, says this rebel organ, was to have waylaid its banks with sections of flying artillery -- dashing in, firing on passing boats, and disappearing in the backwoods -- at any of the " thousand points" on its course susceptible of such operations.

abstract: The slaves of the South must be getting rather crowded. Thousands were taken from Kentucky to Tennessee for fear of our armies, ...
lead_paragraph: The slaves of the South must be getting rather crowded. Thousands were taken from Kentucky to Tennessee for fear of our armies; and when the army entered Tennessee, tens of thousands were driven down into the Cotton States. When, again, our armies began operating on the Yazoo and along the Western rim of Mississippi, the planters of that great Cotton and Slave State felt their negro property was endangered, and sent them into the interior of the State. But after the fall of Vicksburgh and the captur of the State Capital, it was seen that no part of Mississippi was safe from Abolition influence, and the rebels began crowding the slaves eastward into Alabama and Georgia.

abstract: These Clubs met together on Thursday for the first time in five years in a friendly contest of cricket.
lead_paragraph: These Clubs met together on Thursday for the first time in five years in a friendly contest of cricket. The match was between the second elevens of the two Clubs, and took place on the St. George's ground, Hoboken, and it being a one-day's match, it was decided in favor of St. George by the result of the first innings, which was not finished till near sunset, the game standing 184 to 89.

abstract: -- People have been wondering what the ever-active, never-ceasing worker, Gen. GRANT, has been doing since the Fourth of July. He has not been airing his honors, nor parading his laurels, not blowing his trumpet -- nor even, like Hercules, after the twelve labors, has he subsided. The telegraph relieves our anxiety for him. "Gen. GRANT has perfected a complete system of mounted patrols between Vicksburgh and New-Orleans, which, with the gunboats, affords ample protection to vessels." Thus has this great soldier put the finishing touch to the gigantic work which was begun by him two years ago.
lead_paragraph: -- People have been wondering what the ever-active, never-ceasing worker, Gen. GRANT, has been doing since the Fourth of July. Thus has this great soldier put the finishing touch to the gigantic work which was begun by him two years ago.

abstract: Cushing vs. Ketchum, >amp;c.; Income Tax Decision
snippet: Cushing vs. Ketchum, >amp;c.; Income Tax Decision
lead_paragraph: James Cushing, Jr., vs. Edgar Ketcham, James Davis and George Good. -- NELSON, C.J. -- This bill is filed against the Collector and Deputies under the Internal Revenue act of 1st July, 1862, and amendments thereto, by the plaintiff, to restrain them from the collection of an income tax, under and by virtue of the act, upon dividends arising from stocks held in the Adams Express Company. The act of 1862, besides the income tax, imposed a stamp duty upon packages of every description, received by Express Companies for transportation. (??? 105.) The 10th section of the amendatory act, March 3, 1863, provides, "that on and after the 1st April, 18???3, any person or persons, &c., carrying on or doing any express business, shall, in lied of the tax and stamp duties imposed by the existing laws, be subject to and pay a duty of two per centum on the gross amount of all the receipts of such express business," &c., "and all acts and parts of acts, inconsistent therewith, are hereby repealed."

abstract: Motives of his Visit to Washington
snippet: Motives of his Visit to Washington
lead_paragraph: We are having a great many revolations of the secret motives of Vice-President STEPHENS' attempted visit to Washington. Three or four of our cotemporaries know all about it, and are not in the least unwilling to tell all they know. One curious feature of their disclosures is that no two of them agree in a single particular; and another is that each paper ascribes precisely such a motive to the Vice-President's mission as suits its own views of public policy. The Herald, for example, announces that Mr. STEPHENS wanted to go to Washington to inform Mr. LINCOLN that, if he would turn the "Radicals" out of the Cabinet, the Confederates would consent to peace. The Daily News has discovered, through the State Department at Washington, that Mr. STEPHENS wanted to inform the President that, unless he speedily stopped the war, the Confederates intended to call in the aid of LOUIS NAPOLEON; and the Tribune, which for a time swallowed and magnified the story of the News, has now received a special revelation from Richmond, to the effect that the Vice-President desired to announce to the National Government that, if the Union men persisted in arming negroes, the rebels would do the same.

abstract: A dispatch from Harrisburgh to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated the 30th of July, says: "Considerable excitement has been created here by the discovery of enormous frauds upon the Government during the recent army movements in this region consequent the rebel raid.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Harrisburgh to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated the 30th of July, says: "Considerable excitement has been created here by the discovery of enormous frauds upon the Government during the recent army movements in this region consequent the rebel raid. The amounts are stated at millions of dollars. A number of prominent State politicians have been placed under arrest, and the subject will receive the most searching investigation by the War Department. The most corrupt practices have prevailed in horse contracts and in clothing and subsistence supplies. They throw the "shoddy" operators at Harrisburg, in the Summer of 1861, entirely in the shade. Many of the same parties are implicated, and the gangs who have infested the State capital in the Winter have reaped a rich Summer harvest."

abstract: Emperor, the, and Southern Recognition
lead_paragraph: It seems quite certain that LOUIS NAPOLEON intends, if possible, to secure the recogtion of the Southern Confederacy. He will do everything in his power to engage the cooperation of England. Failing in this, he will probably venture on his knowledge of her sympathies, and counting at least on her passive acquiescence, he will recognize the rebel Confederacy alone. We do not believe he can induce any considerable European State to join him: and the moment he is convinced of this, he will probably take independent action.

abstract: The steamer Britannia, Capt. DE FORREST, bound from Charleston to this port, was chased on the 25th ult. by the Federal gunboat St. Jago de Cuba, and captured about 150 miles from A???aco. The chase continued fourteen hours, and, had the gunboat not been between ???er and the land, she would have escaped. The Captain and passengers of the Britannia were transferred to the gunboat, and a prize crew took possession of the vessel. She was then taken in tow by the gunboat, for the purpose of being conveyed to Port Royal, and two days afterward they fell in with the bark Tycoon, bound for New-Orleans. Six of the passengers went on board the bark, (there not being accommodation for more.) who were landed at Great Stirrup's Cay, and arrived hero yesterday in a sloop.

abstract: The obsequies of Brig. Gen, STRONG will be ob  served in this City to-day. Col. P.V. HARNER, United States Inspector in the Ordnance Department, and...
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Brig.-Gen. STRONG will be observed in this City to-day. Col. P.V. HAGNER, United States Inspector in the Ordnance Department, and Col. FRANK E. HOWE were requested by the relatives and friends of the deceased to act as a Committee to confer with the Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council with reference to the programme of arrangements to be adopted. The meeting was held at 11 A.M. yesterday, and the programme, including the order of the procession, which appears in, another column of this paper was agreed upon. By order of Gen. CANBY, the Eighth United States infantry and a section of Battery C, Fifth United States artillery, will constitute the military escort. The pall-bearers will assemble at No. 62 East Nineteenth- street 9:45 o'clock this morning, and bear the remains to the church corner of Twenty-second-street and Fourth-avenue.

abstract: CLOSING OF THE ASTOR LIBRARY.--The Astor Library will close to-day, for four weeks, or until Monday morning, the 31st of August.
lead_paragraph: CLOSING OF THE ASTOR LIBRARY. -- The Astor Library will close to-day, for four weeks, or until Monday morning, the 31st of August. Ever since the library opened it has been the custom to give the Superintendent and librarians a vacation during the month of August, which affords an opportunity to make any repairs that may be necessary, and also to arrange and dust the books. During the vacation, all the alcoves will be thoroughly cleaned, and each book in the library taken down and dusted. The library now contains nearly 132,000 volumes. Since the rebellion broke out, the additions in the way of books have not been large, but the periodicals are all kept up, and a considerable number of works of art have been added. There has been no perceptible falling off in the attendance at the library since the war broke out. The average attendance during this month has been from 150 to 200 persons per day.

abstract: Reynolds, Wm., Actor, by accident
lead_paragraph: At five o'clock on Thursday afternoon Mr. WM. REYNOLDS, who for many years has been attached to Wallack's Theatre, went, in company with a party of ladies, to bathe, at Cliffwood, N.J., opposite Keyport. He left the ladies at the beach and proceeded to the long dock, where he removed his clothes and put on his bathing dress, and went in the water from the dock. As he did not make his appearance for some time, the ladies, fearful that some accident had befallen him, gave the alarm. A gentleman proceeded to the dock, where he found Mr. REYNOLDS' clothing, but all traces of his person had disappeared. It is supposed he must have drowned whilst in a cramp. At the time of the Keyport boat leaving, yesterday morning, the body had not been recovered.

abstract: SHORT's KNAPSACK SLINGING. -- The question of alleviating a soldier's hardships is one that in these days come home to every able-bodied man in the community, and one that has been anxiously canvassed in hundreds of thousands of families during the many months of war. Many schemes are projected by the kind-hearted and philanthropic, some of which are practically useful, while others serve rather to encumber the soldier than lighten his burdens. But on Saturday we were shown an improved knapsack -- the improvement having especial reference to the mode of slinging -- that deserves to take the first place among modern inventions for the comfort of the marching soldier. The material of the knapsack is water-proof duck, and by a simple adjustment of the straps the burden is poised upon the centre of gravity, without bringing any pressure upon the heart or breathing organs. The relief that this arrangement brings can be appreciated to its fullest extent only by those who have borne the old Government knapsacks during a match of wearisome miles, until tempted to throw it by the wayside with all its indispensable contents. Thirty thousand of these improved knapsacks have already been brought into use, and the testimony in their favor is unanimous and overwhelming. It is not too much to say that no new regiments should be sent into the field without them, and that they should be substituted for those already in use as speedily as possible. We have no doubt that our State authorities will secure this result as soon as the merits of the improvement are brought to their attention. -- Providence Journal.

abstract: Thursday evening, at the Seventh-av. Arsenal, the officers and members of the Eighth regiment N. Y.N.G. presented to their Colonel, JOSHUA M. VARIAN, an elegant sword, sash and belt.
lead_paragraph: Thursday evening, at the Seventh-av. Arsenal, the officers and members of the Eighth regiment N.Y.N.G. presented to their Colonel, JOSHUA M. VARIAN, an elegant sword, sash and belt. The entire regiment, also a large number of friends, including many ladies, were present on the occasion. The presentation speech was made by Capt. ELAUVELT, who in appropriate terms referred to the military career of Col. VARIAN, and paid a fitting eulogy to his soldierly promptness and ability. Col. VARIAN, on receiving the gift, responded in a feeling and apposite manner, and briefly sketched the history of the regiment, and his connection with it since its formation. abstract: Capt. JOURDON and Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, yesterday afternoon made a highly important arrest of a man charged with one of the most brutal murders on record.
lead_paragraph: Capt. JOURDON and Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, yesterday afternoon made a highly important arrest of a man charged with one of the most brutal murders on record. Some six days since, Capt. JOURDON received information that JOHN MCALISTER, an Irish laborer, 40 years of age, employed in the sugar house of Messrs. BOOTH & EDGAR, corner of King and West streets, was the individual who so brutally murdered the negro WILLIAM WILLIAMS, (previously reported.) corner of Leroy and Washington streets, early on the morning of the 14th ult. After much trouble Capt. JOURDON and Officer GOLDEN learned that Mr. CAIEB LAWRENCE, of No. 74 Morton- street, witnessed the murder, and if was with the greatest difficulty that he could be persuaded to come forward and lodge a complaint against the prisoner, lest he might be injured therefor in person or property. Yesterday, however, Mr. LAWRENCE seeing MCALISTER in the street, pursued by Capt. JOURDON and Officer GOLDEN, positively identified him as the murderer of WILLIAMS. The officers succeeded in arresting him. He was not at the time made aware of the charge, being led to believe that he was wanted for beating a female, last Thursday, while on an excursion.

abstract: MORGAN'S raid opens up a fine field for thought upon the subject of puffery, especially as connected with certain so-called heroes of the rebel army. It does not cause any very widemouthed surprise when some local newspaper persistently puffs its village General or Colonel, ...
lead_paragraph: MORGAN's raid opens up a fine field for thought upon the subject of puffery, especially as connected with certain so-called heroes of the rebel army. It does not cause any very widemouthed surprise when some local newspaper persistently puffs its village General or Colonel, and refuses to see any hero but him; but when the Press generally settles upon some roving rascal in the rebel service, and elevates him to herodom, surrounding him with the halo of romance, and inventing piquant stories to illustrate his deeds, it is time to seek them a hero that may be worthy of their steel -- pens.

abstract: Discourse on Emancipation in Missouri
lead_paragraph: The moral victories of the nation in this war are less observed and gloried in than the victories won on the battle-field, but they are still of surpassing grandeur and importance. One of the noblest of these triumphs was achieved when the State of Missouri, the young giant of the West, through its own State Convention, inaugurated a scheme for the emancipation of its slaves. It was a victory whose sweep is greater than the capture of Vicksburgh -- whose influence will extend further into time than the opening of the Mississippi, and whose glory will be imperishable -- enduring even when American power has become a story of the past. It is indeed the greatest act, or fact, so far, in this whole war, except, it may be, the uprising of the people at its commencement.

abstract: A horrible tragedy occurred in San Francisco on the 2d inst., resulting in the death of Dr. GEORGE W. BEERS, with his wife and child, a little girl ten years or age. BEERS and his family occupied rooms on the corner of Stockton and Geary streets, and the place having been unusually quiet during the day, the landlady called about 7 o'clock in the evening, when she was shocked at finding the parents lying dead in the front, and the little girl in the adjoining room.

abstract: ARREST OF AN OLD BURGLAR HIS EFFORTS TO ESCAPE. GEORGE SMITH, an old and well-known burglar, late on Friday afternoon forced open the rear window of premises No. 225 West Forty-eight-street, occupied by Mrs. ELIZA STEEPLAR, during the absence of the latter and commeneed a search for plunder.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN OLD BURGLAR -- HIS EFFORTS TO ESCAPE. -- GEORGE SMITH, an old and well-known burglar, late on Friday afternoon forced open the rear window of premises No. 225 West Forty-eight-street, occupied by Mrs. ELIZA STEEPLAR, during the absence of the latter and commeneed a search for plunder. While SMITH was sacking the upper rooms. Mrs. STEEPLAR returned, and having no other means of escape, the thief jumped from a second story window to the yard, and ran off. His movements were discovered by Mrs. S., who gave the alarm, when officers TIERNEY and DALL, of the Twenty-second Precint, pursued the fugitive, and at the corner of Tenth-avenue and Thirty-third-street he was overtaken and arrested by Officer TIERNEY. The prisoner was searched, and the officer found in his possession about $30 in money, a quantity of jewelry, and other property which he had stolen from Mrs. STEEPLAR. He also had a number of skeleton keys, screwdriver and other burglarious implements in his pockets. Justice KELLY committed SMITH to the Toombs, in default of $3,000 bail. Especial credit is due to the officers who made the arrest, for so promptly and closely following up this old offender.

abstract: Federalist, the, on Political Bodies
lead_paragraph: The so-called States Rights politicians have recently revived, and are now maintaining with all the energy at their disposal, the worn-out fallacy, that the United States "are a nation in their relations with foreign Powers, but only a confederation of independent States in their relations with one another." Considering the completeness of the discussion which this theory underwent in all its bearings during the existence of the old Confederacy, at the hand of the ablest statesmen of the Revolution, it may seem strange that anybody should have to warn the public of its absurdity in our day; but when the organ of a political party deliberately and repeatedly puts forward the fact of the President's having suspended the Habeas Corpus Act, as a palliation if not justification of the murders, arson and pillage recently committed by the mob in this City, we need not be surprised by the display on the part of the "blatherskite" school of publicists of any amount, either of ignorance and forgetfulness, or mental confusion.

The main body of the rebels, he says, is thought to be on the south bank of the Rapidan. Its exact location, however, is expected to be soon ascertained, as Gen. MEADE's army is about to make an important movement, which will unmask it. The men and goods carried off by MOSEBY on Friday, from Fairfax Court-house, were yesterday recovered by an expedition under Col. LOVELL. MOSEBY escaped, with all but five of his followers.

abstract: The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday decided, as in the TIMES it has been stated they would do, that the City Judge has no power to issue writs of habeas corpus.
lead_paragraph: The General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday decided, as in the TIMES it has been stated they would do, that the City Judge has no power to issue writs of habeas corpus. This decision, it is understood, was unanimous, and it was in anticipation of at that the Warden of the City Prisons, during the last week, refused to respond to the writs of Judge MCCUNN, and the Sheriff refused to serve attachments for contempt. They took this position under the highest legal advice, and by their action have probably presented a general jail-delivery of the rioters and thieves, thus far arrested. It is estimated that Judge MCCUNN has issued during the last year not less than 2,500 writs of habeas corpus -- probably three times as many as have been issued by all the other Judges in the State. Every one of the parties who have been released by the City Judge, by means of the habeas corpus, is liable to rearrest, and the authorities will take prompt measures to secure them. Provost-Marshal NUGENT intends to take into custody, whenever found, all discharged soldiers and others who have obtained their release on proceedings had by habeas corpus before Judge MCCUNN.

abstract: Another Maori War
lead_paragraph: England, ere this, has been dragged into another Maori war -- a war which will prove still more formidable, and redound still less to her credit, than all former ones with the New-Zealanders. For now the whole aboriginal race have been roused to hostility, and seem determined to make a desperate struggle to preserve what remains to them of the heritage of their ancestors. To the indiscretion of the Colonial Government must be ascribed the beginning of the present trouble. During the last war, the British settlers had been expelled from the Fataraimaka district, and at the conclusion of peace, the right of the natives who had taken possession of it was not called in question. Hence the Maori came to regard their new acquisition as a trophy of their valor, and continued undisputed masters of it till the Spring of the current year. Then it suddenly occurred to Sir GEORGE GREY that he ought to compel the Maori to disgorge Fataraimaka, in order that it might be restored to the emigrant settlers. Had the restoration of the territory to the Europeans been made one of the conditions of the peace it would have been fair enough; but after suffering the natives to hold it for three years, and to look on it as their own property, it was imprudent for the Governor to capriciously revive an obsolete claim, and require the de facto owners to abandon possession; may, to send a military force to drive them from the soil.

abstract: In the Matter of Godfrey March. On the petition of his mother, Barbara Munch, Godfrey Munch was brought before the Court on a writ of habeas corpus.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Godfrey Munch. -- On the petition of his mother, Barbara Munch, Godfrey Munch was brought before the Court on a writ of habeas corpus. The writ was directed to Col. Nugent, Provost-Marshal, in whose custody it was claimed Munch was unlawfully detained. It was further claimed that Munch, though a soldier in the service of the Untied States, was an infant under the age of twenty-one years when he enlisted, and that he did so without the parental consent.

abstract: FIRE AND LOSS OF LIFE. Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Friday night, a fire broke out in the hat factory of J. STEWART  Co., corner of De Kalb and Kent avenues. A large portion of the contents were destroyed, and the building was considerably damaged.
lead_paragraph: FIRE AND LOSS OF LIFE. -- Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Friday night, a fire broke out in the hat factory of J. STEWART & CO., corner of De Kalb and Kent avenues. A large portion of the contents were destroyed, and the building was considerably damaged. A serious accident occurred in Myrtle-avenue, near Duffield-street, involving the death of one man and serious and, perhaps, fatal injuries to two others, caused by racing; engines on the railroad track. -- a practice which, of late, has been extensively indulged in, and which has, within the past two weeks, resulted in the death of two persons, besides the one killed yesterday. It appears that Engine Company No. Nineteen came in collision with Hook and Ladder No. Two, and such was the force of the concussion, that ISAAC T. WHEELER, belonging to to the Truck Company was run over and sustained a fracture of the skull, and one arm broken. HENRY STARK, of the same Company, had his collar bone broken, and PHILLIP SHANNON had one of his legs badly fractured. The latter were taken to the City Hospital. WHEELER was conveyed to his residence, No. 222 Jay-street, where he died in a few hours thereafter. An inquest will be held upon the body this afternoon by Coroner NORRIS. The damage to the property was about $l,200, mostly insured in the Lafa yette Insurance Company of Brooklyn. The fire is supposed to have been caused by accident.

abstract: Vernon, Lord, and the Countess Della Seta Case
snippet: Vernon, Lord, and the Countess Della Seta Case
lead_paragraph: This case, which has been several times mentioned in our columns, came on again before Vice-Chancellor STUART, on Monday. It was stated that in the year 1842 Lord VERNON became acquainted with the Countess DELLA SETA, of Florence. An intimacy soon arose between that lady and his lordship, and the result was that the Countess had four daughters, of which his lordship was the reputed father. In 1852 Lord VERNON discontinued the connection, and by a deed dated the 30th August in that year, he entered into a covenant with trustees to pay them during his life 1,000 per annum, upon trust that they should pay the same to the Countess for her life for her separate use, with a restrict on in anticipation in case of her marriage; and after her death, upon further trust, that they should pay 200 annually out of the said sum of $1,000, to each of his four daughters by the Countess, and the remaining 200, being the residue of the sum of 1,000, to himself; and in case any of the young lad???es should, during the joint lives of the Countess and Lord VERNON, attain the age of twenty-one, or marry under that age, then that each of the daughters who should so attain that age, or marry, should, during the life of Lord VERNON, be paid the sum of 100 out of the annuity of 1,000. Lord VERNON also by the same deed assigned to the trustees thereof a policy of assurance on his own life for 5,000, and covenanted to pay to them at his decease a further sum of 15,000, and directed that they should stand possessed of the moneys to arise from the policy and the sum of 15,000 upon trust for the countess for her life for her separate use, with a restriction in anticipation in case of her marriage, and after her death, for the four young ladies before-named. The deed declared that the provision thereby made for the countess was so made upon the express condition that she should thereout, when received, maintain and educate the young ladies respectively during their minorities to the satisfaction of the trustees, unless and until such conditions should be dispensed with by Lord VERNON; and that, in case of any breach by the Countess of the condition without the licence or consent in writing of Lord VERNON, it should be lawful for the trustees, with the approbation of Lord VERNON, to withhold from the countess such portion as they should think fit of her annual income, and to apply the same toward the maintenance and education of the young ??? The countess married the Count DELLA SETA on the 26th of November, 1853, and one of the ??? ladies died in July, 1858. Lord VERNON, hearing that the surviving children, who were now severally of the ages of 20, 17 and 15, were not happy with their mother, and, further, that they had left her h??? at Cairo, whither she had gone for her health, caused a suit to be instituted on the 20th of June last in behalf of the young ???es by one of his sons, as their next friend, for the purpose of carrying into effect the ??? of August, 1852, and making them wards of court, and for a scheme for their maintenance and education. On the 23d June, 1862, a second ??? was filed, the bill in the first suit having been served on the so???or of the plaintiff in the second suit on the 22d of June. The bill in the cause of the "Countess DELLA SETA vs. Lord VERNON" was originally filed on behalf of the Countess and her three surviving daughters, and it prayed that the trusts of the deed of the 30th of August, 1852, might be carried into execution. An order was made on the 2??? instant directing an annual sum of 100 to be paid to the Countess by monthly instalments, and two sums in s??? port of that allowance had been accordingly paid to her for the months of June last and July inst., the payments for these months being the only sums in arrear on the 2d inst., and on the deed of August, 1852. The object of the present application in the second suit was to raise the allowance of 400 to 700, and also to obtain an order directing that the Countess might have access to her daughters, one of whom had been dangerously ??? at Turin, but was now better. The Countess had started for Turin, but it was said that her daughter did not desire to see her, and that the medical attendant of the young lady that was ill did not think it advisable the Countess should see her. Under these circumstances the Countess had not seen any of her daughters at Turin. Mr. BACON, for Lord VERNON, said that his lordship had no other desire for privacy in the discussion of this case than that, which any man would naturally feel who had formed such a connection as that which had existed between him and the Countess. Beyond this, he personally had no ???ear of publicity. He had always, until within the last few weeks, when he had reason to believe that the Countess was failing in her duty to her children, punctually made the payments he had, by the deed of August, 1852, contracted to make. In the early part of the present year he heard that the young ladies had fled from their mother's house a Cairo to that of a stranger to him there, and that their mother had left for England. He immediately sent a trust worthy person to Cairo to take charge of his daughters, and had them taken to Turin and placed at a boarding-school there, where they now were. His next step was to cause the suit of "Lavoignat vs. White" to be instituted, because If what he had heard respecting the Countess were true, she was not fit to have the custody of the young ladies. Lord VERNON desired only to carry out to the letter the deed of August, 1852. He did not desire to shrink from one ???ota of the liabilities he had thereby laid himself under, and the statements which had been circulated to the contrary were false, and they were, moreover, known to be false by those who had put them abroad. Mr. RUSSELL appeared for the Trustees; and Mr. GREEN for the three young ladies, wards of the Court.

abstract: To the many familiar names that Death has clasped his sheares during the present year must be added, we regret to say, that of Mr. REYNOLDS the actor. Mr. REYNOLDS will be well and kindly remembered by the frequenters of Mr. WALLACK'S theatre. He has been for many years a valuable, ...
lead_paragraph: To the many familiar names that Death has clasped his sheares during the present year must be added, we regret to say, that of Mr. REYNOLDS -- the actor. Mr. REYNOLDS will be well and kindly remembered by the frequenters of Mr. WALLACK's theatre. He has been for many years a valuable, reliable and excellent member of its company. During the past season he appeared on almost every night, and it was generally remarked that his various impersonations were characterized by more than ordinary spirit and intelligence. His powers had ripened beneath the genial influence of public favor, and his career on the nobler altitude of art had fairly commenced. The apothegm to the Latin poet -- Ars longa vita brevis -- applies sadly to his case. The road had been long and dreary, but the goal was in sight when death stepped between him and the object of his ambition. There are but few retails of the calamity. It was purely accidental, Mr. REYNOLDS, it seems, went out batting at Keyport, N.J., Thursday last. He was alone, having separated from some friends for the express purpose of enjoying the water. Some time after ward these friends returned to the spot where Mr. REYNOLDS had entered. They found his clothes, but the unfortunate owner was not to be seen. From that time to the present nothing has been heard of the unhappy gentleman. He was an expert swimmer, and it is conjectured, therefore, that he must have been seized with cramp, or been carried out beyond the possibility of return by a treacherous undertow. His death will be lamented by a large circle of personal friends, and the professional loss to Mr. WALLACE will not be easily replaced. Mr. REYNOLDS was a native of Pennsylvania, and about 35 years of age.

abstract: Recruiting in Kansas for both the new and old regiments proceeds quite briskly. Our present quota, under the draft, is reported as a little over 1,600 men. Keep it off for a month and we shall recruit nearly that number.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting in Kansas for both the new and old regiments proceeds quite briskly. Our present quota, under the draft, is reported as a little over 1,600 men. Keep it off for a month and we shall recruit nearly that number. During the last month we have raised eight companies for old cavalry regiments: Companies M and L, Fifth; I, L and M, Sixth; and I, L and M for the Ninth Kansas. The last two lack about a dozen men to fill up. The Eleventh Kansas, mounted infantry, report 100 men recruited since the receipt of the order to mount, not two weeks since. The Thirteenth, also ordered to be mounted, lacked 70 men of the minimum strength. It has filled up within a week. Companies A, B and "C," of the new cavalry regiment, Fourteenth Kansas, are mustered, and are serving with Gen. BLUNT as a body guard. Company D has mustered 60 men, and three other companies have about the same number, making seven companies raised in little over a month. The Second Kansas Colored regiment has four companies ready for muster, or nearly so, and about 200 recruits in additional detachments. A fact worthy of notice is that all the claim made by the State against the General Government for expenses incurred in organizing troops, is $12,351 04. It is true that the War Department has more directly than in other States been concerned in the primary organization of troops. Yet it is also true, and remarkably so, that such organization has cost far less than elsewhere.

abstract: According to the Springfield Republican, it is no wonder the exempts are greatly in excess of the men accepted, if all the Surgeons proceed on the plan of one in one of the eastern districts of Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: -- According to the Springfield Republican, it is no wonder the exempts are greatly in excess of the men accepted, if all the Surgeons proceed on the plan of one in one of the eastern districts of Massachusetts. Three hardy coasters, half fisherman, half farmers, went to him, and so sine were they that they had no real cause for exemption, that each carried $3???0 in his pocket, with which to pay commutation. Number one was asked if anything ailed him. He did not know of anything, unless it was that one of his feet hurt him after walking a good deal, (quite natural for a fisherman, not much used to it;) and so, after looking at his foot, the Commissioners excused him for "a ???nion," to hurt unconscious. Number two being asked if anything ailed him -- a man famous for success in capturing whales -- he said he sometimes felt a giddiness in his head, (natural to one of good appetite, who sometimes did not have occasion to work off his f???l feed.) He received a certificate of exemption on account of "chronic diarrhoea." The third simply stated that he did not think himself strong enough for a soldier, and was turned by for "general debility."

abstract: At the outbreak of the rebellion CHARLES FOLSOM was driven from Galveston, Texas, together with his father and mother, because of their Union sentiments.
lead_paragraph: At the outbreak of the rebellion CHARLES FOLSOM was driven from Galveston, Texas, together with his father and mother, because of their Union sentiments. They returned to this State, the old folks settling in Putnam County, and young FOLSOM, then twenty-eight years of age, entering in the First New-York mounted riflemen, Col. C.C. DODGE. He served with honor until last May, having been in sixteen battles -- among them those at South Mountain, the seven days battles on the Peninsula, Antietam and on the Blackwater. He was wounded on the Blackwater, and in May was allowed his discharge, then being Orderly Sergeant, returning to his family in Putnam County. On Monday evening, hearing of the riot here, he hurried down, repaired to Headquarters, and volunteered his services in any capacity in which he could be useful. He was sworn in as special Policeman and at once, with others, was sent on active duty against the mob, his part being bravely performed throughout. On Thursday, at 4 o'clock in the morning, he was sent with a squad of Police to Twenty-seventh-street and Seventh-avenue, to recover the body of the colored man hung there. A wagon was taken along, which had to be drawn by hand, and while on return with the body the wheels became fastened in the railroad track; in endeavoring to release them FOLSOM had his right hand and wrist badly broken. He made no complaint, but continued his duties manfully till reaching Headquarters, where he was put under care of the surgeon.

abstract: A dispatch from Washington announcing that the draft would be resumed in this City on Monday next, proves, on inquiry at the Provost-Marshal's office in this City, to be incorrect. Provost-Marshal NUGENT has received no instructions to that effect, ...
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Washington announcing that the draft would be resumed in this City on Monday next, proves, on inquiry at the Provost-Marshal's office in this City, to be incorrect. Provost-Marshal NUGENT has received no instructions to that effect, and, indeed, it would be impossible to resume the draft to-morrow, for the reason that no buildings have been secured in place of those burned by the mob, in which to make the drawing. The probabilities are, however, that it will be resumed early in the week. The Provost-Marshal has been directed to erect temporary quarters for the purpose, in case he is unable to procure suitable buildings. Whenever the authorities at Washington order the draft to be resumed, a notice to that effect will be published in all the papers. It is possible that the draft will begin by Wednesday or Thursday of this week, but not before. The Government will be amply prepared to put down all opposition to the enforcement of the draft and to protect United States property in the City, but further than that they will have nothing to do in suppressing mobs, unless their interposition is asked for by the State or City authorities. It is the duly of the State and municipal authorities to protect the lives and property of the citizens against murderers. Incendiaries, thieves and plunderers, such as roved through the streets during the late riots; and if the people of this City have not sufficient interest at stake to protect themselves, or to compel the proper authorities to protect them, they must submit to whatever consequences may ensue.

abstract: ALINA, who was passing through the hallway at the time, heard the remark, and replied, "Come in here and I will see whether you can or not." Upon this deceased ran after him, and the parties came together in the back yard. ALINA broke away and ran up stairs, while HUNT returned to the passage-way. The Italian came down shortly afterward, and the conversation was renewed very angrily. The parties came together, and in a few moments HUNT was heard to exclaim, "I am stabbed," or "I am murdered." ALINA ran away. HUNT was taken up by Officer MULLIGAN, of the Sixth Precinct, and conveyed to the City Hospital. He died soon after being admitted. ALINA is still at large, but Capt. JOURDAN thinks he will have him today. The Coroner's inquest in the case will be held this morning.

abstract: The Rebel Sympathizers of
lead_paragraph: To what depths of ingratitude human nature may sink when free rein is given to the sordid passions, is well illustrated by the conduct of the Bermudians in relation to our National struggle. For a very long period these islands have been mainly dependent upon the North, and especially upon New-York, for whatever commercial prosperity they enjoy. Here the products of their soil have found a ready and profitable market, in return for which we have sent them supplies of cattle, breadstuffs and assorted merchandise, which, with singular lack of energy and thrift, their people have failed to produce for themselves. Here, too, large numbers of their aspiring young men have found honorable and lucrative employment, that was denied them in the islands of their nativity. It might reasonably have been supposed, therefore, that where the interests of these islanders were so closely allied their sympathies in the contest would have been placed. But these bonds have proved weaker than a spider's web. In the very beginning of the war, abundant evidence was given of Bermudian readiness to affiliate with the rebels of the South, between whom and themselves there had been previously not one thing in common. With eager avarice the merchants at once shamelessly engaged in furnishing material to rebel purchasers; the facilities of the fine harbor of St. George have been steadily extended to the fleet of blockade runners; the dingy newspapers have teemed with malignant diatribes upon the "Yankees;" Union victories have been deplored and rebel successes made the occasion of public exultation. But all these methods of dispensing aid to the enemy, under the guise of neutrality, although assisting to prolong the war, we have endured and can continue to endure with some degree of complaisancy. The base ingratitude they evince we do not take into account, and their moral sympathy we do not yearn after. But they have recently committed an act which makes it high time, not simply for protest, but for retaliation.
headline: {'main': 'Ungrateful Islanders The Rebel Sympathizers of Bermuda.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Ungrateful Islanders The Rebel Sympathizers of Bermuda.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

The enemy appeared in large force on the hills, in the neighborhood of the Gap, and the order was given to dislodge them.

abstract: The funeral of Brig.-Gen. GEORGE C. STRONG, who fell during the recent attack on Fort Wagner, took place, yesterday, from St. Paul's M.E. Church, on the Fourth-avenue. The body was removed from the residence of the deceased, in Nineteenth-street, to the church, about 10 o'clock in the forenoon.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Brig.-Gen. GEORGE C. STRONG, who fell during the recent attack on Fort Wagner, took place, yesterday, from St. Paul's M.E. Church, on the Fourth-avenue. The body was removed from the residence of the deceased, in Nineteenth-street, to the church, about 10 o'clock in the forenoon. A large military force was drawn up in front of the church, and extending some distance up and down the avenue, through which the corpse was borne. Great numbers of spectators also lined the avenue in the neighborhood of the church. As the procession marched into the church the organist played a dirge from MOZART. Among the distinguished military officers present at the funeral were Maj.-Gen. B.F. BUTLER, with several members of his Staff; Gen. CANBY and Staff, and Maj. CHRIST???NSEN.

abstract: -- The claims filed against the City for damages to property sustained during the late riots, already sum up to an amount considerably above $600,000. And the list is by no means complete. Whatever losses shall be established must be paid by an assessment on the property of citizens, not one in ten thousand of whom, it is fair to assume, had anything to do with the destruction caused. If to the claims for damages thus laid we add the $2,500,000 that the City Council propose to pay, to buy off the conscripts that shall be drawn in the City, we shall have a total of over $3,000,000 to be paid by the property-holders of New-York City, on account of a few thousand scamps, thieves and law-breakers, whom $1,000 worth of powder and lead, judiciously administered from the muzzles of muskets, would have converted into lamb-like citizens, if not effective soldiers.

abstract: True lovers of their country watched the action of the last Congress with great anxiety. The interests which are committed to any Congress are widespread and mighty enough to call for the closest attention of every citizen. But upon the action of the last Congress depended not material interests alone.
lead_paragraph: True lovers of their country watched the action of the last Congress with great anxiety. The interests which are committed to any Congress are widespread and mighty enough to call for the closest attention of every citizen. But upon the action of the last Congress depended not material interests alone. The very existence of the nation depended upon its organizing plans not only to raise funds, but to call forth armies for the struggle with the rebellion -- and every patriot breathed more freely when the news was heard that the Conscription bill was passed. We all felt as if the nation had got a new hold on life; a renewed sense of security and confidence spread over the land, in the knowledge that the whole power of the nation could be called forth, not only by the voice of sentiment and enthusiasm, but by that sterner and more potent voice of law, to which the people throughout the Northern States have ever been accustomed to render a ready obedience.

abstract: Yesterday, Aug. 1, 1863, the black gelding Gen. Butler (so famous for last time in his trotting matches against the celebrated stallion George M. Patchen) trotted his match against time on the Fashion Course; his owner backlog him to trot three ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Aug. 1, 1863, the black gelding Gen. Butler (so famous for last time in his trotting matches against the celebrated stallion George M. Patchen) trotted his match against time on the Fashion Course; his owner backing him to trot three miles in harness in less than 7 minutes 32 1/2 seconds, that time having been made, under the saddle, by the famous trotting horse Dutchman, on the 1st of August, 1839, just twenty-four years ago. The match was made by Butler's owner, who took the odes of two to one -- or $500 to $250 -- that Butler would not beat 7 minutes 32 1/2 seconds; Mr. HORACE F. JONES being the backer of time against the horse.

abstract: In accordance with an invitation from the City Inspector's Office, quite a number of gentleman proceeded, in company with Mr. BOOLE, upon a tour of inspection through the City, yesterday afternoon. They were requested to select the localities which they wished to examine, and saying "the very worst," ...
lead_paragraph: In accordance with an invitation from the City Inspector's Office, quite a number of gentleman proceeded, in company with Mr. BOOLE, upon a tour of inspection through the City, yesterday afternoon. They were requested to select the localities which they wished to examine, and saying "the very worst," it was not long before the carriages were ???olling over the disordered cobble-stones of Elm-street, and the various Five Paints thorough tres. The streets and gutters were found to be remarkably clean, the Sixth Ward, in-fact hardly being recognizable. Upon streets that six months ago would have been considered models of nearness the sweepers were hard at work, seeking to scrape up an extra load, and the well-limed gutters gave evidence of general attention. Nothing could have more pleased the visiting party than a sight of in sold pest-hole clean, for it was as clean -- cleaner, in fact -- than some other portions of the City, where there was, apparently, a much better opportunity to exercise the hoe and broom.

abstract: -- Mr. JOHN WERNER, a native of Russia, arrived in New-York on the 12th inst., having come to this country for the benefit of his health. Before leaving his native land, he engaged a Belgian named CHARLES HEOLEN to accompany him as interpreter, at a salary of $10 per week during his visit, and until his return. On account of the riotous proceedings in New-York, Mr. WERNER came to this city, and took lodgings at the Adams House, but being desirous of enjoying sea-bathing, he also took rooms at the Atlantic House, Chelsea Beach, to which place he removed a portion of his baggage. On Saturday, Mr. WERNER, with his interpreter, came up to the city, and going to the hotel, HEOLEN left him there, saying he would return shortly. Three or four hours passed, and as HEOLEN did not return, Mr. WERNER became quite uneasy, being entirely alone, and barely able to utter a word of English. He finally returned to the beach, and on going to his rooms, ascertained that HEOLEN had been there but a short time previously, and that his trunks had been opened and robbed of eight hundred gold five franc pieces and several articles of clothing, leaving him with only about $5 in ready cash, and an entire stranger in a strange land. As HEOLEN has not been heard of since, no doubt exists that he was the robber. He is described as about five feet ten inches high, twenty-eight or thirty years old, prominent and rather that nose, very high forehead, blue eyes, scar across the left temple, yellowish hair and long side-whiskers of the same color, and speaks English, French and German fluently.

abstract: Mr. Purdy's house--desperate conflict
lead_paragraph: For some months past the town of Rye, Westchester County, has been infested with burglars, and to such an extent that a Vigilance Committee had been organized, under the charge of Mr. TITUS, one of the most prominent citizens. The services of Detectives SLOWEY and TIERNAN, of the Metropolitan Police, were called into requisition, and they had been up there repeatedly, and indefatigable in working up the case. Eight or ten burglaries had been committed in the town, and ??? night the gang entered the house of Mr. KINGSLAND. Going up stairs, and attempting to enter his ???, a spring bell gave the alarm; Mr. KINGSLAND and a man in his employ rushed from their beds, and gave the burglars pursuit, but they fled down stairs and escaped; it was subsequently discovered that two dogs in the basement had been chloroformed and then taken out and their brains dashed out against a tree; the Detectives being subsequently called to the house, ascertained by the footmarks in the soil, that one of the villains had a very small and peculiarly shaped foot, and the other a very large one. This discovery was of advantage in identifying the burglars, as portions of those who were subsequently arrested for entering, on last Wednesday morning, the dwelling of Mr. WILLIAM PURDT, a well known and wealthy farmer of that town.

abstract: the City Inspector
lead_paragraph: The mythology of the ancients teems with legends of the destruction of lions, hydras, and all sorts of monsters. Theseus made himself conspicuous by killing a bull. Hercules, in the course of his twelve labors, polished off a lion, a stag, and a cow-stable; and another individual, whose name we forget, earned immortality by demolishing a pig. Later ages, less credulous or less partial, found out that all these stories were only allegories commemorating the progress of civilization. The myths were rationalized into a series of social improvements. The stag of Erymanthus became a swift-footed robber, who used a horn for his crest. The lions of Nemea were a savage nation who slept under trees, and never brushed their hair. The wild boar was interpreted to mean the vice of gluttony, and the person who slew him a man of refined turn of mind, who introduced knives and forks, and left off eating before he burst. The cleaning of the Augean stables was treated as a mere poetical fiction, and Hercules appeared in a new light as the inventor of sewers, and as the first person who taught his countrymen not to throw their slops into the street. In this view there is no telling what future ages may make of our present City Inspector. He will certainly figure among the heroes and demi-gods. Poets will sing his exploits, sculptors will carve him in marble, and astronomers will plant his broom among the stars, as they have the sword of Perseus and the club of Hercules.

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the steamship America we have advices from Europe three days later -- to the 22d ult., on which day she left Southampton. The British Parliament was expected to adjourn for the Summer months on the 28th ult. Lord CLYDE was suffering from atrophy and was not expected to recover. The news of the surrender of Vicksburgh and the results of the great battles at Gettysburgh had reached England, and had caused considerable excitement. The rebel loan took a sudden descent of several per cent. We give the comments of the London press very fully this morning. The answer of the Russian Government to the notes of the three Powers regarding Poland have been published, and was generally considered unsatisfactory. War was considered by no means a remote contingency. There was no abatement in the activity of the revolutionists, and several fights had taken place, with varying results. The news from America had sent up American stocks, and given them a buoyancy not before possessed for some time. A slight advance had also taken place in cotton. There was not much change in either Breadstuffs or Provisions. Consols were quoted at 92 1/2 @ 92 5/8 for money.

abstract: Exemption Money; The Use it Should be Put To
snippet: Exemption Money; The Use it Should be Put To
lead_paragraph: It is very evident that the Conscription law, if it does little else, will yield a very large sum to the National Treasury. From the interior towns of this State, as well as from the New-England States, we hear that although the draft meets no opposition, yet more than half those drafted pay the exemption fee of $300. In the principal cities of the State, beginning with New-York, the legislative authorities have undertaken to pay for all who may be drafted and who are unable to pay for themselves. This is beyond all comparison the most flagrant violation of every sound principle of justice and patriotism, which our records of misgovernment can show. But if it is carried into execution, it will largely swell the receipts of the Treasury, although it will correspondingly diminish the accession to the ranks of the array which the draft was expected to yield. The whole number of men called for under the draft is 450,000. Judging from the results thus far experienced, at least one-third of this whole number, and probably more, will secure exemption by payment of $300 each. This will yield not far from fifty millions of dollars.

abstract: The most ultra Pro-Slavery State before the war, the most rabid secession State in the early days of secession, next to South Carolina, was the State of Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: The most ultra Pro-Slavery State before the war, the most rabid secession State in the early days of secession, next to South Carolina, was the State of Mississippi. Judging by the votes in the Legislature, and by the action of State Conventions, secessionism had a more general popular support there than in any other Southern State, with the exception named. The slave element bore a larger proportion to the whole population there than in any other State, with the single exception of South Carolina. In fact, those two States are the only two in which the slave population outnumbers -- largely outnumbers -- the freemen. A Mississippi fire-eater was supposed to devour the very hottest article of that element -- to devour more of it, and to devour it faster than any other man -- the South Carolinian not excepted. Into the war its people seemed to rush en masse, and the ferocity and bloodthirstiness of its troops were unexampled. It was from the soil of Mississippi from Vicksburgh -- not from South Carolina of the harbor of Charleston -- that the first hostile shot was fired in this war. JEFF. DAVIS was, in many respects, the representative man of the State -- though he differed from ??? in the possession of coolness and shrewdness

abstract: Lecompte, Lieut--Col. F.; The War in the United States; Report to Swiss Military Department
snippet: Lecompte, Lieut--Col. F.; The War in the United States; Report to Swiss Military Department
lead_paragraph: Although we have had in our hands the original of this little book -- it is a simple brochure in its French garb -- we do not remember whether the principal title is as written above, or whether "The War in the United States" is not a bit of a flourish for the advertising columns. Be it as it may, the caption is a misnomer. The book is in no sense a history, treatise or review of the war in the United States. It is simply a report of the military service in the United Stales -- of our armies -- their organization, arms, equipment, dress, discipline, &c. The author, Lieut.-Col. FERDINAND LECOMPTE, appears to have spent some months as a volunteer Aid on the Staff of Gen. MCCLELLAN during the campaign of the Peninsula, and his pamphlet is a report addressed to the Chief of the Swiss Military Department, embodying the results of his observations. These are not profound, and the book bears no comparison with such philosophical survey as we owe to the Prince of JOINVILLE. If, without being profound, it had been a careful and accurate study of what we may call the anatomy and physiology of our army, it would still have had a professional value; and would have served the purpose of giving European soldiers a view of the condition and organization of the military service in the United States. But ii is not even that. The book is full of blunders, misstatements and misapprehensions. It would, in fact, have been difficult to have crowded a greater mass of blunders into the same space. The best we can say of it -- though that does not concern the book, but the author -- is that our Swiss friend is obviously well intentioned, and means to be as laudatory as he knows how. But his report is a very feeble and flimsy thing, and was certainly not worth Mr. VAN NOSTRAND's while to have had translated and publish.

abstract: THE SIXTH WARD HOMICIDE CORONER'S INQUISITION. Coroner RANNEY yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of JOHN HUNT, the man who was stabbed at No. 37 Parkstreet, on Saturday evening, by SALVATOR J. ALNIA, as previously reported in the TIMES.
lead_paragraph: THE SIXTH WARD HOMICIDE -- CORONER's INQUISITION. -- Coroner RANNEY yesterday held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of JOHN HUNT, the man who was stabbed at No. 37 Parkstreet, on Saturday evening, by SALVATOR J. ALNIA, as previously reported in the TIMES. The testimony went to show that deceased was partially intoxicated, and as ALNIA passed him on the way to his room, deceased remarked to the Italian, "I can lick you and all your crowd." ALNIA thought differently, and told HUNT if he would walk into the rear yard an opportunity would be presented for him to test his fighting qualities. HUNT accepted the proposition, and in a few moments a collision ensued between the belligerents, during which HUNT was stabbed in the left side near the heart, and staggering through the hallway to the street door, fell on the pavement, and never spoke afterwards. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, and expired soon after admission. The Jury found that he died "from the effects of a stab with a knife in the hands of SALVATOR J. ALNIA, on the 1st day of August, 1863."

abstract: -- A gentleman who arrived in the city yesterday from Cincinnati, informs us that when the train bearing JOHN MORGAN and Staff reached the depot in that city, the officer in charge called out the names of the prisoners and they stepped forward one at a time. When JOHN MORGAN came forward some one in the large crowd yelled "Horse thief." The cry was taken up by the crowd and "Horse thief," "Horse thief," was heard on all hands, and the demonstrations appeared very riotous. It is said that MORGAN actually shed tears. -- Wheeling Intelligencer.

abstract: Perhaps it is not generally known that the office of Inspector of Ordnance is one of the most important and responsible of any connected with the service. According to the regulations, before a single weapon can be accepted by the Government, it must have undergone a thorough inspection, both in its complete and disjointed state. Every portion of the ordnance, even the smallest screw which is used in its formation, must be submitted to a Government standard. At the beginning of the war, numerous parties applied to the authorities at Washington for contracts to furnish arms to the Government. Some of those parties were small manufacturers, having neither the requisite machinery for carrying on the business, nor the means to provide more, others, although having a large capital invested in machinery, could not, until after a long lapse of time, make practical use of that machinery in the manufacture of fire-arms. Then, again, there were comparatively a very few workmen to be found who understood the business at all. Hence, during the first year of the rebellion, it was with considerable difficulty that the War Department was enabled to secure even a small quantity of arms. Parties to whom had been awarded contracts found it quite impossible to fill them within the specified time, and were compelled to ask for an extension of period, which was usually granted, as it was the aim of the Government to encourage and foster the manufactories. At present, however, the business is so systematized, that there are very few delays. For bringing about that result, much credit is due to Col. P.V. HAGNER, who is the Inspector-in-Chief of all ordinance manufactured for the Government. Forty-five establishments are engaged in the business. These establishments are located in different parts of the country, and each one has a certain number of local inspectors. As a general thing, only a single portion of the ordnance is made in one manufactory. For instance, one is engaged in making the stocks, another the barrels, another the screws, and so on, so that perhaps the work of a dozen or twenty establishments will be represented in the finished musket. Every portion of this work must be made by standard rule, and for that purpose each establishment is furnished with a regulation pattern. Under that arrangement, a barrel made in Ohio, or any other place, can be exactly fitted to a stock made in New-York, and the same with all other parts, no matter where made, they fit each other exactly. A first-class establishment can turn out 1,000 muskets a week, and some have turned out 4,500 per month. It takes from five to seven days for one man to inspect 100 muskets, and from three to four days to inspect cither 100 carbines or pistols. The number of pieces condemned vary according to the class of the manufactories. In some, only three out of a thousand muskets are placed aside, while in others the number is augmented to twenty. In view of that fact it has become necessary to separate the pieces into four ranks. For the first or best rank of musket, the original Government price ($20) is paid. For the inferior ranks a deduction is made, bringing the price of the fourth rank musket down to $16. Nothing inferior to the last rank is accepted.

abstract: Its Reduced Boundaries
lead_paragraph: When, after the construction of the Southern Confederacy, its geographical boundaries were defined by Chesapeake Bay and the Potomac on the East, -- the Pacific Ocean on the West, -- the C???io, the Mississippi and Iowa on the North, -- the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico on the South, -- it certainly presented to the world a territory vast and magnificent enough. Compared with it, the Northern States were a long, narrow, disjointed, preposterously-shaped strip of country, running between the immense British Territory on the north, and the immense Confederacy on the south.

abstract: Abuse of and Services
lead_paragraph: Without any exception, the most bitterly and ceaselessly assailed officer connected with the Government has been and is the Secretary of War. Denunciation, vituperation and malignity have been directed toward him almost since the day he entered upon the duties of his department -- a department whose gigantic and complicated labors demand greater energy, harder work and higher practical ability than any other department of the Government. Assailed by his own party, the Democrats; unbefriended by the Republicans; caviled at by hosts of military incompetents; cursed by knavish contractors; villified by bilious newspapers; berated by unappreciated bores, -- he has still continued at his post and at his work, never replying to his accusers nor noticing his maligners, never claiming any credit nor courting popularity, but executing day by day his multifarious duties with a faithfulness and devotion whose results are now beginning to appear before the country.

abstract: Our Three Representative--Meade, Rosecrans and Grant; The change of feeling in
snippet: Our Three Representative--Meade, Rosecrans and Grant; The change of feeling in
lead_paragraph: Those who are able to recall the mood of the public mind at the outset of the war, will remember with what eagerness our people at that period looked forward to the advent of a great military hero. The Jews did not more confidently await a Messiah than we a military deliverer; and as nothing has more power over the popular imagination than a symbol, the coming man was commonly prefigured as a Napoleon. This new American Napoleon, like his Corsican prototype, was to carry genius, inspiration, and dramatic splendor into the war. He would stride across the continent with flaming sword, smiting the rebels hip and thigh, and driving them all before him into the Gulf of Mexico. Of course he would make short work with the rebellion -- only taking long enough to let each man cover himself with glory, and return to the enjoyment of a millennium of pudding and praise.

abstract: It is said that the draft in this City will be resumed on Wednesday or Thursday of this week. Marsh??? NUGENT will erect temporary quarters for the drawing, in place of these burned in the Eighth and Ninth Districts. The Government will be fully prepared to crush all resistance to the draft, and to protect United States property in the City, and it is presumed that the City and State authorities will also be prepared to protect the citizen from any and all violence. The probabilities are that the lawless will not deem it prudent to resume operations, and that the draft will be completed here without further disturbance.

abstract: The President gives notice to the rebel authorities, in an order which we publish this morning, that the law of retaliation is to be fully carried out.
lead_paragraph: The President gives notice to the rebel authorities, in an order which we publish this morning, that the law of retaliation is to be fully carried out. Every case of ill-treatment of our officers or men, black or white, by the rebels, is to be retaliated in kind. For every soldier of the United States killed in violation of the laws of war, a rebel soldier will be executed, and if a black soldier is taken prisoner and sold, into Slavery, a rebel soldier will be confined at hard labor on the public works, there to continue until the black soldier shall be liberated.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Tyndall, John; Heat as a Mode of Motion
snippet: Tyndall, John; Heat as a Mode of Motion
lead_paragraph: Prof. TYNDALL's course of lectures on Heat is one of the most beautiful illustrations of a mode of handling scientific subjects which is comparatively new, and which promises the best results both to science itself and to literature generally; we mean the treatment of subjects in a style at once profound and popular. The old method of popularizing science was simply to emasculate it -- to deal with its superficies while making readers to believe they were mastering its whole scope and substance. The new method reaches its purpose not by looking away from what seems difficult, but by looking through it. In fact what was once formerly given up to the sciolist is now taken up by the savant, Science has a grand function to perform, aside from its direct teachings, in its indirect influence on the culture. Prof. TYNDALL, in a profound passage in his preface touches this key-note. "As a means of intellectual education its claims are still disputed, though, once properly organized, greater and more beneficent revolutions await its employment here, than those which have already marked its applications in the material world. Surely, the men whose noble vocation it is to symtematize the culture of England, can never allow this giant power to grow up in their midst without endeavoring to turn it to practical account. Science does not need their protection, but it desires their friendship on honorable terms; it wishes to work with them toward the great end of all education -- the bettering of man's estate."
headline: {'main': 'NEW PUBLICATIONS.; HEAT CONSIDERED AS A MODE OF MORTION. Being a Course of Twelve Lectures delivered at the Royal Institution of Great Britain in the season of 1862. abstract: It is right, publicly to give thanks to Almighty God for the victories recently vouchsafed to the armies of the United States; and in the midst of thanksgiving, to remember in prayer those who have been bereaved through the casualties of war. It is right, for a Christian people to invoke the Holy Spirit to change the hearts of their enemies; and also to guide with wisdom the counsels of their own Government, to the end that the Union of the States may be maintained, the Constitution preserved, and peace and prosperity speedily established. Therefore, I recommend that the people of the State of New-Jersey observe by Thanksgiving and Prayer, in their usual places of public worship, the day designated for that purpose by the President of the United States, to wit, THURSDAY, the 6th day of August. A.D., 1863.

abstract: Much of the interest in the trotting-match on Saturday, the result of which was given in yesterday's TIMES, arose from the fact that on August 1, exactly twenty-four years ago, Dutchman a noted bay gelding, ...
lead_paragraph: Much of the interest in the trotting-match on Saturday, the result of which was given in yesterday's TIMES, arose from the fact that on August 1, exactly twenty-four years ago, Dutchman -- a noted bay gelding, sired by the celebrated Bashaw -- trotted the same distance, under the saddle, in 7 min. 32 1/2 sec., and from the further facts that the veteran of the trotting-course. who rode Dutchman on that occasion, was present, as was also Mr. JAMES. F. HAMMILL of Philadelphia, who owned and backed Dutchman at the time aforesaid. The match was made by Mr. HAMMILL, for $1,000, that Dutchman, ridden by HIRAM WCOLRUFF, would beat the time Dutchman had made on a previous race, in harness, wherein he had distanced Messrs. ISAAC and JOHN ANDERSON's gelding Awful of New-York, and won in 7 min. 41 sec. On this race HIRAM weighed 145 lbs., his sulky 82 lbs., and the three miles were done in 2:34, 2:33, 2:34. Total, 7 min. 41 sec.

abstract: The drowsy monotony of the Summer solstice extending to the theatres, and even to those who frequent them, will be rudely shaken on Thursday next, by the production at Mr. WALLACK'S Theatre of a veritable Ghost.
lead_paragraph: The drowsy monotony of the Summer solstice extending to the theatres, and even to those who frequent them, will be rudely shaken on Thursday next, by the production at Mr. WALLACK's Theatre of a veritable Ghost. This is none other than the spicy article of Prof. PEPPER -- the Ghost that has made the fortune of half-a-dozen London managers, and has even brought a dividend to the Royal Polytechnic Institute -- a place that greatly needed ghostly comfort. Mr. Moss, the Treasurer of Wallack's Theatre, who is noted for his taste in fancy articles, and frequently imports them directly from Europe, has secured the Ghost, and in company with a theatrical combination, headed by Mr. and Mrs. H. WATKINS, will introduce it to the community on Thursday next. We may mention, as a timely nervine, that whilst the Ghost is purely spiritual and impalpable on the stage, it is derived from excellent materials of bone, muscle and mechanism, deftly secreted behind the scenes, and worked with a settled purpose by the stage manager. The actor, indeed, is simply reflected on the stage, but so powerfully that the effect is most startling. His Ghostship will make his appearance in a piece called "True to the Last."

abstract: -- We have the text of the Proclamation of the President concerning retaliation upon the rebels for the maltreatment of the black troops in our army. By this document, it is ordered "that for every soldier of the United States killed in violation of the laws of war, a rebel soldier shall be executed, and for every one enslaved by the enemy or sold into slavery, a rebel soldier shall be placed at hard labor on the public works." We suppose no man can deny the validity of this principle, its absolute justice, or its conformity to the laws of war. There are probably, altogether, not less than twenty thousand colored soldiers now in the National service, and since they have been in numerous battles lately, and some of them were, of course, taken prisoners of war, it was necessary that some rule should be established to counteract the atrocious proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS, which threatened all captured soldiers of this class and all white officers commanding them, with summary execution. Having entered upon war, the rebels are bound by, and must be compelled to abide by, its laws.
lead_paragraph: -- We have the text of the Proclamation of the President concerning retaliation upon the rebels for the maltreatment of the black troops in our army.
