We suppose no man can deny the validity of this principle, its absolute justice, or its conformity to the laws of war. There are probably, altogether, not less than twenty thousand colored soldiers now in the National service, and since they have been in numerous battles lately, and some of them were, of course, taken prisoners of war, it was necessary that some rule should be established to counteract the atrocious proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS, which threatened all captured soldiers of this class and all white officers commanding them, with summary execution. Having entered upon war, the rebels are bound by, and must be compelled to abide by, its laws.

lead_paragraph: The man who walked off a Greenpoint ferryboat on Thursday last, was named JAMES LARRASON, formerly of Babylon, L.I. He was at one time a member of Berdan's Sharpshooters, and was wounded at the battle of Williamsburgh, Va. For the last five months he had been employed by HULSE & BEGEBER, Greenpoint. In order to render his drowning certain as he wrote in one letter to his wife he would do, he filled his carpet bag with stones, tied it to us ???m, and, on reaching the middle of the river, walked overboard. He leaves a wife, who is at ??? ten, L.L. The following letter, also to ??? the 28th ult., will explain the cause of his suicide.

abstract: Our readers remember the bitter contest which took place at the last Tammany election between the Old Guard and the New Guard, when the younger Indians of the Grand Lodge rebelied against the dictum of those who so long indisputably held away in the Councils of the Democratic party.
lead_paragraph: Our readers remember the bitter contest which took place at the last Tammany election between the Old Guard and the New Guard, when the younger Indians of the Grand Lodge rebelied against the dictum of those who so long indisputably held away in the Councils of the Democratic party. It was deemed a fitting hour for insurrection, because unity no longer existed and harmony of thought and action was a stranger in the old Wigwam. The fight was short, sharp and decisive. The old ones marshaled their hosts, and encouraged by former successes, made a gallant fight, but it resulted in an utter defeat, complete as was the repulse of the famous Light Brigade at Balaklava. Shortly after this, the old "War Horse." as his friends term ELIJAM F. PURDY, was elevated to the time-honored seat of "Ye Grand Sachem," and invested with all the powers thereto be taming. This elevation caused a vacancy in the Sachem membership, and an election was ordered for last evening.

abstract: Secession and Restoration by States
lead_paragraph: It is universally admitted that the rebellion in its first stage was greatly facilitated by the existence in our civil system of State governments, each in itself a complete civil organization. One great difficulty of revolutionists in other lands always is the necessity they are under of improvising a government as soon as they have delivered their first blow. They are seldom able to do this on the spur of the occasion, except in a manner so imperfect as to work great confusion. All the detail of administration is lacking; and so, too, are all the prestige and moral influence that attend regular authority. It takes the revolution a long while to acquire consistency and organization, and in the mean time a rude, self-constituted, irresponsible, "provisional Government," has to rough-hew matters as it can -- at best but the miserable makeshift of the day. But in the case of our Southern rebellion, all this disadvantage was escaped. Government, in its full perfection, was at hand to direct the movement from the start. Nay, in most of the States it positively initiated the movement, not only determining its course in advance, but overcoming all the first inertia. It was, in fact, the State Governments that engineered the States into secession. Without them, in all earthly probability, the movement would have never been possible.
headline: {'main': 'Secession by States and Restoration by States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Secession by States and Restoration by States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SUN-STROKES. The excessively hot weather of the past few days has proved fatal to many laborers and others exposed to the sun. About 30 cases of death were reported at the Coroner's office, yesterday, the majority of which were the result of heat. HEYO ATTMANS, a German, who lived at No. 14 Catharine street, was overcome by the heat, and died in a drugstore near by, which he had entered for medical aid.
lead_paragraph: SUN-STROKES. -- The excessively hot weather of the past few days has proved fatal to many laborers and others exposed to the sun. About 30 cases of death were reported at the Coroner's office, yesterday, the majority of which were the result of heat. HEYO ATTMANS, a German, who lived at No. 14 Catharine street, was overcome by the heat, and died in a drugstore near by, which he had entered for medical aid.....MARY MORGAN, of No. 252 East-Twelfth-street, in passing through Ninth-street, near Sixth-avenue, was overpowered by the heat and fell to the pavement. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and expired soon after admission.... Coroner RANNEY held an inquest on the body of JAMES KEENS, who was sun-struck corner of Twenty-sixth-street and Seventh-avenue. KEENS was 27 years of age, and a native of Ireland.... MARTIN KILLEEN, a German soldier, recently attached to the One Hundred and Ninth regiment New-York volunteers, was found corner Barclay and Greenwich streets partially overcome by the heat. He was taken to the New-York Hospital by the Third Ward Police....A soldier belonging to the Ninth regiment (Hawkins' Zouaves,) was sun-struck corner of Frankfort and William streets. Deputy Coroner ROBINSON administered the necessary remedies, and after partially recovering, the patient was taken to the New-York Hospital....Coroner COLLIN held an inquest at the Fourth Ward Station-house, on the body of an unknown woman who was found sun-struck in the doorway of a house in Water-street, near Dover.....JOHN MEDDLECOTT, a discharged soldier, died suddenly yesterday afternoon, at No. 23 Chatham-street. He was overcome by the heat. Deceased belonged to the Second Troy regiment, 33 years of age, and a native of England ... A man named WALLEY, 60 years of age, and born in Germany, died at No. 70 Essex-street, yesterday afternoon, from the effects of the extreme heat. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body....THOMAS COOPER, a longshoreman, died yesterday from the effects of the heat; he was first sun-truck several days ago, and taking a trip to Staten Island on Sunday, he was much exposed to the sun, which soon prostrated him. He started for home, but calling in at No. 68 East Broadway, became insensible, and died there. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on the body. Deceased was 25 years of age, and a native of England....Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at No. 44 Gold-street on the body of TERENCE MCCARTHY, who died from the effects of the heat on Sunday. MCCARTHY was 29 years of age, and a native of Ireland.... JOHN MCLACKHEIMER, a German, 50 years of age, died at No. 158 Washington-street, from the effects of a sun-stroke received several days ago.

lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamer Alabama, Capt. NICHOLS, arrived at this port yesterday, from St. Domingo, W.I., with the yellow fever on board. She was immediately put in Quarantine, and, on Admiral PAULDING being informed of the fact, he instructed the commander of the U.S. steamer Magnolia to proceed down the bay, and to take on board the ???nvalesments and the healthy portion of the Alabama's crew, who were immediately by provided with clean clothes, bedding, etc. The Alabama reports all quiet at St. Domingo, no pirates having been seen in that neighborhood for some time. The following in a list of the Alabama's officers:

abstract: Advices from Europe, four days later, are received by the Arabia, which arrived at Halifax yesterday. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. It is announced that the Galway line of steamers is to go into operation again on the 19th of August. The marine insurance companies had been heavy losers by the capture of the ship B.F. Horie by ...
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe, four days later, are received by the Arabia, which arrived at Halifax yesterday. She left Liverpool on the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult. It is announced that the Galway line of steamers is to go into operation again on the 19th of August. The marine insurance companies had been heavy losers by the capture of the ship B.F. Hoxie by the Alabama -- some 150,000 having been sunk by the operation. The owners of the Alexandra had applied for the release of their vessel, and for compensation for her detention, but the application could not be entertained until certain proceedings before the Courts were gone through with. An Anti-Southern Association had been formed at Manchester. On the 23d, in the House of Commons, Mr. COBDEN called up the subject of the Foreign Enlistment act, and advocated its amendment. He referred to the Alabama, Florida and Virginia, and said it was well known that two iron-clads were now being built at Liverpool for the rebels. He called upon the British Government to prevent the departure of these iron-clads, and thus prevent a declaration of war on the part of the American Government. Mr. LAYARD, in behalf of the Government, insisted that everything had been done which could be done to prevent the equipment of vessels for the rebels in English ports. He further insisted that the Americans had built ships of war for Russia during the Crimean war, and had recruited their armies in Ireland during the present war, both of which statements Mr. LAYARD doubtless knew to be untrue when he uttered them. Lord PALMERSTON also defended the course of the Government, and said he could see no distinction in principle between "selling arms to the Federals and selling ships to the Confederates." Mr. COBDEN offered to read a letter from Secretary WELLES, denying the truth of the statement made by Mr. LAIRD in the House of Commons some time ago, that his firm had been approached by agents of the United States Government relative to building war vessels for the North. The Polish question remains much as represented by the previous steamer. There is much dissatisfaction, both in France and England, at the tenor of the Russian note, and the Cabinet of Vienna is also said to be much excited. There had been a further advance on Cotton in Liverpool. Breadstuffs and Provisions also had an upward tendency. Console were quoted at 92 ???@92 3/4 for money.

abstract: Breadstuffs for Belligerents in Europe
lead_paragraph: The reports from the West in regard to the growing crops are, on the whole, quite favorable. Notwithstanding the drought that has fallen so heavily on Minnesota and other sections in the extreme Northwest, and the wet weather that has impeded harvesting operations in the Atlantic States, the fact remains unquestioned that much more than an average crop of cereals will be produced. The single State of Iowa is likely to make up by her excess all the partial losses that have been suffered elsewhere by reason of the unfavorable weather. The American grain crop for 1863 will be immense.

lead_paragraph: The steamship Melville, from Havana on the 25th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. There had been no later arrivals from Vera Cruz, and consequently there is no later news from Mexico. The fire at Havana stated on the 25th, after destroying nine stores, containing 75,000 boxes augar, 4,000 bales cotton, and a large quantity of other merchandise. The fire was supposed to be caused by carelessness of laborers in drying cotton, in letting fall their lighted cigars among the combustible materials.

abstract: In Demarara, the City of Georgetown had been visited by a devastating fire, the most destructive which had occurred, it is said, since the year 1828. It originated in a building which had been a resort for the most depraved characters of the place, and is supposed to have been caused by the overturning of a lamp in a scuffle among gamblers, who fled and left the flames to rage unheeded.
lead_paragraph: In Demarara, the City of Georgetown had been visited by a devastating fire, the most destructive which had occurred, it is said, since the year 1828. It originated in a building which had been a resort for the most depraved characters of the place, and is supposed to have been caused by the overturning of a lamp in a scuffle among gamblers, who fled and left the flames to rage unheeded. The fire was discovered a little before 12 o'clock on the night of the 17th ult., and before 2 o'clock, despite the strenuous exertions of the towns-people, powerfully assisted by the military, some thirteen houses had been destroyed. Several poor people have lost their all, and are reduced to a state of the utmost destitution. The amount of property destroyed is said to be about $70,000. The exports of produce from January 1 to June 21 have been: Sugar, 3,022 hhds., 1,737 1/2 tcs., 6,409 bbls., 14,406 hags; Rum, 14,391 punch., 2,046 hhds., 1,257 bbls.; Molasses, 1,775 casks; Timber, 183,711 cubic feet; Charcoal, 14,124 bbls.: Cocoanuts, 237,243; Shingles, 3,869,700.

abstract: Convicts ??? by Eng and Here
lead_paragraph: The English authorities are taking a new way, or rather they have revived an old way, of showing their friendship for this country, and at the same time getting rid of the thieves, burglars, garroters and cut-throats which form so large and powerful an element of the Queen's subjects. They are paying their passage money and transporting them over to this country. Of this fact there is no more doubt than there is of the fact that a few years ago these flowers of English society were transplanted to Van Dieman's Land. They are being sent over here in unusually large numbers this Summer.

abstract: THE ACCIDENT AT THE LAUNCHING OF THE OMONDAGA. Coroner BARRETT, of Brooklyn. (E.D.,) has investigated the cause of the death of JAMES CONWELL, injured fatally at the launch of the iron-clad battery, on Wednesday last.
lead_paragraph: THE ACCIDENT AT THE LAUNCHING OF THE ONONDAGA. -- Coroner BARRETT, of Brooklyn. (E.D.,) has investigated the cause of the death of JAMES CONWELL, injured fatally at the launch of the iron-clad battery, on Wednesday last. The evidence before the jury appeared conclusively to establish the fact that the proprietors of the Continental Works had taken every precaution which experience could suggest, and that the injuries inflicted were by reason of a failure against which no human foresight could guard. A new invention, called a "Spur Shore," was used in addition to all else, by which vessels have been held for half an hour, and then let go. In the case of the Onondaga the lever bent, thus sending the vessel off prematurely. In order to effect increased carefulness in future, the jury saw fit to censure the Company for not leaving means of escape well aft, although it was shown to be unusual so to do. Messrs. ROWLAND have made a liberal donation to the young widow of the deceased.

abstract: The Restoration of
lead_paragraph: The order of Gen. ROSECRANS, published in another column, addressed to his army from headquarters at Winchester, Tenn., under date of 28th July, shows that while addressing himself to the work of clearing the armed force of the rebellion from before him, he fully appreciates the other duties that circumstances impose. There is an army to destroy, but there is also a State to regenerate. The war breaks up all bonds -- it leaves the region it has passed over in a condition of simple anarchy or no-government, and the people are literally what our Saxon forefathers called "waifs." Gen. ROSECRANS tells his army that they are now called upon to aid their unfortunate fellow-citizens of Tennessee "in restoring law, and securing its protection to persons and property -- the right of every free citizen." With this view he calls upon them, first of all, to do their part in the restoration of law, by putting them upon their honor that no acts of lawlessness, no pillaging, no marauding, shall be committed by them. Such acts have been too common in all our armies, and cannot but produce the worst effects. Gen. ROSECRANS then invites all citizens to unite in restoring law and order, and promises all privileges and protections to such as will conduct themselves peaceably and do no injury to the Government. "Assure Tennesseans of this, "he says to the army --

abstract: We have information by a late arrival from Bermuda that the pirate Florida, after receiving a supply of coal from a rebel steamer at St. George's, and extraordinary hospitalities from the sympathizing islanders, has again put to sea on her errand of rapine and destruction.
lead_paragraph: We have information by a late arrival from Bermuda that the pirate Florida, after receiving a supply of coal from a rebel steamer at St. George's, and extraordinary hospitalities from the sympathizing islanders, has again put to sea on her errand of rapine and destruction. For this shameful infraction of the proclamation of neutrality on the part of British subjects our Government owes to itself to demand prompt and full reparation. The justice of such a demand, in view of a decision of Earl RUSSELL bearing upon an analogous case that arose in 1861, must at once be acknowledged on the part of the British Government.

abstract: AMERICAN AND FOREIGN BIBLE SOCIETY. The Managers of this Society, at a recent monthly meeting held at their rooms No. 116 Nassau-street, had under consideration an unusual number of applications for Scriptures, particularly from the army and hospitals.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN AND FOREIGN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- The Managers of this Society, at a recent monthly meeting held at their rooms No. 116 Nassau-street, had under consideration an unusual number of applications for Scriptures, particularly from the army and hospitals. One hospital chaplain, located in Virginia says: "We have now 1,500 patients and 17 Bibles all told. There are 21 wards, each 25 feet wide and 150 feet long, each containing as man; as they can hold, and some 70 or 80 tents full beside. My object is to place in each building or ward four or five Bibles to be kept in them for the use of the patients. I have almost daily calls for the Bible. The Bible it for active service and I can employ all that you can send, I hope, with God's blessing, for good. Send certainly not less than 200 copies." Large numbers of Scriptures were applied for from Michigan to supply the 10,000 French residents in one of the cities of that State. Application was also made from the Territory of Arizona for Scriptures, mostly in Spanish, to be circulated in that far off but most interesting field. Requests from the navy-merchant service and destitute localities were presented, all of which were promptly and most cheerfully granted. In connection with the work in this country, the Managers directed that the sum of $500 should be immediately forwarded to Burmah, India, to aid in publishing and circulating the Scriptures in the Karen language: also, $500 to Rev. E.C. LORD, of Ningpo, for Chinese Scriptures.

abstract: BROOKLYN BOARD OF EDUCATION. The Board held a regular meeting last evening and transacted the usual amount of routine business.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN BOARD OF EDUCATION. -- The Board held a regular meeting last evening and transacted the usual amount of routine business. Dr. J.S. THORNE moved that the Committee on Supplies be empowered to take such steps as they deemed advisable in procuring a supply of fuel for the Public Schools, it being explained that in consequence of the uncertain state of the markets, it was unadvisable to advertise for proposals, as heretofore, and that the matter had best be left to the discretion of the Committee. A discussion ensued during which Mr. E.W. FISKE produced a circular from the Pittston Coal Company, stating that they will supply coal, when purchased in large amounts at $6 60 per ton, to be delivered at some point on the Hudson River. The motion was adopted. Mr. S.J. EAG???LAN sent in his resignation as Chairman of the Committee on Colored School No. l. which was accepted. The reports of the Principals of the Public Schools in relation to the length of time occupied daily in teaching the children were presented, showing the average number of school hours daily, including intermissions, was 6 1/2,. The report was accepted, and the Board shortly after adjourned.

abstract: On Sunday last, at the Metropolitan Tabernacle, Rev. C.H. SPURGEON, in the most emphatic and eloquent terms, expressed the coincidence of his opinions with those of Rev. Dr. CANDLISH, relative to the inscription lately placed over the Memorial to the Prince Consort. He observed that the ministers of Christ were on all occasions bound under the most solemn obligations to stand manfully by the truths of the Gospel, and firmly to maintain the essentials of Christianity, even in the face of those sitting in high places. He, therefore, held with Dr. CANDLISH in his late noble stand against an inscription which was, beyond all question of doubt, of Romish origin. The late Prince would, he believed, have utterly repudiated such an inscription had he been alive, for the great and good Prince was a Christian and a Protestant in every sense of the word. It was recorded of him by Hon. and Rev. BAPTIST NOEL that his last words, upon his death-bed, were:

abstract: The following is given by a correspondent of the Independance Belgs: "The incident I am about to relate occurred at the commencement of the reign of LOUIS PHILLIPE. The Ex-Queen CAROLINE of Naples had come to Paris to see the King, and support personally some claims on the French Government. At that period the writer of this letter was in possession of a large number of documents referring to the history of the "Bonaparte family. It is well known that when Kings JOSEPH and LOUIS died, a large, part of their correspondence was offered for public sale. I purchased a considerable portion of it; and I had especially obtained possession of a correspondence between LUGIEN, his brothers, and one of his secretaries of the name of CAMP, during the years 1814 and 1815, Baron DE MENNEYAL, formerly private secretary to NAPOLEON I., with whom I was intimate, knew of my hobby as a collector, and I had shown him several letters of historical interest, which proved, I may mention, en passant, that harmony had not always reigned amongst the members of the Imperial family. M. DE MENNENAL spoke of this correspondence to Queen CAROLINE, Who expressed a wish to see me, and made inquiries respecting the letters. I had the honor of several interviews with her on the subject. The Princess asked me to dispose of the letters to her, to which she said she attached a great value. 'I understand,' I replied, 'the family interest which causes you to desire to obtain possession of them. I certainly was not disposed to part with them, nevertheless I take a pleasure in offering them to you if you will give me in exchange a letter of year brother NAPOLEON I.' 'I have something better than that to give you,' she said. 'My brother's letters are at Milan, but here are eight small volumes of great value, which I beg you to accept.' This was a copy of Caesar's Commentaries, in eight duodecimo volumes, bound in calf, and their dilapidated state showed the constant use which had been made of them. They had in fact been made use of by NAPOLEON during his stay at St. Helena, and almost every page was covered with notes written by the Emperor's hand; in certain parts the text was positively hidden by the manuscript notes of the august commentator. I looked upon these volumes as of a value far superior to that of my letters, and I had the want of tact to display my eagerness to possess them. Two days after I took the documents to Queen CAROLINE to make the exchange agreed upon, and she now offered me only the four first volumes of the work. I rejected this offer with warmth, for to divide such a valuable work I looked upon as a literary crime. 'No,' I said, 'I must have the whole or nothing.' And I had nothing, for the Princess hesitated a long time, returned to Italy, and died shortly after. What has become of these little volumes, which would certainly be of great assistance to NAPOLEON III.? Is he aware of their existence? I cannot say, but I have thought it right to publish this recollection to call attention to a literary curiosity of such importance."

abstract: The honorable and learned member for Westminster. Sir DE LACY EVANS, who has fought many brilliant battles in Spain, and who invaded the Crimea without loss of life or limb, measured his full length on the floor of the House of Commons, the other evening, in a very distressing and undignified manner. The honorable and gallant gentleman was passing in front of the Treasury Bench, when his spurs got entangled, some way or other, in the long legs of the Right Honorable F. PEEL, the Financial Secretary to the Treasury, and the result was that he lost his balance and sprawled over the feet of the whole Cabinet! Lord PALMERSTON most fortunately managed to get his legs out of the way in time, and escaped disaster, but Mr. MILNER GIBSON and the Chancellor of the Exchequer were sadly spurred, although they good-naturedly picked up the member for Westminster and set him upright. Mr. FREDERICK PEEL rubbed his shins, as well he might -- an operation which occasioned no small amount of amusement to the occupants of the Treasury Bench opposite. For the future, it is clear that Sir DE LACY must either abandon the use of spurs in the House of Commons, or Mr. FREDERICK PEEL must keep his legs out of the way. The former, we need scarcely say, is far more easy of accomplishment than the latter."

abstract: Citizen, Last Words of
lead_paragraph: When GRANT took possession of Vicksburgh, a detachment of the Fifteenth Illinois cavalry visited the office of the Daily Citizen. They found the number intended for July 2 in type, and the paper all ready for printing, but circumstances had prevented its issue. The number contains four columns, equal to about half a page of the TIMES. The paper was very poor wall-paper. The matter was wholly editorial, with the exception of a column and a half of "Yankee News from all Points," copied from the Memphis Bulletin, a paper which the Citizen says is "edited by a pink-nosed, slab-sided, toad-eating Yankee, who is a lineal descendant of Judas Iscariot, and a brother germain of the greatest Puritanical, sycophantic, howling scoundrel unhung -- Parson BROWN-LOW." Yet, continues the Citizen, "with such a character, this paper cannot cloak the fact that Gen. BOB???T E. LEE has given HOOKER, MILROY & Co. one of the best and soundest whippings on record, and that the 'galorious Union' is now exceedingly weak in the knees."

lead_paragraph: The belief is entertained to some extent in Washington that LEE's army is again rapidly retreating toward Richmond, and that it will not again halt until it has gained the further bank of the ??? River. The impression is that he will ??? means in his power to avoid another general engagement with the Army of the Potomac, as his army, discouraged by the great National victories in the Southwest, as well as by its own defeat at Gettysburgh, is in no condition to fight, and has no in???lination to do so. This is evidenced by the fact that Gen. BUFORD, after the fight of Saturday last, was allowed to remain on the south bank of the Rappahann???k without molestation, although within a few miles of LEE's headquarters, and although a heavy rebel force was at Culpepper Court-house, in his immediate vicinity.

abstract: A Paris correspondent of the London Telegraph writes: "The Court has decreed the separation a me???sd et thoro of Count and Countess DE PERSIGNY. It is no business of mine to report scandals, and when I go to Mabille, I make a point of never seeing anybody who wishes to be invisible; and if an ex-Minister cannot manage his own "interior" life, it is no business of your correspondent's. Good-natured friends have stories of all shades, about both husband wife, and I believe it is not the first time that ladies have been found to side with Monsieur, while the gentlemen all vote en masse for Madame."

abstract: "If there be any one among us who may, peradventure, have still clung to the idea that some friendship exits for us in England, we trust he is undeceived.
lead_paragraph: "If there be any one among us who may, peradventure, have still clung to the idea that some friendship exits for us in England, we trust he is undeceived. But there are yet some who imagine that France is probably about to recognize us by herself. This, also, we gravely doubt. France certainly is more friendly to us than England; has much less interest than England in the breaking down of American commerce, and no interest at all in the overthrow of American democracy, seeing that she is quite as democratic herself. It is true, also, that by temperament and by the traditions of their race, the French are much more likely to feel a generous and disinterested sympathy with a brave people struggling for its rights against heavy odds. Yet Lord FALMERSTON is right in saying that the Emperor has his own impediments, which have hither to kept him back from all action in our favor. Perhaps the chief of these is the formidable "Liberal," or "Republican" party in his empire, which is stupidly Abolitionist, which avails itself of every pretext for assailing the Emperor's acts, and which would be quite sure to cry out against, his recognition of the Confederacy, as a sanction of Slavery and a disgrace to the banner of France. And these wretched "liberals" are growing stronger, the defeats or Government candidates in the late elections being all in their favor. The Emperor would not fear this opposition, if be were acting conjointly with England; but his hastening to recognize us first, and contrary to the remonstrances of Egland, would assuredly be made a powerful weapon against his power.

abstract: An official dispatch, dated Morton, Miss., July 30, states that it is reported on authority deemed reliable, that an engagement took place recently near Donaldsonville, La., between Maj.-Gen. abstract: There was no firing of any importance Monday, Fort Sumter and our batteries sending only an occasional shot of shell at the Yankees on Morris island. The latter made no response. They were again at work upon their battery, previously reported in Monday's issue. This seems to be a very small concern, in the form of semi-circle, erecting on the beach. We could discern but one mortar placed in position in the battery, and but very few men at work.

abstract: A gratifying secrecy is observed regarding the position and movements of the Army of the Potomac, and we are left to simple conjecture as to the nature and direction of future operations. From present indications, however, it does not seem probable that either army will occupy precisely the same front as that held previously to LEE's invasion. LEE's headquarters appear to be at Culpepper, and his army is probably massed between that and Gordonsvide, with a corps of observation at Fredericksburgh. We hold from Warrenton to Rappahannock Station, observing the upper fords of the Rappahannock River. Sanitary considerations, if nothing else, will prompt both armies to avoid their old camping-grounds, as the country for miles around there is covered with the accumulated offal of six months' occupancy by great armies. For the present, therefore, the debatable ground will probably be the dozen miles between the upper fords of the Rappahannock and Culpepper. Our army is well placed, either to lie by or to make an advance on the Gordonsville line, which will avoid the Rappahannock and all its hideous associations. Our line of communication will be by the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, which is perfectly covered.

abstract: -- It is not only Union observers in the Southwest who report that the resident population there have given up their hopes of the rebellion, and are anxious to return to the old condition of things; but the rebel writers themselves are compelled to confess the same fact. We published some remarkable statements on Monday, concerning the change of heart that the rebels are undergoing in Mississippi, and the Richmond Examiner, of the 2d inst., has an article on "Traitors at Home" which verifies these Statements, and admits that "the Mississippi troops, in large numbers, were deserting the army of Gen. JOHNSTON," and that that State, like other Southern States, "has her proportions of timorous and cowardly traitors, who are ready to yield to the domination of the dastardly foe at the first approach of danger." "This state of feeling," says the Examiner, "is greatly to be deprecated, and we regret especially to see it in Mississippi, the home of the President."
lead_paragraph: -- It is not only Union observers in the Southwest who report that the resident population there have given up their hopes of the rebellion, and are anxious to return to the old condition of things; but the rebel writers themselves are compelled to confess the same fact. abstract: Charge on New-York Riots; Preservation of Peace and Order
snippet: Charge on New-York Riots; Preservation of Peace and Order
lead_paragraph: It is fortunate that while justice is debased in this City by some of those who are styled its ministers, the majority of the officers of the law are still true to their duties. Recorder HOFFMAN's charge to the Grand Jury is a proof that New-York is not yet wholly given over to the reign of lawlessness. He uses no euphemistic language in speaking of crime, and no shady words in characterizing criminals. Those who burn houses and asylums and stores, he says, are guilty of arson; those who plunder other men's goods are guilty of robbery; a rioter is an enemy of society; and the punishment for murder is death. And he warns each and all of these classes that the penalty which the law affixes to their crimes will be sternly meted out to them.

July 24, (outward passage.) at 0 A.M., lat. 34 10, lon. 76 30. course S W., saw black smoke to westward; shortly afterward, saw a steamer with two white smoke-pipes, hull painted lead color, steering S.E.; same time, saw a large steamer in chase, but the first seemed gaining on her pursuer. The Eagle cut her off in order that the chase might come up with her, and fired a blank shot, which at once stopped her. She was an English built iron side wheel steamer, of about 600 tons, laden with cotton, of which, on our approach, she threw a quantity overboard. The Eagle stopped until the man-of-war, which was supposed to be the Lackawana, came up and took possession of her. The Eagle then proceeded on her course.
lead_paragraph: Steamship Eagle, Adams, Havana Aug. 1, at 1 1/2 P.M., with mdse. and passengers to Spofford, Tileston & Co. The Eagle cut her off in order that the chase might come up with her, and fired a blank shot, which at once stopped her. She was an English built iron side wheel steamer, of about 600 tons, laden with cotton, of which, on our approach, she threw a quantity overboard. The Eagle stopped until the man-of-war, which was supposed to be the Lackawana, came up and took possession of her. The Eagle then proceeded on her course.

abstract: -- Our London Correspondent does not give us the name of the noble lord who made the remark recently, that "England was strong enough to -- mind her own business." But, whoever he was, we commend his good sense and statesmanlike intellect; and, be he Whig or Tory, we hope he will live long enough to be Premier of England, or at least Foreign Secretary. Had he occupied the latter position for the last three years, and carried out the theory involved in his epigrammatic remark, we should have been saved an immense amount of bad blood in this country, and England would have been saved still more. Earl RUSSELL has done tolerably well, but he has not come up to this high standard. So far as this country is concerned, it is all we have ever asked of England. We want no aid, no favor, no applause from her in our struggle. We do not envy her in her possession of power, wealth and territory -- ships, colonies and commerce. All we ask of her and all other Governments is, to mind their own business. We have never interfered in theirs.

abstract: Speech at Dugoin on the War
snippet: Speech at Dugoin on the War
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. JOHN A. LOGAN, of Illinois, one of the boldest and most dashing leaders in the army of Gen. GRANT, and who returned North on a brief visit after the tall of Vicksburgh, delivered a long, eloquent and thoroughly Western Speech at Duquoin, (Ill.,) on the 31st ult. An immense concourse of people had gathered to hear him; and as he has long been the representative Democratic man of Southern Illinois, both there and in Washington, his speech produced a profound effect.

abstract: Of the five senses, that which we call seeing is the most important and most valued. In proportion as this sense fails us we are reduced to helplessness.
lead_paragraph: Of the five senses, that which we call seeing is the most important and most valued. In proportion as this sense fails us we are reduced to helplessness. If entirely destitute of sight, how slow would be our progress in knowledge, and how limited our sphere of action and usefulness. Endowed with it, the universe becomes a new creation, clothed with beauty and diversified by that infinite variety which never fails to attract the mind and heart.

abstract: This vessel, which has arrived at this port, was captured on the 18th May, by the United States steamer Octorara, between Abacoa and Nassau, after a most obstinate resistance, the Octorara firing no less than sixteen shots at her, several of which took effect, passing through her smoke-stack, rigging, &c. She did not stop her engine until a 9-inch shell exploded in her starboard wheel-house, effectually crippling her. She was commanded by Capt. COPPER, who acknowledged having run the blockade on several occasions. He exhibited determination and bravery worthy a better cause. She had a valuable assorted cargo; is a Clyde built steamer, with oscillating engines, having two cylinders of thirty inches each and four feet stroke being over 200 horse power. Her boiler is nearly new, and is one of NAPIER's, with vertical tubes. This prize, with her engines in perfect order, would be one of the fastest vessels in our waters; and being of very light draft, would be of great service in our rivers and inlets along our coast.

abstract: Neutrality; Foreign Enlistment Act, Debate on in Parliament
snippet: Neutrality; Foreign Enlistment Act, Debate on in Parliament
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN, in rising to call attention to a memorial signed by thirty of the most respectable shipowners of Liverpool respecting the evasion of our Foreign Enlishment law, said that the Government professed its inability to detect and punish the breaches of the law committed by British subjects in building and sending to sea vessels-of-war to be employed against a friendly Power. It appeared to him, however, in reading the correspondence on this subject, that the Foreign-office assumed a passive position, and thought they could only be called upon to interfere when some foreign Government complained that the provisions of the law were impugned. But the Foreign Enlistment act was passed not for the benefit of foreign Powers, but for our own protection. It was, therefore, the duty of the Executive to see that the law was obeyed, and he could not conceive that the Home-office and all its machinery of magistrates and, policemen could be better employed than in inforcing the observance of the act of Parliament. There were three vessels specifically Known which were now preying upon the commerce of a friendly Power -- the Orelo, alias the Florida, the Alabama, alias the "290," and the Japan, alias the Virginia. All these were built in England, were armed and chiefly manned from England. One of these ships managed to get into Mobile and get back again, but the others had never yet entered a Confederate port. He wished the House to consider how this state of things would effect our interests if we were at war and the Americans were at peace. If the law as it now stood were not sufficient, the memorialists suggested some amendments that would give greater power to the Government to seize in British ports vessel? that were destined for the use of the belligerents. He believed that the addition of a single word would be sufficient -- the word "building" in addition to the words " furnishing out and arming"' ships. This would prevent vessels leaving our ports in a partially unfinished state, and afterward being converted into a vessel-of-war. He was informed that were at this moment two ironclads now being built in this country, and that the Government had received a reclamation from the United States Minister in this country that these vessels were intended for the Confederate Government. From all he observed of the slate of public opinion in America, he was convinced that if these vessels went out and began to prey upon the United States shipping it would lead to a war with that country. Tin se ships now building at Liver pool were lion rams. They were a match for any vessel of war that America now had, or that we ourselves possessed and if they were allowed to sail it would probably lead to a rupture between this country and the United States. The fact was, we had rendered the mercantile marine of America practically valueless. The American ship-owners found the rate of insurance so raised that they could no longer compete with the ships of England and other maritime Powers. They had consequently been selling their ships to English shipowners, and he asked the House to consider the effect of such a state of thin is on the minds of the shipowners of New-York and Boston, who had always been favorable to peace with Great Britain. During the recess. Her Majesty's Government might take precautions against these ships leaving the ports of this country for service against a friendly Power. In the case of every vessel captured by the Florida, the Alabama and the Virginia, the American Government took depositions on oath as to the value of the ship and cargo, and claims for this amount were made upon the English Government- Every vessel seized and burnt was thus debited to the account of England, and a, formal claim made for the amount. Her Majesty's Government had refused to acknowledge these claims, but some day, when the demand could be made most inconveniently for the Government, the result would probably be either humiliation or war. i\o doubt many persons in this country would prefer war; but was it desirable that the interest of the whole community should be affected by the conduct of two or three firms in this country? The hon. member for Birkenhead, on a former- occasion, spoke of the greater export of arms and ammunition to the Federal States. There was, however, a great difference between the export of ships and the export of arms and ammunition Gunpowder was a constant article or commerce, and was extensively used in the operations of mining, blasting. &c. To prohibit the export of ammunition would, therefore, be injurious to a large and regular industry. There was, moreover, no law against this export. But the law undertook to prevent the people of this country from supplying ships-of-war to be used against a friendly Power, and the manning of such ships. The honorable gentleman (Mr. LAIRD) had told the House that he had been applied to to build ships for the Federal Government. If that were so, the honorable member was quite right to refuse the applications, but he held in his hand an official contradiction to the statement of the honorable member for Birkenhead.

abstract: The Election in
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky election, contrary to the hopes and expectations of the Secessionists, has gone very largely for the Union candidates. The friends of CHARLES A. WICKLIFFE the "Democratic" candidate for Governor, claimed the State by 50,000 majority. They now lay their defeat to "military intimidation" and the proclamation of martial law by Gen. BURNSIDE. The remoter districts of the State are not fully heard from, but so far as reports are in, they do not sustain the complaints of the defeated candidates, for the Union candidates run fully as well ahead where there were no Union soldiers stationed.

abstract: River; the commerce of the
lead_paragraph: The reopening of the Mississippi River may fairly be rejoiced over as the heaviest blow yet delivered to the rebellion, inasmuch as it dismembers the so-called Confederacy and secures to the Union armies and fleet unembarrassed transportation on the great highway, so necessary in the further prosecution of hostilities. But all theories based on the immediate resumption of a large commerce on the Mississippi River, such as existed before the war, are doomed to severe disappointment.

abstract: At the opening of the Court, yesterday morning, District-Attorney HALL called on for trial the riot cases.
lead_paragraph: At the opening of the Court, yesterday morning, District-Attorney HALL called on for trial the riot cases. The first case called was that of DENNIS CAREY and MARKS J. SILVA, jointly indicted for the murder and hanging of a negro named ABRAM FRANKLIN, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Seventh-avenue. Ex-Judge STUART appeared for CAREY and JONAS B. PHILIPS, Esq., for SILVA. The prisoners demanded separate trials, and neither of them were ready. The trial of SILVA was finally set down for Friday, and that of CAREY for Monday.

abstract: Upward of twenty-five years since, Dr. BENJAMIN BRANDRETH introduced to the community a vegetable pill which has since become the household medicine of tens of thousands of families in the United States, and throughout the countries of Europe and South America.
lead_paragraph: Upward of twenty-five years since, Dr. BENJAMIN BRANDRETH introduced to the community a vegetable pill which has since become the household medicine of tens of thousands of families in the United States, and throughout the countries of Europe and South America. When first brought to the notice of the public, few could be persuaded of its virtues. Gradually, at first, it was tried, and then, as case after case of recovery from many diseases reached the ears of the public, its value increased in what might be called geometrical proportion. Medical men, who had seen patients recover rapidly by the use of BRANDRETH's pills who had for indefinite periods of time been under their charge without showing signs of improvement, began to despair, believing that the great secret of life and health had been discovered, and that their occupation was gone from them. Some, more enterprising than their fellows, at once adopted into their practice the great conservator of health, and their success corresponded with their liberality. Since then, the Brandrethian system has been in the ascendant.

abstract: Neutrality--Laird, Mr.; How he Wriggles Out
snippet: Neutrality--Laird, Mr.; How he Wriggles Out
lead_paragraph: -- We give the text of Secretary WELLES' note denying the allegation made by Mr. LAIRD in the House of Commons, that our Government had applied to him to build vessels for our service. The denial is very explicit and direct; and though Mr. LAIRD has tried to get out of his false position by publishing certain letters on the subject, it turns out that these letters were from "anonymous individuals" in this country. We suppose they had such signatures as "A True American," "British Honor," "Privateer," ", s.d.," "Blank & Co.," and proposed very big jobs and very stupendous profits. But if this is the best authority that Mr. LAIRD can give for his positive assertion, people will be very chary about crediting anything he may assert in future. The London Daily News declares that "the House of Commons was never more completely surprised than it was when Mr. LAIRD announced that the Federal Government had applied to him to build war-ships;" that the "announcement electrified the House; the friends of the Federal cause were struck dumb, and those of the Confederacy shouted for joy." We should like to know how the members of the House of Commons, Mr. LAIRD, the friends of the Federal cause and those of the Confederacy, feel about the matter now.

abstract: Her speed is expected to exceed that of any vessel now in the service. The Navy Constructor at this station has also instructions from the Navy Department to commence immediately another fast steamer on his own plan. Considerable interest attaches in naval circles to the progress of these ships, as there is a sort of friendly rivalry exhibited between Mr. STEERS and his competitor. The name of the vessel to be built at the Navy-yard is Wambanoge, and it is understood that she will measure some 3,000 tons burden.

abstract: -- The loss of two millions and a half of dollars by the burning of the steamer Ruth, on the Mississippi on Tuesday last, is an unfortunate affair for GRANT's soldiers, who will have to wait a, few days longer for their greenbacks. But that is the worst of it. The cost of the two millions and a half to the Government was only the price it paid for the paper and ink.

abstract: -- The Richmond correspondent of the London Times, writing before the fall of Vicksburgh, gives some reasons why Gen. JOHNSTON, with his large force, did not attempt to raise the siege. JOHNSTON had a great difficulty in his way in the immense strength of GRANT's position, and his large army: beside this, "there was not much harmony or kindness of feeling existing between JOHNSTON and the Richmond War Department:" but a much more plausible cause than either of these is given when he says that Gen. JOHNSTON was "despondent beyond expression." This, says the correspondent, is "one of the worst qualities which a soldier can possess, and was regarded by NAPOLEON as always fatal to success."

abstract: GRAND LODGE OF I.O. of O.F. ANNUAL SESSION. The R.W. Grand Lodge of Southern NewYork convened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, being the regular stated session.
lead_paragraph: GRAND LODGE OF I.O. of O.F. -- ANNUAL SESSION. -- The R.W. Grand Lodge of Southern New-York convened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, being the regular stated session. EDWIN SWANTON, M.W. Grand Master, presided, and a large representation from subordinate Lodges were present. A Committee on Credentials, P.G.R.G. MILLARD, of No. 64; P.C.W. DUNSCOMBE, of No. 61, and THOMAS WALSH, of No. 140, retired and examined the credentials of the several representatives, which were found correct, and acce ???ed by the Grand Lodge. After prayer by the R.W. Grand Chaplain, Rev. Brother R. TRAVIS, a number of new members of the Grand Lodge were admitted and instructed in the Grand Lodge degree. A petition from Worth Lodge. No. 400, was received, requesting to move their place of meeting from Brooklyn to New-York. Referred. Communications were received from the R.W. Grand Lodges of Missouri, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Indiana and Maryland, and referred to the Committee on Correspondence. Two cases of appeal against subordinate Lodges were received and referred. A communication from the Grand Lodge of Pennsylvania, transmitting a resolution adopted, in which they assert devotion to the Union as the duty of every true Odd Fellow, was, on motion of P.G.M. TH. FROMENT, received. The Grand Lodge took a recess until 8 o'clock in the evening, when the Grand Master delivered his annual address.

abstract: The Ghost will make his appearance at this house to-night in a piece called "True to the Last" -- a drama written for the express purpose of introducing that extraordinary illusion. The greatest curiosity prevails on the subject of this new comer. If the effect is what it pretends to be -- and in view of the great success of the spectre in London and Paris, this scarcely admits of a doubt -- the stage has undoubtedly gained a new and thrilling effect. We may expect to have Ghosts for a twelvemonth at least. In the meantime Mr. and Mrs. WATKINS have secured their Ghost in time to get the first fright out of the public.

abstract: The National Thanksgiving proclaimed by the President and our State and Municipal authorities, was observed by our Roman Catholic citizens more especially in the light of one of their highest church festivals, owing to the fact that it coincided with the Feast of the Transfiguration or Glorification of Christ on Mount Tabor, which has been solemnized by their denomination with the greatest care since the Twelfth Century. In the chief Catholic Churches of the City the high masses dedicated to this marked occasion were pronounced before unusually large congregations at 6 1/2 and 7 1/2 A.M. The absence of Archbishop HUGHES was due to his enfeebled health, which he is now endeavoring to recruit at Saratoga Springs.
lead_paragraph: The National Thanksgiving proclaimed by the President and our State and Municipal authorities, was observed by our Roman Catholic citizens more especially in the light of one of their highest church festivals, owing to the fact that it coincided with the Feast of the Transfiguration or Glorification of Christ on Mount Tabor, which has been solemnized by their denomination with the greatest care since the Twelfth Century. abstract: Sumter, The, and the Gibralter
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between the British Customs' Department and its employes at Liverpool, respecting the detention of the Gibraltar, (formerly the Sumter,) has been presented to the House of Commons, on the motion of Lord ROBERT CECIL. It appears that on the 19th of March, six days after the arrival of the vessel at Liverpool from Gibraltar, the Board of Customs instructed Mr. EDWARDS, the Collector at that port, to watch her, and report any information he might be enabled to obtain with respect to her and the bona fide character of her ownership. Mr. EDWARDS reported, on the following day, that the vessel had been watched since her arrival in the Mersey, and that nothing of a suspicious character bad taken place. On the 25th of May, a second order was sent down to Mr. EDWARDS, to inquire and report, in consequence of Mr. ADAMS having notified the British Government that the Gibraltar was being prepared for sea. Mr. EDWARDS, on the following day, forwarded to the Board of Customs a letter from Mr. KLINGENDER, the owner, to himself, stating that the vessel was chartered to convey 250 tons of cargo, and that he was landing all spare water-tanks, destroying her magazine, and cutting hatches in her main-deck, for the purpose of receiving cargo; and a report from Mr. MORGAN, Surveyor of Customs, stating that the vessel had been lying quietly in the great float at Birkenhead since her arrival, until Friday last, when she removed to the Clarence Dock, where she now lies, refitting for sea. Callao is said to be her destination. All fittings for warlike purposes have been removed from her since she obtained British registry at Gibraltar, and it appears, from pricate information received, that it is not intended to refit her for warlike purposes, perhaps because she is not well adapted to compete with modern vessels of war."
headline: {'main': 'The British Government and the Sumter, alias Gibraltar.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The British Government and the Sumter, alias Gibraltar.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Elections, Significance of the
lead_paragraph: The strongest argument of the Copperheads, from their first origin, has been the necessity of conciliating the Border States and keeping them well-affected. In itself it was a fair argument. No intelligent man could deny that it was a matter of great moment that Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri, which originally held back from the Confederacy, should still be retained on the side of the Union. This was important physically, for their combined population was over three millions; and still more important morally, for they were all Slave States, and their interests were identical with those for the defence of which the rebellion had been originally undertaken.

abstract: -- In St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Mulberry-street, there was a third and very impressive service, yesterday, at 10 o'clock, when a grand high mass was said and a requiem sung for the repose of the soul of Mrs. Gen. CORCORAN, whose remains had been conveyed thither previous to their removal to Calvary Cemetery for interment. Gen. CORCORAN, summoned from his post of duty by this domestic bereavement, was present, surrounded by many of his old companions in arms, as well as in civil life. The remaining obsequies of Mrs. CORCORAN were conducted with the quiet solemnity becoming an event so sudden and mournful.

abstract: Alderman TERENCE FARLEY, residing at No. 135 East Fifty-fourth-street, appeared before Justic DODGE, of the Yorkville Police Court, on Wednesday, and entered a complaint against one PATRICE GOLDING, charging that he and others willfully and unlawfully assembled in and about the Colored Orphan Asylum, Firth-avenue, on the 13th ultimo, for the purpose of sacking and burning the same, and that then and there GOLDING did attempt to incite the mob to proceed to the Alderman's residence, and sack and burn it; that GOLDING called at his house while the Alderman was concealed on the opposite side of the street, and exhibiting a pistol, threatened to shoot Alderman FARLEY dead, and then sack and burn his dwelling. GOLDING, failing to find the Alderman, proceeded to the residence of Rev. JAMES MCMAHON, Fiftieth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues, and stated to him and Rev. Mr. MCAVOY that Alderman FARLEY was concealed there, and that he wished to see the Alderman, so that he could shoot him; that he came there for that purpose. GOLDING was expostulated with by the reverend gentlemen, and advised to go home. Mr. MCMAHON subsequently called at the Alderman's house, and there saw GOLDING in the street with a gang of rioters, endeavoring by signs and gestures to incite them to sack and burn the house. GOLDING there renewed the threat to take Alderman's FARLEY's life.

abstract: Quite a large congregation assembled to hear this fearless champion of human rights and ilberty, expecting a rich treat, considering the day and the theme.
lead_paragraph: Quite a large congregation assembled to hear this fearless champion of human rights and ilberty, expecting a rich treat, considering the day and the theme. It was a great disappointment, therefore. when the Reverend Doctor began his discourse by announcing that, during the whole course of his ministry, he himself had never experienced a worse disappointment than on the present occasion. Supposing that only a few friends could assemble at this season, he had prepared no discourse, intending only to make a simple exhortation suited to the times.

abstract: Thanksgiving and its Fruits
lead_paragraph: From Maine to California, the day of National Thanksgiving was celebrated yesterday. Thousands of clergymen held forth from their pulpits, and hundreds of thousands of men, women and children united in ascriptions of praise to Heaven. In New-England, in the Middle States, in the Valley of the Mississippi, in the Far West, and on the coast of the Pacific, the people were of one mind. In our Armies, stationed on the Potomac, on the Tennessee, on the Upper and Lower Mississippi, and on the headwaters of the Arkansas -- in our Navy, stationed all along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, and on all the rivers of the South -- our soldiers and our sailors kept holiday, and acknowledged that not alone their own valor and endurance, but a higher Power had led them on to victory. In the City of San Francisco, as we learn by telegraph, there were national salutes and ringing of bells morning, noon and night, and in the evening there was a grand assemblage of the people, and a general illumination of the city; and from the farthest East we have reports of a like character. In New-York, we have seldom known a holiday to be so generally kept. In the earlier part of the day some business was done, but toward noon it was almost universally suspended, and the citizens cheerfully carried out the advice of President LINCOLN in his most excellent Proclamation.
headline: {'main': 'Thanksgiving and its Fruits.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Thanksgiving and its Fruits.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: o'clock this forenoon, people could be seen by thousands, running to Andrews-street Bridge, drawn by a report that a woman was going over the falls. It turned but that there was a woman in the river in danger of such a fate, but she was rescued. The woman was a disorderly character, known as "Crazy Mag," who has wandered about the streets for years, a public nuisance, using foul language and insulting respectable people. Her name is MARGARET O'KERRON, Several complaints were made to the Police, and on Saturday she was arrested, to be sent to the Asylum. This morning, soon after the Magistrate had disposed of her case, a policeman undertook to escort her to a cell. While going along the balcony beside the river, the girl sprang away and leaped the railing, throwing herself into the swift water, twelve feet below. The policeman caught her dress, which he tore off, but did not save the prisoner. The girl struck out into the swift water, and was rapidly drifting toward the High Falls. Ex-Policeman MCANNALLY leaped in to rescue her, but she had too much the start of him. An alarm was sounded and heard by JAMES WHITE, employed at the Gas Works, and he plunged into the river below the woman, and soon rescued her, though at considerable risk, for the water was high. The girl was taken into the yard of the Gas Company, and after considerable delay, physicians were found to attend her. For some time she showed no animation, but at length began to revive. It was thought that she would recover. -- Rochester Democrat, Aug. 3.

abstract: SUN-STROKES, CORONERS' INQUESTS, ETC.  There were several cases of sun-stroke and sudden deaths reported at the Coroner's office yesterday.
lead_paragraph: SUN-STROKES, CORONERS' INQUESTS, ETC. -- There were several cases of sun-stroke and sudden deaths reported at the Coroner's office yesterday. Coroner RANNEY held inquests in the following cases: MARTIN SPLEIS, a German, who died while being conveyed to Ward's Island; ROBERT MARTIN, a native of Ireland, who died at No. 129 Christopher-street, and an unknown man in West Thirty-seventh-street, and a woman at No. 239 Tenth-avenue, both natives of Ireland. All the above parties died from the effects of the heat.... Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at No. 74 Leonard-street upon the bodies of ALEXANDER M. MCDORY and his wife CATHARINE, who died within an hour and thirty minutes of each other, under peculiar circumstances. It appears that the man had been subject to fits, and that he passed into one of them yesterday morning. His wife, thinking him to be in a dying condition, ran out and so informed another woman. Upon returning, she found her husband lifeless. In one hour and a half she also became a corpse. A post-mortem examination of the bodies has failed to elicit any prominent cause of death in the parties, except fits in the one case and possibly excess of grief in the other....The same Coroner held inquests on the bodies of Patrick Bride, a native of Ireland. 63 years of age, and residing at No. 183 Tenth-avenue; Alex. Burns, 44 years of age, a native of Ireland, residing at No. 83 West Twenty-eighth-street; Carl Kl???, a German baker, of Delancy and Broome; John Cain, of Stanton-street and Bowery; Christy Stevenson, a lad eight years of age, residing at No. 216 East Eleventh-street; Thomas Garren, No. 133 Mulberry; George Higby, of No. 151 Ludlow -- all of these were from effects of the heat. Eliza Briggs, of No. 61 Washington-street, and Wm. Buord, a carpenter, of One Hundred and Eighty- fourth-street, were also victims to the great heat.

abstract: Ceremonies, Discourses, >amp;c; Ceremonies, Discourses, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The National Thanksgiving was observed throughout the City yesterday by an almost entire abstaining from secular pursuits. The stores throughout were closed, and there appeared to be a very general desire to unite in the purposes of the day -- Thanksgiving and Praise. Very many of the churches were open, where proper observances were had, and each was crowded to overflowing. A large number, however, and many of them among the most prominent, were closed, this being "vacation season" with the pastors. It was a matter of disappointment and remark that on such an occasion the pulpits of all the churches in the City were not filled, either by the regular officiates, or from the many who would have volunteered. In a number of the churches no discourses were delivered, the services consisting of special prayers and hymns.

abstract: at Vicksburgh since its surrender, writes the New-  Albany Ledger that he has made the most careful inquiry as to the actual number of women killed in the city during the bombardment of the town by Gen. GRANT. He learns that the number is 20. Besides these, quite a number of children were also killed. Capt. MCDOUGAL states that during the bombardment, it was not an uncommon sight for women to be seen, parasol in hand, promenading the streets, and that the number of them killed is attributable to the bravado spirit with which they thus exposed themselves. In one instance of the death of children, eight or ten little boys were playing together in front of one of the caves dug into the hill-side for the protection of the women and children; a shell exploded in their midst, killing seven of them. One little fellow, a most interesting child, and son of a formerly prominent merchant of the town, was literally torn into fragments.

abstract: The "Ghost" of which we have heard so much, made its appearance last night, and with commendable promptness did all that was expected of it. Without disparagement to Twenty-seventh-street we may say, briefly and boldly, that it is the best "Ghost" we have ever had in New-York.
lead_paragraph: The "Ghost" of which we have heard so much, made its appearance last night, and with commendable promptness did all that was expected of it. Without disparagement to Twenty-seventh-street we may say, briefly and boldly, that it is the best "Ghost" we have ever had in New-York. The "Ghost" was introduced in a drama called "True to the Last," a word of quaint and curious design, and singular inferiorily of workmanship. It serves its purpose, however, and whilst the public appetite is ravenous for "Ghosts" it will be bolted with avidity, notwithstanding its crudenes. Abler hands will in time supply more suitable media for the spirit players. An imaginative writer could hardly desire a more powerful ally than Prof. PEPPER. There cannot be a doubt that the spectral drama, thanks to that gentleman's Ghost, will sweep over the land with more than the violence that characterised the sensational or contemporaneous dramas in their palmiest day. The breathless anxiety of the public last evening, and the tremor of surprise at the first appalling aspect of the spectre were the best proofs of the success of the initial experiment. The first "appearance," however, was the least effective part of the entertainment. It was not a Ghost in the correct sense of the word, but a hard and angular reflection of a skeleton. Subsequently, the shades of the Bride of a Night and of the Old Miser completely electrified the audience, notwithstanding that they appeared somewhat abruptly. Their disappearrnce was far better, and was curiously spectral and mysterious Allowance has. of course, to be made for a first night, but, notwithstanding the few drawbacks that occurred -- such as the very palpable skirt-board, whence the apparatives always came, and the determination of Mr. DALY to expose the whereabouts of the spirit, by always keeping in its vicinity the "Ghost," was a complete and thorough success.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader, and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- During the squall from northwest yesterday, the lightning struck and shattered the flagstaff on the Battery, scoring it, from near the vane to the ground. The topmast has since fallen down. The brig North Point, at the Union Stores, Brooklyn, had foreyard, topmast-yard and topgallant-yard and topmast-head shivered. The schooner Anna Leverett, at the same pier, had main-  topmast carried away. The fluid then passed over the prize-steamer Peterhoff, on the next pier, but she being of iron, received no damage. The squall did not extend beyond the upper part of the City northward, but passed over Brooklyn and Williamsburgh.

abstract: The National Thanksgiving was quite generally observed yesterday by various separate classes and denominations of our citizens. High masses were said in St. Patrick's Cathedral and all the leading Catholic Churches, together with prayers for those in power and authority.
lead_paragraph: The National Thanksgiving was quite generally observed yesterday by various separate classes and denominations of our citizens. High masses were said in St. Patrick's Cathedral and all the leading Catholic Churches, together with prayers for those in power and authority. The Catholics paid chief attention to the day, as one of their great solemnities, the Feast of the Transfiguration. At St. Patrick's the obsequies of Mrs. Gen. CORCORAN were performed in the morning. The Israelites were conspicuous in their respect for the day. At the Green-street Synagogue services were conducted by Rev. Mr. KRAMER; at the Wooster and Nineteenth-street Synagogues by Rev. Messrs??? S.M. ISAACS and J.J. LYONS, with brief appropriate ??? is-cours??? s. The Germans, too, were not behind ??? and is making the occasion one of rare festivity, and their numerous places of resort in and around the City were thousand until the latest h???irs with merry thousand, the Picnic and Summer-night Festival at Cremome Gardens being the most marked. The Father Mathew Total Abstinence Society No. 2. JAMES BRENNAN, President, celebrated their first Picnic at Jones' Wood with speeches, music and dancing. Characteristic letters from P.T. BARNUM, Esq., and GEO. FRANCIS TRAIN were read, and all passed off successfully.

abstract: I have been, till now, a great admirer of the gentleman who sends to the TIMES valuable articles from "The Beeches" and signs himself a "Veteran Observer," whoever he is. We have had several affairs of outposts with the enemy, in all of which we have been successful.

abstract: The Sons of Fatherland in America, and particularly in the vicinity of our good City, are never behind hand upon occasions of public rejoicing, and right worthily did they honor the 6th of August. All their places of popular resort in and near the Metropolis and sister cities were thronged with joyous merry-makers from early morning until late at night; in fact, the festivities were, here and there, prolonged until the ensuing dawn.
lead_paragraph: The Sons of Fatherland in America, and particularly in the vicinity of our good City, are never behind hand upon occasions of public rejoicing, and right worthily did they honor the 6th of August. All their places of popular resort in and near the Metropolis and sister cities were thronged with joyous merry-makers from early morning until late at night; in fact, the festivities were, here and there, prolonged until the ensuing dawn. At the Lyon Brewery Park, on One Hundred and Tenth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues; at CONRAD's Elm Park, on Ninetieth-street and Ninth-avenue; at LANDMANN's Hamilton Park, On Sixty-ninth street and Third-avenue; at MUELLEE's Central Park House, on Seventy-first-street and Fourth-avenue, and at Harmonie Garden, on Essex- street, immense crowds of Teutonic folk feted the day with laughter and song, not omitting copious but harmless potations of the national beverages they have imported with them and made welcome in this country. The Union flag waved over all, prophetic of bright hopes for the future of their race in the land of their adoption.

abstract: On  Monday GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS delivered an address before the Adelphic Union of Williams College. His topic was "The True Idea of American Liberty." The lecture was in outline the same that he delivered in various places last Winter, but modified and adapted to the occasion and the changes in public affairs.
lead_paragraph: -- On Monday GEORGE WILLIAM CURTIS delivered an address before the Adelphic Union of Williams College. His topic was "The True Idea of American Liberty." The lecture was in outline the same that he delivered in various places last Winter, but modified and adapted to the occasion and the changes in public affairs. The Freshman Class celebrated on Monday night the completion of the first year's studies by a grotesque masquerade, in which the Springfield Republican says some of the performers were indecent and offensive, if not positively blasphemous. The man who made the first burlesque oration has been promptly expelled by the faculty.

abstract: And her "Excellent Ally," France
lead_paragraph: -- England is likely to have enough of her "excellent ally," France. Amiable John Bull is led into every imaginable quarrel by his restless, scheming neighbor, and must either fight and increase taxes to advance "French glory," or back out and lose prestige as a great power.

abstract: THANKSGIVING DAY. The city presented the appearance of a Sunday yesterday. All places of business were closed, and large numbers took advantage of the occasion to take a trip to the numerous public resorts on the Island, or enjoy themselves on pic-nic excursions. The streets were thronged with vehicles going out of town in the morning and the cars were overcrowded.
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING DAY. -- The city presented the appearance of a Sunday yesterday. All places of business were closed, and large numbers took advantage of the occasion to take a trip to the numerous public resorts on the Island, or enjoy themselves on pic-nic excursions. The streets were thronged with vehicles going out of town in the morning and the cars were overcrowded. Services were held in a number of churches, but in consequence of the absence of the more prominent clergymen, as well as the usual attendants the congregations were, in several instances, not as large as they might have been under different circumstances. During the shower about noon, an accident occurred at Leffert's Park, where a large number of persons were enjoying themselves on a pic-nic. Many persons rushed to the speakers' stand, which was covered, to get out of the rain, and the weight becoming too great, the platform gave way and they were precipitated to the ground. Three persons were severely injured, namely: MARY FORBISH, residing at No. 175 Hudson-avenue; MARY PIGLAN, a child, and JOHN KELLY, residing in York-street, near Jay. Several others were bruised, but not badly hurt. The injured parties were taken to their homes.

abstract: The repulse at Fort Wagner, so nearly a succees, will be long remembered for its gallantry and its loss of valuable life. Three young men fell on those bloody ramparts, who had recently walked our streets full of vigor and promise each of them worthy to assert his preeminence even in South Carolina, where pride is a monomania and treason an inheritance.
lead_paragraph: The repulse at Fort Wagner, so nearly a succees, will be long remembered for its gallantry and its loss of valuable life. Three young men fell on those bloody ramparts, who had recently walked our streets full of vigor and promise -- each of them worthy to assert his preeminence even in South Carolina, where pride is a monomania and treason an inheritance. Either of these gentlemen were by talents and education, and in every accomplishment, the superior of the most gifted of a people whose polished and courteous demeanor lays on the surface and does not reach the heart. They were young lions struggling with the tigers of South Carolina, and destined to fall in their bloody fangs. Each of them held high rank and had given promise of a brilliant future. GEORGE C. STRONG and HALDEMAN S. PUTNAM were class-mates at West Point, the one graduating in the Ordnance class, the other in the Engineers -- both evidences of high professional attainments. Both served for awhile on the Staff of Gen. BUTLER; and the New-York regiments in service at Annapolis, in April, 1861, will remember in Col. PUTNAM the young Lieutenant of Topographical Engineers, who mustered them into service by order of the War Department, in which he was assisted by (now) Brig.-Gen. EDWARD E. POTTER. PUTNAM. after serving in the Army of Virginia, was called to the command of the Seventh New-Hampshire, raised as a regiment of cavalry, but never mounted, with which he served during the past year, in Florida and South Carolina. At the attack on Fort Wagner he led his brigade gallantly into action, and fell while rallying his men, holding his position within the enemy's works.

abstract: The  Associated Press of this City was favored, yesterday morning, with an owlish dispatch from washington, the gist of which  was, that "the United States might become involved in a war with England," and that war, however undersirable, "is not the greatest of evils."
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press of this City was favored, yesterday morning, with an owlish dispatch from washington, the gist of which was, that "the United States might become involved in a war with England," and that war, however undersirable, "is not the greatest of evils." But as England is not the only country just now amenable lo American criticism, it is added in the dispatch, that as to France's peccadilloes, they may be postponed to a more convenient season, and that the Emperor of the French may make use of the grace of our delay, to withdraw from Mexico and get out of the range of our displeasure!
