abstract: We are officially informed that the order for the draft has been received at the Provost-Marshal's office, and the drawing of the names will commence at 10 o'clock Wednesday morning, in the Court-housesquare, in the rear of the Court-house. The drawing will be suspended on Thursday, on account of the National Thanksgiving, but will be resumed on Friday morning and continued until completed for the entire district.

abstract: has just been the scene of another political emeute. Certain invalid soldiers became offended by a flag, the owner of which had the bad taste to have inscribed with the names of VALLANDINGHAM and PUGH, and flung to the breeze over his store. They tore it down, and treated it with some nameless indignity. But this was contrary to the Bill of Rights, the Declaration of Independence, the Fourth of July, and the peace and dignity of the commonwealth; and the friends of the reviled flag assembled in large numbers, and raised it again.

abstract: The rather Matthew Total Abstinence Benevolent Society, No.2, held their first grand picnic, yesterday, at Jones' Wood. The Association assembled at 10 A.M. in their hall corner of Second-avenue and Twenty-third-street, and thence proceeded in the cars to the place of festivity, one of the most delightful parks and groves in the vicinity of the metropolis.
lead_paragraph: The Father Matthew Total Abstinence Benevolent Society, No. 2, held their first grand picnic, yesterday, at Jones' Wood. The Association assembled at 10 A.M. in their hall corner of Second-avenue and Twenty-third-street, and thence proceeded in the cars to the place of festivity, one of the most delightful parks and groves in the vicinity of the metropolis. Mine host SOMMERS, the hospitable occupant of the hotel and grounds, had put forth all his well-known talent and good-will in preparing his beautiful retreat for the expected guests, and the throng of both sexes, big and little, who soon filled it, bore testimony to his success.

abstract: -- The literary estate has sent its representatives to the field, and in no case have they failed to uphold the honor of the profession. There was Winthrop, who fell at Big Bethel, one of the first heroes of the war; FITZ JAMES O'BRIEN, who met his death wound with LANDER, and had we time, we could call over a long roll of names well known in the literature of the country, that have gone out to battle -- many that went out, but were fated to never return. The New-York Times contributed its quota early in the war. Several went from the composition and press rooms. CHARLES G. HALPINE, an editorial writer, is now a Colonel on HUNTER's Staff, having joined the army as a Staff officer before the first battle of Bull Run, and continued with it ever since. Maj. GOVERNEUR CARR went from the TIMES Office, too, as a Lieutenant in Duryea's Zouaves, participated in the action at Big Bethel, where WINTHROP fell, and won a Captaincy fairly. When it was proposed to raise a regiment to be known as the second battalion of Duryea's Zouaves, he took an active part, and to his exertions, in a good measure, its successful raising was due. He was commissioned Major. The regiment went from New-York with BANKS' Expedition. and now news comes that the Major was severely wounded at the head of his men in the attack on Port Hudson -- ADAM BADEAU, too -- a brother-in-law of "DICK BUSTEED," a writer who acquired some celebrity from his contributions to the light literature of the day, and from a series of essays written over the signature of "Vagabond," which originally appeared in some of the weeklies, and were subsequently published in book form, for some time a war correspondent of the TIMES, joined the army at Port Royal, being appointed to the Captaincy of a company. He saw service at the West, and went with Gen. SHERMAN to the Lower Mississippi. Capt. BADEAU also was wounded in the same action where CAPR got his last scars. These are newspaper men who will have something to talk about "when the war is over," and whose patriotism was not a mere thing of words. Other journalists are serving their country bravely and effectually at home, but they must all yield the palm of sacrifice to those who have gone into actual service where bombs fall and bullets fly -- San Francisco Bulletin.

abstract: Monday afternoon, the force of the Fourth Precinct Capt. BRYAN, No. Oak-street reported at Headquarters, under Sergeants DELANEY and LOCKWOOD, only one section being retained at the Station, under Sergeants RODE and WILLIAMS.
lead_paragraph: Monday afternoon, the force of the Fourth Precinct -- Capt. BRYAN, No. _____ Oak-street -- reported at Headquarters, under Sergeants DELANEY and LOCKWOOD, only one section being retained at the Station, under Sergeants RODE and WILLIAMS. This was engaged all day in saving the lives of colored persons in the Precinct, some seventy of whom were rescued from gangs and brought for safety to the Station- house. During the day, thirteen houses occupied by this class were sacked and partially burned, the active efforts of the force preventing their entire destruction. In the evening, Sergeant WILLIAMS and Roundsman WEBB, with four men, all in citizen's dress, mingled with the crowd at the Tribune building, and ascertaining its purpose, made prompt report to Capt. BRYAN, who, with what men he had was soon thereafter engaged with the Twenty-sixth Precinct in the defeat of the mob. Subsequently, Capt. BRYAN acted as guide to Inspector CARPENTER's tour through the Fourth Ward, and, with some of his Precinct, joined in the attacks upon the mob in Roosevelt and in Dover streets. During all Monday night, and until Tuesday morning, his men were constantly on active duty in the Ward.

abstract: At the Libby Prison, on the 5th, there were some 740 Yankees received, the remnant of captures at Gettsburgh and other points. In this lot of prisoners were the following officers, viz.: Capts. C.D. Bowers, 18th Connecticut; R.T. Cornell, 67th Pennsylvania; W.H. Bender, 123d Ohio, and J.P. Gleason, 5th New-York; First Lieut. Murwin, 18th Connecticut: Second Lieuts. J.S. Paul. 122d Ohio, and G.D. Dakers, 123d Ohio; Surgeons D. Meeker and L. Holbrook; Assistant Surgeons A.M. Parker, S.L. Henry, and J.R. Uhler. In addition to the above, there were nine citizens of Gettysburgh received at the above-named prison.

abstract: Some indications from the other side of the line render it probable that the Yankees propose to make a more vigorous effort than ever to capture Richmond. From these signs, it seems likely that a large portion of GRANT'S and ROSECRANS' armies are moving ...
lead_paragraph: Some indications from the other side of the line render it probable that the Yankees propose to make a more vigorous effort than ever to capture Richmond. From these signs, it seems likely that a large portion of GRANT's and ROSECRANS' armies are moving eastward, and may be in Virginia by the 1st of September. Whether they will join MEADE, or come by the way of tide-water, either on the south side of James River, or up York, is not yet developed.

abstract: We infer from the movements of the enemy that he is preparing for a great, probably a final struggle in Virginia. Large numbers of GRANT'S troops are passing up the Mississippi River from Vicksburgh, destined, as stated by their officers, for the army of MEADE. We have intimations also that ROSECRANS has fallen back from the late positions occupied ...
lead_paragraph: We infer from the movements of the enemy that he is preparing for a great, probably a final struggle in Virginia. Large numbers of GRANT's troops are passing up the Mississippi River from Vicksburgh, destined, as stated by their officers, for the army of MEADE. We have intimations also that ROSECRANS has fallen back from the late positions occupied by him. and it may be that he too is sending aid to the Federal army in Virginia. Gen. DIX, with some twenty to thirty thousand troops, has already joined Gen. MEADE, and it is not at all improbable that within a few weeks the Federal commander will be enabled to throw against Gen. LEE an army of one hundred and fifty to two hundred thousand strong.

abstract: Rifled Ordnance and Fort Sumter
lead_paragraph: Gen. GILLIMORE has recorded, in a very full and valuable report on the reduction of Fort Pulaski, the results of his experiments on the power of rifled ordnance for effecting breaches in brick walls. It is not unlikely that he has by this time made still further tests of the same interesting nature -- namely, the effect of rifled ordnance on the brick walls of Fort Sumter -- though all the elements in the present problem, will be on a far greater scale than those in the case of Pulaski. In that undertaking the guns used were 24, 32 and 42-pounder rifled guns, and 30-pounder Parrott rifles, and 8 and 10-inch Columbiads (smooth-bore.) The three breaching batteries were established at a mean distance of 1,700 yards from Fort Pulaski. It was found that the 42-pounder, with a charge of eight pounds of powder, penetrated twenty-six inches; the 30-pounder Parrott, with a charge of three and a half pounds, penetrated eighteen inches, and the 10-inch Columbiad, with a charge of twenty pounds, penetrated thirteen inches.

abstract: This Precinct, Capt. JOHN JOURDAN, No. 9 Franklin-street, had no little work to do.
lead_paragraph: This Precinct, Capt. JOHN JOURDAN, No. 9 Franklin-street, had no little work to do. At 3 P.M. on Monday an attack was made by a large mob on premises of colored people at No. 42 Baxter-street. Capt. JOURDEN, with Sergeants WALSH and MCGIVEN and the second platoon, were soon at the spot, and after a severe fight, in which the force was boldly opposed, the rioters were dispersed, many of them badly injured. Of the force Roundsman RYAN was the only one hurt; he was knocked down and his club wrenched from him, but was at once-on his feet again and the in thickest of the fray. Soon alter the Captain, with same officers and platoon, repaired to CROOK's, No, 74 Chatham-Street, which was being assailed by a mob. A charge was made unexpectedly upon the rascals, the locust liberally used and a general scattering ensued. At 5 1/2 P.M. some 300 men, women and boys attacked the dwellings of colored people in Pell, near Mott street; with the same officers and force, the captain repaired thither, charged upon and routed the assailants. In this cowardly attack by the rioters, Elizabeth Hennesy, a colored woman 57 years of age, was struck and severely injured by a brick; she was rescued by the police, and conveyed to the City Hospital. At 6 P M., upwards of six hundred rioters attacked a house at Leonard and Baxter streets, occupied by some twenty colored families, stoning in the windows, attempting to break in and fire it. Capt. JOURDAN. with Sergeants WALSH, QUIN and KENNEDY, and first and second platoon, were speedily on hand; a severe fight ensued; the rioters were effectively handled, and dozens lay senseless on the street; ultimately they fled.

abstract: Riots; Bogus Claims for Damages
lead_paragraph: That there was heavy loss of life and property in this City during the late disgraceful and bloody riots, no one will doubt. A number of houses were entered and sacked, and not a few burned. But that the losses of property were so enormous as the claims filed with the Comptroller for damages would imply, is preposterous and incredible. The claims make up a grand total of about a million dollars; and the claimants, from every class and rank in life, but mainly from persons who were not objects of the mob's violence, number over a thousand.

abstract: A new dodge to swindle the Corporation out of moneys belonging to the Volunteer Family Aid Fund, has been developed before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs.
lead_paragraph: A new dodge to swindle the Corporation out of moneys belonging to the Volunteer Family Aid Fund, has been developed before Justice CONNOLLY at the Tombs. Mr. MICHAEL J. RYAN, of No. 46 Centre- street, is Assistant Treasurer for the Fund for the ???rth Senatorial District. On and prior to the 8th on July, one FRANK FLEET was employed as "visitor," to make inquiries and report on the genuineness of applicants??? claims living in the Eighth Ward. JOHN GAVIN was also employed as "assistant visitor" for the same Ward. Of the certificates issued by these men, the claims of applicants for relief were honored and paid. Facts have recently come to the knowledge of Mr. RYAN that on or about the 8th ultimo, FLEET and GAVIN did wickedly and corruptly conspire together to utter false tokens to obtain moneys from the relief fund, with intent to cheat and defraud the Corporation of New-York, and that they subsequent??? did obtain divers sums of money, amounting, in the aggregate, ???o $36. As charged, FLEET & GAVIN had filled out certificates containing the assumed names of JOHN CAMPBELL and JOHN DUNN, and purporting to be the names of soldiers whose families were entitled to relief. Mr. RYAN avers that these names were knowingly and designedly written upon the tokens by FLEET & GAVIN, for the so???e purpose of cheating and raising money for their own personal benefit. Again it is set forth that the parties complained of issued a certificate to CHARLOTTE CAMPBELL, and prevailed upon her to present it to the Treasurer, and demand payment; to falsely represent that her husband, JOHN CAMPBELL, was in the army. According to the a???avit, the "visitor" and his "assistant" further induced her to take another certificate issued to MARY DUNN, and represent to the Treasurer, on presenting it, that Mrs. DUNN was unable, by reason of sickness, to present the same in person. The woman CAMPBELL listened to their urgent entreaties, and presenting three bogus certificates for $12 each, drew the money, and, paying it over to GAVIN, received one-third of the amount ($12) for the part she played in the alleged swindling operation. This woman, who lives at No. 5 Wooster-street, also makes an affidavit setting forth that, two or three months ago, GAVIN made a proposition for her to join ??? in making money out of the relief fund, and was very persistent in his overtures.

abstract: The trial of the rioters continued in the Court of Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN. Two prisoners, charged with the crime of riot, ...
lead_paragraph: The trial of the rioters continued in the Court of Sessions yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN. Two prisoners, charged with the crime of riot, pleaded guilty, and were sentenced to the penitentiary; two were convicted and remanded for sentence to-day; and in the case of one, tried for grand larceny from a clothing-store that was sacked by the mob, the jury were unable to agree.

abstract: Through the arrival of the steamship S.R. Spaulding at Fortress Monroe, and through a letter written on board Admiral DAHLGREN'S flagship, ...
lead_paragraph: Through the arrival of the steamship S.R. Spaulding at Fortress Monroe, and through a letter written on board Admiral DAHLGREN's flagship, and published in the Baltimore American last evening, we receive advices from the theatre of operations against Charleston to the 4th inst. The siege was then progressing satisfactorily in every respect, and all were confident of ultimate success. The grand attack, on Fort Sumter was expected to open in the course of the week, the preparations for it being nearly completed. Buoys had been located for the Monitors, and the position of the Ironsides was within five hundred yards of the fort. On Morris Island, the guns on the naval battery, which is the most advanced one, were to be mounted on the night of the 3d. The enemy were erecting batteries on James Island, to enfilade our positions, but counter batteries were also being erected to command them. On the 2d inst., 500 rebels were captured by four companies of "Les Enfans Perdus," on an island in the rear of Folly Island. Gen. GILLMORE's troops had been gladdened by the arrival of reinforcements.

abstract: -- Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS has again delivered himself of his opinions concerning the war and Slavery -- this time in the shape of a labored letter. He writes to defend the Abolitionists for their "change of base." The former Disunionism of the Abolitionists, he says, "their effort to break the Union, was only a means to an end -- the abolition of Slavery." Now, however, the Abolitionists favor the Union because "to uphold it in this struggle for existence is the readiest way to convert the nation into Abolitionists," and secure abolition. Following out the same line and the same logic, Mr. PHILLIPS and his party must now stand ready for still another change. For, in case the Union is likely to be restored without the universal, final, immediate and total abolition of Slavery, he must necessarily oppose that consummation, and resume his original ground of Disunion. In all this, PHILLIPS' policy is directly the opposite of the policy of the President, who proclaimed that the Union was the foremost and final object sought for. PHILLIPS' Unionism is like' the "little joker" -- now you see it, and now you don't.

abstract: Flour, under the exhilarating manipulation of speculators in the life-blood of their country, has suddenly become very scarce in this marker, and exceedingly high in prices. Within the past few days, hundreds of barrels of this staff of life have been spirited off by railroads to secret hiding-places else-  where, there to remain till famine prices again brings it into market. Will the Government and people stand by and see the country overrun and ruined by these vampyres in trade, who care for nothing but gold and its equivalent? Has the Government no power to rid itself of these leeches? Are the people powerless, that they should stand with folded arms till speculators have deprived the army of subsistence and starved to death the wives, children and widows of our beloved soldiers? Rather than submit to such fearful results, let every speculator in the necessaries of life be marched to the front and made to receive the bullets and bayonets of that hated foe whom they are striving to assist in crushing out the liberty and happiness of the South.

abstract: The Montgomery Advertiser, of the 29th ult., contains the announcement of the decease of Hon. WILLIAM L. YANCEY, who died on the 28th ult., at 3:40 o'clock P.M., at his residence near Montgomery, in the 49th year of his age. He suffered through a severe illness of four weeks' duration, the effects of a disease of the kidneys. The Advertiser says: "Such was the spirit with which he had borne up through all the struggles of a momentous life, that few, even of his neighbors and friends, were prepared for this sad intelligence; but Mr. YANCEY has been a sufferer from the knawings of disease for years, and the summons did not find him unprepared. He seemed to have a premonition of death months ago, and repeatedly, during his last illness, expressed himself ready and willing to die. He returned from the late session of Congress greatly worn by his labors, and it was a real pleasure to him to be again at his home in the country, free from the incessant turmoil of official life incident to the troubled condition of affairs. Still, even while endeavoring to recruit his shattered health, his whole soul was wrapped in contemplation of the great contest going on for liberty and independence. Even during the last days of his life, when his body was racked with excruciating pain, his mind soared above his own sufferings, and he was hotly engaged in field and forum combatting the enemies to the peace and independence of his country.

abstract: Letter of W. G. Brownlow
lead_paragraph: I have this day conversed with Dr. EVERETT, Surgeon of the Fifth East Tennessee infantry, who was recently confined in the infamous Libby Prison, at Richmond. He tells me that he was confined in the same room with Ex-Gov. AIKIN, of South Carolina, and held frequent conversations with him. So many ounces of bread and meat were dealt out to each prisoner per day, and the venerable old gray- haired patriot received his daily allowance, while the boys in prison volunteered to do his cooking for him. The offences for which he was imprisoned were, refusing to take the oath of allegiance to the Confederacy, and to contribute means to sustain the rebellion. In conversing about his confinement, he would frequently shed tears.

abstract: Over confidence the great peril
lead_paragraph: The only real danger which now threatens the National cause, lies in excessive confidence. The marvelous successes for which we have just rendered thanks to Heaven, have excited a very general feeling that the extinction of the rebellion is sure, and nigh at hand. The feeling is natural, and undoubtedly there is much to warrant it. If we will only keep it in its true place, we have a right to cherish it. But that place is outside of practical duty. It does not touch action at all. We must beware that we do not bend our action to it. Otherwise we may yet be betrayed to our ruin.
headline: {'main': 'Over-Confidence the Great Peril.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Over-Confidence the Great Peril.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Some interest was occasioned yesterday in naval circles by the announcement that Chief Engineer STIMERS, the Inspector of iron-clad machinery in this vicinity, is to be removed on the 15th of August, and Chief Engineer WILLIAM R. KING, now superintending iron-clad vessels in the West, to be ordered in his place. The report, on being traced to its source, was found to emanate from a letter received by a naval officer here from a friend in the Navy Department. The following is a paragraph from it.

abstract: In Mobile, last week, a Vicksburgh soldier went into Mr. SIMON's clothing-store, on Dauphin-  street, to purchase a shirt. The clerk -- a man named MARK WOHL -- attended on him and commenced to exhibit his goods. During the conversation WOHL asked him if he had some greenbacks, and was answered in the affirmative. The soldier selected a shirt and inquired the price. He was told that he could have it for $25 in Confederate money, or $2 50 in greenbacks. The soldier paid him with the latter, and immediately afterward reported the case to Maj. DENIS, the Provost-Marshal, who ordered his arrest. The Advertiser says:

abstract: AN EXCURSION TO STONY BROOK, L.I. -- Brig.-  Gen. SPINOLA, having sufficiently recovered from his wounds, received at the battle of Wapping Heights, as to be able to do so, will leave for his residence at Stony Brook, L.I., this morning, the Surveyor of the Port, Mr. ANDREWS, having placed a steamboat at the disposal of himself and his friends. Among those invited to accompany the General are Ex-Mayor Powell, Isaac Van Anden, Esq., Thomas Kinselia, Esq., Hon. J.S.T. Stranahan. Hon. E.W. Fiske. Hon. R B. Connolly, Chas. W. Baker, Esq., Hon. James Kerrigan, Gen. Nelson Taylor, Col. Buckingham, Col. B. Murphy, A.W. Bensen, Esq., and many others. The boat will leave Montague-street wharf at 9 o'clock A.M., and Thirty-seventh-street, East River, New-York, at 9 1/2 A.M.

abstract: This gallant and enterprising officer is a son of the celebrated Methodist preacher and orator. Rev. JOHN NEWLIN MAFFIT. He entered the United States Navy, we think, about the year 1832, and roust be now about 45 years old. We rejoice to see the havoc that the brilliant Confederate Captain is playing with Yankee commerce. He has made them bleed already nearly to the tune of ten millions, which we hope will swell to a hundred millions before he has done with them. Like his father before him, he has to deal with some hardened sinners; but he generally manages to bring them to the anxious seat and make them howl for mercy. Between the MAFFITS, father and son, the devil has had a very uneasy time of it both on land and water. One of the orator MAFFIT's finest pulpit efforts was from the text. "Come thou and all thy house into the ark," an invitation which the son extends through the cannon of the Florida to all Yankee wayfarers upon the ocean. We rejoice at the success which has attended his mission, and hope he will continue to press it with irresistible urgency till the ocean is delivered of the most unclean and nefarious of all its reptiles -- the sons of the Pilgrims.

abstract: -- The injunction obtained by the executors of the estate of the late WM.B. MOFFAT, to prohibit his father, JOHN MOFFAT, from carrying on the manufacture and sale of the medicines extensively known as "Moffat's Life Pills and Phoenix Bitters," has been dissolved. Dr. JOHN MOFFAT, who first introduced these medicines in the year 1835, and afterwards gave the recipes and the business to his son, WM.B. MOFFAT, is, therefore, adjudged to have a perfect right to resume the manufacture and sale of his pills and bitters. He was the "Original Jacobs," and the public mav rest assured that the medicines now sold by JOHN MOFFAT & Co. are precisely the same concoctions which first obtained celebrity for Moffat's Pills and Bitters. Dr. MOFFAT has associated with him, in his resumption of business, Mr. GEORGE ROBERTS, formerly of Boston, who is extensively known in connection with the Press, having been for many years the proprietor of the Boston Daily Times, the Yankee Notions, &c. Mr. ROBERTS is a gentleman of enterprise and business capacity, and we have no doubt his association with Dr. MOFFAT will be found advantageous to both parties. JOHN MOFFAT & Co's. Genuine Vegetable Life Pills and Phoenix Bitters are advertised in another column of the Atlas, to which we refer for further particulars. -- Sunday Atlas, Aug. 2.

abstract: The Montgomery Mail has learned with deep regret, that Gen. STERLING PRICE has resigned his commission, and retired from the army in Arkansas. It is said that being placed in a subordinate position to Gen. HOLMES, he was unable to execute his plans for the liberation of Arkansas from the presence of the Yankees. It is also that despairing to receive from President DAVIS the position to which he was entitled by his military service, he finally determined to retire from his command. It is to be hoped that the report is untrue, but the Mail says it comes so well authenticated, that it is constrained to believe it.
lead_paragraph: The Montgomery Mail has learned with deep regret, that Gen. STERLING PRICE has resigned his commission, and retired from the army in Arkansas. It is also that despairing to receive from President DAVIS the position to which he was entitled by his military service, he finally determined to retire from his command. It is to be hoped that the report is untrue, but the Mail says it comes so well authenticated, that it is constrained to believe it.

abstract: Social Theories and their Exponents
lead_paragraph: Judging from what we see and hear all over the world, it is hard to avoid doubting whether Christendom has not for thirty or forty years been retrograding alarmingly in its theories, if not in its practice, on the subject of human rights. The idea under which the nations had been governed for a thousand years before the French Revolution, and which that revolution overthrew, was that the earth was made for the inheritance of men born high. For forty years, or thereabouts afterwards, it was the fashion to acknowledge that, at least in theory, neither birth nor anything else furnished an excuse for throwing artificial obstacles in men's way, in their pursuit of happiness. "Equality before the law," was then the watchword, and reformers directed all their efforts to the removal of all legal impediments to everybody's having a fair start in life. It was under the influence of this "noble rage," that the Bourbons were expelled from France, and the Catholics and Negroes emancipated and the Reform Bill passed in England.

abstract: Curtin, Gov. A. G., Renomination of
snippet: Curtin, Gov. A. G., Renomination of
lead_paragraph: -- The nomination of Gov. ANDREW C. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, for reelection, by the Union Convention that has just assembled at Pittsburgh, is a deserved tribute to one of the truest and ablest men that has filled the Executive chair of any State, in these eventful times. Gov. CURTIN had his first election just on the eve of the Presidential election, and was not chosen especially because of his supposed fitness to control the affairs of a State during a period of revolution and war. But he quickly developed a capacity equal to the exigencies that met him in office. On the uncovering of the plot of treason and war in 1861, he was one of the first Governors to present himself in Washington, and pledge to the incoming Administration the full support of the great commonwealth he presided over in upholding the Constitution and enforcing the laws of the land. And from that day to this, he has never ceased to work, in season and out of season, to make good his promise. He has not only been zealous to meet demands on Pennsylvania, but has sometimes outrun higher military authority in schemes to ward off the attacks of invaders. And events have proved his sagacity, as they also tried his patience and courage. But it is chiefly because of his devoted care and attention to Pennsylvania soldiers after they got into the field, and when they fell away into hospitals from battle or disease, that Gov. CURTIN obtained the confidence and affection of his people. His conduct has been a model in this respect. No Governor of any State has exceeded, if equaled, him in persistent thoughtfulness and care of sick and wounded soldiers, and his popularity on this ground is deserved and very great.

abstract: New-York; Heisterburgh, Mrs., by Frederick Munter
snippet: New-York; Heisterburgh, Mrs., by Frederick Munter
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, about 5 o'clock, a horrible murder was committed at No. 358 Tenth-avenue, the victim being Mrs. CAROLINE HEISTERBURGH, a widow woman, 23 years of age, the mother of three children. It appears that FREDERICK MUNTER, a German, employed as clerk in the store of NICHOLAS HELLMER, brother of the deceased, doing business at the above number, had fallen desperately in love with Mrs. HEISTERBURGH. Some weeks ago he proposed marriage to the fair widow and received a response which led him to press his suit with much earnestness. He seemed sanguine of winning the hand and heart of Mrs. H., but it appears that on further acquaintance her regard for him diminished, and she determined not to marry him, although she did not make known her decision. MUNTER observed that she had treated him with a certain degree of coo???ess for two or three weeks past, which fact aroused his jealousy. He imagined that Mrs. H. had another lover, and that all his hopes of winning her heart were lost; this made him desperate, and he determined to take her life. Accordingly, yesterday morning, MUNTER, armed with a butcher's knife and a hatchet, proceeded to her room, and after knocking her senseless to the floor, str???ck her two powerful blows in the face with the hatchet, and then cut her throat from ear to ear with the knife. She died almost instantly.
headline: {'main': 'HORRIBLE MURDEB BY A GROCERY CLERK.; The Hatchet and the Knife A Widow Woman the Victim Jealousy the Cause TheMurderer Surrenders Himself.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HORRIBLE MURDEB BY A GROCERY CLERK.; The Hatchet and the Knife A Widow Woman the Victim Jealousy the Cause TheMurderer Surrenders Himself.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: YOUNG FEMALE SHOPLIFTERS. Three girls, named ELIZA FERGUSON, of No. 5 Vandam-street, MARIA JANE ...
lead_paragraph: YOUNG FEMALE SHOPLIFTERS. -- Three girls, named ELIZA FERGUSON, of No. 5 Vandam-street, MARIA JANE and JULIA KELERHAN, residing at No. 108 Mulberry-street, and from 8 to 12 years of age, entered the furnishing store of Mr. THOMAS WHITE, No. 20 Bowery, late on Thursday afternoon, under pretence of making some purchases. While there, they were detected in the act of purloining some perfumes, and dropping their plunder, attempted to escape. Officer CUDDELL, of the Sixth Ward, arrested them. On being questioned at the Station-house by Capt. JOURDAN the prisoners stated they had been shoplifting for the last six??? months. MARIA JANE KELERHAN said that she was taught to steal by her mother, and that all the plunder secured by the trio they either pawned or sold. The prisoners were searched, and on the person of JULIA KELERHAN were found three pieces of Balmoral skirting, which she confessed had been stolen from the store of Mr. MCCABE. No. 19 Catharine-street. This plunder was secured to her underclothing by means of hooks used by shoplifters. The girl FERGUSON had a pair of ladles shoes hooked to her nether garments, and said she bad taken them from the store of Mr. MCGUIRE. No. 84 Catharine-street. This girl also confessed that, on the 5th Inst., they made a raid on some stores in Brooklyn, and "gobbled up" seven or eight pairs of shoes, which they subsequently pawned. She still further confesses that on the same day they purloined a quantity of costly ribbons from a store in Sixth-avenue and sold them. The mother of the KELERHAN girls (so say the Police) practices the same kind of stealing. The prisoners were held for further examination.

abstract: The Conscripts in the Field
lead_paragraph: The first of our conscript soldiers -- the first fruits of the Conscription law -- have begun to arrive in the Army of the Potomac. On their arrival they are at once put into the ranks of the old, war-worn and badly-thinned regiments. It will take but a very short time to make out of them soldiers almost equal to veterans. Say that a regiment, three hundred and fifty strong, obtains a recruitment of one hundred and fifty freshly-raised conscripts, the latter will not only at once assimilate in character and in feeling, but will obtain the benefit of the experience in camp and field duties, in style of living and in discipline, which has been acquired by their comrades. In the first year of the war, our soldiers suffered greatly because of the lack of the military habit. They had it not themselves, and they had no way of learning it, except through the hard and slow teachings of experience. But our new conscript soldiers will have a great advantage in this respect; and the mortality among them will doubtless be much less than it has been among our previous raw recruits. They have but to copy the daily habits of life (we refer to the good habits, the military habits) of the old volunteer troops, to attain at once to comparative freedom in the routine of camp existence. As regards the National aspect of the case, the forming of an army now, under our new system, is a very different matter from what it was at first and under the old plan. The army can be increased imperceptibly and regularly until it reaches the maximum strength needed, and then, without trouble, without disintegration, without having perpetually to go over the process of reorganization, it can be kept up to that maximum.

abstract: "Yeoman" on Mrs. Kemble's Revelations of Slavery; Kemble, Frances; Revelations of Slavery; "Yeoman," Correspondent TIMES on
snippet: "Yeoman" on Mrs. Kemble's Revelations of Slavery; Kemble, Frances; Revelations of Slavery; "Yeoman," Correspondent TIMES on
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a series of letters appeared in the TIMES, signed as the present, chiefly descriptive of matters of personal observation in the Slave States. The series really consisted of two parts, of which the first contained observations made during a Winter's journey, in which I had followed ordinary routes of travel, (until near its close,) having been guided chiefly by the addresses of the letters of introduction with which I had been furnished by friends, these friends being mostly New-York merchants. Before I concluded this journey, I satisfied myself that what I had become most familiar with in the South was of a superficial and unusual, if not exceptional, character. My interest having been excited to penetrate the real South, I undertook a second journey, in which I discarded letters of introduction and public conveyances as much as practicable, and took pains to see, not merely that which was recommended to me as best worth seeing, but that which was common, and not supposed by my friends to be worth seeing by a stranger at all. In respect to the social condition of the Southerners, and the economic character of Slavery, my observations thus became of some positive value, and this was all the value that I claimed or intended to present in my letters. They were received, however, by many readers of the TIMES, as revelations of the wicked cruelty of Slavery, and this was made evident to me at the time both by public comments upon them and by many letters addressed to me personally by strangers upon this subject. This fact led me to give, late in the series, more information bearing upon this topic than I otherwise should have done, simply because I saw this was expected of me, and if I neglected it, my reason for doing so would be misunderstood. It was neither my purpose in writing nor in traveling to study the humanity of Slavery, and I have always considered that such observations as I recorded bearing upon such a study, were incidental to other purposes, and necessarily superficial and unimportant, except negatively, perhaps, in establishing the error of some commonly received opinions. It was not for want of interest in the question of humanity that they were so. It was not from want of sympathy with the human nature of the negro that I did not pursue it, and obtain some positive knowledge of the interior life of the plantation out or the economic field; nor was it because my life was threatened if I undertook a third journey that I did not subsequently follow up my two journeys with a third, in which special reference should be had to the condition of the slaves, otherwise than as it affected their value as laborers, and thus the whole economic condition of the South. I was satisfied that it would not be possible for me to make such a study. It could be made only, I concluded, by some one with duties which would carry him into the cabins of the slaves, at all times, and in such a manner that he would be regarded by them as a friend. No stranger could do this, not even a missionary or clergyman especially charged with pastoral duties toward the slaves. Of this I had been assured by facts in the experience of clergymen related by themselves. To them the slaves were habitually the most consummate hypocrites and deceivers.

abstract: What Diplomacy has done for Her
snippet: What Diplomacy has done for Her
lead_paragraph: Russia's replies to the Interventionists, proclaim what their diplomacy has achieved for Poland. When the Western Powers determined to intervene in behalf of the Poles, they sought the cooperation of Austria, lest their own remonstrances should not have sufficient weight. The accession of Austria to the coalition elated them highly, and they imagined that, thus backed, they might demand almost anything in the shape of concession from the Czar, without danger of failure. The illusion, under which they so long labored, has however been suddenly dissipated, and now the allies are sensible how little they have gained by their pains.

abstract: -- A letter from Lexington, Ky., alludes to [???] attack upon Lebanon by Morgan, and says: "Thos, Morgan, the youngest of four brothers of John, that were in his command, was among the Killed. The love between John and Thomas is said to have been like that between David and Jonathan; but how a notorious blackleg, debauchee and. thief can have any sincere love for anybody is a mystery. Thomas is remembered here with interest. Several years ago, when he was a mere youth, he attended a "big meeting" at the Baptist Church, thought he experienced religion, and wanted to be baptized. The Pastor of the Baptist Church, together with Dr. Dillard, interceded with Mrs. Morgan, who is an Episcopalian, to gratify the sun's wishes, but she was inexorable," and forbid his ever attending the Baptist meeting again. Under such circumstances, it is not to be wondered at that he lost his interest in religion, and should be drawn into the vortex of rebellion by his older brother, who has captivated and ruined so many others. It is by no means certain that a connection with the church would have saved the lad, for church members, and, I am sorry to say, Baptist members, and ministers, are deeply Implicated in this 'mystery of iniquity;' but at least the mother might now be spared the reflection of having thwarted her boy in one of the most cherished and holy purposes of his life."

abstract: RIOTERS AND ROBBERS TWO MORE ARRESTS  THE AMERICAN FLAG DESECRATED. Officers IRVING and MACPHERSON, of the Twentieth Ward, on Friday night, succeeded in arresting two men named JAMES FITZHERBERT ...
lead_paragraph: RIOTERS AND ROBBERS -- TWO MORE ARRESTS -- THE AMERICAN FLAG DESECRATED. -- Officers IRVING and MACPHERSON, of the Twentieth Ward, on Friday night, succeeded in arresting two men named JAMES FITZHERBERT and MICHAEL O'BRIEN, who stand charged with being engaged in the late riots. Mr. ANDREW HANSER, of No. 326 West Twenty-second-street, is the complainant against the prisoners, and charges that they robbed him of a horse and wagon worth $100. He makes oath that while passing through Twenty-eighth-street on Monday, July 13, he was attacked by a gang of men and boys, brutally beaten, and robbed of $70, in Treasury notes. His stable was subsequently forced open and his horse and wagon stolen; the doors and windows of his residence were crushed in by the mob and his house plundered. MARY CONLAN, MARY E. COON and MARGARET BLACK, all young women living in the neighborhood, witnessed the assault on Mr. HANSER and his house, and deposed to seeing the prisoners leading the mob in the attack, FITZHERBERT having a pistol in his hand at the time. After Mr. HANSER had been rescued by the mob they entered his house and searched it all over, but did not succeed in finding him. Maddened at not finding him, the witnesses saw O'BRIEN and FITZHERBERT, with other rioters, break open Mr. HANSER's stable and steal the horse and wagon. One of the witnesses also swears that during the attack on the house of Mr. H., FITZHERBERT proposed three cheers for JEFF. DVVIS, which were given by the mob and some of the neighbors. Another witness swears that the mob led by the prisoner, FITZHERBERT, inarched down Ninth-avenue bearing the American flag, and that the flag-bearer threw the colors down, trampled on them, fore them in pieces, and exclaimed in a loud voice, "D -- n that flag." Justice QUACKENBUSH committed the prisoners for trial without bail. They are both natives of Ireland.

abstract: Cailloux, Capt. Andre, The Funeral of
snippet: Cailloux, Capt. Andre, The Funeral of
lead_paragraph: letter, published yesterday, contained a thrilling account of the funeral of Capt. ANDRE CAILLOUX, a member of the First regiment of Louisiana Native (colored) Guards, who fell at the head of his company while gallantly leading it on to the charge in the celebrated assault made upon the enemy's works at Port Hudson on the 17th of May last. Capt. CAILLOUX was a fine-looking mulatto, and, as an officer, was said to be a striking and marked personage even among the large body of officers assembled at Gen. BANKS' headquarters. His funeral was the most remarkable affair of the kind that ever took place in New-Orleans or in the South. He was buried with all the pompous rites and ceremonies of the Roman Catholic Church, the officiating priest delivering a glowing eulogy on the virtues of the deceased. No less than thirty-seven benevolent, charitable, religious and patriotic societies took part in the pageant. The coffin was draped in the American flag, and around it flowers were strewn in the greatest profusion, while the band of one of our white volunteer regiments performed the dirges and other customary solemn music. It was not because he was a negro, but because he was a brave man -- a man who had fallen fighting for our flag, and had sealed with his blood his devotion to liberty -- that these honors were conferred upon Capt. ANDRE CAILLOUX by the colored inhabitants of New-Orleans.

abstract: The thieves, petty gamblers and vagabonds generally of this City have been operating in those sections of this and adjoining States where the draft has been enforced, by offering themselves as substitutes, being accepted, they receive the three hundred dollars, are mustered in, and become part and parcel of the army; this is no sooner done than they proceed, in their own parlance, to "Jump the Bounty." which means nothing more or less than pocketing the money, playing possum to Uncle Sam, and es[???] from his service and custody forthwith. A number have succeeded in this, and been three hundred dollars [???] and considerably freer; but the [???] game" having been exposed to the military authorities, the [???]es will hereafter be rarer, and the risks of "jumping" so great that few will un[???]ik it.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian passed Cape Race on Friday evening, with advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 30th, and Grrencastle on the 31st ult. Intelligence had reached England of the destruction, by the pirate Alabama, of the ships Talisman, from New-York for Shanghai, and Conrad, from Montevideo for New-York. On the 29th the rebel loan took another tumble of 2 per cent., the immediate cause of which is not explained. American stocks were buoyant. Cotton had advanced half a penny in the week, while Breadstuffs were dull and Provisions steady. The news regarding the Poli[???]s question does not look quite so warlike. In Frankfort the opinion is entertained that the difficulties will be settled by diplomacy. Consols were quoted at 93@93 1/8.

abstract: And her Colonies; The Confederacy and the Allies
snippet: And her Colonies; The Confederacy and the Allies
lead_paragraph: The dark cloud of war which is now hovering over all Europe, and which had its origin in Poland, has, for the time being, and especially in France, withdrawn attention from LOUIS NAPOLEON's Mexican expedition and conquests, and from the bearings of his Mexican policy upon the general interests of North America. The Southern Confederacy or the Southern rebellion is almost forgotten in France in the midst of the new excitement which has arisen. There is no proof, however, that the shrewd and far-seeing LOUIS NAPOLEON has turned his thoughts or his eyes altogether away from the map of Mexico, or that he is less anxious for the establishment of an ally in the Southern Confederacy, or for the cooperation of Great Britain in his schemes of aggrandizement on this continent. In fact, in a far-reaching view, LOUIS NAPOLEON has more to gain on this continent than he could possibly gain by a war for Poland. For the annexation to his Empire of a rich and magnificent colony, sweeping from the Rio Grande to the Isthmus of Panama, would be more than the extension of the French boundary to the River Rhine -- which he probably sees as the main gain from a pro-Polish war.

abstract: A Port Hudson correspondent of the Boston Traveller states that on the 22d the Twelfth Connecticut and Thirteenth Maine left Danaldsonville for Brashear City via New-Orleans, where they were joined by the Ninth Connecticut. They go down the river, then up Berwick's Bay. Two graduates of Dartmouth College were found in Port Hudson -- JOHN BUTLER, from Port Gibson, Mass., who graduated in 1859, and Lieut. BUOKNER, from Kentucky, who was in the class of 1858, and being suspended for some misdemeanor, never returned. Butler was employed by Gen. GARDNER, the rebel commander, as an engineer, for which he had great capacity, and had sent to Richmond for a commission for him. Major HOYT, U.S. Paymaster, was at Port Hudson paving some of the nine months' regiments, previous to their departure north.

abstract: Crime and its Punishment
lead_paragraph: The fact that the authorities were strong enough to meet the bloody violence of the late riot promptly, with superior armed force, and crush it out at once in the struggle of brutish strength which the law-breakers had invoked, was in every way creditable to our institutions. The work of suppression could not have been more thoroughly done in any Government of Europe menaced by such an outbreak, though the symbols of physical power and the occasions for exercising the same are so much more frequent and familiar there than here. We are not accustomed to riots in America. We have had but two or three times during this century to appeal to military force to repress popular outbreaks. Our people are not acquainted with the necessity of shedding blood in streets to maintain social order; and so far from being hardened to such scenes as were witnessed recently in the upper Wards of this City, when soldiers fired upon crowds of citizens, and slew by scores, the spectacle was one to shock and appal an American community. It might have been deemed safe, in the judgment of many, to predict that such an unusual tragedy would have maddened instead of composed the elements of an American city, so unaccustomed to the avenging terrors of martial law.

abstract: The Court of Sessions does not usually sit for the trial of prisoners on Saturdays, that day being devoted to passing sentences, hearing motions,
lead_paragraph: The Court of Sessions does not usually sit for the trial of prisoners on Saturdays, that day being devoted to passing sentences, hearing motions, &c.; but owing to the great press of business arising out of the recent riots, the Recorder yesterday determined to continue the trials of the riot cases. In several of these cases sentence had been postponed, and the Court first proceeded to dispose of them. The first one called up for sentence was JOSEPH MARSHALL, who was convicted on Thursday of assault and battery, and robbery, in connection with the attack on the negro JACKSON, in the First Ward, who, it wilt be recollected, was knocked down, robbed, and thrown into the dock, from pier No. 4, North River. The Recorder told MARSHALL that, although the District-Attorney did not see fit to press his case before the jury for any higher offence than attempt at robbery, owing to the peculiar character of the evidence, yet the jury had seen fit to convict him of the full crime of robbery in the first degree. He should therefore sentence him to the State prison for ten years. The prisoner is about 21 years of age, and is a hard-looking rowdy. PATRICK SWEENEY, who was convicted on Friday of riot in Thompson-street, was next brought up for sentence. The character of SWEENEY for industry and general good behavior was shown to have been good, and as the evidence against him did not prove any very serious offence, the Recorder said he would discriminate in his favor. The prisoner made a full and evidently truthful statement to the Court of his agency in the disturbance in Thompson-street, at the conclusion of which the Recorder sentenced him to the Penitentiary for three months.

abstract: The anti draft organs are anxious to repudiate any responsibility for the riots, or for forcible resistance to the execution of any of the laws. The Cincinnati Enquirer, the chief organ of the Western Butternuts and of VALLANDIGHAM, in its issue of Wednesday last, publishes the "great speech" delivered by VALLANDIGHUM in this City in March; and the caption of the speech, in formidable gothic type, informs its re[???]drer that he (VAL!) advises submission to the laws," that "the courts and the ballot-box are the remedy for political ills," and it emphasises the fact that he "counsels, in the most earnest and impressive manner, submission to all statutes and to the constituted authorities." It is a good sign, that not even a Western Copperhead journal dares apologize for any opposition to the authorities other than the opposition of argument and the Constitution, and that all respectable Democratic papers everywhere condemn the riotous spirit and its fruits. It is pitiful to think, however that in the Press of this City the mob has still apologists and stimulators.

abstract: A conference of the Special Committee of the Common Council, the Board of Contracts and the Presidents of the different banking institutions of Brooklyn was held in the Mayor's office yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: A conference of the Special Committee of the Common Council, the Board of Contracts and the Presidents of the different banking institutions of Brooklyn was held in the Mayor's office yesterday morning. The object was to ascertain if the sum of one million of dollars appropriated by the Common Council to relieve poor men with large families from the draft could be procured, and upon what terms the banks would loan the amount. Those present were the Mayor and the Comptroller on the part of the Board of Contracts; Alderman TERNAN and PERRY, of the Special Committee; and Messrs. PRUYN, of the Central Bank; STUDWELL, of the City Bank; BRUSH, of the Mechanics Bank; FROTHINGHAM, of the Nassau Bank; HERRIMAN, of the Long Island Bank; EMBURY, of the Atlantic Bank; FIELDS, of the Williamsburgh City Bank, and BEACH, of the Farmers' and Citizens' Bank.

abstract: Maj. BRADY, of our Eighth Regiment, was one of the lucky captors of the private papers of JEFF. DAVIS, at Jackson, Miss., the other day, and through the kindness of a friend to whom he sent a portion of them, we are in possession of two letters from JAMES BUCHANAN, marked "confidential," one long one from BEAUREGARD, and another from a man who signs himself "One of the D -- d Abolitionists." The first two are dated 1850, and contain nothing relating to the rebellion, of course, though they give us a little interior view of the Democratic household at that time. The letter from BEAUREGARD is seven big pages long, and discusses minutely the project of sending an expedition against the Mormons from the Pacific side of the country. It is dated 1858. The other letter is an amusing bit of '"bosh." It cordially congratulates DAVIS on the secession movement, and bids him "God speed," "for," it says. "the separation of the South from the Union is the sure precursor and cause of the downfall of Slavery." -- Indianapolis Journal, Aug. 5.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, JOS. MARSHALL, one of the rioters convicted, on Friday, of assaulting the ...
lead_paragraph: In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, JOS. MARSHALL, one of the rioters convicted, on Friday, of assaulting the negro JACKSON, robbing him and throwing him off of Pier No. 4, North River, was sentenced to the State Prison for ten years. PATRICK SWEENEY, convicted, on Friday, of riot in Thompson-street, was sent to the Penitentiary for three months. DENNIS WELCH was tried for stealing a mattress from Mr. GIBBONS' residence, at the time it was sacked by the mob. It was proved that the prisoner was forced to join the mob, and having proved an excellent previous character, the jury acquitted him.

abstract: Coroner RANNEY yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of Col. HENRY F. O'BRIEN, who was brutally murdered on the second day of the not, at the corner of Thirty-fourth-street and Second-avenue, a full account of which has been published in the TIMES. The jury rendered a verdict against PATRICK KEEGAN and PATRICK O'BRIEN as principals in the murder. These same parties were arrested a day or two since by Officer BOGERT, of the Eleventh Precinct upon this charge. On the rendition of the verdict, they were arraigned and asked what they had to [???] to the charge. The answer was that they were not guilty. The paper in the case were thereupon immediately sent to the Grand Jury for their action.

abstract: The Boston Pilot asserts that the veteran Commander of the Army or the Potomac is a Roman Catholic, and many of the Copperhead journals assert that he is a Democrat. We presume that in either case It Would not make any difference in the value of his services. It is as well, however, that the truth should be known. Gen. MEADE is a Philadelphian. His family resides here. His sons have been drafted here. He is a member of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and his family hands a pew, where it has long been in regular attendance, in St. Mark's Church. Gen. MEADE's relations in lift, as regards politics, have ever been Whig.

abstract: If the relations of all imperial peoples to their dependencies are similar to those which England bears to her colonies, then is the lot ...
lead_paragraph: If the relations of all imperial peoples to their dependencies are similar to those which England bears to her colonies, then is the lot of an imperial people nnot by any means enviable. It is commonly supposed that the power of England arises chiefly from the vastness of her colonial possessions; but this is a fallacy. The wealth, the power, which England boasts, would be hers in a still greater degree, were every one of her forty-five colonies cut off. Why, those colonies, in their present state, are a source of weakness, not of strength, to the mother country. In time of peace they are continually drawing grants from her treasury; in time of war they render her everywhere vulnerable, prevent her from concentrating her forces, which must be frittered away for their defence, and involve her in fivefold greater expenses than she need otherwise incur. No individual, or section of a nation, has a right to claim exemption from military service in defence of the State; but the colonies of England claim this privilege. In behalf of their institutions, in behalf of the position which they respectively occupy in the empire of which they are members, they refuse to strike a blow. If England is ready to shield them from enemies in war, it is well; if not, they are resigned to abjure connection with her, and to submit to the yoke of the victor, be he who he may.
headline: {'main': 'England and Her Colonies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and Her Colonies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The force of this Precinct, Capt. THERON R. BENNETT, No. 247 Madison-street, reported at Headquarters Monday afternoon, with Sergeants McCONNELL, ...
lead_paragraph: The force of this Precinct, Capt. THERON R. BENNETT, No. 247 Madison-street, reported at Headquarters Monday afternoon, with Sergeants MCCONNELL, GARLAND and CLARK, Sergeant LOUDON being left in charge of Station. The force, with Sergts MCCONNELL and GARLAND, composed a portion of Inspector CARPENTER's command in the attack upon and severe usage of the rioters at Broadway and Amity-street, being active and prominent therein. At night the force reported to Inspector LEONARD, at the City Hall, and was engaged in the many duties which were necessary for the protection of the portion of the City thereabouts. On Tuesday morning they were ordered to Headquarters, and subsequently, with Inspector DILKS' command, visited Second-avenue, where the sharp fighting was done, and in which the Seventh were actively engaged. Later in the day, under Inspector LEONARD, a mob at Broadway and Bond-street was attacked and dispersed, the Seventh participating. On return to Headquarters, Sergt. McCONNELL relieved Sergt, LOUDEN at Station, who reported for duty at Centre office. Capt. BENNETT, with his command, was detailed, with a company of military, to visit Thirty fourth-street, where Col. O'BRIEN was so horribly murdered, to recover the body. On reaching the ground, it was ascertained that the bo[???]y had been rescued from the rioters and taken to Bellevue. On the same evening the force was ordered to the care of its own Precinct, where patrol duty was resumed Friday.

abstract: A young woman named MARY BENNON, a domestic, residing at No. 202 1/2 East Twentieth-street, was poisoned yesterday and died in fifteen minutes, from taking "cyanite of potassium" in place of "cyanite of potassium fero," the former being a deadly poison, and the latter a medicine. The woman procured the prescription of Dr. HUNTER, and applied for it at the store of Dr. COOPER, on First-avenue. The doctor not having it, sent his clerk, Mr. MOHAN, to Dr. BLAISDELL's store, where he asked for "cyanite of potassium." This was given to the woman, producing the fatal results as above described. Dr. JOHN BEACH, of No. 66 East Twenty-seventh-street, made a post-mortem examination of the body, and found death to have been the result of poison. Dr. KIMBARK, Police Surgeon, made an analysis of the contents of the bottle, and found it to be poison.

abstract: -- The fortunes of the City of Natchez in this war have been rather remarkable. It is the only rebel city of any size on the Mississippi River whose capture has given us no trouble whatever. It first fell into our hands in May of last year, when its Mayor surrendered it to the fleet of Commodore FARRAGUT who made a trip up the river after he bad captured New-Orleans. We had no troops to hold it, but the City was put upon its good behavior, under penalty. Its good faith was tested when FARRAGUT again passed It on his return from the first bombardment of Vicksburgh; subsequently it was tested at the close of last year, when ELLET's rams passed it on their daring tour down the Mississippi and up the Red River; and again, a third time, was it tested, when it was passed by FARRAGUT's vessels three months ago, after he had run the Port Hudson batteries. In all these instances the authorities of Natchez have kept their pledge, and not a shot was fired at our passing vessels. After the fall of Vicksburgh, a portion of GRANT's troops went down the river, and without resistance took possession of Natchez. Natchez is the largest city in the State of Mississippi -- one-third larger than Vicksburgh -- is placed on a high bluff, and in a commanding position, and it is remarkable that the rebels did not at any time make any efforts to hold it.
lead_paragraph: -- The fortunes of the City of Natchez in this war have been rather remarkable. In all these instances the authorities of Natchez have kept their pledge, and not a shot was fired at our passing vessels. After the fall of Vicksburgh, a portion of GRANT's troops went down the river, and without resistance took possession of Natchez. Natchez is the largest city in the State of Mississippi -- one-third larger than Vicksburgh -- is placed on a high bluff, and in a commanding position, and it is remarkable that the rebels did not at any time make any efforts to hold it.

abstract: It has been discovered that extensive frauds have been perpetrated upon the Government in this city and eise-where, by men pretending to be army officers, and presenting forged pay-roils at the offices of different paymasters. One individual, representing himself as a Major in the volunteer service is alleged to have objected over $700 from a paymaster in this city, and a considerable sum from a paymaster in Harrisburgh and one in Bak[???]re and New-York. Something wrong was suspected after the payment of the money in New-York, and measures were taken to have the person arrested, which was done. It is known that others have been committing similar frauds, and that the Government has been swm[???]dled out of many thou[???]son is of dollars in that way. Beside the forged pay-roll, a fr[???]itious leave of absence is presented by the swindler. -- Phela. Ledger, Aug. 8.

abstract: Corner-stone of Monastery Laid at Hoboken
snippet: Corner-stone of Monastery Laid at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: St. Mary's Catholic Church, West Hoboken, was filled to overflowing yesterday afternoon by those desirous of witnessing the ceremonies attend ant upon laying the corner stone of the Monastery of the Passionists. Vespers were sang, and the Benediction of the Blessed Sacrament concluded the services in the church. The procession was then formed in the aisle of the church in the following order; three Acolytes, two bearing large candles, the third a crucifix; ten Fathers and Brothers of the Order of the Passionists, with cassocks and lace surplices; the Secular Priests; the Rt. Rev. Bishop BAYLAY, of the Diocese of Newark, in his Episcopal robes, supported by Father DOMINIC, Provincial of the Passionists, as Deacan, and Father DOANE, Chancellor of the Diocese, as Sub-Deacon, each wearing richly ornamented and costly cassocks. Thus the procession at once moved to the monastery grounds, which are beautifully situated in the woods, some quarter of a mile from the church, and away from the noise and turmoil of city life.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions, on Saturday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Jos. MARSHALL, one of the rioters convicted, on Friday, of assaulting the negro JACKSON, robbing him and throwing him off of Pier No. 4, North River, was sentenced to the...
lead_paragraph: In the Court of General Sessions, on Saturday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Jos. MARSHALL, one of the rioters convicted, on Friday, of assaulting the negro JACKSON, robbing him and throwing him off of Pier No. 4, North River, was sentenced to the State Prison for ten years. PATRICK SWEENEY. convicted, on Friday, of riot in Thompson-street, was sent to the Penitentiary for three months. DENNIS WELCH was tried for stealing a mattress from Mr. GIBBONS' resilience, at the time it was sacked by the mob. It was proved that the prisoner was forced to join the mob, and having proved an excellent previous character, the jury acquitted him.

abstract: Shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday morning, flames were seen issuing from the building No. 1,358 Broadway, occupied by Messrs, HERRING  BROTHERS, ...
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday morning, flames were seen issuing from the building No. 1,358 Broadway, occupied by Messrs, HERRING & BROTHERS, and known as the Union Comb Manufactory. The building and contents were entirely consumed in a very slant lime. The damage to Messrs. HERRING on stock is about $1,500. Their insurance could not be ascertained. From these premises the fire extended to the Cummings planting Mills adjoining, (Nos.1,356,) which were also totally destroyed. The lose on stock and fixtures is about $2,000. The buildings were owned by Mr. CHARLES BEARDELEY, of No. 1,362 Broadway. They are insured for $2,000 in City companies.
headline: {'main': 'An Extensive Fire in Broadway.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Extensive Fire in Broadway.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE CONSCRIPTION FUND. A conference of the officers of the Brooklyn City Banks, the Board of Contracts and Special Committee of the Common Council, was held in the City Hall on Saturday, for...
lead_paragraph: THE CONSCRIPTION FUND. -- A conference of the officers of the Brooklyn City Banks, the Board of Contracts and Special Committee of the Common Council, was held in the City Hall on Saturday, for the purpose of consulting in relation to the raising of $1,000,000 by the city, to be used in mitigating the hardships of the draft. There were present Messrs. J.J. Studwell, of the City Bank; Conklin Brush, of the Mechanics' Bank; John K.Pruyn, of the Central Bank; W.S. Herriman, of the Long Island Bank; Daniel Embury, of the Atlantic Bank; George Field, of the Williamsburgh City Bank: I.H. Frothingham, of the Nassau Bank; O.M. Beach, of the Farmers' and Citizens' Bank; Mayor Kalbfeisch; Aldermen Ternan, Perry and Nodyne. The Mayor stated the action of the Common Council, and the object of inviting the officers of the city banks -- to ascertain what amounts these institutions were willing to advance on the load, and that it was desirable that the banks should act in concert. The subject was spoken of in a conversational manner. The financial gentlemen, it appeared, had no authority to make any proposition before submitting the matter to the Boards of Directors of the different Banks. The principal point they wished to ascertain, however, was whether there was not such a division of public opinion as to the justice or policy of the action of the Common Council as might deter the Legislature from legalizing the measure -- whether, in fact, the security for the payment of money was beyond doubt. The Mayor expressed the opinion that there was no doubt but the Legislature would legalize the act, and that he believed it met with the approval of a great majority of the people. The opinion was expressed by several gentlemen that our full quota could be raised without the draft by offering from $250 to $300 bounty for each man. Finally, it was understood that the matter would be laid before the Bank Directors, and another meeting held on Wednesday nest to receive their proposition.

abstract: The "regular Summer season" at the Winter Garden came to a close on Saturday evening, and we are glad to hear that it covered a very handsome profit to all parties concerned.
lead_paragraph: The "regular Summer season" at the Winter Garden came to a close on Saturday evening, and we are glad to hear that it covered a very handsome profit to all parties concerned. The artists who formed the troupe appear in Boston this evening, where Mr. FRANK WOOD's extravaganza of "Leah the Forsook" will be played for the first time. We can recommend both play and players to such of the Athenians who desire to laugh and grow fat. The Winter Garden will be closed during the present week.

abstract: During the past ten days, as is ascertained from official sources, but seven hundred men have volunteered for service in our New-York regiments. Three times that number might readily have been procured were it not for a system practiced by the recruiting agents of some of our sister States. These persons availing themselves of the fact that the bounty here is but a trifle, and of the further fact that thousands are ready to volunteer so soon as liberal inducements are made, have been operating with great success during the past week. It is stated that at least seven hundred have accepted the bounty of the State of Massachusetts and are now enrolled in her regiments. These men should be credited to the quota of New-York. They live here, enlisted here and can vote here, while their families will most likely call upon our authorities for assistance in the coming Winter. This matter should receive the early attention of our authorities, as there are official reasons for believing that it is being carried on to a very great extent. The same thing was done last year by the agents of New-Jersey and Connecticut, who, by the offer of very large bounties, drew away from us a very large number of our soldiery.

abstract: A Port Hudson correspondent of the Boston Traveller sates that on the 22d the Twelfth Connecticut and Thirteenth Maine left Donaldsonville for Brashear City via New-Orleans, where they were joined by the Ninth Connecticut. They go down the river, then up Bet wick's Bay. Two graduates of Dartmouth College were found in Port Hudson-JOHN BUTLER, from Port Gibson, Mass., who graduated in 1859, and Lieut. BUCKNER, from Kentucky, who was in Hip class of 1858, and being suspended for some misdemeanor, never returned. BUTLER was employed by Gen. GARDNER, the rebel commander, as an engineer, for which he had great capacity, and had sent to Richmond for a commission for him. Major Hon, U.S. Paymaster, was at Port Hudson paving some of the nine months' regiments, previous to their; departure north,

abstract: AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. At the meeting, Thankgiving Day, of this society, appropriate readings from the Psalms and prayer were had.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- At the meeting, Thankgiving Day, of this society, appropriate readings from the Psalms and prayer were had. A new auxiliary was recognized in Ohio. Thanks from members in different parts of the globe for the aid rendered in translation, printing and circulation of the Bible were received, and from others for appropriation of funds. Grants were made of books in different languages, to the number of near 40,000 volumes, of which, over 32,000 were for the South, or Confederate prisoners.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of JOHN KILLEEN, who died on Saturday night from injuries received by having been stabbed in the abdomen with a knife in the hands of JOHN DEVENNY.
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of JOHN KILLEEN, who died on Saturday night from injuries received by having been stabbed in the abdomen with a knife in the hands of JOHN DEVENNY. The deceased and accused, it appears, resided on the second floor of the tenement house No. 148 Sullivan-street. About 12 o'clock on Thursday night last, a difficulty occurred between deceased and a family named DUNN on one side. DE VENNY on the other. The testimony was, that the latter went up stairs between 11 and 12 o'clock and endeavored first to create a disturbance with the DUNN family by calling them all sorts of vile and offensive names, -- repeatedly asserting -- although an Irishman himself, that he could whip any or the Irish. Unable to get into a fight with DUNN, he set upon the deceased who was just then ascending the stairs, and in affray ensuing, the l[???]er himself was fatally stabbed an the abdomen. DE VENNY produced testimony to show that the stab was given in self-defence, and the jury evidently took that view of the case as appears from the following verdict, viz:

abstract: JACOB L. SEBRING, Captain, No. 94 Charlesstreet. On Monday, at 10 A.M., Sergeant MANGIN, with ten men, reported to Capt. SPEIGHT, No. 1,190 Broadway, and were parties to the defence of the Provost-Marshal's office there.
lead_paragraph: JACOB L. SEBRING, Captain, No. 94 Charles-street. On Monday, at 10 A.M., Sergeant MANGIN, with ten men, reported to Capt. SPEIGHT, No. 1,190 Broadway, and were parties to the defence of the Provost-Marshal's office there. At 11 A.M. Sergeant SMITH, with a platoon, was also ordered to report to Capt. SPRIGHT. Both of these officers and their commands are subsequently ordered to the assistance of Sergeant ELLISON and his force at the battles in Forty-sixth-street, of which we gave a detailed account yesterday. They arrived at the scene same time as Sergeant WADE, and went gallantly into the fight against overwhelming odds; the list of casualties -- Sergeants MANGIN and SMITH and senen of the force being badly injured -- shows how well and bravely they performed their part on this disastrous occasion. After the retreat they returned to their own Precinct, escaping tf[???]r as best they could, and instantly reformed for [???] duty. At 5:30 P.M., the entire force, under Capt. SEBRING, reported at headquarters. They were with inspector CARPENTER in the evening, at the exemplary punishment of the mob in the City Hail Park and Printing-House-square, and thence with him in the useful tour through the Fourth and adjacent wards.

abstract: The London Globe, in reviewing the question of American affairs, contends that the rebels are far from being conquered, and thinks that Lee, at Culpepper, is as safe as ever. Gen. GRANT's campaign is the most brilliant, but will be confined in its fruits to the immediate neighborhood of the river. The Globe says if the Federals are wise they will exert themselves to secure what they have got for territorial arrangements, and abandon the impossible enterprise of subjugation.

GRANT's campaign is the most brilliant, but will be confined in its fruits to the immediate neighborhood of the river. The Globe says if the Federals are wise they will exert themselves to secure what they have got for territorial arrangements, and abandon the impossible enterprise of subjugation.

abstract: River; the navigation of the
lead_paragraph: Though a month has now elapsed since we obtained entire control of the Mississippi River, and though quite a number of steamboats have passed to and fro between New-Orleans, Vicksburgh, and points higher up stream, not a hostile shot has been fired from the river banks upon any of these steamers. The rebels have threatened so long and so loudly that in case their river stronghold fell, they would still prevent navigation by means of guerrillas and pieces of light artillery, located and moveable, on the river banks, that it is a wonder we have had no sign of the thing having been opened. They have told us that it was impossible to guard both banks of the river for the thousand miles it passes through rebel territory; and though impossible is a word to which our people do not usually pay much attention, we have been too fearful that there was some truth in the assertions and some danger in the threats of the rebels. The Southern newspapers now claim that a system of guerrillaism is in process of organization, which, when completed, will enable them again to interrupt the navigation of the Mississippi.

abstract: The Military Situation in
lead_paragraph: Everything goes to show that Gen. LEE has definitively taken up the line which we surmised from his movements he would assume -- namely, the line of the Rapidan. The Rapidan, rising among the spurs of the Blue Ridge Mountains, flows in an easterly direction, and unites with the Rappahannock at united States Ford. Along this line he observes the river as far as Fredericksburgh. where he has a corps de place. Our own front appears to extend along the upper forks of the Rappahannock, so that the triangle between the Rapidan and the Rappahannock will probably be for some time the debatable territory.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR's letter to the President concerning the Conscription, is unnecessarily long, pitifully captious, and painfully pettifogging. Alter the labored, and in many items incorrect history of the late riots which he furnishes for Presidential perusal, he enters upon his argument regarding the Conscription, which consists of two parts -- first, its unfairness as applied to certain districts of this State; and second, its doubtful constitutionality as a principle; and he then asks of the President that the draft may be suspended in this State until the result of recruiting shall be seen. We hare not time at the moment the document reaches us, to give due examination of the statistics of Gov. SEYMOUR; but if they are as partisan as his arguments, and as unfairly drawn as his inferences, the document altogether will be sufficiently characteristic.
