abstract: One of the morning papers, whose forte lies chiefly in giving flaming sensation headings to stale items of news, has just made the wonderful discovery that there are a set of men in New-York Called "office-brokers" -- men who, through political intrigue and wire-pulling, obtain places for themselves or their friends from newly-elected office-holders, and then tell these places out to poor devils without political influence at a certain percentage on the salary. This is a business which has been carried on in all the official bureaus is of this City -- to say nothing of the departments under the control of the General Government -- for the last twenty years, and is as will known to the public as the fact that our offices are generally filled with unprincipled and incompetent political speculators and public plunderers. It is one of the least of the evils under which this community suffers from the workings of our corrupt party politics, and concerns chiefly those who are parties to the bargain, if Mr. O'Bludgeon, by means of his "knock-down arguments" at the polls, can secure the promise of a place from the successful candidate, for whose election he exerts his powerful influence. It matters e to the public whether he afterward sells out the place for a consideration or holds it himself. The chances are that if he sells out a more competent man than himself will [???]ll the place. What the public needs is a reform in the workings of the political machine, which will render it impossible for such men as P. O'Bludgeon to secure places at all, either for themselves of anybody else. Until this is effected, it is hardly worth while to get excited over the operations of the office-brokers." As long as our citizens are content: to sit quietly and see themselves governed and plundered by political thieves and vagabonds, they will not be likely to concern on ill selves about the manager in which the spoil are divided.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian passed Cape Race on Friday evening, with advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 30th, and Greencastle on the 31st ult. The steamship China passed the same point at noon of Saturday, with advices to the 2d inst -- two days later than by the Hibernian. Intelligence had reached England of the destruction, by the pirate Alabama, of the ships Talisman, from New-York for Shanghai, and Conrad, from Montevideo for New-York. On the 20th ult. the rebel loan took another tumble of 2 per cent. American stocks were buoyant. Cotton had advanced half a penny in the week, while Breadstuffs were dull and Provisions steady. The news regarding the Polish question does not look quite so warlike. I Frankfort the opinion is entertained that the difficulties will be settled by diplomacy, and in Pails the war panic had pretty much subsided.

abstract: Queen, the Speech, at the Close of Parliament
snippet: Queen, the Speech, at the Close of Parliament
lead_paragraph: MY LORDS AND GENTLEMEN: We are commanded by her Majesty to dismiss you from further attendance in Parliament, and at the same time to convey to you Her Majesty's acknowledgments for the zeal and assiduity with which you have applied yourselves to the performance of your duties during the Session now brought to a close. Her Majesty has seen, with deep regret, the present condition of Poland. Her Majesty has been engaged, in concert with the Emperors of France and Austria in negotiation on the subject which has been opened to obtain the fulfilment of the stipulation of the treaty of Vienna of 1815 in behalf of the Poles. Her Majesty trusts that those stipulations will be carried into execution, and that thus a conflict distressing to Her Majesty, and dangerous to the tranquillity of Europe, may be brought to a close. The civil war between the Northern and Southern States of the American Union still unfortunately continues, and is necessarily attended with much evil, not only to the contending parties, but also to nations which have taken no part in the conflict. Her Majesty, however, has seen no reason to depart from the strict neutrality which Her Majesty has observed from the beginning of the contest. The Greek nation having chosen Prince WILLIAM of Denmark for the King, Her Majesty is taking steps with a view to the union of the London Islands to the Kingdom of Greece. For this purpose Her Majesty is in communication with the Powers who were parties to the treaty of 1815, by which these Islands were placed under the protectorate of the British Crown, and the wishes of the Ionians on the subject of the union will be ascertained. Several barbarous outrages committed in Japan upon British subjects have rendered it necessary for Her Majesty to demand reparation, and Her Majesty hopes Her demands will be conceded by the Japanese Government without its being necessary to enforce them. The Emperor of Brazil has thought fit to break off his diplomatic relations with Her Majesty, in consequence of Her Majesty not having complied with demands which she did not deem proper to accede to. Her Majesty has no wish that this estrangement should continue, and would be glad to see her relations with Brazil reestablished.

abstract: Officer FOWLER, of the Twenty-first Precinct, yesterday, arrested CHARLES DENNIN, charged with having been concerned in the riot on Third-avenue, Monday, the 13th of July.
lead_paragraph: Officer FOWLER, of the Twenty-first Precinct, yesterday, arrested CHARLES DENNIN, charged with having been concerned in the riot on Third-avenue, Monday, the 13th of July. The officer testified that while he was on duty in Forty-sixth-street, between Second and Third avenues, at the time in question, end during the time that Provost-Marshal JENKINS' office was burning, he saw the accused leading a large number of men and boys; that they were ail engaged in throwing stones and other missiles, at that and the adjoining houses. The prisoner seemed to be a ringleader among them, and did all he could to incite them and urge them on in performing deeds of robbery and arson. He also advised the rioters to resist the authorities, and was frequently seen throwing brickbats and stones at the police; and called out loudly to his followers to "kill the sons of -- " DENNIN was taken before Justice QAACKKNBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and commuted to prison in default of ball.

abstract: Dispatch of National Govergment and Note to Count Rechberg

abstract: The popularity of JEFF DAVIS is just now at a very low ebb in Dixie.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of JEFF DAVIS is just now at a very low ebb in Dixie. The rebels generally have a notion that he is somehow responsible for the great reverses that have overtaken them; and, without scruple, they are casting at him the sharpest reproaches. He is stigmatized both for incapacity and for neglect -- for lack of brain and for lack of heart. The prevailing criticism upon him is all adverse; and his former lieges now make him out to be a man very much to be despised.

abstract: While the brilliant victories that have of late crowned the National arms on the three theatres of war may justly inspire hearty rejoicing in all who love the Union cause, it ...
lead_paragraph: While the brilliant victories that have of late crowned the National arms on the three theatres of war may justly inspire hearty rejoicing in all who love the Union cause, it would be greatly to misuse those victories to make them a haven to rest in, instead of a place by the way where we may receive refreshment and inspiration for new and greater effots. Sanguine souls speak of the "backbone of the rebellion" as being now at length fairly "broken," and even many sober and thoughtful minds are looking forward to the immediate collapse of the gigantic power that for two years and over has withstood all efforts at subjugation.

abstract: Memphis Appeal on holding Southern rivers
snippet: Memphis Appeal on holding Southern rivers
lead_paragraph: The Memphis Appeal (Atlanta, Ga.) states a very significant principle in the remark that "every attempt we [the rebels] have made to hold interior points on navigable rivers have been disastrous, either on account of the overwhelming naval force which the enemy has been able to bring to bear, or the facility with which he could transport troops and supplies, landing when and where he would."

abstract: The Political and Social Status of the Southern Negro
snippet: The Political and Social Status of the Southern Negro
lead_paragraph: The great argument on which the apologists of Slavery, both at the North and the South, used to rely, before the war, was that the amalgamation of the two races would be the inevitable consequence of emancipation, and amalgamation, of course, involved the degradation and debasement of the superior race. The way in which this alarming conclusion was reached was by taking it for granted that as soon as the negroes were free, intermarriages between them and the whites would inevitably follow; and this theory was so firmly held by the more ignorant portion of the Southern population, that they looked on an Anti-Slavery man with a sort of not unreasonable disgust, as a gentleman who, if he had a daughter, was longing eagerly to see her united in the bonds of wedlock with a full-blooded African. The idea that amalgamation could go on without marriage, strange as it may appear to those who know the condition of Southern society, never seems to have occurred to the majority of Pro-Slavery writers, and nothing was more common than to hear a Slavery propagandist, fresh from plantation life -- and perfectly well aware that the pure negro has almost entire y disappeared from the South, and has been replaced by mulattos of every shade of color -- talk of the physical consequences of the success of the Abolitionists as the most horrible feature in their crusade against "the peculiar institution."
headline: {'main': 'The Social and Political Status of the Southern Negro.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Social and Political Status of the Southern Negro.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Statements appear to be gaining ground that there is a desire on the part of Spain to enter info renewed cooperation with France on the Mexican question. Whether France is now willing to admit her into partnership is not stated. Originally many difficulties might possibly have been obviated by united action; but now, that the chief work of the expedition may prove to have been surmounted, it is not easy to discover any advantage that France could gain from the offer. Looking merely to the interests of the creditors of Mexico, it is to be earnestly hoped, that Spain will not be permitted to regain the slightest interest in that country. Whatever may be the expectations of the bondholders from the honor or power of France, these would all be diminished in exact proportion to the extent to which Spain might have a voice on the question. Standing alone in the world as the only country stained by the practice of actual confiscation, and keeping alive her disgrace in other respects by the habit, month by month, of misappropriating even the funds which she admits she is bound to pay, her object would naturally be to keep other defaulting countries as nearly as possible in her own condition, so that her degradation may be diminished by companionship. Her interference would also be bad by checking the revival of Mexican commerce. The prospects of the bondholders partly depend upon the development of the industry of the country, end the disposition of merchants and capitalists to embark their money for that purpose, and this would be checked it the Spanish Government were to have the opportunity of carrying thither their practice on points of national honor. It will be said that these are hard words, and the members of the Madrid Cabinet will probably, in some future grandiloquent speeches, announce that, in consequence of their having been used, it is essential for the dignity of Spain that she should continue to punish those who have trusted her by declining to pay them anything. There will also [???] a cry that it is unjust to the Spanish people at large to confound them with their Government. But the time for the Spanish Cabinet to complain of hard words will be when they can point to the fact that there is no ban against them in the money markets of the world, and for the Spanish people to claim to be more worthy than their Government when they have exercised the privilege they fully possess of calling that Government to account for its bad faith.

abstract: Life of
lead_paragraph: Rear-Admiral DAVID GLASGOW FARRAGUT is now a veteran officer. He was born about sixty years since in East Tennessee, twelve miles from Knoxville. His father at that time was in the service of the United States as a Major in a cavalry regiment, and was an intimate and honored friend of Gen. JACKSON, who throughout his life lost no opportunity of showing the high regard he felt for the FARRAGUT family. Young DAVID's early years were passed among the thrilling and dangerous scenes of border life. He remembers vividly an encounter that his mother had with the Indians when he could not have been more than five years age, Seeing a number of the savages approaching the house, she required the children to hide themselves in the loft of a barn, while she and her servants secured the house in such a manner that the assailants could not enter without breaking open the doors or setting the house in flames. They threatened to do both, but Mrs. FARRAGUT, with great determination, refused to admit them, and, in order to gain time, parleyed with them through a partially barricaded door, which, however, was not so tightly closed as to prevent the entrance of a tomahawk that came very nearly taking off the heroic woman's head. Fortunately at this critical moment the hoofs of Major FARRAGUT's squadron of horse were heard upon the road, and the Indians scampered off, but being pursued, were overtaken and almost annihilated. From that time the family were no more troubled by the red-skins.

Also, all official, orders, reports and documents, and the latest and f[???]est Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. abstract: In the Third District yesterday, the Board of Enrollment only examined 48 conscripts, and of these 28 were given certificates of exemption, 7 showed receipts from the Collector of Internal Revenue for the payment of the commutation money, and 13 substitutes were accepted. Durtng the week, in this District, ...
lead_paragraph: In the Third District yesterday, the Board of Enrollment only examined 48 conscripts, and of these 28 were given certificates of exemption, 7 showed receipts from the Collector of Internal Revenue for the payment of the commutation money, and 13 substitutes were accepted. Durtng the week, in this District, there have been 351 conscripts examined. Of these 85 were exempted for alienage, 116 for physical disability, 6 as being over 45 years of age, 7 as being under 20 years old, 10 non-residents of the District, 14 the only sons of widows, 4 the only sons of aged and infirm parents, 3 the fathers of motherless children, 10 in the United Stales service March 3, 24 over 35 years and married, 27 as having paid the commutation money, 4 reported for duty, and 41 presented accepted substitutes.

abstract: On Saturday the great American land steam engine, known in this country as the Manhattan, was publicly tried in the Shadwell entrance of the London Docks, in presence of several distinguished persons and the representatives of various fire offices. Mr. VAN TINE, Mr. JONES and Mr. EVANS, with Engineer COLLINS, all of the "American delegation," were in attendance, as well as Capt. SHAW, the Superintendent of the Fire Brigade. The fire in the first experiment was lighted at 1:20 P.M., and in 10 min. 38 sec. the engine started at a pressure of 33 pounds of steam. The pressure in 14 min. 5 sec. rose to 14 pounds. In 14 min. 40 sec. the engine was stopped to adjust the nozzle, and in 1 min. and 24 sec. she was started again, and threw the water horizontally through an inch and a quarter nozzle to a distance of 189 feet. Toward the end of this trial the boiler was found to leak so much that the fire had to be drawn, so us to see if the leak could be found. The fire was afterward relaid, and the engine again set to work, and threw the water a foot beyond the former distance. The engine then sent a vertical jet through the same nozzle, but the leak increased to such an extent as to render it necessary to discontinue the experiments. The engine had been hastily repaired after the accident it met with at the Crystal Palace, where the damage done turned out to be more serious than was at first expected.

abstract: MOSEBY'S guerrillas are still infesting the region of country between Alexandria and Fairfax, and they make continued attackS upon sutlers' trains going and coming. On Thursday, while a train of fifteen ...
lead_paragraph: MOSEBY's guerrillas are still infesting the region of country between Alexandria and Fairfax, and they make continued attackS upon sutlers' trains going and coming. On Thursday, while a train of fifteen or twenty wagons (returning) were about four miles this side of Fairfax, the driver of the wagon ahead noticed a cavalryman standing in the road, who beckoned him to come on. Believing him to be a rebel guerrilla, but at the same time not daring to disregard the motion to "move on," he slowly drove his team forward, and was captured and taken into the woods near by. Shortly afterward the rest of the train was also captured, and was taken also into the same locality, where were about thirty of MOSEBY's gang, who commenced at once to secure the horses attached to the wagons, and to compel the drivers, and those connected with them, to shell out all they had about them, even to pocket combs and jackknives.

abstract: Capt. A.S. RELAY, Harlem, One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street, near Third avenue. Early orders were received at this Precinct, on Monday morning, to call in reserve and hold the force in readiness, but owing to the subsequent destruction of the telegraph it was not until 5:30 P.M. that, by a special messenger, directions were received upon which Sergts. OSBORN and WALTERS left for Headquarters with thirty-five men. They took the Third avenue cars as far as Seventy-first-street, where, the operations of the road being stopped below, the company had concluded to leave off. The force thence took up the long march to headquarters, reaching there at 8 P.M. In the evening they were with Inspector LEONARD's command at City Hall, and engaged on the various and constant duties of the night in that vicinity; portions of the time being the only force in Printing-house-square, and effectually keeping it clear of the ill-disposed. On Tuesday morning reported at headquarters, and attached to Capt. WAILING's command, made the tour through the Bowery and adjacent streets; in the afternoon another tour to the Bowery and vicinity, under Inspector CARPENTER. On the return, one PATRICK CARLEY stood on the sidewalk brandishing a sword, and threatening destruction to all in, and some out of authority. Officer BAMFIELD seized him, secured the weapon, and drew him into the ranks, conveying him to headquarters, where he was looked up. In the evening the command were at the City Hall: again, and participated in the various excursions therefrom. On Wednesday morning the force were ordered to the Twenty-seventh Precinct, and thence to their own Precinct, Harlem. They reached Harlem in the afternoon, and were received with enthusiasm by the residents. Although this force were not engaged on any very hazardous duty. yet they were actively employed, and what duties were assigned them were fully performed.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR has written a rejoinder to the President's reply to his letter asking for a suspension of the draft in this State. He regrets that ...
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has written a rejoinder to the President's reply to his letter asking for a suspension of the draft in this State. He regrets that the President has decided that the draft must go on; seeks to show that the enrollment is unjust, oppressive and partisan in its character, and declares that the President cannot refuse to set right what he denominates as "gross wrongs."

abstract: At the close of the last financial year - that is to say, on the 31st of March, 1863, the National debt consisted of [???]783,306,739 funded debt, and [???]16,493,480 unfunded, making in all [???]795,802,130. snippet: Pearson, Charles, Bankruptcy by Blockade Running
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at the London Bankruptcy Court, there was an adjourned sitting in the affairs of the bankrupt, ZACHARIAH CHARLES PEARSON, merchant and shipowner, of Hull and London. The accounts, prepared by Messrs. JOHNSTONE & Co., were only [???]ed on Saturday last, and are of a very voluminous character, occupying 120 sheets of paper. The aggregate liabilities have bean hitherto stated in round numbers at upward of half a million; the exact amount is now shown to be [???], 135. The bankrupt states his expenditures in the two years preceding his bankruptcy at [???]1,590 a year. He has filed a statement recounting for his deficiency, in which the following items appear: Losses -- Steamship. [???]; working accounts. [???]33,873; adventure, per Pa[???]s, [???]2,651; ditto, Stettm, [???]691; by sundry ships, [???]170; shares in public companies, [???]3,780; by Southampton Times newspaper, [???]1,394; [???] 1,038; free hold offices at Hull, [???]1,746; [???]se, [???]1,050; coals, [???]2,472; coal yard, [???]378; law and other coals, [???]1,935: horses and carriages, [???]; had debts, [???]4,652; trade expenses, [???]15,781; interest on purchases and mortgages of ships, discounts, &c, [???]61,516; commission for guarantee on sundry insurances, [???]6,875; amount paid JAMES COLEMAN on retiring from firm, in july, 1860. [???]4,000; drawings of COLEMAN, [???]3,009; bankrupts drawings (from July 31, 1858, to Sept. 23, 1863,) [???]12,414. On the other side of the deficiency account appear the items of capital. 31st of July, 1858, [???]20,145; profits since the same date, [???]65,864. The largest secured creditors are Messrs. OVEREND, GURNEY & Co., whose dept is [???]211,813. They hold security valued at [???]9,-835, consisting chiefly of mortgages on ships [???] charges on outward freights of goods in the following ships of the Confederate States: Modern Greece. [???] ashore,( [???]10,000; Patras, (captured,) [???]6,500 ([???] received on account;) Ann, (captured, part of goods saved.) [???]7,000; Stettin, ditto, [???]3,938: Ci[???] ditto, [???]1,000; Merrimac and cargo, [???]23,000. They also hold a seco[???] mortgage on the Peterhoff, and 600 shares in the Intercolonial Royal Mail Steam Packet Company, valued at [???]3,150 Mr. R.C. BREGGS. of Hull, is a secured creditor for [???]64,569; Messrs. BARKER BROTHERS of Abchurch[???]e, $38,334; Messrs, ROBINSON & FLEMING. shipbrckers, [???]27,873; M. SAMUELSON & Co., [???]25,394; SMITH BROTHERS & Co., [???]29,220; WEICKERSHIEM & Co., Vienna, [???]10,000. The property given up to the assignees consists chiefly of ships, shares of slips and ships states, valued at [???]21,59[???]. His residence in Beverley Road, Bull, two freehold houses, and several policies of insurance, are settled on the bankrupt's wife and family.

abstract: For August, from Le Monde Elegant
snippet: For August, from Le Monde Elegant
lead_paragraph: The present season, both in London and Paris, is one of the most brilliant that we have had for many years. A long series of parties, fetes, flower-shows, morning concerts, &c., have been attended by a perfect galaxy of rank and fashion; and in these and other fashionable promenades the eye is charmed by a succession of costumes, each seeming to surpass the other in elegance and taste, and in the production of which our best artistes d[???]s modes are, and have been, b[???]ly engaged.

abstract: Riots, the; the Danger to the Forts
snippet: Riots, the; the Danger to the Forts
lead_paragraph: In Gov. SEYMOUR's first letter to the President, there is one bit of information given which the Government ought at once to adopt the most active measures to prevent any future mob taking advantage of. The Governor, in descanting upon the late riots, says that the National authorities were so badly prepared for the emergency that they "could not even man their own forts," and for a time "these very fortifications were the chief danger to the harbor of New-York." "One thousand men," he adds, "could have seized them all, and have used their armaments for the destruction of its shipping, and of the City itself." We are really thankful that the Governor did not inform the rioters of this fact when he addressed them from the steps of the City Hall. For, if he had done so, who can doubt, after what we saw in this City, that the "thousand men" would have been forthcoming instanter, and before that night's sun had set, we should have seen the guns of the harbor-forts turned upon our City and our shipping? Who can doubt that ten thousand from the riotous classes of this City would have rushed to the aid of the first thousand? And who can tell what would have been the upshot of all this? We know very well what would have been the final upshot of it. We know that the rioters would have been ground to powder by the power of the people and the Government. But who can say what bloodshed there might have been in our streets, what destruction of property, what fights in our harbor, when all the riotous elements of New-York, stimulated by blood, and fired by passion and whisky, would have ravaged the City, under the protection of the fortifications in the harbor, held by their allies?
headline: {'main': 'The Perils We Have Escaped.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Perils We Have Escaped.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT. A number of persons were prostrated by the intense heat yesterday and the day previous, and several deaths occurred in consequence. MICHAEL NEWMAN, an undertaker, doing ...
lead_paragraph: THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT. -- A number of persons were prostrated by the intense heat yesterday and the day previous, and several deaths occurred in consequence. MICHAEL NEWMAN, an undertaker, doing business at No. 148 court-street, died on account of the heat.....THOMAS BURNS, a carpenter, residing at No. 169 Smith-street, while about starting for Staten Island, on Sunday, felt a strange feeling, and returned to his room, He lingered until night, when he expired.....A blind man, who has for years been stationed near the corner of Sands and Fulton streets, sellciting alms, dropped down dead on the sidewalk, near the corner of Main and Water streets. Yesterday. He was accompanied by his wife. The body was taken to the Forty-second Precinct Station-house. Inquests were held on the above cases, and verdicts that death was caused by the intense heat were rendered.

abstract: The following letter shows the high consideration in which the Christian Commission is held by the Commander-in-Chief of the Army of the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: The following letter shows the high consideration in which the Christian Commission is held by the Commander-in-Chief of the Army of the Potomac. The many testimonials received of the devotion and efficiency of the Commission's delegates upon the field of Gettysburgh, and subsequently in the overcrowded hospitals at the front, added to many offered on previous occasions, prove the General's encomium to be well merited. and that the Commission, is worthy the confidence and cordial support of every true Christian and patriot:

abstract: The first of the series of Cricket Matches between the Massachusetts Cricketers and the Cricket Clubs of New-York, was commenced yesterday at 11 o'clock on the New-York Cricket Ground, Hoboken. There are about thirty cricketers ant a number ...
lead_paragraph: The first of the series of Cricket Matches between the Massachusetts Cricketers and the Cricket Clubs of New-York, was commenced yesterday at 11 o'clock on the New-York Cricket Ground, Hoboken. There are about thirty cricketers ant a number of their friends, who arrived from Boston on Sunday morning by the Stonington Line, and who are stopping at the International Hotel. They present a strong array of cricket talent, but unfortunately met with a severe loss by one of their best players being drowned by the oapsizing of a sailboat about a fortnight since.

abstract: The trial of the rioters was continued in the Court of Sessions, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN. From prisoners pleaded guilty to riot and were remanded for sentence on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The trial of the rioters was continued in the Court of Sessions, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN. From prisoners pleaded guilty to riot and were remanded for sentence on Wednesday. Two were convicted of robbery in the first degree, one of whom was sentenced to ten years in the State Prison, and the other remanded for sentence on Wednesday. Another was placed on trial for robbery in the first degree, and pending the hearing of the case, the Court adjourned to this morning at 10 o'clock.

abstract: PETER McINTYRE, a Policeman of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, from the effects of injuries received on the head and breast during the late riot. The deceased was a brave and efficient offer. On the breaking out of the riot, on Monday, July 13, he and his brother officers were promptly ordered to the scene of conflict in Third avenue. Here it was that he received the wounds which have caused his death. For over two hours he, with other officials, fought the thousands of desperate men and boys who surged and swept the avenue for many blocks during the time that provost-Marshal JENKINS' office was burning. The mob finally overcame the Police, and among the many who were left on the ground as dead was deceased. It was afterward discovered that life was not extinct, and a few friends of his picked him up and conveyed him home. He was confined to the house only a few days, but on getting out complained continually of his head, and gave evidences of derangement. His friends placed him in Bellevue Hospital, where, despite unremitting care, he died Sunday evening, from congestion of the brain.
lead_paragraph: PETER McINTYRE, a Policeman of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, from the effects of injuries received on the head and breast during the late riot. The deceased was a brave and efficient offer. On the breaking out of the riot, on Monday, July 13, he and his brother officers were promptly ordered to the scene of conflict in Third avenue. Here it was that he received the wounds which have caused his death. For over two hours he, with other officials, fought the thousands of desperate men and boys who surged and swept the avenue for many blocks during the time that provost-Marshal JENKINS' office was burning. The mob finally overcame the Police, and among the many who were left on the ground as dead was deceased. It was afterward discovered that life was not extinct, and a few friends of his picked him up and conveyed him home. He was confined to the house only a few days, but on getting out complained continually of his head, and gave evidences of derangement. His friends placed him in Bellevue Hospital, where, despite unremitting care, he died Sunday evening, from congestion of the brain.

abstract: From the United Kingdom; Emigration from the United Kingdom
snippet: From the United Kingdom; Emigration from the United Kingdom
lead_paragraph: A blue book of 216 pages, containing the twenty-third general report of the Emigration Commissioners, has been published. The emigration from the United Kingdom, in 1862, amounted to 121,214 souls, of whom 58,706 or upward of 48 per cent. Went to the United States. 15,522 or a little more than 12 per cent. To British North America. 41,843 or nearly 34 per cent. To Australia and New-Zealand, and 5,143 or more than 4 per cent. To other places The emigration of 1862 exceeded the emigration of 1861 by upward of 20,000 souls, and was larger than the average of the tour previous years -- but fell much short of the emigration of 18[???], 1856 and 18[???]7, and was less than two-fifths of the emigration of the eight years from 1817 to 18[???]5. The greatest decrease, both in 1861 and 1862 was, as might we expected, in the emigration to the United States. In 1861 this emigration had fallen to 49,764 [???] to 5[???]1,22 per cent, of the whole emigration of that year. In 1862 it rose to 5[???],766, but its proportion to the whole emigration was even less than in 1861, being only 1843 per cent in fact, its proportion to the whole emigration was smaller in 1862 than in any year since 1811. In the 21 years which have elapsed since 1811, the proportion of the emigration to the United States to the whole emigration, has varied From 7[???] per cent to 48,[???] the average being 61[???]93. The decease in the last two years was of course the result of the civil war. The same cause increased the proportion of the emigration to British North America. Between 1849 and 1862 the proportion of that emigration to the whole emigration varied from 3[???] per cent in 185[???] to 18[???] per cent. in 1861. In 1862 it amounted to 12[???] Per cent. Nevertheless, the emigration to British North America, though proportionally large, was absolutely small. With the exception of the four preceding years ([???] to 1861 inclusive,) it was the smallest since 1839. Of the whole number of emigrants, 40,680, or 40[???] per cent., were Irish. This proportion is larger than in 1861, and in some recent years and indicates an increase of pressure upon the laboring class in Ireland. Whenever that is the case the ample remittances so nobly sent home to their friends in Ireland by those who have preceded them, afford a ready means of extending the emigration. The amount returned as sent home in 1862 was [???]463,024 making in the sixteen years for which there are returns, a total of [???]12,642,000. It is necessary to repeat that these returns are very imperfect, as they contain none of the remittances through the post or through private hands, or [???]ough any bank of [???] houses, which de[???] to furnish us with information. It would s[???]ely be unreasonable to estimate the amount of which there are no returns as half as much again as that of which there are returns. During the first four months of the year, the emigration is for obvious reasons generally small. The numbers who emigrated in those months during the five years preceding the present year were -- 1858. 31,423; 1859, 33,767: 1860, 38,285; 1861, 34,740; 1862, 30,016. In 1863, they have amounted to 68,571. Of this emigration, there proceeded to the United States, 46,904, which, though numerically large, is larger in proportion to the whole than the average of former years. But the proportion of Irish in the emigration was considerably larger than in previous years, Thus the proportion of Irish was in 1858, 54.61 per cent: 1859, 63.17; 1860, 64.06; 1861, 63.71; 1[???]2, 58.95. In 1863 it was 70.59 per cent. The proportion [???] single men to the whole emigration to the United States was in 1858, 37.20; 1859, 38.57; 1860, 33.74; 1861, 32.85; 1862, 32.64. In 1863 it was 36.16. The Commissioners believe that the great increase in the Irish emigration of the present year is to be attributed rather to the distress caused in Ireland by an unfortunate succession of bad seasons and to the high wages now prevailing in the United States, than to any preconceived intention on the part of the emigrants to take service with either party in the civil war now raging.

abstract: Gen. NEAL DOW, in a letter to the Secretary of the United Kingdom Alliance, da[???]ed from near Port Hudson, on the 23d June, save: "I read with a great deal of interest everything in your paper relating to the cotton famine, and its consequences to the English people and to British interests. Your manufacturers ought to know that they will get no large supply of cotton from this country for some time to come, if ever again, that they may arrange their affairs accordingly. The slave system of this country is already completely overthrown by the rebellion and the war, and for all industrial purposes is dead. The planters have always declared that the cotton culture is impossible with any other than slave labor; and while we do not believe this to be true, yet the planters are sincere in that opinion, and will not only be disinclined to try a system of free labor but will be, from temper and prejudice, determined against it. They will not try it. To do so they would seem to acquiesce in the policy and principles of the hated Anti-Slavery men, to which, as a body, they will not yield for many years to come, nor at all, indeed, in the present generation. The planters, as a body, are ruined by the rebellion. While a few of them were very rich, and are yet so to a considerable degree, the great majority of them were otherwise, and were living every year upon the credit of the ensuing crop. That was the general system. They had no floating capital, but all they had was invested in [???] and negroes; mostly in the latter, to the extent in all, for negroes alone, of four hundred mill [???] of pounds sterling. And now this vast amount of capital is sunk by the rebellion and vanished, as completely as if it had been destroyed by fire or flood. For a great deal of this capital the planters were indebted to merchants and slave traders, by whom the negroes were sold on one, two, three and four years, with interest, the purchaser giving as security a mortgage on part or all of his property. The large profits of the cotton planters were not permanently invested in any way outside his business, nor indeed at all, but were put into more negroes and more land, and thus the cotton culture was stimulated, and extended to the utmost limits of the ability of the planters to obtain more land and more negroes. This question enhanced the price of slaves to almost a fabulous extentt; so that the reopening of the African Slave-trade was generally discussed in the cotton and sugar States, and its expediency and necessity were insisted on is of vital importance to the South. It was said that the inter-state Slave-trade had about it all the cruelties of the African Slave-trade, except the crowding in slave ships, which would not be if the trade were legalized. They said the slaves from Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky and Tennessee, sold South, were torn away from home, kindred, and friends, inflicting far more suffering upon them than savage Africans endured from the same causes. That if Slavery was right, the supply of slaves was also right, and that if the trade was properly regulated, its cruel features would disappear; and that slaves from Africa could be had for $100, where as they were now compelled to pay to the American slave-breeding States from one thousand to twenty-five hundred dollars for each slave; and in accordance with this reasoning, some cargoes of slaves were actually imported into the Gulf States in defiance of the law, and the results of the adventure greatly stimulated the zeal of the planting States in favor of reopening the African Slave-trade, and prepared the way for the rebellion, because the planting States perfectly well knew that the reopening of the Slave-trade within the Union was impossible. A gentleman of New-Orleans, well acqu[???]nted with the business of the State of Louisiana, said that if the debts of all the planter were paid, not three hundred of them would have money enough left to pay for a dinner at a hotel! The peace, when it comes, will find the planters, as a body, entirely ruined, and burdened with a large amount of debt beyond their ability ever to pay, their slaves converted into freemen, instead of cash, and their lands of small value apart from the labor which had given them a price in the market. The merchants and traders to whom they are largely indebted for supplies and for negroes, and who furnished them with their needful floating capital, will find their means largely or entirely absorbed by these debts, and will be unable or unw[???]ing to lend capital to aid in inaugurating a free labor system. If the cotton culture is to be continued at all in this country after the suppression of the rebellion, it will be. I think, by new men who will succeed to the estates of the ruined cotton planters, who will have neither the means, the inclination, nor the knowledge necessary to carry on the business with a kind of labor they are unacquainted with, and which they cannot pay for a year in advance of the crop. It will require a very long time, as any one can see, for a new set of men with sufficient capital to take up the cotton lands and bring up the culture of that article to its former extent. It is indispensable, therefore, if the cotton manufacture is to be continued in England on its former scale, that other resources of supply than this country should be provided.

abstract: Officer ROGERS, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday arrested EDWARD SMITH, who is charged, on the complaint of JAMES HAYES, of No. 435 West Twenty-sixth-street, with having been one of the leaders during the riot week. The accused led a ...
lead_paragraph: Officer ROGERS, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday arrested EDWARD SMITH, who is charged, on the complaint of JAMES HAYES, of No. 435 West Twenty-sixth-street, with having been one of the leaders during the riot week. The accused led a crowd of men who on the...Eleventh avenues. HAYES further charges that the prisoner was armed with a loaded musket which he had taken from the military, and that he was for two days constantly engaged as a leader of the rioters, and pressed a large number of laborers to leave their work. Under threats of personal violence they were induced to join the mob, but deserted at the first opportunity. Some of the men who had been thus pressed into the company of the rioter will appear at the Police Courts to-day and testify against the parties. Justice KELLY committed SMITH to answer in default of bail.

abstract: Correspondence with the President on the Draft
snippet: Correspondence with the President on the Draft
lead_paragraph: The letter of Gov. SEYMOUR to President LINCOLN, on the draft in this City and Brooklyn, published by us yesterday, does him no credit. The difference between it and the reply to it, both in tone and in matter, is just the difference between half-heartedness, and whole-souled, straightforward devotion to duty.

abstract: Lovers of scandal have been for many months amused with the vagaries of the youthful and fourth spouse of a septuagenarian squire on the banks of the Tees, who enjoys the odd celebrity of haying buried two partners and possessing a pair of living wives, while every one of them has left a legacy of plighted troth and affection in the shape of a single child. No doubt, on the recovery of Sir CRESSWELL CRESSWELL from his untoward accident, the fox-hunting squire will once more apply for redress and obtain it, when in all likelihood the prophecy at his youth of being "blessed with five wives" may be verified. It appears that a noble earl of high descent and ancient lineage in Scotland, well-known on the turf, was introduced to the lady in question not very long ago, and by her invited to her husband's house. The acquaintance seems soon to have gone beyond the Platonic, as a few days since, on the pretence of visiting a sister-in-law in the midland counties, Mrs. -- left home. Unhappily, another lady of the same name visiting the intended hostess opened a letter directed as hers generally, and read from the peer's own hand the programme of the intended flight with her connection, on whose arrival the coldness and confusion may be imagined, and the immediate progress of the fugitive could not be wondered at. The worst of it is that his lordship has a young family, and his countess moves in the cream of society.

abstract: In the First District, yesterday, 16 drafted men passed the Board without exemption; 15 substitutes were accepted, and 18 were discharged from the draft -- 8 for physical disability, 3 for non-residence. 1 for alienage, 2 for unsuitableness of age, I because two of same family in the service, I was in the service, and 2 commuted. One man, ALMERIN L. ACKLEY, Jr., of Portsmouth, worked the substitute mine for three days, and presented the eleventh man, who was accepted, to his no small gratification.
lead_paragraph: In the First District, yesterday, 16 drafted men passed the Board without exemption; 15 substitutes were accepted, and 18 were discharged from the draft -- 8 for physical disability, 3 for non-residence. 1 for alienage, 2 for unsuitableness of age, I because two of same family in the service, I was in the service, and 2 commuted. abstract: Conscripts on the March
lead_paragraph: We learn by telegraph from Washington that a thousand conscripts a day are now arriving at the Army of the Potomac, and attaching themselves to the old regiments. "They go forward," says the telegram, "in excellent spirits." Substitutes are offering themselves at very cheap rates, both in Philadelphia and Washington, as well as at other points where drafting is going on. Prices range from one hundred to two hundred dollars, and cases are reported where persons voluntarily and freely offer themselves as substitutes for their drafted friends.

abstract: Within the last few weaks, says the Louisville Journal, scandal, involving the character of a military officer of rank in Edinburgh, and that of a young unmarried lady of highly respectable connection, has been matter of public comment.
lead_paragraph: -- Within the last few weaks, says the Louisville Journal, scandal, involving the character of a military officer of rank in Edinburgh, and that of a young unmarried lady of highly respectable connection, has been matter of public comment. It appears that the wife of the military officer concerned was suspicious of her husband's fidelity to herself and conduct toward the young lady in question, and that, a watch having been set, certain proofs, assumed to be undoubted, were obtained. The matter, however, did not rest here. The brother-in-law of the young lady, who holds an official position in the Edinburgh Rifle Volunteers, having got possession of a letter in which certain arrangements were proposed in the event of the officer being divorced from his present wife, came in contact with him in the New Club, and on his acknowledging the authenticity of the document, produced a horsewhip and soundly castigated him.

abstract: The trotting match for $1,000, mile heats, best three in five, between Gen. McClellan and lady Sheehan, took place yesterday afternoon on the Union Course, and was won by the General in three straight heats. The General went to wagon, and the Lady in harness; and although the time was remarkably fast, the inequality in the positions of the horses did not make it us interesting a race as many in which slower time is made.
lead_paragraph: The trotting match for $1,000, mile heats, best three in five, between Gen. abstract: On Saturday the Board of Enrollment for the Fourth Congressional District had not completed the hearing of claimants for exemption form the Fourteenth Ward. Although the Board has worked ...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday the Board of Enrollment for the Fourth Congressional District had not completed the hearing of claimants for exemption form the Fourteenth Ward. Although the Board has worked diligently from 8 o'clock in the morning until 5 o'clock in the afternoon, it has been found impossible to dispose of more than an average of sixty cases per day, and at the same time do justice to the Government and the citizen. The present week will be devoted to the fourteenth Ward, and the time of the citizens in other Wards will be extended until such time as the Board can reach their cases.

abstract: The, Never for Disunion
lead_paragraph: It was the special work of the leaders of the Southern rebellion, for several years before it broke out, to prepare the people of the South for its coming. This was done under various disguises. The "Commercial Convention," became the most usual, because it was the safest cloak under which the treasonable work could proceed. At the so-called "Commercial Convention," which marked the latter history of the South, some advance was made every year toward separation. Speeches were there made setting forth the superior resources of the South over any other country for supporting a powerful nation. The Free States were decried, and represented as being absolutely dependent on the South. And in this connection the revenue laws of the United States were denounced as being oppressive to the South, and devised with the sole view of enriching Northern merchants and manufacturers at the expense of Southern industry. The peculiar social and political theories of the Southern rebels, were shrewdly and constantly mixed in with these disquisitions on agriculture and commerce, and the South shown to be alien, not only in interest and feeling, from the North, but absolutely antagonistic and irreconciliable in the very framework and body of society. We were two totally distinct peoples, of incompatible temper, of widely diverse interests; and yet the Union bound the two together, and compelled the superior race, (the South,) to work, in order to support and enrich the inferior race, (the North.)
headline: {'main': 'The South Never for Disunion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The South Never for Disunion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Staten Island, New Dorp Barracks fired by incendiary
snippet: Staten Island, New Dorp Barracks fired by incendiary
lead_paragraph: These barracks, of which a detailed description was published in the TIMES a few days since, were fired about midnight Monday and nearly half destroyed. Col. LANSING, in command, does not account for the cause, but is actively encaged in investigating for it. By some it is ascribed to the friends of one of the soldiers who was in confinement, by others to disaffected recruits, and by others to parties who have been continually insubordinate since in the barracks.

abstract: Officer FERGUSON, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesderday took into custody HENRY TILTON, who is charged with having been a leader of the gang of men who made the attack upon Col. O'BRIEN on the second day of the riot, at the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty fourth-street.
lead_paragraph: Officer FERGUSON, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesderday took into custody HENRY TILTON, who is charged with having been a leader of the gang of men who made the attack upon Col. O'BRIEN on the second day of the riot, at the corner of Second-avenue and Thirty fourth-street. The prisoner was arraigned before Justice KELLY, and a complaint made against him by Mrs. A.M. MATHEWS, of No. 156 East Thirty-second-street. This lady swears that on the 14th of July last she saw the accused at the head of the mob make the attack on Col. OBRIEN. They sacked and plundered the residence of the Colonel and afterward murdered him in the most brutal manner.

abstract: The charges against Col. DeFOREST, of the Filth regiment, Harris cavalry, are for defrauding the Government of upward of sixty thousand dollars, which, it is alleged, he did by false bills of articles which were never purchased for his regiment. The Colonel is now in this City under arrest and will soon be tried, the Government having turned him over to the care of the United States District-Attorney.

abstract: The London Times, in discoursing of the French invasion of Mexico, says that the pervading idea in France is, ï¿½that wherever on the wide earth anything is to be amended or regulated, any wrong redressed, any oppression overthrown, any antiquated institution abolished, and succeeded by all that is clear and logical, there the bayonets of France are to glitter." If the bayonets of France wish to be kept busy in doing all these nice and logical things, we think there is plenty of occasion and opportunity for their active use in France itself, It is work directly the opposite of all this that French bayonets are employed upon in Mexico. And when the rebel sympathizers in Europe urge the Emperor to use his bayonets in sustaining the Southern Confederacy, they must be well aware that in that case the bayonets would be put to no such employment as redressing wrong, overthrowing oppression, abolishing antiquated institutions, or establishing lucidity and logic.

abstract: ARREST OF PICKPOCKET. A well-dressed young man, named GRORGE GRANT, well-known to the Police of this City as a suspicious character, was arrested yesterday by Officer CHRYSTAL, of the Ninth Precinct, ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF PICKPOCKET. -- A well-dressed young man, named GRORGE GRANT, well-known to the Police of this City as a suspicious character, was arrested yesterday by Officer CHRYSTAL, of the Ninth Precinct, charge with having stolen a pocket-book containing about $10, from Miss ELIZABETH DOUGLASS, of No. 464 Sixth-avenue. The latter was riding down town in a Sixth-avenue stage; on arriving at the corner of Eleventh-street, she discovered that her dress had been out about the pocket, and her pocket-book was gone. The prisoner who sat neither, at once started from the stage at quick pace. On the next block Miss D. found Officer CHRYSTAL to whom she made known her loss, and described the thief so accurately that that officer effected his arrest soon after. He was found secreted in the cellar of a place called the "Woodbine" in Sixth-avenue. No money was found upon him when searched by the officer. Justice KELLY committed him in default of $500 bail.

abstract: THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT. MARTIN RITTER, a native of Germany, residing in Van Brunt-street, was prostrated by the heat on Monday, and conveyed to the Long Island College Hospital, where he died yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: THE EFFECTS OF THE HEAT. -- MARTIN RITTER, a native of Germany, residing in Van Brunt-street, was prostrated by the heat on Monday, and conveyed to the Long Island College Hospital, where he died yesterday morning. Deceased was about 48 years of age....JOHN CORNELIA, a native of Ireland, died at his residence, No. 66 John-street, yesterday, from the effects of the heat. The deceased had recently landed, and on Monday commenced his first day's work In this country, at the gas-house, foot of Hudson-avenue....MARGARET BRANAGAN, wife of EDWARD BRANAGAN, residing at No. 154 Navy-street, died yesterday from the heat. She leaves several children. ....JOHN CARLTON residing at No. 4 Doughty-street, was sun-truck on Monday afternoon, and died the following night....THOMAS AGNEW, residing at No. 66 John-street, died on Monday night from the effect of the heat....Several other persons were prostrated by the heat, but the cases did not result fatally.

abstract: The "excavations," as they have been aptly termed by a cotemporary, which have been going on at the Comptroller's Office in regard to certain mat  ters of percentage on salaries charged and paid on political account to the Mozart fund are, we hope, ...
lead_paragraph: The "excavations," as they have been aptly termed by a cotemporary, which have been going on at the Comptroller's Office in regard to certain matters of percentage on salaries charged and paid on political account -- to the Mozart fund -- are, we hope, the initiative to investigations in matters of graver concern, and which -- as these certainly do not -- directly affect the public interests abd the City Treasury. As an amateur performances for our lively and really competent Comptroller, but of no earthly advantages to our citizens, this investigation may toe of service in the way of experience. When done with it, with a sense made keener and a wit sharpened, let him turn his attention and vigilance to matters of actual and public interest; to the plethoric contracts constantly being given out and paid for; to the sums needlessly disbursed from the Public Treasury to the political favorites and hangers-on of the Coal Hole; to the sinecures awarded to men of the same kidney. Certainly here are matters in which the public are interested, and wherein a revolution wrought by the Comptroller would be of general benefit and add to his re[???].

abstract: The Collapse of the in Europe
snippet: The Collapse of the in Europe
lead_paragraph: -- As the Confederacy collapses, so collapses the great Confederate fifteen million European loan. To ignorant and thoughtless men, the fortunes of the rebellion looked bright when the loan was first launched upon the market, and it sailed forth gaily and with well filled sails. It soon, however, began to reel and plunge under the influence of the stormy breezes from the West, and latterly it has plunged downward till it reached 20 discount. Even this fall is not at all in proportion to the fall in the rebel prospects, and it will not be until the value of the great loan is quoted on the bourses of Europe at zero, that the proper figure will be reached.

abstract: Capt. BROWER, First-avenue, corner of Fifth. street. Early on Monday morning the Captain, with his force, reported to Capt. PORTER, at Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. When reaching there the crowd was not large, but soon the rioters assembled in force, coming in fifties and hundreds from different sections, until swelled to thousands of excited men armed with clubs and other weapons.
lead_paragraph: Capt. BROWER, First-avenue, corner of Fifth. street. Early on Monday morning the Captain, with his force, reported to Capt. PORTER, at Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. When reaching there the crowd was not large, but soon the rioters assembled in force, coming in fifties and hundreds from different sections, until swelled to thousands of excited men armed with clubs and other weapons. The first overt act was the stoppage of the Third-avenue care, the taking off of the driver and horses, and compelling the passengers to get out. The force attempted to prevent this, but were driven back. Then ensued an attack on the Marshal's Office, a shower of stones breaking doors and windows, and finally the mob rushed into the building beating back the small force who valiantly opposed them, until flight or death were the alternatives. The force retreated to Forty-sixth-street, where they were engaged in Saving the occupants of the building and their property -- the premises having been fired -- until they were again beaten back by overwhelming numbers. Sergeant FINCH arrived about this time and took command, Capt. BROWER going to the Station-house. The Sergeant made, with his force a charge upon the mob, but failed to disperse them, and received a severe gash from a blow on the forehead, which subsequently laid him up, and his [???] was compelled to retreat. The mob was a huge one, thousands composing it, and the opposing force, bravely as they did, were entirely inadequate. After the discomfiture here they reported to headquarters, and in the evening, under Capt. BROWER, were at the Park with Inspector CARPENTER, where they made havoc upon the mob in the grand charge heretofore detailed, thence through Fourth Ward and to Central office for the night. On Tuesday this Precinct joined Capt. PETTY's command in the visit to the soap-factory in Sixteenth-street, and aided in restoring order in that section. They were also with Capt. HELMS' hazardous expedition in the second-avenue, and took a liberal hand in the severe fight there; they charged the building in which the stolen guns were stored, taking it after a savage fight, and recovering a large number of arms. At night Sergt. SLOTE and ten men were detailed for duty to Gen. WOOL, so remaining unlit quiet was restored. At midnight Capt. BROWER took command of 150 men, marching through the Eleventh, Thirteenth and Seventeenth Precincts, returning to headquarters Wednesday morning. At 9 A.M., in command of his own and the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Precine; forces, he proceeded to the scene of riot and murder in Thirty-second-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, dispersing the crowd and recovering the body of the colored man hung there, bringing it to headquarters.

abstract: Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT was officially received, yesterday, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. About 10 o'clock in the forenoon, he arrived off the yard, accompanied by Commodore PALMER, of the Hartford, and other officers. In the absence of Admiral PAULDING, Commodore RADFORD, Commandant of the New-York Naval Station, proceeded to welcome ...
lead_paragraph: Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT was officially received, yesterday, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. About 10 o'clock in the forenoon, he arrived off the yard, accompanied by Commodore PALMER, of the Hartford, and other officers. In the absence of Admiral PAULDING, Commodore RADFORD, Commandant of the New-York Naval Station, proceeded to welcome the hero of the Mississippi, and soon afterwards the chief officers of the post, Capt. PERCIVAL DRAYTON, Capt. WORDEN, of the Montauk, and Lieut.-Commander FILLERSOWNE, joined him. The distinguished visitor was most cordially greeted and congratulated on his brilliant career in the Mississippi. He replied to the warm eulogies of the officers very modestly. He was glad the people of the loyal Stated appreciated the difficult nature of the work performed by me East Gulf and Mississippi Squadron, and spoke favorably of the gallant seamen and marines attached to the different vessels, whose bravery and perseverance enabled their officers to undertake, hopefully, the most arduous enterprises, Having exchanged salutatory good wishes, the party visited the iron-clad Lehigh, the receiving-ship North Carolina and the Lyceum, the Admiral frequently expressing his pleasure at once more meeting with New-York officers.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR is not satisfied with President LINCOLN'S offer to accept the average quota from the four districts which he had claimed to be overburdened, until a second enrollment can test the accuracy of the first.
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR is not satisfied with President LINCOLN's offer to accept the average quota from the four districts which he had claimed to be overburdened, until a second enrollment can test the accuracy of the first. He returns to the assault with new statistics. Whether his figures are correct or not, or whether they are not reconcilable with a strict correctness of the enrollment, in the lack of all details, we are not able to say. It there is any real reason to suspect error. President LINCOLN will undoubtedly pay it due hoed. He has already given the amplest proof of a disposition to exclude every chance of injustice or unfairness in the premises. There will be no trouble about any reasonable adjustment.

abstract: Officers BOYLE and JOHNSON, of the Sixth Precinct, discovered a fire, about 10 O'clock last night, issuing from the third story of building No. 257 Canalstreet, owned by Messrs. NEIDIG, DECKER  Co., and occupied by them as a furniture and bedding warehouse.
lead_paragraph: Officers BOYLE and JOHNSON, of the Sixth Precinct, discovered a fire, about 10 o'clock last night, issuing from the third story of building No. 257 Canal-street, owned by Messrs. NEIDIG, DECKER & CO., and occupied by them as a furniture and bedding warehouse. The building and contents were entirely destroyed. Their loss on stock is estimated at $25,000, and on the building at $12,000. Insured for $43,000 in the St. Mark's, St. Nicholas, Bowery, Hamilton, Brooklyn, Williamsburgh City, Relief and Liverpool and London Insurances. Building No. 255 is occupied by the same firm, the stock contained therein being badly mamaged by water. The flames spread to the upper portion of building No. 259, occupied in the upper part by Messrs. COVEL, WESTON & SCHITCHTING wood moulders. The lower portion of the building is occupied by HUTCHINGS & WICKERSHAM, ornamental iron-workers. Their damage is not ascertained. The building is owned by Mr. LYONS, gunsmith, on Broadway, and is damaged about $2,000. Up to the time of going to press the fire had not been extinguished. Adjoining building No. 259 is the Devlin building, in which are stored $300,000 worth of Government property. This building was saved only by the untiring exertions of the firemen. Officer Dwyer, of the Sixteenth Precinct, and Mr. JACOB STARRECK of Patrol Insurance No. 2 were very severely injured by the dummy from the third story falling upon them. Mr. STARRECK had his ribs crushed in, and was injured near the spine. Both parties were taken to the hospital. A member of Engine Company No. 29 was knocked down and run over by Engine No. 34, in Greene-street near prince. The machine passed over his breast, breaking his collar-bone and inflicting other injuries. He was taken to Dr. TURNER's on the corner of Prince and Spring streets, by Assistant Fire Marshal BAKER and other firemen, and afterwards to the Station-house.

abstract: London Times on Archbishop Hughes' Speech to New-York Rioters
snippet: London Times on Archbishop Hughes' Speech to New-York Rioters
lead_paragraph: It is really worth while to study the speech of Archbishop HUGHES to the rioters of New-York, if only to learn how little Irish character is modified by residence in America. When an Archbishop comes forward in the capacity of the [???]r pietate gravis to still the passions of an angry mob, we must not look for logic, or even for any very high flight of common sense, but we may assume that he will use the gravest arguments that are likely to tell upon his audience. We should naturally expert a forcible and serious appeal to the motives of patriotism, of humanity, and of religion, and a careful abstinence from every topic calculated to awaken dangerous prejudices and fierce antipathies. A Bishop is a peace maker by profession, and though our own spiritual peers have not, always been the most backward to draw the sword in a national quarrel, we cannot fancy them flattering an English crowd into obedience to the law by vulgar tirades against France or America. They would be restrained from doing so by a sense of their own dignity, but they would also feel the hopelessness of carrying their hearers with them. Englishmen in a state of excitement cannot, indeed, argue, but they know what argument is, and they will not cheer claptrap, if it be not only incoherent but irrevelent. Irishmen, it we may just by what their demagogues, both lay and spiritual, address to them by way of paternal warning, prefer this Kind or oratory to the semblance of reasoning, and are more easily dissuaded from committing crimes in one quarter by receiving a plenary indulgence for the future gratincation or their wengeance in another. At all events, hatred of England was the key-note of Archbishop HUGHES's specific harangue, the report of which sounds too familiar to a Saxon ear for us to doubt that it was pitched in the strain which an Irish populace loves best whether at home or abroad, and delivered with a rich Milesian brogue.
headline: {'main': "The London Times on Archbishop Hughes' Special to the New-York Rioters.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The London Times on Archbishop Hughes' Special to the New-York Rioters.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A Defence of, in Reference to Lee's Escape after Gettysburgh
snippet: A Defence of, in Reference to Lee's Escape after Gettysburgh
lead_paragraph: After the battle of Gettysburgh, when LEE retreated through the mountain passes, MEADE's army was greatly exhausted by three days' fighting and its previous forced marches, and was also greatly reduced in numbers, having lost nearly twenty thousand men, killed, wounded and missing, saying nothing of stragglers. Directly to pursue LEE through the mountains, in narrow passes, would have enabled him, with a strong rearguard, to have held MEADE in check till he could have reassembled his army in the Cumberland Valley, and then thrown his massoe the heads of his columns when he forced his way through, or he could have detained, MEADE so long in the mountains, that he could easily have gotten away with the main portion of his army, if he so desired.

abstract: Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, Reopening of the
snippet: Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, Reopening of the
lead_paragraph: -- The announcement is made by the officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad that that great thoroughfare is opened anew for freight and travel, through its entire length, from Baltimore to Wheeling. Three times since the beginning of the war this road has suffered the ravages of the rebel army, which, each time, broke up its business and indicted enormous loss. But the injuries perpetrated during the late invasion were heaviest, and apparently designed to be irreparable for many months to come. Every bridge -- and there are twelve large ones -- in a distance of eighty miles, was destroyed. Over 18,000 new ties were dug up and burned, and hundreds of tons of new and heavy rails burnt, bent, and made unserviceable. Thirty miles of telegraph wire were taken away or destroyed, and most of the supporting poles in the district, occupied or commanded by the rebels, cut down.

abstract: The Election
lead_paragraph: Since the election in Kentucky has taken place and the result become known, we have the very singular spectacle of all parties out of the State by turns claiming and repudiating the success. This comes of inattention to the facts of the canvass as developed in the resolutions of conventions that nominated candidates, and in the speeches and letters of candidates themselves. There is no misunderstanding in the State of Kentucky as to the position of the successful candidates, and there should be none abroad. What that position is, we indicated in these columns on the 6th instant, and here more fully repeat and set forth.

abstract: have proved in a thousand ways their hostility to the Constitution of the United States and their contempt for the principles on which it is based.
lead_paragraph: have proved in a thousand ways their hostility to the Constitution of the United States and their contempt for the principles on which it is based. But the latest and most characteristic instance of their disregard of principles they were once hound to observe, has just been witnessed in Mobile, in the administration of "cruel and unusual punishment" on a poor clerk in a clothing store. This clerk sold to a paroled Vicksburgh prisoner a shirt, and preferred to take in payment $2 50 in greenbacks to $25 in Confederate money! The story getting to the ears of the Provost-Marshal, the offending clerk was incontinently hauled up and sentenced to be sent (at Confederate expense, of course,) to the North," i.e., to the United States! This inhuman decree was immediately set in execution: and the rebel newspapers are triumphing over the result, in shocking glee, and saying, "Served him right." The mercantile martyr, we are happy to believe, is doing as well as could be expected.

abstract: The following cases of death from sun-stroke were reported yesterday at the Coroner's Office. In addition to those which bave proved fatal, there are about fifty persons reported by the Police as having been prostrated by the intense heat within the last two days.
lead_paragraph: The following cases of death from sun-stroke were reported yesterday at the Coroner's Office. In addition to those which have proved fatal, there are about fifty persons reported by the Police as having been prostrated by the intense heat within the last two days. Many of these will, no doubt, result in death. The hospitals are rapidly filling up with men, women and children who are suffering from the effects of the exceedingly warm weather.

abstract: All the vessels of war engaged in the late operations in the Mississippi are to be surveyed, in obedience to official orders, and such of them as need repairs are to be sent home.
lead_paragraph: All the vessels of war engaged in the late operations in the Mississippi are to be surveyed, in obedience to official orders, and such of them as need repairs are to be sent home. This is practically withdrawing me present fleet, as nearly every ship composing it has suffered severely in action and must be relieved. The East Gulf blockading squadron and the Mississippi squadron proper conjointly acted in the great battles which have resulted in the opening of our most valuable river. We subjoin a list of all the vessels and their commanders:

abstract: A new and perplexing question is about to arise and add to the embarrassments of the Government. All the secession exiles sent away South from St. Louis and other loyal places, were ordered not to put themselves again within the Union lines during the war, under penalty of being dealt with as traitors. But the "Union lines" do not remain where they were when the exiles were sent over, but are continually advancing, and now include again many of the exiles that lately supposed themselves safely in Dixie -- having gone away down into the Cotton States on the Gulf. The question arises, is the decree of banishment canceled by the advance of the Union arms? Are the exiles at liberty when placed again within the Union lines by the voluntary act of the Government? Or must they run away, so as to keep themselves banished?

abstract: Capt. G.T. PORTER, East Fifty-ninth-street, near Third-avenue. The riots commenced in this Precinct, an excited crowd collecting about 9 o'clock A.M. at the Provost-Marshal's office, corner of Fortysixth-street and Third-avenue. This was soon swelled by arrivals from all directions,until thousands had assembled, many of them armed with clubs and other weapons and all demonstrative of mischief.
lead_paragraph: Capt. G.T. PORTER, East Fifty-ninth-street, near Third-avenue. The riots commenced in this Precinct, an excited crowd collecting about 9 o'clock A.M. at the Provost-Marshal's office, corner of Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. This was soon swelled by arrivals from all directions,until thousands had assembled, many of them armed with clubs and other weapons and all demonstrative of mischief. Capt. PORTER repaired to the office, stationing a portion of his force -- in all sixty men -- in front and the balance inside of the building. The drafting commenced at 10 1/4 A.M., and was uninterrupted for some twenty minutes. Meantime the mob outside increased to huge proportions, were feeding their excitement with threats and execrations, and suddenly turned their attention to the Third-avenue cars, one of which was passing down. The cry "Stop the cars!" was raised, a rush was made, the drivers taken off, horses detached and the passengers compelled to abdicate, two of them relieved of their watches; a section of the Police went to the rescue, and were assailed with clubs and stones, overpowered and driven back. Having committed the first overt act the mob became frenzied, and at once made a rush on to the Marshal's office, assailing the force on the street, driving them into the building, and showering into the windows stones and all kinds of missiles. To fight or to keep at bay the thousands was an impossibility. The Marshal and his clerks, with the Police, were driven back with clubs through the building and escaped from the rear. In a few moments the furniture was destroyed, piled up and fired, and the building was in flames so speedily that two families living up stairs barely escaped with their lives. The Police repaired to the adjoining buildings and attempted to save the property in them. They were fiercely attacked and driven away. The firemen reached the scene, but were prevented from doing anything. The Chief Engineer was present and addressed the mob, urging them to allow the firemen to go to work. Meantime the fire had spread rapidly, and three of a row of brick buildings wore in flames; the mob yielded to Chief DECKER's appeal, the companies went to work and the fourth house was saved. It was about this time that the rioters made the first serious demonstrations against the Police. Hitherto in the progress to arson and pillage, they had driven them away, but had not concentrated against them; now they massed on the Third-avenue and made a furious attack on the force, with pistols, clubs and stones. Very soon Officer COOK was knocked down and seriously injured, and several others badly hurt. The aid sent to Capt. PORTER from below could not reach him and were themselves engaged with another portion of the mob; resistance against the over whelming numbers was madness, and after a brief but severe fight the force broke and fled, the mob masters of the situation. The men recollected at the Station-house, and, in citizen's dress, revisited the section where they were defeated, and succeeded in bringing off those of the injured who had remained there. In the evening the entire force were ordered to headquarters, and were with Sergeant COPELAND's command, to Clarkson-street, for the recovery of the body of a colored man murdered there.

abstract: -- The World and the News accuse the TIMES of mutilating and distorting the letter of Mr. VALLANDIGHAM to the Democratic meeting at Toledo. It were demeaning to reply to such a charge; but we may say (1) that the transcript of the letter which we published on Saturday last was the same throughout as that which the World was enterprising enough to publish on Monday, or two days after. We have compared the two copies and find them identical in every sentence, with the exception of one or two insignificant telegraphic blunders, which vary in each journal. As for the News, we do not know whether it published the letter in any shape. We may further say (2) that the copy of the letter which we published was clipped from the Cincinnati Commercial, to which journal it was telegraphed from Toledo, with such abbreviations -- we suppose to save expense -- as the telegraphic agent of the Western journal saw fit to make. The TIMES publishes all important documents of all public men, and of every party promptly, and, so far as we can, fully; and we do not imagine that the Vallandigham journals will gain anything by imputing to others the perversity and dishonesty which are their own characteristics.
