abstract: -- The announcement the appointment of Brig.-Gen. G.K. WARREN, Chief of Topographical Engineers, to a Major-Generalship of Volunteers, will be received with unusual gratification by his brother officers, and by all who have had the opportunity to know the high soldierly qualities of Gen. WARREN. Though yet very young, (not exceeding thirty, we think,) he has still by pure merit reached in the army the very highest rounds of fame. He is a West Pointer, having, we believe, been an instructor at the Academy. At the outbreak of the war, he raised a regiment -- the Warren Zouaves -- which soon rose to be regarded as the finest Volunteer regiment in the service, and enjoyed the distinction of being brigaded with the Regulars. He then commanded what was regarded as the finest Volunteer brigade in the service, and at its head displayed the highest military talent throughout the Peninsular campaign. At Chancellorsville as a Staff officer (Chief of Engineers) he showed himself on a larger field, and took even his friends by surprise by his brilliant gallantry, his fertility of resources and general military ability. His conduct at Gettysburg, where he acted as Gen. MEADE's Chief of Staff, added still further to his fame. It is within our personal knowledge that Gen. WARREN is looked upon by his fellow academicians, (who have a high and severe standard of judgment of their own,) as displaying more of that faculty, or combination of faculties, for which genius is the only name, than any of his compeers in the army. His appointment to the Major-Generalship is the fitting reward of pure merit. The double star does not glitter on the shoulders of a more accomplished or a more promising soldier.

abstract: ARREST OF A DEAD MAN; THE DEAD AND LIVING. Ex-policeman CUSICK, a fellow some time since turned out of the force, was arrested and lodged in Headquarters yesterday on charge of riot, arson,  It is alleged also that he was one of the dastardly assailants of Superintendent KENNEDY. After the riots he was dead and buried killed by the Police.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A DEAD MAN; THE DEAD AND LIVING. -- Ex-policeman CUSICK, a fellow some time since turned out of the force, was arrested and lodged in Headquarters yesterday on charge of riot, arson, &c. It is alleged also that he was one of the dastardly assailants of Superintendent KENNEDY. After the riots he was dead and buried -- killed by the Police. That is, by himself and friends, the report was widely circulated that he had been fatally injured in the invaded Districts, by the Police, had crawled into a stone yard and dissolved his connection with the mob, and the world generally, by laying down and soon after dying; that he was gathered up, conveyed to his family, waked over and decently buried thereafter. All this was of course a lie, manufactured to divert the search for him. Despite it, however, he has been arrested, and was brought into Headquarters, and placed under lock and key, in disgrace and with ignominy, and also with the prospects of State Prison before him, about the time that a member of the force with which he had been connected -- Officer McINTYRE, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct -- was being taken from the building and escorted with all Metropolitan honors to the tomb. This officer had lost his life in the preservation of the law which the other and his kind had violated. The one was loved and honored -- these expressions are not stereotyped ones in speaking of McINTYRE -- by every officer and comrade in his Precinct; the other, a recreant, and despised and contemned by all men as a ruffian, rioter and arsonist. Which in their condition is the most to be envied?

WHITTEN, alias Whitter, indicated for leading the riot against the Tribune office, was brought on for trial,and occupied the entire day. abstract: Among the passengers who left our shores yesterday for Europe, on the Cunard steamer Scotia, was the Marquis DE MONTHOLON, the recent Consul-General of France at this port, where he has held his high and honorable post for more than nine years. During that considerable period Mr. DE MONTHOLON has had many delicate and difficult questions to adjust, and has, throughout, borne himself with distinguished tact and ability. His absence, which circumstances may render final, will leave a void difficult to fill.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER. Yesterday noon a colored man named SAMUEL JOHNSON, was arrested in Brooklyn, E.D., charged with killing an old man named SAMUEL BRAEUER, residing at No. 7 Marshall street. It appears that in a difficulty the old man was knocked down and fell, striking his head heavily, and died shortly afterward. The Coroner will investigate the case to-day.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE MURDER. -- Yesterday noon a colored man named SAMUEL JOHNSON, was arrested in Brooklyn, E.D., charged with killing an old man named SAMUEL BRAEUER, residing at No. 7 Marshall-street. It appears that in a difficulty the old man was knocked down and fell, striking his head heavily, and died shortly afterward. The Coroner will investigate the case to-day.

abstract: The political character of JOHN CONNESS, United States Senator from California, has been authoritatively settled. A distinguished member of the Cabinet to-day said: "The California Senator is in character a combination in equal parts of BEN WADE and DAVE BRODERICK. He is a man of conscience and of courage." Mr. CONNESS, before going to visit his friends in Illinois, left behind his assurance that the Unionists of California would carry that State in the coming election by 50,000 majority.

abstract: -- Marshal MURRAY has arrested RICHARD FOSTER and JOHN HOWE, on charge of inducing private SMITH, of the Sprague cavalry, to desert. All three were recognized there, taken into custody, and brought back.

abstract: We received and published a report of a battle off Schoodac Island, on Thursday, July 23, giving some particulars of it. abstract: Reconstruction, The Question of
lead_paragraph: We have repeatedly warned our readers against supposing that the rebellion was crushed by the recent victories of the Union troops. Much remains yet to be done before the military power of the rebel Confederacy will be so far broken as to make the question of peace and reconstruction one of practical politics. The rebels have strong armies still in the field; they have strong positions and important seaports still in their possession; they have the active and effective support of England and France to stimulate their hopes and prolong their efforts, -- and they have the still more effective and important support of a powerful allied party in the Northern States. All these difficulties stand in the way of peace, and must be removed before peace can be restored. Until they are out of the way, we have but one practical question -- but one important and imperative duty; we must bend all our efforts to their removal. We must aid the Government in the prosecution of the war. We must aid it in strengthening our armies, in defeating the designs of its foes, in quelling all open or disguised hostility wherever it may exist. And until this result has been accomplished, and the military and political power of the rebellion has been broken, we regard as premature and as mischievous any sharp and angry controversy concerning the terms of peace or the basis of the political reconstruction by which peace is to be followed.

abstract: The United States revenue transport steamer Flora, Commander W.A. BOOTH, arrived here last evening from Charleston. She reports that she left Port Royal on Friday, the 7th, and passed by Charleston at 11 o'clock that evening, when heavy and rapid firing was heard. The bombarding was between Fort Sumter and Morris Island, and the sky was brilliantly illuminated by the shells.

abstract: The greatest activity combined with the most profound secresy is manifested in the military circles of our City, and in fact of the Department of the East generally. The most absolute harmony of purpose and of action appears to exist between the National and State authorities. It is a significant fact that yesterday Gov. SEYMOUR issued orders for the issuing of large numbers of new arms to several of the City regiments; that the order is being executed rapidly and without public display.

abstract: The report of the operations of the Army of the Tennessee, from the day when Maj.-Gen. GRANT assumed immediate command of the expedition against Vicksburgh to the surrender of that place, is published in the TIMES this morning. He says that it is a striking feature, so far as his observation of the present volunteer army of the United States goes, that there is nothing which men are called upon to do, mechanical or professional, that accomplished adepts cannot be found to do in almost every regiment. He cannot close his report without an expression of thankfulness for his good fortune in being placed in cooperation with an officer of the navy who accorded to every move that seemed for the interest and success of our arms, his hearty and energetic support. "Admiral PORTER," he adds, "and the very efficient officers under him, have ever shown the greatest readiness in their cooperation, no matter what was to be done or what risk to be taken, either by their men or their vessels. Without this prompt and cordial support my movements would have been much embarrassed, if not wholly defeated."
lead_paragraph: The report of the operations of the Army of the Tennessee, from the day when Maj.-Gen. abstract: The present condition of military operations, more especially in the West, are bringing into peculiar prominence an arm of the service which may almost be called the creation of this war namely, "mounted infantry." It is, as the name indicates, a hermaphrodite organization, combining certain peculiarities of the cavalry arm with certain peculiarities of the infantry arm.
lead_paragraph: The present condition of military operations, more especially in the West, are bringing into peculiar prominence an arm of the service which may almost be called the creation of this war -- namely, "mounted infantry." It is, as the name indicates, a hermaphrodite organization, combining certain peculiarities of the cavalry arm with certain peculiarities of the infantry arm. It shares the nature of cavalry so far that the men are mounted; but the horse is merely designed as the means of locomotion, and takes no part in the shock of battle. When they meet the enemy, mounted infantry dismount and fight on foot; and to this end they are armed with the rifle instead of with the carbine, pistol and sabre, as are the cavalry.

Superintendent KENNEDY, Commissioner ACTON, Inspectors CARPENTER and DILKS were in attendance. A force of three hundred policemen acted as an escort. abstract: I hear that it is the intention of those interested in the Peterhoff to carry the case up to a higher Court. The decision just rendered against the vessel and cargo is claimed to be unwarranted, and to rest on no reliable basis. Suspicion, it is alleged, was largely employed in making up the verdict, and vigorous measures to upset it will be made before the captors are allowed a division of the spoils.

abstract: Exactly at 1 o'clock yesterday the United States steamer Hartford, late flagship of Admiral FARRAGUT, arrived at the Brooklyn Navy-yard amid one of the most exciting demonstrations witnessed there for some years. The precincts of the yard were crowded long before the vessel got up the river; and as she neared the wharf the docks were literally crammed with spectators, among whom were a large number of ladies. Naval officers of every rank and grade assembled in uniform and undress to witness the anchorage. At about 1 o'clock the vessel came up to the buoy, and on stopping the crew of the receiving-ship North Carolina and the sailors of several other vessels in the yard sprang into the rigging, and tumultuously cheered her. The spectators on the wharf also joined in the boisterous welcome, in return to which the crew of the Hartford gave three cheers and a "tiger" for New-York, the Union, Admiral PAULDING, &c. On anchoring the ship was boarded by the officers of the station and by an immense number of male and female friends of her officers and crew. She is now moored opposite the long dock, and will remain there for some time. Her ship's company will receive liberty and the officers be detached. The marines will be transferred to the barracks in charge of Major GARLAND, who will see that they are properly taken care of. The Hartford is to be thoroughly overhauled and repaired.
lead_paragraph: Exactly at 1 o'clock yesterday the United States steamer Hartford, late flagship of Admiral FARRAGUT, arrived at the Brooklyn Navy-yard amid one of the most exciting demonstrations witnessed there for some years. On anchoring the ship was boarded by the officers of the station and by an immense number of male and female friends of her officers and crew. The marines will be transferred to the barracks in charge of Major GARLAND, who will see that they are properly taken care of. The Hartford is to be thoroughly overhauled and repaired.

abstract: THE ONE MILLION DOLLAR CONSCRIPTION LOAN. The Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council, appointed to make arrangements for the loan of one million of dollars, to be applied to the paying of exemption for men of large families who should be drafted, held a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday morning for the purpose of receiving the replies of the Brooklyn Banks in relation to the loan.
lead_paragraph: THE ONE MILLION DOLLAR CONSCRIPTION LOAN. -- The Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council, appointed to make arrangements for the loan of one million of dollars, to be applied to the paying of exemption for men of large families who should be drafted, held a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday morning for the purpose of receiving the replies of the Brooklyn Banks in relation to the loan. There were present Aldermen TERNAN, NEW-MAN, PERRY and NODYNE; Mayor KALBFLEISCH, and Tax-Commissioner O'RORKE. The Mayor stated that he had received replies from the Banks, some verbal and some written, but all to the same effect, respectfully declining to take any portion of the loan. No reason was given, but the general impression is, that the refusal of the Banks is based upon the fact that the Common Council have no legal authority to authorize the loan; and if authorized and taken, it will depend upon contingencies whether or not the next Legislature will legalize it. It was suggested, in Committee, that a special meeting of the Aldermen be called, and the resolutions so modified as to offer bounties to volunteers instead of paying for exempting men from the draft; but after consultation, it was decided to adopt the Mayor's proposition to advertise for a loan from the public. It was finally agreed to issue proposals to the following effect:

abstract: -- We give the report of Judge-Advocate WATERBURY concerning the draft in this State, which was referred to by Gov. SEYMOUR in his second letter to the President. It is a bitterly partisan document throughout, and we are sorry to see that an officer holding such an important position in the military system of the State, and who by aiding or by embarrassing the Government in its severe and difficult labors, may exercise a beneficial or a baneful influence upon the National cause, should have so far prostituted his office to aid the purposes of party. He openly charges that the whole scheme of drafting in this State was one of conscious fraud -- from any knowledge or responsibility of which, however, he relieves the President, the Provost-Marshal-General, and all the proper authorities, and blames it upon the "irresponsible cabal outside." Even amid his perversions and partisanship, he is compelled to confess that the officers of the Government were determined upon fairness and equity. The President was anxious to obtain a knowledge of every wrong or injustice, and earnest and emphatic in the assurance that every error pointed out to him should be corrected, and he remarked to the Judge-Advocate that he "would not permit either a real or an apparent fraud." The Provost-Marshal-General also was emphatically of the same views and sentiments. Under these circumstances, we do not see that the local or State authorities could have found the least difficulty in at once rectifying every mistake -- if mistakes there were. We have already given facts which contradict or greatly modify many of the statements and deductions in this letter; and it is quite evident that the whole case, and all the statistics, are set forth in such a manner as to sub-serve other purposes than those of justice and patriotism. It cannot be too widely known, or too frequently repeated, however, that whether there may have been mistakes on the part of officers, or intentional wrong on the part of the "outside cabal," the President has, by the modification of the quotas and the provision for a new enrollment, taken the most careful measures to set all to rights, and secure equality to every district and every party. This simple fact obviates every difficulty and removes every quibble of the Judge-Advocate, in regard to the future enforcement of the draft.

abstract: The Committee established in this City immediately after the first battle of Bull Run, or about two years ago, to collect funds for the benefit of the widows and orphans of the Seventy-ninth regiment N.Y.S.M., (or Highland Guard,) held their annual pic-nic or festival at Jones' Wood yesterday. The beauty and greatly diminished heat of the weather favored this praiseworthy and popular fete, and we are happy to say that from 10 A.M., the hour of commencement, until 8 P.M., the hour of its close, the merry-making was one of the liveliest and gayest that even Scottish hilarity could produce. The Regiment Relief Committee, as it is called, consists of a number of gentlemen who have united voluntarily for the noble object already indicated. Although but in the beginning of the third year of their labors, they have already applied in the first year $1,000, in the second year $1,500, and propose for the third year to dispense $l,800 for the purposes of their benevolent undertaking. Three months ago, they reported in the Scottish American Journal the possession of a fund of $800 in hand, and their Treasurer, Lieut. THOMAS R. SANDERSON, last night estimated the proceeds of the festival at $1,000. The Chairman of the Committee is the gallant and well-known Capt. WM. BRUCE, and its Secretary Mr. JAMES NICHOLOSON, to whose exertions much of its success is due.

abstract: -- Major-Gen. ULYSSES S. GRANT's "report of the operations of the Army of the Tennessee from the day he assumed command of the expedition against Vicksburgh to the surrender of that place," will be read with intense interest by every reader of the TIMES. It is a document for the present hour and for all time. It is full, clear, vivid, able and modest. His gallant army and his subordinate commanders deserve all the praise he gives them, and he himself commands honor from the whole country and the world. Those who from the fragmentary details of the correspondents, and the contradictory dispatches of the telegraph, were unable to gain an accurate and comprehensive idea of the splendid operations at Vicksburgh while they were in progress, will find the whole thing set forth here with the skill of a master.

abstract: The Auburn Advertiser says that five wagonloads of conscripts, from Lyons and other towns in Wayne County, arrived in that city yesterday morning, to the tune of "Marching Along," rendered in sonorous tones from the occupants of the leading wagon, as they drove up to the Exchange for refreshments to man and beast -- hay for the latter and good dinners for the former. abstract: REMOVING A PUMP. -- Mr. WM. G. BOGGS appeared before Justice BO[???]RUM yesterday, on the complaint of Mr. DAN[???] MCLAU[???]LIN, Alderman of the Second Ward, on the charge of violating the ordinance in removing a pump and filling up a well in front of premises in Front street, between Fulton and James streets. Mr. BOGGS is the business manager of a newspaper to be started in this city. A building in Front-street is now being remodeled and fitted up for a printing office. A vault under the sidewalk being necessary for the steam apparatus to work the presses, an excavation was made after obtaining a permit from the proper officer. Authority was also obtained from the Mayor to remove the well and pump in front of the building. This, pump was a convenience to the residents of the vicinity, and objection is made to its removal. The Alderman made the complaint therefore on behalf of some of his constituents. The complainant and defendant gave their evidence, and the Justice reserved his decision.

abstract: This annual match was commenced yesterday morning at Hoboken; and, as we anticipated, the Bostonians, fatigued as they were with the two previous days' cricketing under the intense heat, were entirely overmatched by the fresh team of the strongest players in the country outside the St. George's Club, which were pitted against these amateurs by the New-Yorkers. O'Brien's and Martin's bowling was much less effective than in the St. George's match, although Haigh's wicket-keeping had much improved, and Martin's useless left hand compelled his retirement from the field at times, he having missed an easy chance of catching out Hammond when he had only scored five runs. Sadler also gave a catch, which was badly missed by another fielder. At sunset the score stood: New-York, 126 runs, of which Hammond scored 37, and Sadler 28; Boston stood 49 runs, of which Haigh scored 11.

Sadler also gave a catch, which was badly missed by another fielder. At sunset the score stood: New-York, 126 runs, of which Hammond scored 37, and Sadler 28; Boston stood 49 runs, of which Haigh scored 11.

abstract: MOVEMENT FOR AN ARSENAL. -- At the meeting of the Board of Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County, yesterday afternoon, one of the members, Mr. JOHN MCGUIGAN, offered a resolution, which was adopted, for the appointment of a Committee to ascertain and report to the Board the probable cost for the erection of an arsenal for the use of the county. Messrs. MCGUIGAN, DENNING, DUER and Col. ABEL SPEAR were appointed said Committee. They were instructed to confer with officers of the Government with a view of procuring, if possible, the old United States Arsenal and grounds located at Hudson City.
lead_paragraph: MOVEMENT FOR AN ARSENAL. -- At the meeting of the Board of Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County, yesterday afternoon, one of the members, Mr. JOHN MCGUIGAN, offered a resolution, which was adopted, for the appointment of a Committee to ascertain and report to the Board the probable cost for the erection of an arsenal for the use of the county. Messrs. MCGUIGAN, DENNING, DUER and Col. ABEL SPEAR were appointed said Committee. They were instructed to confer with officers of the Government with a view of procuring, if possible, the old United States Arsenal and grounds located at Hudson City.

abstract: -- Thomas Addis Emmet, Esq., a much respected member of the Bar in this City, died on Wednesday at his residence, Astoria, L.I., at the age of sixty-five. Mr. Emmet was a nephew of Robert Emmet, the Irish patriot and martyr to liberty, who made the name illustrious, and the son of Thos. Addis Emmet, who, thirty-two years since, was suddenly stricken down white engaged in his professional labors, and whose monument at St. Paul's Church is daily seen by thousands as they pass through Broadway. Mr. Emmet was a quiet, unassuming gentleman, pursuing the even tenor of his way through life, being careful only to transmit the legacy, priceless above political or social distinction, of a good name to his children. He was for a number of years a Master in Chancery, an office which he filled with ability. In early life he married a very estimable young lady, a member of one of our oldest, most respected and wealthy families. Mr. Emmet was a man of domestic habits, warmly attached to his family, and has been for a number of years a communicant of the Protestant Episcopal Church in which he was born. His funeral takes place at Astoria on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: -- Thomas Addis Emmet, Esq., a much respected member of the Bar in this City, died on Wednesday at his residence, Astoria, L.I., at the age of sixty-five. Mr. Emmet was a nephew of Robert Emmet, the Irish patriot and martyr to liberty, who made the name illustrious, and the son of Thos. Addis Emmet, who, thirty-two years since, was suddenly stricken down white engaged in his professional labors, and whose monument at St. Paul's Church is daily seen by thousands as they pass through Broadway. Mr. Emmet was a quiet, unassuming gentleman, pursuing the even tenor of his way through life, being careful only to transmit the legacy, priceless above political or social distinction, of a good name to his children. He was for a number of years a Master in Chancery, an office which he filled with ability. abstract: For August, from Le Follet
lead_paragraph: The Court of General Sessions adjourned yes-day for the Term, having been in session nearly two weeks. The Court has been mainly occupied during the present Term in the trial of cases growing out of the late riots. There are many indictments yet pending against participators in the riots, and many complaints are on file in the District Attorney's office, on Which no indictments have yet been found; but owing to the extreme heat of the weather, and to the fact that in many of the riot cases the prosecuting authorities desire time to perfect the chain of evidence against the parties under arrest, the Recorder concluded not to continue the August Term of the Court any longer than two weeks. Enough cases have been tried, however, during these two weeks to give the rioters a foretaste of the doom that awaits them, and to serve as an example to such as may be disposed to renew the scenes which were witnessed in this City last month. In all the cases tried during this Term, of persons charged with crime committed during the riots, there has been only one acquittal, and that was in the case of a man who was proved to have been forced to join the mob against his will, and also escaped from the rioters as soon as he got a chance. In one case the jury did not agree, and in all the other cases tried the jury promptly found a verdict of guilty. The cases which remained pending at the adjournment of the Court were, on motion of the District-Attorney, transferred to the Court of Oyer and Terminer, which holds its next regular session in October. More important cases than any that have been tried during the last week will be brought on at that term -- cases of murder and arson committed during the riots -- the details of which, when brought out by the testimony, will cause the community to stand aghast with horror. It is to be hoped that a Judge will occupy the bench of the Oyer and Terminer who will perform his duty to the public with the same fearlessness, impartiality and justice that have characterized the course of Recorder HOFFMAN during the recent trials.

abstract: John Jay, Receiver, vs. W.H. Degroot et al. -- This was a motion made by the defendant to vacate a Judgment entered by the plaintiff against the defendants for the deficiency under a decree of foreclosure. The grounds of the motion were, that there had been a verbal agreement by the plaintiff not to enter the judgment, and that in pursuance of such agreement, the defendant had paid a claim in suit against the plaintiff, and thereby satisfied the deficiency for which the judgment was entered.
lead_paragraph: John Jay, Receiver, vs. W.H. abstract: Gold Mines, New, in the West
snippet: Gold Mines, New, in the West
lead_paragraph: The fact that the entire range of Rocky Mountains, extending from the Mexican States northward to the Russian possessions, are gold-bearing, is so well attested now as to leave no doubter remaining. The only question is, on which side of the mountains, or within what mountain basins, are the deposits of precious metals the richer. California long bore the palm, and obscured all previous visions of fabulous wealth by the profusion of its placer yields. But, in the course of time, Nevada Territory revealed mines that put the most dazzling exhibits of California in the background.

abstract: Here are two wonderful stories. Says the Journal de Constantinople: "One evening last week two young men of the Isle of Prinkipo were returning in a calque from a sporting excursion on the coast of Asia, when they suddenly heard a noise for which they could not account; but soon after they ...
lead_paragraph: -- Here are two wonderful stories. Says the Journal de Constantinople: "One evening last week two young men of the Isle of Prinkipo were returning in a calque from a sporting excursion on the coast of Asia, when they suddenly heard a noise for which they could not account; but soon after they perceived over their heads an enormous bird, the sight of which filled them with alarm. Seizing their guns they both fired at it, and were still more amazed when they heard broken words and cries which could only proceed from human organs. They at once steered for the spot where the supposed bird had fallen, and were struck with stupefaction on finding that what they had taken for a volatile was a man with an immense pair of mechanical wings. They took him into their boat, and were not a little relieved on finding that he had only received a few small shot in the legs. This new Icarus was flying from Antigone to Plati to visit a young person whom he wished to marry, but whose parents were opposed to the match. To visit his lady love he had invented and made the wings he wore, and had already twice crossed the strait between the islands. On his third journey his flight was cut short by this untoward accident. He is now at Plati."

abstract: Riots; Central Park Laborers Joining the Rioters
snippet: Riots; Central Park Laborers Joining the Rioters
lead_paragraph: We understand that on the first morning of the July riot one or two of the gangs of workmen employed on the Central Park left their work, and marched down the Park, forcing or inducing the other gangs to leave their work also and follow them, and that the whole body then proceeded to take part in the business of murder and rapine then going on in the City, and continued engaged in it during two entire days, furnishing by far the best organized, and, therefore, most dangerous and destructive of the bands which contributed the memorabilia of that pleasant week to the vandals of New-York. We understood also that, although by the rules of the Park absence for two entire days from work without permission or lawful excuse entails dismissal, that these ruffians came back red-handed from their crimes, and resumed their labor on the third day, without remark or apology, and in all respects as if nothing had happened, and were suffered to do so. We understand, moreover, that to this hour no inquiry has been made, no reproof administered, and nobody selected for punishment; and that the men who are at this moment working on the Park and drawing the money of the people of this City in wages, are men who notoriously, and in open daylight, and without any attempt at concealment, spent nearly half a week, a month ago, in pillaging and burning our houses and in polluting our streets by assassination. We understand, moreover, that so far from any attempt having been made by the Park authorities to bring them to punishment, their chief care is, at this moment, to hush the matter up, and have it pass unnoticed.

abstract: Carlyle, Thomas, Ilias (Americana) in Nuce
lead_paragraph: pher is now growing very old -- verging on his seventieth year; but the years which make him more gray and grizzly do not add to the brightness of his vision or the sweep of his genius. He is descending from the "empyrean immensities" in which erstwhile he loved to disport, into the "abysses" to which he has damned so many men and humbugs. Like the blind, though not "purblind" old man of Scio's rocky isle, he has written an "Iliad," and as it is neither long nor poetry, we present it in mass to our readers. It is the Ilias (Americana) in Nuce, -- "The American Iliad in a Nutshell." The plot is simple; the characters few; the dialogue brief and brisk; the denouement quickly reached, but dubious and smoky when found. It opens with a quarrel and ends with a scrimmage -- in the midst of which the curtain falls, and the hapless author plunges into the mud. Like Gen. MCCLELLAN's prospective battles, it is "short and sharp," but unlike them, is not "decisive." It is brevity without wit. The style and spirit of the dialogue show that "T.C." is not at all acquainted with the character of the interlocutors or the cause of the woes unnumbered which have befallen America. Peter of the North never addressed Paul of the South in any such terms or fashion as is represented. Paul never responded to Peter's never-administered upbraidings with any such pacific phrase as is put into his mouth; and the rejoinder of Peter, which preceded his attempt upon Paul's brains, might better have been attributed to Paul as the address-precedent to his attempt upon Peter's brains. The author's note which follows the termination of the epic and the commencement of the row is fortunately succeeded by the date of May, 1863, for by August it certainly required considerable modification; and had the new Homer, who is his own annotator, delayed the publication of his piece for a few months longer, he might have had occasion to completely reverse the character of his observation.

abstract: -- Three table-waiters at the American House [???]n Boston were recently drafted and immediately absconded to Wolfboro, N.H.; they were found by the Provost-Marshal. On hearing that they were about to be taken back to Boston, the Copperheads of the place got up a meeting in opposition, which was inaugurated by an ex-naval officer belonging in the Tenth Ward of Boston, and bearing the name of a celebrated Mormon prophet, who held forth on the "unconstitutionality" of the Conscription law, &c. The proceedings were cut short by one of the officers announcing that they had nothing to do about the law except to enforce it, and that they should take the prisoners by the boat about to leave -- at the same time exhibiting a loaded revolver. The opposition at once subsided, and the deserters were brought away without further trouble.

abstract: By the steamship Arago, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have news of the siege of Charleston on the afternoon of the 10th inst.  Monday last. Gen. GILLMORE then expected to be in readiness to open the grand attack on Sumter and Wagner on the 13th yesterday and had so notified Admiral DAHLGREN, who was entirely ready to cooperate with the land forces.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Arago, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have news of the siege of Charleston on the afternoon of the 10th inst. -- Monday last. Gen. GILLMORE then expected to be in readiness to open the grand attack on Sumter and Wagner on the 13th -- yesterday -- and had so notified Admiral DAHLGREN, who was entirely ready to cooperate with the land forces. The utmost confidence was felt in the result. Meantime shelling from both sides was going on daily, though with very trifling loss to us -- the casualties at most not exceeding three or four per day. The health of our troops was improving rapidly, the location on Morris Island having been found much more healthy than that on Folly Island, on account of the absence of vegetation. A good sea breeze prevails during most of the day and night.

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen, which left Aspinwall on the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, bringing $313,464 in treasure from California and the Isthmus. There is no South American news by this arrival. In Central American affairs there is not much change.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen, which left Aspinwall on the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, bringing $313,464 in treasure from California and the Isthmus. There is no South American news by this arrival. In Central American affairs there is not much change. Salvador is represented to be almost entirely in possession of the invading President of Guatemala, and BARRIOS is considered hopelessly beaten. Affairs in the United States of Colombia remain quiet, though the contest between the Clergy and the National Government is not yet ended.

abstract: The report relative to the loss of this ship, near Cape Race, on the 27th of April last, has been prepared for transmission to the Board of Trade, by Mr. RAFFLES and Capts. HARRIS and BAKER, before whom the official inquiry into the circumstances attending the wreck took place. The Court characterize the conduct of the late Capt. BURGESS, in driving the ship at the rate of twelve knot an hour when she was passing a dangerous coast, as highly reprehensible. Capt. BURGESS is also severely blamed for not using the lead when the ship was so near Cape Race, and in a position which he must have known from recent surveys was a most dangerous one. The Court approve of the regulations drawn up by Messrs. ALLAN BROTHERS, the owners of the steamer, and regret that the officers did not pay more attention to them.

abstract: Mr. COBDEN, M.P., is out with a couple of sharp letters addressed to the London Times. That journal saw fit to publish a garbled report of his observations in Parliament on the Liverpool Saipo where Memorial, while the speech of Mr. LAIRD, though not occupying a quarter as long in the delivery, was published in full, with the extracts and quotations given verbatim. This capricious deviation from the usual mode of dealing, because Mr. COBDEN's views differed from those of the editors, could not be borne in silence, and the honorable gentleman sent a note, which he hoped would be published, denying the general accuracy of the report. In reply he received a private explanatory letter from the reporter; but, as no notice of his communication appeared in the columns of the Times, a second letter was dispatched to the editor, in which Mr. COBDEN says: "I do not ask for private explanations. Circumstances have tended to give the Times a virtual monopoly of the reports of our debates in Parliament, and every member of the House, as well as the public, is therefore interested in the equitable exercise of its power, or in finding a remedy against the abuse of it. Whether the grievance of which I complain arose from inadvertence or design. It is a public one, and can easily be redressed publicly. I beg, therefore, again to request the publication of my former letter, unless (but I do not ask this) you should think it more fair to print the speech as it appeared in the Morning Star, which, although not free from verbal inaccuracies, is a full report of what I said, and contains the quotations which were wholly omitted from your report." The Times of the following day reproduced the report from the Morning Star, but it was accompanied and followed by partial allusions to, and extracts from, the correspondence which has led to the publication of the above letters.

abstract: Capt. A.M. PALMER, No. 120 East Twenty-fifthstreet. The Captain, with his command, was in the battle with the mob on the morning of Monday, at the Provost-Marshal's office, Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. All the forces engaged, it will be recollected, were repulsed.
lead_paragraph: Capt. A.M. PALMER, No. 120 East Twenty-fifth-street. The Captain, with his command, was in the battle with the mob on the morning of Monday, at the Provost-Marshal's office, Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. All the forces engaged, it will be recollected, were repulsed. On the return to the Station, the Captain went home, and, in consequence of the stoppage of the Third-avenue cars, could not get back again until Tuesday morning, when he reported with his command to the Central Office. The force was with Capt. PETTY's command on that morning at the disturbances in the vicinity of Sixteenth-street and Tenth-avenue, and the balance of the day and night on general duty at the Central Office. On Wednesday morning they were returned to their own Precinct, and in the afternoon the Captain, being sick, went home, and Sergeant BRACKETT took command. The force were kept in reserve in the Precinct, portions being constantly on valuable scouting and picket duty. All that night and all Thursday were gangs around, armed with clubs and other weapons, threatening dwellings, howling, hooting and terrifying citizens; the stores were all closed and terror reigned, Sergeant BRACKETT's well arranged plans of operating in detail, boldly seconded by his men, prevented any concentration or more serious demonstration during this period. At 7 P.M., Thursday, Officer CHANDLER was brought to the Station badly beaten, and was thence conveyed to Bellevue Hospital. He had been attacked at Thirty-fourth-Street and Second-avenue by a gang, against which he made manful fight, but uselessly. During the night the Sergeant and his force continued on the qui vive, and no outrages occurred. They were in Squads, here, there, everywhere, and although in an infected district, by their promptness, activity and intelligent movements, frustrated attempts at ourtage.

abstract: DIED IN THE CELLS. -- A man named JAMES BURNS was admitted to the Station-house in Jersey City on Thursday evening, as a lodger. Yesterday morning he was found to be unwell, and a physician was called, but he died shortly after. Deceased was about 40 years of age, a stranger in the City, and enlisted in a New-Jersey regiment on Thursday.

abstract: THE NEW COURT-HOUSE. -- The new Kings County Court-house is beginning to assume shape. The marble front on Fulton-street is completed, with the exception of the elevation of one or two capitals to surmount the pillars of the wings, and the erection of the main pillars on the portico. There is more progress made now toward the completion of the edifice than there has been at any time heretofore. More men are employed, and the contractor appears determined to complete the work as soon as it is possible to do so with the help he can procure. The building promises to be a very fine one, in an architectural point of view, but the site it ocuupies is unfortunate, and the lack of any vacant space whatever in front detracts greatly from its-otherwise fine appearance. The front is flush with the line of the sidewalk, while the arch covering the main entrance, extends some 12 feet over the sidewalk, a blunder which becomes more apparent as the edifice approaches completion. In the rear, on Livingston-street, where it is not required, either for use or ornament, there is an abundance of vacant ground.

abstract: Mobile Register on Stephens' Mission
lead_paragraph: We thank God from the depths of our heart that, the authorities at Washington snubbed Vice-President STEPHENS, in his late attempt to confer with them on international affairs, without form or ceremony. It has long been Known here that this gentleman thought, if he could get to whisper into the ears of some men about Washington, the result might be terms of peace on some sort of union or reconstruction. He seemed to forget that DOUGLAS, with whom he used to serve, is dead, and notwithstanding his mantle has fallen, by dividing it into four pieces, upon RICHARDSON and VOORHEES, VALLANDIGHAM and PUGH, still the Democratic party is not in power now, and we may thank God for it. The prospect looked gloomy to the Vice-President, whose infirmity of body no doubt casts a shadow over his spirits, and he said that one of two things must be done -- either some terms must be made, or the whole militia of the Confederacy must be called out and an immediate alliance proposed with foreign Powers. President DAVIS gave him full powers to treat on honorable terms, and started him off to the Kingdom of Abraham. But Father Abraham told him there was an impassable gulf between them and the Vice-President had to steam back to Richmond, a little top-fallen. We hope this will put a stop forever to some coakers about here who intimate that there are people enough friendly to the South, in the North, to restore the Union as it was. And we also hope the Government at Richmond will not humiliate itself any more, but from this time will look only to the one end of final and substantial independence. The North is not less set on a purpose of final separation than we are. The Republican party are not fighting to restore this Union, any more than the old Romans fought to establish the independence of the countries they invaded. The Republicans are fighting for conquest and dominion, we for liberty and independence.

abstract: New-York to Washington
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent intimated yesterday that the conference of the delegates of the various railroad lines between New-York and the National Capital had determined upon various improvements in the through line, so as to respond to the urgent and very reasonable demands of the public for better accommodations and higher speed. The mismanagement of the through business has justly excited popular disgust. A line disjointed at Philadelphia, Perryville and Baltimore, and only welded by a tedious passage with horse power through the streets, or by boat over the river; perpetual irregularity of time; frequent accidents, and consequent detentions, with constant liability to accident, a single track for the most of the distance; unnecessary and dangerous curves; uncomfortable, ill-ventilated cars; these are but a portion of the elements of dissatisfaction which have irritated the traveling community. In the extremity of the general desire to escape from the necessity of thus imperiling life and limb and time, various projects were resorted to for opening other routes. One traversing a wide segment of Pennsylvania on the westward of the existing line, was planned. Another styled an "Air Line" was projected to the eastward of the present route; but which, traversing large expanses of water, might more properly be called a "Water Line;" and which was really longer, in fact, and would have been greatly longer in time than the road via Philadelphia. In the meanwhile, a glance at the map showed that no nearer approach to an "Air Line" between New-York and Washington than the road via Philadelphia is possible, a straight-edge laid over Jersey City and Washington, passing almost exactly through Philadelphia and Baltimore. To rectify this straight line in all its arrangements, was what the public demanded of the several proprietary companies; and to that demand the companies -- some of them cheerfully and the others under compulsion -- have decided to yield.

abstract: New-York Volunteers, arrived here by the St. Mary, from New-Orleans. Although 64 years of age, Capt. COOKE organized a Company, took is command, and became an active participant in the war. He was severely wounded at Port Hudson, and laid for 44 days in St. James' Hospital, New-Orleans. Although he returns in shattered health, his devotion to the cause is strong as ever, and he wants but recovery to return to its service. On parting with his Company he was the recipient of a letter from officers and men bearing feeling and eloquent testimony of their attachment to him as an officer and man, and expressing their admiration for his endurance and courage on all occasion. He left for his residence. Albany, last evening, where he is universally esteemed, and where hosts of friends will cordially welcome him.

abstract: The daily life of the German population in this great human hive is one of its most interesting features. They entirely occupy whole streets and dis-...
lead_paragraph: The daily life of the German population in this great human hive is one of its most interesting features. They entirely occupy whole streets and districts of the City, impressing upon the neighborhood of their residence the peculiar characteristics that distinguish them at home, modified to some extent, indeed, by the necessities of American life, yet preserving all the leading features of their own peculiar system of "living, moving and having their being." HANS is easily recognized, no matter how he may strive to look as though he had never worn short jackets with bell-buttons and a queer little tail, nearly up to his shoulders. Of course, the more highly educated classes of all modern countries in Christendom are greatly assimilated by certain universal rules of dress and decorum, and are to be distinguished only by national fixed peculiarities of complexion, physiognomy and temperament, as well as language. Englishmen, French, Spaniards, Italians, Dutch, Danes, Swedes, West Indians and South Americans are found in numbers ranging about in the order of their mention in this vast centre, and there are sprinklings of nearly every other nation under the sun, but these are completely overborne and rendered inconsiderable by the great German immigration.

abstract: Our correspondent "Nemo," now at NewOrleans, but at Port Hudson during the siege, sends us a copy of the following highly interesting correspondence, which came to his notice at the latter  place since its surrender. He sends it without names...
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent "Nemo," now at New-Orleans, but at Port Hudson during the siege, sends us a copy of the following highly interesting correspondence, which came to his notice at the latter place since its surrender. He sends it without names or traces of identification -- the object not being to wound individual sensibilities, but only to show, on the one hand, the painful position of dependence to which this horrible rebellion has already reduced many a proud and wealthy Southern family, and also to teach our lukewarm patriots how a true soldier can and should regard his duties to his country, even when they are of a nature to tear his own heartstrings asunder. Our correspondent vouches for the truth of every word of this correspondence, for the officer in question is one of his most intimate friends, and he knows how much sorrow the penning of that letter cost its author.

abstract: The riot cases that were not tried at the August Term of the Court of Sessions having been transferred to the Court of Over and Terminer, which sits in October, it becomes a matter of interest to the public who is to occupy the Bench at that Term. We are informed that the Court will be held by Judge ALLEN, well known as one of the ablest and most upright Judges in the State. As Judge ALLEN lives out of the City, and is not mixed up in any way with the local politics and factions of the City, he is eminently qualified to act as Judge in the trial of these cases. Recorder HOFFMAN, by his stern adherence to justice in the riot cases, has won an honor which years of routine duty could not have acquired for him, while District Attorney HALL and his Assistant. SAMUEL B. GARVIN, have literally crowded upon themselves the plaudits and honorable appreciation of the public.

abstract: The rich of our people never knew before how few were their actual wants, and the poor have seen all classes reduced to an equality. Wealth has become a source of misfortune since those who possess it are subjected to apprehensions of loss which the poor have never felt. Should the close of the war find us stripped of all wealth, both of cotton and gold, with nothing beside land and slaves, it is a consolatory reflection that a fathomless abyss separates us from the North, and after all that we have borne -- mere poverty is no longer a burden -- it will be deemed neither a crime nor a calamity. There was a time when the poor may have envied the rich, but the rich now envy the poor.

abstract: at Japan. Whether Japan deserves a flogging or not; whether she has violated treaties and assassinated British residents, is a matter concerning which opinions differ. We can...
lead_paragraph: at Japan. Whether Japan deserves a flogging or not; whether she has violated treaties and assassinated British residents, is a matter concerning which opinions differ. We can view the contest from afar, and, without aspiring to the spirit of prophecy, can easily foretell which will come out of the contest winner. Japan is a wealthy nation, and England always makes a war pay -- or, in other words, after whipping a people, sends in the bill and has it cashed.

abstract: The fact that the District-Attorney felt it necessary to give notice the other day in Court that, if any of the cases arising out of...
lead_paragraph: The fact that the District-Attorney felt it necessary to give notice the other day in Court that, if any of the cases arising out of the riots were postponed this term, he would let them lie over until October, and thus-avoid having them tried before Judge MCCUNN, proves how thoroughly successful this last-named functionary has been in persuading the criminals that he will stand by them on the bench. Every one of the rioters who is now in custody would be content to lie another month in jail untried, for the chance of being brought up before MCCUNN, instead of having to face Recorder HOFFMAN. There has, of course, never been any question that MCCUNN's object in parading himself before the rioters at the meeting called by Archbishop HUGHES was to assure the mob in advance that they had at least one friend among the judges; and the run on him for writs of habeas corpus which followed was the legitimate consequence of the demonstration. The decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court, touching his power to issue them, was, of course, a severe blow to the hopes of those who counted on him for impunity, and they were still further dashed by the admirable attitude taken by Recorder HOFFMAN. But they have nevertheless not ceased entirely to count on him. There was the chance that if their counsel could stave their trials off into September they would come before Judge MCCUNN alone, and then, although he could not order their summany discharge as if they were brought up on a habeas corpus, he could render their escape easy and certain in the thousand ways -- the charges to the juries, the rulings, on points of law and on points of evidence -- with which we are already unhappily too familiar; and if the worst came to the worst, he could "suspend sentence," or make it light. Thanks to the District-Attorney, HALL, we are, however; to be spared this shameful and humiliating spectacle.

abstract: By private advices to July 30 from San Salvador, we learn that Gen. BARRIOS has gained some advantages over his enemy, CARREES, of Guatemala, notwithstanding the conduct of the traitor GONZALEZ.
lead_paragraph: By private advices to July 30 from San Salvador, we learn that Gen. BARRIOS has gained some advantages over his enemy, CARRERA, of Guatemala, notwithstanding the conduct of the traitor GONZALEZ. The Guatemalan troops, since their conflict with him, had suffered much from the inclemency of the weather, and were so much demoralized that about one-third of their force had deserted and marched home. CARRERA also found himself deceived by the representations of the would-be President DUENOS and the Priests. Instead of joining them the people had rallied around BARRIOS, in the capitol, who knowing the condition of the Guatemalans, sent out Gen. CABANAS to attack them, and he succeeded in driving them back, recapturing the cannon lost by the defection of GOFZALEZ, and also some siege guns of CARRERA's.

abstract: The Approaching, in New-York
lead_paragraph: Intimidation and artifice have been alike unavailing with President LINCOLN. It is settled that the draft in this City shall go on. New-York, notwithstanding its Democratic majority of thirty thousand, and notwithstanding its surcharge with the worst material of any spot on the continent, is not to be exempted from the control of law. The same National enactment which was framed for all the loyal parts of the country, and which is cheerfully submitted to in every other county and town throughout the North, is to be again undertaken here, whether the mob which recently robbed, and burnt, and murdered in opposition to it, is or is not willing. The issue is going to be fairly tried whether this Metropolis is or is not outside of the National jurisdiction.

lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Admiral DAHLGREN, commanding the fleet off Charleston, were received by the Navy Department yesterday. The tenor of these dispatches is said to be such as to leave little room for doubt that the reduction of Fort Sumter and the other rebel works in the vicinity would be speedily accomplished.

abstract: Alabama cavalry, is in this City, on a brief leave of absence. The regiment, which is composed entirely of Alabamians and Mississippians, is one of the finest in the Southwest, and has done an extraordinary amount of hard service since its organization. It is now stationed near Co[???]n, Miss., and is one of the regiments that was in the command of the late Brig.-Gen. CORWYN. There are clergymen, members of the Legislature and Southern planters serving as privates in Col. SPENCER's regiment -- men who know by experience what the rebel t[???]nv is, and are willing to spend their life in exterminating it. They are a noble body of soldiers, and have a most accomplished and gallant leader.

abstract: At Albany, on Tuesday of this week, Deputy United States Marshal LOWELL arrested a man aged about twenty-five years, known there as R.H. WEB
lead_paragraph: At Albany, on Tuesday of this week, Deputy United States Marshal LOWELL arrested a man aged about twenty-five years, known there as R.H. WEBSTER, who professed to be engaged in "the study of the law," on the charge of manufacturing United states Treasury Notes. The accused was brought to this city, and gave bail to appear before Commissioner RUGER for examination on Monday next. The Marshal found on WEBSTER's person, when he made the arrest, a quantity of letters, which are from persons in all parts of the Northern States, and contain the fullest evidence of extensive swinding operations in which he has been engaged for some time, and with excellent success. He has been sending circulars to postmasters, and other local officers, at small towns throughout the country, covering a proposition to furnish the means of successful speculation, and offering for sale, at 30 cents on the dollar, imitations of United States Treasury Notes, which he promised should be so perfect as to defy detection. If the person addressed responded favorably, further correspondence ensued, a sample of the "imitation notes" (of the denomination of $1, genuine issue,) would be sent, which in most cases would call out an order for a larger quantity of the notes, inclosing bank bills to pay for them at the rate of 30 cents on the dollar. It is evident from the tenor of some of the accused's correspondence that he never furnished the "imitation notes" spoken of in his circulars; that the genuine $1 note was employed as a bail to call out an order for a quantity of them, accompanied by a remittance in advance payment, which he would pocket. In this manner WEBSTER has done a large business, and his correspondence shows that he has received hundreds of dollars from dupes in all parts of the Northern States. He denies that he has manufactured or dealt in counterfeits, and claims that his proposition to furnish "imitation notes" is innocent at least so far as the Government is concerned. His operations are of the sharpest character, and it is probable that the only advantage to be gained from his arrest will be an exposition of his swindling operations, which may serve to put the public on the lookout for frauds of like character.

abstract: pride themselves on be lopping to a race of men who have never been conquered, arrived in New-York. Our citizens, and strangers visiting the City, stare after them, and imagine with anxious voices-who and what they are? Their picturesque costume and manly bearing are objects of the greatest interest, and the admiration they excite is unbounded. They are Bedouin Arabs, men of the desert, and the only genuine Arabs that have ever visited this country. The chief characteristic of the Bedouin Arabs is their unbounded hospitality, great bravery and heroic conduct. The favorite pastime of the Bedouin Arab is in athletic exercises, in which they become exceedingly efficient. The Arabs we have now with us, it is said, are wonderful gymnasts, and have lately astonished the principal cities of Europe -- London and Paris -- by their wonderful feats. It is stated that before leaving the City they intend letting New-Yorkers have a taste of their quality, and for that purpose a pavilion on the Arabian plan will be erected on Fourteenth-street, opposite the Academy of Music.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met specially at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday. The resolutions from the other Board complimentary to Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT, and extendting to him the freedom and hospitalities of the City, were concurred in. The...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met specially at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday. The resolutions from the other Board complimentary to Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT, and extendting to him the freedom and hospitalities of the City, were concurred in. The Comptroller sent in a communication saying that he is determined to commence a suit against the Houston-street (Brooklyn) Ferry Company for $18,100, for the rent accrued up to the commencement of this quarter, and if they oppose, he will take immediate measures to dispossess them. The Comptroller reported the balance in the City Treasury on Aug. 8, to be $1,375,133 42, and that the expenditures on City account for the year, to July 31, were $4,374,080, 58, leaving an unexpended balance of appropriations of $4,052,621 58. The President, MORGAN JONES, presented a new conscript exemption ordinance appropriating $3,000,000 for the purpose of commuting the draft of all persons who are unable to pay the commutation fee. This ordinance is the same in effect as the one laid over in the Board of Aldermen on Thursday. It differs from that in the sum of $500,000 increase of appropriation, and in more stringent provisions, and exempts the active firemen, that is, by providing the commutation fee for each. It is understood that this ordinance was drawn by Mr. JONES after consultation with eminent legal and official gentleman, and also Judge-Advocate-General. NELSON J. WATERBURY, and meets the approval of a majority of the Aldermen and Mayor O[???]DYKE. After its adoption, on suggestion of Mr. JONES, a resolution was adopted, c[???]l Gov. SEYMOUR to forbid recruiting here for United States, and a resolution by Mr. GROSS was adopted, forbidding the extension of aid from the City Relief Fund to the families of any persons who shall enlist or serve as substitutes in [???] regiment out of this State. The Board stands [???] [???]urned to the second Monday in September.

abstract: The Executive Committee of the German Republican Central Committee assembled at 8 o'clock, last evening, at the Steuben House, on the Bowery, E. LUEDER, President, and M.C. HANDSCHUG, Secretary. The business of the evening was important, but owing to the strict secrecy preserved, did not transpire. A general meeting of the Central Committee will take place on Friday evening next, when matters of great interest will be openly debated.

abstract: ACCIDENTALLY SHOT BY A CENTRAL PARK GATE-KEEPER. Quite a serious accident occurred on...
lead_paragraph: ACCIDENTALLY SHOT BY A CENTRAL PARK GATE-KEEPER. -- Quite a serious accident occurred on Thursday last in the vicinity of Central Park. EDWARD BURNS, a gate-keeper, while walking along Seventy-eighth-street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues, saw a dog making an attack upon a small boy. He hastened forward, and attempted to drive the animal away, when it turned upon him. BURNS had a double-barreled shot-gun with him, which he is in the habit of carrying for the purpose of killing stray dogs that infest the Park. This weapon he now raised for the purpose of firing upon the rabid animal, when his foot slipped and the contents of the gun, instead of entering the dog, went wide of the mark. One of the buckshot struck a woman named Mrs. JANE HENRY, who was standing in the door of her residence on the opposite side of the street. It entered her shoulder, inflicting a serious, though probably not a mortal wound. BURNS at once gave himself up, but the investigation showed that the shooting was purely accidental, and he was therefore discharged from custody.

abstract: By the steamship Constitution we have received dates from the City of Mexico to the 1st day of July, from Mr. H.D. DALTON, a passenger, who has...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Constitution we have received dates from the City of Mexico to the 1st day of July, from Mr. H.D. DALTON, a passenger, who has recently left the Mexican capital, we have some interesting intelligence. He state that on the entrance of the French, by orders of the Comandante POTIER, who was appointed Military Governor of the city, the residents were compelled to receive the army of the French with triumphal honors.

abstract: Rear-Admiral FARRAGUY left the Navy-yard yesterday, bound for Hastings, on the Hudson River, his country seat. All the officers took a kindly fare-...
lead_paragraph: Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT left the Navy-yard yesterday, bound for Hastings, on the Hudson River, his country seat. All the officers took a kindly farewell of him, and some escorted him to the boat. He was accompanied by his wife and one of his sons. After staying a few days in Hastings, he will, it is understood, leave for Washington, the Secretary of the Navy having expressed a desire to see him.

abstract: Lieut. H.H. Goodell, of the Twenty-fifth Connecticut regiment, a son of Rev. Dr. Goodell, the...
lead_paragraph: -- Lieut. H.H. Goodell, of the Twenty-fifth Connecticut regiment, a son of Rev. Dr. Goodell, the veteran missionary of Constantinople, Turkey, and a graduate in 1862 at Amherst, according to the Spring-field Republican, has had some interesting experience during his nine months in Louisiana. The Twenty-fifth has suffered severely in several battles, and Lieut. Goodell has seen many narrow escapes. At Irish Bend, a wounded man whom he was carrying from the field, was shot a second time in his very arms. When Gen. Banks called for 1,000 men, with officers, to storm the works at Port Hudson, after the unsuccesslul assault of the 14th of June, he was one of the first to offer his services, although the early capitulation of the place made the attack unnecessary. During the siege, in one of the charges made by his regiment, his life was saved in the most singular manner. A rebel soldier not more than twelve yards in front, turned upon him, aiming a loaded rifle full at his breast. At the moment he fired a soldier of the One Hundred and Tenth New-York stepped in front of Lieut. Goodell, and, receiving the discharge, was instantly killed. It is not certainly known, but it is thought, that the act was intentional. The Union troops were at the time driving the rebels up the steep side of a ravine, and as the soldier fell backward, being on higher ground, he struck Lieut. Goodell, knocking him over, and rendering him unconscious for some time. When he regained his senses, bis regiment had retired, and although in close proximity to his "Southern brethren," he preferred not to remain. Rolling himself slowly and quietly down into the ravine, he crept off, and at last found his comrades, who hailed him as one from the dead, for they had seen him fall and thought him killed. Lieut. Goodell was promoted from Second to First Lieutenant after the battle of Irish Bend, was for some time Acting Adjutant, and is now on the Staff of Col. Bissell, Acting Brigadier in Grover's division.

abstract: Capt. JAMES TODD, Steamboat No. 1. The force of this Precinct constitute the Harbor Police. On the morning of Monday, Capt. Todd, on hearing of the riot, volunteered his command for service in any way useful. The first order received was about noon,...
lead_paragraph: Capt. JAMES TODD, Steamboat No. 1. The force of this Precinct constitute the Harbor Police. On the morning of Monday, Capt. TODD, on hearing of the riot, volunteered his command for service in any way useful. The first order received was about noon, from Maj.-Gen. WOOL, to collect all the military at Governor's Island, and bring them to the City, which was promptly obeyed, and the troops landed at North Moore-street at 2 1/2 P.M. In the afternoon special duties were performed between the City and the Island; arms and ammunition were brought over for the Custom-house, Sub-Treasury, and other Government buildings; others were furnished by this force for the defence of the ram Dunderberg, lying near WEBB's ship-yard, and which had been threatened with destruction; muskets were also brought for the defence of the buildings threatened at Printing-House-square. Patrolman BLACKWELL performed a hazardous duty in the conveyance of the arms from the landing to their destination, but did it with a sagacity which prevented suspicion, and prevented in every case interference. At midnight, by request of Col. O'BRIEN, this force went to Governor's Island, procured arms and ammunition, and conveyed them to four hundred men of his command then at Staten Island ferry; thus at 4 A.M., armed and equipped, they were enabled to be in the City.

abstract: My latest intelligence from Vicksburgh is up to the evening of the 29th, on which day the R.C. Wood sailed with about 400 sick and wounded soldiers on board. The number of wounded is only 75; the balance are sick with the intermittent or typhold fever, and a few cases of chronic diarrhoea.
lead_paragraph: My latest intelligence from Vicksburgh is up to the evening of the 29th, on which day the R.C. Wood sailed with about 400 sick and wounded soldiers on board. The number of wounded is only 75; the balance are sick with the intermittent or typhold fever, and a few cases of chronic diarrhoea. I have not seen men who had the appearance of death before on a hospital boat; as a rule, the great majority of them look as if they would soon recover; but the poor fellows on board the Wood look as if they would leave the hospital only in their coffins. Between Vicksburgh and this city 15 deaths occurred; and to judge from the emaciated forms of the poor fellows stretched out on their cots, a great many more than that number will reach a soldier's grave before they arrive in St. Louis, the place of their destination.

abstract: Almost the only item of war news we have this morning comes from Missouri. Col. CATHERWOOD, commanding a Misouri regiment of artillery, telegraphs to headquarters at St. LOUIS, from Pineville, McDonald County, that he was attacked by the rebel Col. COFFEE yesterday, and that the rebels were severely handled. COFFEE'S force was completely routed, with the loss of thirty or forty killed and a number wounded. The rebels were completely scattered.

abstract: By the steamship Hibernian which passed Cape Race on Friday evening, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Greencastle on the 7th inst. The politcal news is reported of but little importance. The Liverpool Cotton market was flat and unchanged. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. Consols were quiet at 93@93 1/8 for money. The Rebel Cotton Loan had touched a point as low as 35 cent. discount.

abstract: One of the bugbear terrors with reference to society in Slave States, after Emancipation, is the fear of Amalgamation, and the consequent South American degradation and feebleness. Intelligent Southerners--even those holding Slaves--do not entertain such apprehensions. They, of course, admit that Slavery...
lead_paragraph: One of the bugbear terrors with reference to society in Slave States, after Emancipation, is the fear of Amalgamation, and the consequent South American degradation and feebleness. Intelligent Southerners -- even those holding Slaves -- do not entertain such apprehensions. They, of course, admit that Slavery has brought about a hundred-fold more amalgamation thus far than liberty; but they urge that this has taken place where no suspicion or claim of equality was ever imagined, and that in the normal and natural condition of the two races -- both being free -- the diversities of each, as well as the pride of blood, would keep them apart. Of the truth of this last position there need be no doubt.

abstract: At about 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning the dental establishment of Dr. JOHN ALLEN, on the second floor of No. 59 Bond-street, wherein artificial teeth were manufactured, was destroyed by flames communicated through a smoke pipe from the furnace in which the Doctor baked artificial teeth. The Doctor's loss on stock &c., as estimated by Fire Marshal BAKES, is about $1,500. On the first floor the damage of Dr. FULLGRAFY's furniture is about $50. The building, which is owned by Mr. W.H. ALBRO, has been rendered nearly worthless. The loss thereon is estimated at little less than $1,000. Mr. ALBRO is insured in the Broadway Insurance Company's office. Drs. FULLGRAFY and ALLEN have no insurance.
lead_paragraph: At about 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning the dental establishment of Dr. JOHN ALLEN, on the second floor of No. 59 Bond-street, wherein artificial teeth were manufactured, was destroyed by flames communicated through a smoke pipe from the furnace in which the Doctor baked artificial teeth. The Doctor's loss on stock &c., as estimated by Fire Marshal BAKES, is about $1,500. On the first floor the damage of Dr. FULLGRAFY's furniture is about $50. The building, which is owned by Mr. W.H. ALBRO, has been rendered nearly worthless. The loss thereon is estimated at little less than $1,000. Mr. ALBRO is insured in the Broadway Insurance Company's office. Drs. FULLGRAFY and ALLEN have no insurance.

abstract: In Paris
lead_paragraph: "I undertook to speak French. It was a spectacle of lingual gymnastics that did not fail to excite admiration and elicit smiles. Usually I began with a noon. Throwing that out in a very bold manner, I then sent the verb straggling after it, as best it might, somewhat disheveled, and often much dislocated, and then the adverbs and adjectives were thrown in at the end, as so much to boot, for the very obliging manner in which my other parts of speech had been entertained. There are three of us, you know, in company, the LL.D., the Preacher, and myself the Editor. The Doctor is dignified, deliberate, and slightly sensitive to inaccuracies. His attempt at French consists, usually, in drawing himself up like a statue of marble, and receiving the whirl of sentences with which polite officials come down upon him with the most patient silence. Sometimes he would (like a bird that has not quite made up its mind whether to sing or not, and throws a note or two) very deliberately ejaculate one or two good French words, and while the polite shopman, or woman rather, waited for the rest, he relapsed into silence and meditations on that mysterious providence that debarred so large a part of mankind from the privilege of understanding English!

abstract: The ordinance which passed the Board of Councilmen on Friday evening, and was concurred in by the Board of Aldermen yesterday, and which will doubtless, be approved by the Mayor, has divested the coming draft in this city of that intense interest which has heretofore surrounded it.
lead_paragraph: The ordinance which passed the Board of Councilmen on Friday evening, and was concurred in by the Board of Aldermen yesterday, and which will, doubtless, be approved by the Mayor, has divested the coming draft in this city of that intense interest which has heretofore surrounded it. The ordinance is so framed as to place it upon the same legal footing as the previous ordinances to raise money for the relief of families of volunteers, and there is no doubt that the $3,000,000 will be raised without any difficulty. Indeed numerous capitalists have already signified their willingness to take stock in the loan, and there appears to be no doubt of its legality. Although the money is to be raised ostensibly for the support of the families of drafted men: yet its provisions are such that it amounts practically to a payment by the City of the $300 commutation money for every drafted man who is poor, and has a family dependent on him for support. He is allowed to take the $300 for his family and go himself, or to procure a substitute who will receive the $300, or in case be declines to do either, the $300 is paid over to the Government for his commutation. This applies to all poor men with families who may be drafted, and to all members of regular organized fire companies. The passage of this ordinance takes away from the secession demagogues the entire capital with which they have operated to work upon the passions and sympathies of the laboring men. Meantime every good citizen will rejoice that a legal and peaceable way has been devised by which the law may be enforced in this City as in other parts of the country, without working injustice or hardship to any one. All apprehensions of further disturbance in connection with the draft may be set at rest. Any future riot in that connection will be evidently what many believed the last riot was actually, the work of rebel sympathisers in our midst, and designed to assist the traitors of the South in their efforts to overthrow the Government.

abstract: A letter to the New-Orleans Picayune dated Johnson's Island, July 25, announces the death at that place of Capt. E.W. FULLER, formerly Commandant of the Confederate gunboat Cotten, and afterwards of the Queen of the West. He was wounded and made prisoner at the time of the destruction of the latter vessel by the Federal gunboats on Grand Lake, some time in April last. He was removed from New-Orleans, in company with other prisoners, on the 2d of June, to Fort Delaware, thence to Johnson's Island on the 18th inst., when he died. His remains have been placed in a metallic burial case and inferred in the cemetery on the Island, whence he can be removed at any time his friends may wish to do so. It was previously reported that Capt. FULLER had made his escape with a number of prisoners, who seized the Maple Leaf and landed from her below Fortress Monroe some weeks since.

abstract: A match between the Champion and the above skilfull French expert, will take place on Wednesday afternoon next, at KAVANAGH's Rooms. They are to play the three ball French game, one hundred and fifty points up, for a purse of $200. It will be remembered that in this game caroms only count, each carom adding one to the score; yet these parties are so expert at this specialty of billiards, that it is confidently expected they will complete the game with in two hours from its commencement. There will, undoubtedly, be a large attendance, as the affair is creating a marked excitement in billiard circles. The playing begins at 4 P.M.
