abstract: The Police of the Thirteenth Precinct, under Capt. STEERS, are deserving of much credit for having effected a very important arrest. If all that has been stated under oath be true, the prisoner whom they have just taken into custody was one of the most determined and influential, and consequently one of the most dangerous leaders of the mob that for three days ravaged this City.
lead_paragraph: The Police of the Thirteenth Precinct, under Capt. STEERS, are deserving of much credit for having effected a very important arrest. If all that has been stated under oath be true, the prisoner whom they have just taken into custody was one of the most determined and influential, and consequently one of the most dangerous leaders of the mob that for three days ravaged this City. The arrest was accomplished only after great labor and the most untiring efforts on the part of the Captain and Officers ANDERSON and BUCKBEE. The name of the accused is FRANCIS CUSICK, aged about 35 years, and residing at No. 268 Avenue B. His occupation is that of a stage-driver.

abstract: The Paterson Guardian gives a very enricus account of the operations of an association of miners in the coal region about Pittsburgh Penn., for the purpose of resisting the draft.
lead_paragraph: The Paterson Guardian gives a very curious account of the operations of an association of miners in the coal region about Pottsville, Penn., for the purpose of resisting the draft. They were circumvented, it appears, and their plans discovered by a United States officer of high ra[???], who, disguised as a priest, traversed the whole region, and having tha e[???]use of the boy office of the confessional, ascertained that fifteen thousand men were in secret league to resist the execution of the Conscript act. He obtained their signs and watchwords -- their places of meeting in the mines, the mode. Four of drill, and a complete clue to the entire [???]am fica[???]ons of the plot. He discovered that the MOLLYS were [???] possession of 700 United States Springfield rifles, with which they perform company and battalion d[???]constantly; that is, they passed by secret passages known only to themselves, the arms from mine to mine, and thus the 700 rifles did duty for the drilling of 15,000 strong, determined desperadoes. The drill masters of these men are old soldiers, some discharged for disability and others deserters who have fled to the mines for safety, where no provost guard can well go in search of them.

abstract: The yachts of the New-York Yacht Club will rendezvous at Whitestone, L.I., to-day, preparatory to their annual Summer cruise up the Sound. The fleet will include two steam propellers, and will be commanded by the Vice-Commodore, A.C. KINGSLAND, Esq., who will hoist his penant on board his fine schooner yacht Favorita. There will, no doubt, be some interesting scenes between the yachts; and a grand regatta at Newport. New-Bedford, or other towns on the Sound, will very likely be given before the yachts receive the Vice-Commodore's signal to part company.

abstract: COLORED CLAIMANTS FOR DAMAGES. -- The Board of Supervisors, with a promptness which does them great credit, have given notice to the attorneys for the colored sufferers by the late riot, that they were prepared to hear the statements of these claimants and examine their witnesses. To prevent waste of time for the colored people, and to avoid a crowd at the Supervisor's Office, it would be better that all colored claimants who have their witnesses ready should go to the Merchants' Committee Depot, No. 350 Fourth-street, and give notice of that fact, in order that they may be called forward at such times as their cases can be attended to. As many of the colored people who suffered loss by the riots have not yet had their papers made out, they should bear in mind that the time within which claims for damage for losses against the City legally made is limited, and they should see to this at an early day. To have left their names upon the books of the Committee is not sufficient. They must sign the papers themselves. No charge is made by the lawyers.

lead_paragraph: The New City Hall was crowed to repletion last evening to near Gen. SHEPLEY. He spoke for two hours, and although the evening was very warm, he held his audience and their undivided attention to the close. We can attempt no report of his speech -- only indicate the scope of his remarks. The first part of his speech was a condensed history of military operations since the rebellion began, and the progress our arms have made.

abstract: Austria and the European Crisis
lead_paragraph: The time approaches when it must be determined whether diplomacy or the sword is to solve the Polish problem. The defiant tone of the Russian dispatches would seem to indicate that the Czar had chosen war rather than concession. But when those dispatches were written, the impression at St. Petersburgh was that Austria could be seduced from the coalition, and that, without her, the Western Powers would not venture to have recourse to arms. The reply of Count RECHBERG to GORTSCHAKOFF's proposition, in favor of a Conference of the Partitioning States, has, however, dissipated the illusion touching the possibility of winning over Austria. The Kaiser, so far from being flattered by the invitation, is even highly offended with ALEXANDER for presuming to institute a parallel between Galicia and the Kingdom of Poland, and will be no party to a Conference from which France and England may be excluded. Austria's prompt and peremptory rejection of the Russian Conference scheme, proves that the coalition is not altogether of so hollow a nature as the Czar imagined, and may induce him to adopt a more cautious and conciliatory tone in his future rejoinders.

abstract: Iron-clad Fleet, the
lead_paragraph: The iron-clad Miantonomah was launched from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday. This is the first iron-clad built in this country by the Government. Our naval reporter gives some interesting facts concerning her character, size and armament. The fact is recalled that at the time the iron-clad mania took possession of the country, the stocks of our Navy-yards were all occupied with wooden vessels-of-war. Armored ships were wanted at once to confront the terrible Merrimac, which was menacing Wasington, and the Monitor was built in ninety days by contract. Other vessels were immediately contracted for; and the first batch of nine Monitors, now all in service -- the second nine which are about to be launched, and the third fifteen light-draught ships in course of construction -- were all put upon the stocks in rapid succession.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  I venture to thank you for an article in your paper of yesterday, on subject of "Reconstruction." You have, according to my poor opinion, placed this important point fairly and carefully accarate before the world. This is a point so vitally important to the future of our country that it cannot be too often referred to in the columns of so important a paper as the TIMES.

abstract: This is the first launch of an iron-ciad built in the country by the Government. At the time the ironclad mania took possession of the country, the stocks of our Navy-yards were all occupied with wooden vessels of war. Armored salps were wanted in ninety...
lead_paragraph: This is the first launch of an iron-clad built in the country by the Government. At the time the iron-clad mania took possession of the country, the stocks of our Navy-yards were all occupied with wooden vessels of war. Armored salps were wanted in ninety days, as the Merrimac was menacing Washington. The Monitor was built in that time, being a contracted vessel, and of course successful. Others were immediately contracted for, and the batch of nine Monitors, of which the Passaic is one -- the second nine which are about to be launched, and the third fifteen light draught ships, which were in course of construction -- were all put upon the stocks in rapid succession. Government employes not being so hurried as those outside, have, as a matter of course, made better work of their ships than the latter. It is probably true that no vessel was ever launched from any Navy-yard in this country so perfectly finished in every way, so strong and sound, as the Miantonomah. Considerable interest is therefore manifested concerning her, and yesterday morning it was hoped she would first touch her native element "all right." The affair came off at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. From every flagstaff in the yard and on the shipping United States bunting was flung to the breeze in honor of the occasion. Under a cloudless sky and rather warm atmosphere about three thousand ladies and gentleman and officers of the United States Navy assembled in the immediate vicinity of the Miantonomah. The celebrated band of the North Carolina, lying near by, discoursed sweet music. All the vessels and boats in the offing were filled with spectators. The shiphouse itself was filled with a select party, accommodations having been erected -- three galleries tastefully decorated with the colors of all nations. The noble vessel as she lay upon the stocks was the object of universal admiration. She looks like an ordinary ship cut down to the deck -- the logging and armor are to be placed on the outside of the plank as soon as possible. Her extreme length is 259 feet, extreme breadth 52 feet 10 inches, and depth of hold 14 feet 9 inches. Some anxiety was felt on the score that being so broad and flat-bottomed she would not make a good launch. Her tonnage is 1,800 tons. She has two decks and two revolving turrets, one tore and one aft.; two guns in each. A 15-inch gun and a 20d-pounder will probably be the armament of each turret. The internal diameter of the turrets is 21 feet. The accommodations for the crew take up the whole forward part of the deck. The Captain's cabin is in the extreme aft.; the other officers wardrooms are also in the aft. She is a propellor, worked by four engines, which are smaller than usual for such a large vessel. The machinery is being constructed at the Novelty Iron Works. The cylinders are 32 inches in diameter; the diameter of the propeller is 11 feet 6 inches, and 24 feet pitch. Unlike the other Monitors they are on each side and not in a "well." She has four bollers. The iron armor is composed of inch plates of iron five thicknesses. She is the strongest vessel of wood that could be built. Mr. B.F. DELANO is the Naval Constructor, and R.W. STEELE the Master Carpenter.

abstract: -The negro regiments raised in the Eastern Atlantic States are, as fast as they are formed, sent down to South Carolina, to take part in operations, under Gen. GILLMORE, against the rebels of that State. Gen. GILLMORE has under him the regiments of Col. HIGGINSON and Col. MONTGOMERY, both raised in that section of country, the Fifty-fourth Massachusetts regiment, raised in Boston, -- and the Third colored regiment, raised in Pennsylvania, left Philadelphia on Wednesday last for the same field. The last named regiment numbers one thousand men, and is under command of Col. C.B. TILGHMAN, formerly of the Twenty-sixth Pennsylvania. We understand that other colored regiments will soon be sent down to the same department.

abstract: The Wheeling Intelligencer gives the story of BENJ, B. BLACK, of Worthing, Washington County, Georgia, and a member of the Forty-eighth regiment from that State, who was captured near Strasburgh a few days since. He says that in his district only five...
lead_paragraph: The Wheeling Intelligencer gives the story of BENJ. B. BLACK, of Worthing, Washington County, Georgia, and a member of the Forty-eighth regiment from that State, who was captured near Strasburgh a few days since. He says that in his district only five votes were cast for secession and upward of 100 against it. His part of the State was considered the Union or disaffected part of Georgia. The sympathies of the people were largely against secession up to the last moment. In his regiment are many men like himself -- unwilling soldiers in the cause of rebellion. He says that when he left home he prayed God to keep him from ever shooting a Union soldier, and he is happy in the belief that he has never killed one, although he was in the battles of Fredericksburgh and Chancellorsville. He was wounded in the latter battle. He says that in Georgia, as elsewhere in the extreme South, a poor man who has to work at day's work for a living has a very hard chance in the world. Fifty cents a day was considered a big price for a laborer. They worked at the same work as negroes, and were held in the light of "poor white trash" by those who owned negroes, He thinks that those who owned negroes and who started the secession business ought to have been the men to right it out. Such men as him, having no ownership or interest in negroes, felt that they had no rights that were being injured, and only desired to be left at home with their families. He first heard the news of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson at Guiness Station, and he says that it fell like a shower of bombs in the rebel ranks. The Union men among the soldiers secretly rejoiced, while the others cursed and talked very despondently, saying that the cause of the South had gone up, and that there was no chance. BLACK was not in the battle of Gettysburgh, being sick with the fever-ague. He, however, had been sent forward to Winchester to reinforce LEE, and met his regiment on its return from Pennsylvania. It had suffered terribly in the battle. One of his brothers had been badly wounded, and his Captain had lost an arm. He says that the Captain told him that their men had been badly used, and that it was the severest and, to them, the most disastrous fight of the war. Their own estimate of their loss in killed and wounded was about twelve thousand. He never heare how many prisoners they lost. The men were very dejected, wearied, foot-sore, sick and hungry. They made no concealment of their belief that everything was going against the South, and that the Union armies would speedily triumph. The rations of the rebel soldiers in camp were a tin of flour and a half a pound of meat per day to the man. Their rations had to be cooked op every man for himself. They had no such thing as sugar, coffee or any vegetables. They rarely had even salt. He had simply one meal per day of the food named. On the march, BLACK says he has been three days without food. Such a thing as tents for the private soldiers had been unknown for a long time past. He says that at Fredericksburgh last winter he slept every night by a log-fire with nothing over him or under him except snow, sleet, rain and mud. He and all the private soldiers suffered terribly and many were ruined for life. Desertions were very frequent and in large numbers, especially within the last few months. The men had begun better than ever to appreciate the fact that they were fighting against their best hopes and interests, and they were determined to do so no longer. He thinks there will be a terrible reaction in the South against the leaders once the rebel armies are overthrown. Georgia will be too hot to hold them.

abstract: His Captured Private Letters
lead_paragraph: The country will be interested and amused, if not instructed, by the letters received by JEFF. DAVIS from all sections and all sorts of men during the secession Winter, and which have been recently brought to light by the progress of our armies in the Southwest. We are rather surprised not to find in any of those which came from the North the injunction, "Destroy my communications, as I shall yours," with which WEBSTER, the Treasury-note swindler, closes his circular to his victims. Certainly, if any of the writers had thought that his letter would ever be shown up in this way, he would have been most earnest to have it destroyed; or, rather, if he had a grain of common sense, he would never have written at all, "for there is nothing concealed that shall not be made known." We hardly know which characteristics are more remarkably displayed in these documents, the ignorance and subserviency of those who wrote to DAVIS from the North, or the arrogance and deadly earnestness of his Southern friends.

abstract: -- A CITIZEN KILLED BY A COLORED CITIZEN. -- WM. Fox, a gardener to Mrs. BUTLER, was shot on Friday night at Camp Wm. Penn, Chelton Hills, by a colored sentry named CHARLES REILLY, and died in an hour from the effects of his injuries. Deceased, who was in company with several men and boys, stopped at a fence near the post of REILLY, and was ordered away. The others started off, but FOX remained and denied the right of the sentry to compel him to go. The Corporal of the Guard was called for by REILLY, and to the question what was the matter, the sentry replied that some men were at the fence and refused to leave. A voice cried out. "Shoot them, then." At this REILLY raised his gun and said. "Are you going to leave? If you don't I'll shoot." "I guess not," replied FOX, who seemed to look upon the matter as a joke. In another moment the sentry fired his gun, and the shot took effect in the right wrist, and then passed through the body. The report of the musket brought the officers of the camp to the scene of the shooting, and the ball was extracted by the regimental surgeon, Dr. J.F. HOLT. Mr. FOX was then removed to his residence, and died in about an hour. Lieut-Col. WAGNER made an investigation of the affair, and ascertained that the Corporal of the Guard did not use the words "shoot them," but they were used by one of the privates off duty. The Corporal of the Guard did not arrive until the shooting was over. REILEY gave as an excuse for the shooting that he thought the man was getting over the fence. Coroner CONRAD will investigate the matter to-day, and the investigation should be a thorough one. The shooting, as it now appears, was wholly unjustifiable. There was no attempt to get within the camp ground, nor was anything done to call for interference on the part of the sentry. The deceased was there a mere spectator, and it is not pretended that he did not conduct himself properly. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 10.

abstract: The im  mense number of deaths from sun-stroke during the last four weeks may be accounted for in part, not only by the great heat of the sun, but by the extraordinary prevalence of southeast winds. These winds come directly off the Gulf stream, heavily laden with moisture, which induces so damp and heavy a condition of the atmosphere, that it prevents or retards the natural perspiration of the body.
lead_paragraph: The immense number of deaths from sun-stroke during the last four weeks may be accounted for in part, not only by the great heat of the sun, but by the extraordinary prevalence of southeast winds. These winds come directly off the Gulf stream, heavily laden with moisture, which induces so damp and heavy a condition of the atmosphere, that it prevents or retards the natural perspiration of the body. The atmosphere being already saturated to repletion, refuses to absorb the moisture of the body, and as free perspiration is the means of evaporating the heat from the human system, and this not being active, the man dies as it were from the generation of heat in his own body.

abstract: HELD TO AWAIT THE ACTION OF THE GRAND JURY. -- Coroner BARRETT, of Brooklyn, E.D., on Friday evening last, concluded the investigations into the death of GEORGE BREUDE, the aged German who was killed by the fist of SAMUEL JOHNSON, a colored man. The striking was impulsively done while the German was sitting by JOHNSON's wife, with a heavy stick, and on being knocked down the aged man hit his head on a projection of a wall -- causing almost immediate death. The affair occurred on Sunday week, at No. 7 Marshall-street, Brooklyn, E.D. The evidence shows that the blow without the fall would not have caused death, but the jury held JOHNSON to await the action of the Grand Jury, and also CHARLES HONABLE, a witness of the transaction. They further censured Mr. PHILIP ENGLEHART for neglecting to procure medical aid for the injured man.

lead_paragraph: The draft in this City will be resumed on Wednesday next, at 10 o'clock A.M., in the Sixth District, at the headquarters of the Assistant Provost-Marshal, No. 165 Sixth-avenue. This fact is announced officially this morning in our advertising columns. In anticipation of this important event, Major-Gen. DIX, who is now in command of the Department of the East, has issued an address to the citizens of New-York, explaining the circumstances under which the draft is to be made, commanding submission to the terms of the Conscription law, and closing with a significant warning of ample preparation on the part of the authorities to meet all unlawful opposition promptly and effectually. We also publish this morning an important letter from Provost-Marshal-General FRY to the Secretary of War, in answer to the allegations contained in the letter of Adj.-Gen. WATERBURY, regarding the enrollment in this State.

abstract: The Third colored regiment, under command of Col. C.B. TILGHMAN, numbering one thousand men, who have for some time past been encamped at Camp William Penn, Chelton Hills, about eight miles from Philadelphia, on the line of the North Pennsylvania Railroad, took their departure for Charleston yesterday morning. The regiment left campt at halfpast seven o'clock, and taking the cars of the North Pennsylvania Railroad, arrived at America and Master streets about nine o'clock.

abstract: After careful and particular inquiry, it cannot be ascertained that any prominent parties in the South have made any formal proposition to the United States authorities for terms of peace. Nor has even a hint for an accommodation been suggested. The vigorous prosecution of the war is regarded by the Administration as the best mode of ending it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Aug. 16.

abstract: All the Broadway theatres, with the exception of LAURA KEENE's, will be open to-night -- an unusual state of things for the dog days, and indicating equal tenacity of constitution and capacity for amusement on the part of the good public. LAURA KEENE's Theatre has passed into the hands of Mr. DUFF, who has leased it to Mrs. JOHN WOOD for a period of years. The fair lessee will take possession in a few weeks, and in the interval the interior of the house is being remodeled and newly decorated. One of the earliest changes will, we presume, be in the name, for Mrs. JOHN WOOD is not likely to sail under any colors but her own, and Miss LAURA KEENE, it is rumored, (but in a very mysterious and non-committal sort of way,) is having a new theatre built for herself up town. Not one, but half a dozen new theatres should be crected in the City. As an investment there is no property that pays so well. Theatres are always occupied, and the rent, in doubtful cases, can be obtained in advance. At present they are confined almost exclusively to Broadway. Persons living far west or east are subjected to a long journey across the City before they can reach them. A few well-conducted places of amusement, erected in the populous districts of the East and North River, would pay handsomely. Whilst on this subject, we may mention that Mr. PIKE, of the Cincinnati Opera House, will, it is stated, erect a new Opera House in this City; a house for theatrical performances is also in course of erection in Brooklyn.

abstract: In the Democratic State Convention of Maine, held in Portland last week for the nomination of State officers, the question was asked whether Hon. BION BRADBURY, the candidate for Governor, "would, as he would have a right to do, withdraw the troops now in the field?" To this Gen. S.J. ANDERSON, his special friend, replied: "When Gov. SEYMOUR withdraws the New-York troops, then I pledge you that BION BRADBURY will withdraw the Maine troops."
lead_paragraph: In the Democratic State Convention of Maine, held in Portland last week for the nomination of State officers, the question was asked whether Hon. abstract: COLLECTOR LOW PROHIBITS THE SHIPMENT. -- On Saturday, a lot of blasting powder was sent to Jackson-street wharf, to be shipped to Acapulco, on board the schooner Wild Pigeon. As this was contraband of war to that port, the officers of the Wild Pigeon refused to receive it without a permit from the Collector of the Port, while the charterers of the vessel demanded that it should be taken, as no reservation as to kind of freight was mentioned in the charter party. The French Consul, hearing of the intended shipment to Acapulco, waited on the Collector and protested against it; and also warned the officers of the Wild Pigeon that if it were taken she would be liable to seizure if fallen in with by any French war vessel which might be on the Mexican coast. The Consul stated that there were mines in the States of Sinaloa, Sonora, Durango and Lower California, but none in the State of Guerrero, and that if the Collector should receive satisfactory proof from reliable persons that the powder, was to be used for mining purposes only in the States first mentioned, that he would withdraw his protest, as he did not desire to embarrass any purely mining or ordinary mercantile business. He added, that he had no power to enforce his protest, but if it were disregarded, that it would he looked at as an unfriendly act and hostile to the interests of France. The result was, that the Collector determined that the powder should not be shipped to Acapulco anyhow, nor to other Mexican ports, if satisfactory assurances were not received from responsible parties that it was intended for mining uses only. The powder has since been returned to the magazine. We understand that the charterers, when applied to, were unwilling to give the name of the intended shipper, which unwillingness is deemed a very suspicious circumstance as connected with its shipment to a port where no mining requirement for the article are said to exist. -- San Francisco Bulletin, July 20.

abstract: Sergt. CHARLES G. FRAZER, of the Second Delaware regiment, a paroled prisoner, just from Richmond, called in yesterday, and gave us the cutjoined statement with regard to general affairs at Richmond, and what he saw while en route there. The Second Delaware was attached to HANCOCK'S corps at the battle of Gettysburgh, and Mr. FRAZER was captured on the second day of the light, together with about two hundred others, belonging to various other regiments.
lead_paragraph: From the Philadelphia Inquirer, Aug. 15.

lead_paragraph: There will be found in the TIMES this morning three official documents of very great interest and importance to the citizens of New-York. One of these documents (to be found in our advertising columns) consists of three parts -- the first being an announcement from the President of the number of troops (2,050) assigned as the first proportional part of the quota to be furnished by the Sixth District -- the second being an order from the Provost-Marshal-General to make the draft in the aforesaid district with the least possible delay -- and the third part being a notification from the Provost-Marshal of the same district that the draft therein will be commenced on Wednesday of this week, at 10 o'clock in the morning.

abstract: By the steamship Hibernian, which passed Cape Race on Friday evening, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Greencastle on the 7th inst. The political news by this arrival is of but little importance. The rebel Cotton Loan on the 5th touched a point as low as 35 per cent. discount, but subsequently rallied somewhat, the latest quotations being 26 to 24 discount.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Hibernian, which passed Cape Race on Friday evening, we receive advices from Europe five days later. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Greencastle on the 7th inst. The political news by this arrival is of but little importance. The rebel Cotton Loan on the 5th touched a point as low as 35 per cent. discount, but subsequently rallied somewhat, the latest quotations being 26 to 24 discount. The London Times editorily apologizes for the tumble in the loan, and says that if the battle of Gettysburgh had resulted differently, the sagacity of the patrons of the loan would have been justified. The Times also contains a letter from Mr. MCRAE, agent for the loan, who explains the means taken by the rebel Government to secure an amount of cotton adequate to secure the loan. Their purchases, he says, will "probably" amount to 500,000 bales. The London Morning Post thinks the "bluster" of the North regarding Canada may have the good effect of inducing the Canadians to look after their defences. The aspect of the Polish question has undergone little change. It is understood that, instead of a collective note to Russia, each of the Powers will forward a separate one, but identical in idea. The Russians had suffered another defeat at the hands of the revolutionists. The Emperor of Austria has invited an assembly of the German sovereigns, to discuss the question of a reorganization of the Germanic Confederation. The Liverpool Cotton market was flat and unchanged. Breadstuffs and Provisions were dull. Consoles were quiet at 93@93 1/8 for money.

abstract: Gen. SIBLEY telegraphs, under date of the 7th inst., that he has had three engagements with 2,200 Sioux warriors, in all of which the Indians were routed, and finally driven across the Missouri River, with the loss of all their subsistence, &c., and at least one hundred and fifty killed and wounded. The loss among the white troops was but seven killed and wounded. Gen. POPE considers Indian hostilities east of the Missouri as at an end, LITTLE CROW, the principal Chief, having been killed, and his son captured.

abstract: Capt. THOMAS W. THORNE, City Hall. Early on Monday thousands of excited people were gathered in the Park and in Printing-House-square. Incendiary harangues were made, and threats uttered; every colored man met in the vicinity was attacked and beaten. Capt. THORNE detailed five of his force, in citizen's dress, who mingled with the different crowds, and reported every fifteen minutes. At 5 1/2 o'clock P.M. the force with Capt. WENLOW's command reported to headquarters, and were sent thence to the First Precinct, through which tour was made. On returning at dusk, met by citizens at the Post-office, who informed them of attack on Tribune building. Started up Nassau-street at double-quick, came on the crowd of five or six thousand, the work of destruction having been commenced, the office entered, gutted and fired. Capt. THORNE gave the word to his men to keep together. The order to charge was given, and on went, without waiting to estimate odds, the handful, with a ringing cheer, against the thousands; the first blow was received by the Captain, a bludgeon on the head, knocking him back six feet; down went the man who gave it by the locust of Officer COWEN; on went the men, dealing blows right and left, desperately and with fearful effect; the mob even with its proportions could not stand the impetuous charge; they fought a few moments, surged back, and then again swung forward as though to crush out the force; it was too late; on and among them were the command, nearly every blow bringing to the ground a rioter; in one place, six lay so close as almost to touch each other; it was too much for the lawless, and after hard and hand-to-hand fighting to Frankfort-street, they broke, fleeing in wild confusion. That portion which went up Chatham and Centre streets were closely followed for a while, and severely clubbed by this force; that portion which fled across the Park were met by Inspector CARPENTER and his men, and scores knocked down. No mercy was shown, and over a hundred lay in the square and Park, the well-punished victims of their own folly and crime.
lead_paragraph: Capt. THOMAS W. THORNE, City Hall. Early on Monday thousands of excited people were gathered in the Park and in Printing-House-square. Incendiary harangues were made, and threats uttered; every colored man met in the vicinity was attacked and beaten. Capt. THORNE detailed five of his force, in citizen's dress, who mingled with the different crowds, and reported every fifteen minutes. At 5 1/2 o'clock P.M. the force with Capt. WENLOW's command reported to headquarters, and were sent thence to the First Precinct, through which tour was made. On returning at dusk, met by citizens at the Post-office, who informed them of attack on Tribune building. Started up Nassau-street at double-quick, came on the crowd of five or six thousand, the work of destruction having been commenced, the office entered, gutted and fired. Capt. THORNE gave the word to his men to keep together. The order to charge was given, and on went, without waiting to estimate odds, the handful, with a ringing cheer, against the thousands; the first blow was received by the Captain, a bludgeon on the head, knocking him back six feet; down went the man who gave it by the locust of Officer COWEN; on went the men, dealing blows right and left, desperately and with fearful effect; the mob even with its proportions could not stand the impetuous charge; they fought a few moments, surged back, and then again swung forward as though to crush out the force; it was too late; on and among them were the command, nearly every blow bringing to the ground a rioter; in one place, six lay so close as almost to touch each other; it was too much for the lawless, and after hard and hand-to-hand fighting to Frankfort-street, they broke, fleeing in wild confusion. That portion which went up Chatham and Centre streets were closely followed for a while, and severely clubbed by this force; that portion which fled across the Park were met by Inspector CARPENTER and his men, and scores knocked down. No mercy was shown, and over a hundred lay in the square and Park, the well-punished victims of their own folly and crime.

abstract: Our advices from Gen. BLUNT and his army are not of the most encouraging character. At last accounts they were unquestionably in a situation of peril, and but for our confidence in the commander, we should regard their case as desperate. As it stands, it is more than probable a battle before this has been fought, and owing to the great disparity of numbers, we should not be surprised to learn of a defeat to the Union arms.

abstract: It is not necessary that the infantry which it is proposed to mount for hard service in the Southwest should all be mounted upon horses. Mules are more available, and in many respects more serviceable. They are more enduring, require less care, live upon far less, and are cheaper. It is not intended that the new mounted infantry shall fight mounted, but only that the animals shall carry the men over the great distances involved in Western campaigning, and set them down fresh and unfatigued, ready for work as infantry; and the use of mules instead of horses will take away the temptation which besets this class of soldiers to fight mounted, for the mule has mental and moral qualities which unfit him for taking part in the contests of the battle-field. The splendid description given by Job of the war horse, which "smelleth the battle afar off and plungeth into it, mocking at fear, and filled with fierceness and rage; which laughs at the sound of the trumpets, the thunder of the captains and the shouting; whose neck is clothed with thunder, and the glory of whose nostrils is terrible," does not apply at all to the hybrid mule. But if the mule, like the negro, lacks the highest military qualities, he has other excellent characteristics of belly and brains, and they are just the characteristics that are needed in the kind of service required for mounted infantry.

abstract: A Washington telegram announces that there are indications that LEE designs making another offensive movement by the left flank of our army. The announcement, it is true, only comes in the shape of a "vague suspicion;" but there are intrinsic probabilities that render such action on the part of the rebel General not at all unlikely. Now is undoubtedly his opportunity, looking both to the condition of his own army and of ours. There is good evidence that his army is this moment numerically superior to ours. It is pretty certain that LEE has been reinforced by one corps, or at least one division of BRAGG's army. Our own force is now at its minimum. The two years' men are all out. On the other hand we gain by time. The drafted men are going forward. In less than a month the Army of the Potomac may be reinforced by a hundred thousand fresh troops. If the friends of the Confederacy had been able to squelch the draft, it would have been all very well. But the firm attitude of the Government has removed all hope of this. All our armies will speedily be strengthened by large additions. The policy, therefore, of an enterprising leader like LEE is to take time by the forelock, anticipate events, concentrate for decisive blows, and seize the prestige which the offensive always imparts. MEADE's army is not at present well placed. It has no naturally strong defensive line. Both wings are, in military parlance, "in the air." Nevertheless, Gen. MEADE has shown that he well deserves the implicit confidence of the country. If he is strong enough to give battle with good prospect of success he will do so. If not he will retire his army within the defences of Washington, until his depleted battalions are filled up with the fruits of the draft. We own, we should not be sorry to see him do so in any event. The stretch of territory between the Potomac and the Rappahannock is of no earthly importance to either army. It is without an ear of corn for man or a blade of forage for beast. It can be taken at any time by us. The mere holding of fifty odd miles of barren territory under such circumstances is of no account. Our present business is to recruit our armies. We can wait. The rebels cannot. it was about setting forth upon a long expedition in pursuit of the rebels in that section. The mules did their work nobly, as did also the men mounted upon them, and the success of the experiment was so great that the regiment have used their mules in all their expeditions ever since, and have performed an extraordinary amount of service. We have always been astonished, as the scheme worked so well in this instance, that its application was not extended.

abstract: There has been a very large assemblage of Christian patriots here to-day, at a Convention of the Christian Commission, which crowded the Baptist Church in this place morning and evening. President HOPKINS, of Williams College presided. After the reading of the Scriptures and prayer, Rev. GEO. J. MISGINS, a delegate of the Commission, made a most earnest and eloquent address. Some of the incidents which he related drew tears from unaccustomed eyes.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA, Friday, Aug. 14, 1863.

abstract: FLAG FOR THE IRON BRIGADE. -- There is on exhibition at the store of Messrs. TIFFANY & CO., a beautiful flag, which has been procured for the celebrated "Iron Brigade," of the First army corps, Army of the Potomac. The flag is of regulation size, and made of heavy dark blue silk. It is embellished by a handsome vignette of eagle, shield, and scroll motto, "E Pluribus Unum" -- the same as on the ten dollar Treasury note. The names of the principal battles in which the brigade has been engaged are handsomely worked, each on a separate scroll. The vignette, the scroll work, and the name of each regiment composing the brigade -- the Second, Sixth, and Seventh Wisconsin, Nineteenth Indiana and Twenty-fourth Michigan -- are all worked in the flag with silk chenille, and the shading is most exquisitely done. A rich and heavy border adds to and completes the effect. The staff is mounted with a massive silver spear-head. The flag has bean manufactured by Messrs. TIFFANY & CO., under the supervision of W.T. SELL[???]CK, Esq., Military Agent of Wisconsin, and is the gift of a number of gentlemen from the States of Wisconsin, Indiana and Michigan. It is a fit and elegant tribute to the heroism of one of the most glorious organizations in the entire army.

abstract: Gen. Dix's Address on Resumption of the; Address on Renewal of Draft in New-York
snippet: Gen. Dix's Address on Resumption of the; Address on Renewal of Draft in New-York
lead_paragraph: The Draft will commence in this City next Wednesday, Aug. 19, in the Sixth District, Marshal J.W. FARR, which comprises the Ninth, Fifteenth and Sixteenth Wards, The quota of this District is two thousand and fifty; but fifty per cent. in addition to this will be drawn, in order to meet the contingencies of exemptions, &., making the number taken from the wheel three thousand and seventy-five, of this, the Ninth, or First sub-District, furnishes one thousand one hundred; the Fifteenth, or Second sub-District, seven hundred and ninety-four; and the Sixteenth, or third sub-district, 1,181. The draft is from the first class, which embraces all between the ages of twenty and thirty-five, married or single, and up to forty-five unmarried. It will be made separately on the enrollment lists of each district, and will commence at 10 o'clock A.M., at the Provost Marshal's office, No. 165 Sixth-avenue. The drafting will take place place publicly. Whatever corrections were needed in the enrollment have been carefully and thoroughly made, and there will not be afforded the last opportunity for cavil either as to their accuracy, or as to the manner of conducting the draft.

abstract: The Resumption of, in New-York; Corporation Exemption Ordinance
snippet: The Resumption of, in New-York; Corporation Exemption Ordinance
lead_paragraph: The ordinance of the City Government, appropriating three millions of dollars to relieve citizens of New-York from the draft, has been so perfected as to free it from many of the objections that lay against it in the first case. As it now stands, it need not become very oppressive to the City treasury, nor at all embarrassing to the Government. A careful and honest administration of it will, on the contrary, wholly disarm the late complaining parties of all just grounds of resentment, and lead to active enlistments of men who will serve cheerfully as soldiers.

abstract: -- We have before reported that this British thief plundered and destroyed the ship Southern Cross, but a letter from Capt HOWES, dated Ceara, Brazil, July 6, gives a few facts not before published. Capt. HOWES showed the pirate commander that his cargo was shipped on French account, but he replied that made no difference, "the ship was American, and bound to New-York and would, therefore, be burned;" and he was as bad as his word. Capt. HOWES had his wife with him, and some of her trunks were plundered by the British robbers, though MAFFIT himself, the tool of his British masters, treated the lady well. The crew of the Southern Cross have since arrived at New-York; but the Captain, his wife and three mates were at Ceara, and would return home by the way of Pernambuco. -- Boston Journal.
lead_paragraph: -- We have before reported that this British thief plundered and destroyed the ship Southern Cross, but a letter from Capt HOWES, dated Ceara, Brazil, July 6, gives a few facts not before published. Capt. HOWES showed the pirate commander that his cargo was shipped on French account, but he replied that made no difference, "the ship was American, and bound to New-York and would, therefore, be burned;" and he was as bad as his word. Capt. HOWES had his wife with him, and some of her trunks were plundered by the British robbers, though MAFFIT himself, the tool of his British masters, treated the lady well. The crew of the Southern Cross have since arrived at New-York; but the Captain, his wife and three mates were at Ceara, and would return home by the way of Pernambuco. -- Boston Journal.

abstract: The Siege of
lead_paragraph: We read with some degree of trepidation the telegraphic announcement already several times promulgated, to the effect that, when the grand bombardment opens on Sumter, "the rebel stronghold is sure to fall in two hours." We chance to remember that, on the occasion of the last attack, we were positively assured that Admiral DUPONT would make a brick pile of Sumter in "an hour and a half," which turned out to be just about the time it took to drive our whole iron fleet chop-fallen out of the harbor.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday afternoon by Coroner RANNEV, at the Bellevue Hospital, on the body of a young man named GEORGE BOUGH. The deceased died from wounds received on Thursday last from a mad ox. He and his brother were passing along First-avenue, and when is the vicinity of Thirty-second-street, a large and infuriated ox came dashing toward them at a fearful rate of speed. Just as the animal arrived opposite Thirty-second-street it caught on its horns a man who was trying to get across the avenue. The man was tossed into the air and much injured by the fall. The next victim was a child, which the beast caught upon one horn, twirled it in the air with the greatest ease, and threw it upon the sidewalk in a bruised and bleeding state. The poor child was so much injured that it is not expected to recover.

abstract: Yesterday Admiral PAULDING received orders from the Navy Department to dispatch to sea at once the United States steamer Quaker City. The authorities of the yard immediately were set to work to prepare the vessel, and in a few hours she had all the stores and provisions on board and everything ready to depart. She cleared from the wharf about 4 o'clock in the afternoon, having on board the special orders of the Navy Department, and being bound for some unknown destination. The Quaker City is a side-wheel steamer, of nine guns, 1,000 tons burden, and rates second class in the navy. She was attached to Admiral DUPONT's fleet, but got so worn out in service the she had to be sent home for repairs, which have been effected in the same satisfactory manner. The following is a list of her officers: Commander, J.M. WAILEY; Lieutenant, Silas Carey; Ensigns, H.J. Blanchard, A. Delano, T. Halstead, Charles Hill; Surgeon, J.J. Bromlee; Engineers, Geo. W. Farrel. Henry Wanklin, E.T. McG[???]nnis, J.J. King, John K. Hickey, Sandford B. Hawes, James R. Wilbue.

abstract: Draper, J. W., M. D., LL. D.; Intellectual Development of Europe
snippet: Draper, J. W., M. D., LL. D.; Intellectual Development of Europe
lead_paragraph: If there be any truth, in the Greek proverb that "a great book is a great evil," Mr. BUCKLE has much to answer for. The success he achieved in his attempt to introduce the forms of scientific induction into the phenomena of human affairs, has given rise to a score of pretenders in the same field, both in Europe and America; and. for our own part, we have come to regard the Philosophy of History as a good deal of a humbug -- not to say a good deal of a bore. By this we hope it will not be understood that we fail to appreciate the value of the tendency of this class of investigation. The guiding principle that human affairs obey the same governance of cause and effect operative in nature -- that the multifarious and complex outgivings of the mind of man in politics, society and life, that constitute history, are the work of reason, consequently rational, that is, logical, and hence subject to scientific treatment, is a thought destined to be in many ways, and in the largest sense, what BACON called "fruitful." But this principle, so far from being a new discovery, (as our modern charlatanism claims,) was really never absent from the minds of the great philosophers, poets and statesmen. The belief in the moral order of the universe indeed was, with the Greeks, an article of aesthetic faith; and DANTE, SHAKESPEARE, ST. AUGUSTINE, SPINOSA, MACHIAVELLI, PASCAL, BACON, are full of the same sublime thought, whether developed in aphorisms or running unconsciously, as the animating soul, through their work. It is true that, toward the close of last century, for the first time, this principle was seized upon as a conscious instrument of historical investigation, and applied with great success by MONTESQUIEU and CONDORCET, in France; HERDER, in Germany, and by HUME and ADAM SMITH, in England. Since that time this tendency has been favored by the great development given to history in general, both through the vast accession of historical material and by the importation of new methods of historical treatment and criticism. All our best modern historical works, as for example GROTE, NIEBUHR. MOMMSEN, BUNSEN, GUIZOT, MACAULAY, THIERS, THIERRY, SISMONDI, HALLAM, CARLYLE, show profoundly the impress of the new manner of dealing with history, That history shall deal with the broad humanities, instead of circling around Kings and Courts, that political and social growths are traceable to necessary causes, that "through the ages one increasing purpose runs," are acquired truths whose light and guidance we hope never to lose.

abstract: Mr. W.H. MARKS, a refugee from Lexington. Va., to whose statements we have already alluded, has made further revelation. He states that he last week saw in one body more than one hundred deserters from LEE's army, composed of men from North Carolina, Texas. Alabama. Georgia and Mississippi regiments, going home through Rockbrige County, and the Provost Guard was afraid to oppose them. Coming up the valley he learned that four hundred or five hundred men from different regiments had left for home, with their arms. and a fight occurred near Snickers Ferry between these deserters and STUART's cavalry, in which the deserters routed the cavalry, and then made off.

abstract: A few days  ago we had some shocking news by telegraph from California concerning a secession rebellion there, which some of our cotemporaries worked up into a first-class sensation. lead_paragraph: -- A few days ago we had some shocking news by telegraph from California concerning a secession rebellion there, which some of our cotemporaries worked up into a first-class sensation. But we observed on a close reading of the dispatch that it consisted of a "rumor of a contemplated uprising of secessionists," and that "it was discredited." Sensible people could not be expected to go into spasms over a rumor, a discredited rumor, of the belligerent nature of somebody's contemplations; and we were not surprised when, the day after the publication of this dispatch, another was received to the effect that "the reports of trouble were untrue." Judging by the telegrams this morning from the same quarter, however, we should not wonder if trouble were brewing in California. Read the following from San Francisco, under date of Saturday last, and see if there are not grounds for it:

abstract: The substitute market was again in an excited state yesterday, and quite a number of swindling deserters and their more criminal alders and abettors came to grief before the going down of the sun. Not a substitute was finally accepted by either Board. JOHN LEO progressed so far in the First District as to receive his money and be sworn in, but before he got his uniform on he was recognized as a deserter, he and his factor made to disgorge the money, and he was marched to the lock-up. The draftee, whose $300 were saved, was a happy conscript for several hours thereafter.

abstract: The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool and Queenstown, and the Bremen, from Southampton, arrived at this port last evening. Their advices are not so late as were received by the Hibernian off Cape Race, but we receive our mail details to the 6th inst. News of further captures by the rebel pirates on the South American coast had reached England -- some two or three ships in addition to those before reported. The pirates, however, now seem to have adopted the plan of bonding the vessels captured by them -- such, at all events, being the case with these latest captures. The rebel cotton loan appears to be hopelessly down. The London Times says that anticipation of the full of Charleston is one of the causes of its depression. The American war was a prominent topic of discussion at the half-yearly meeting of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce on the 3d inst. The President, (Mr. MCFIE.) Mr. JAMES SPENCE. the well known Secessionist advocate, and Mr. PATTERSON, a prominent supporter of the North all virtually expressed the opinion that the disastrous conflict was not far from its close. Mr. C. TURNER, M.P., referring to the Foreign Enlistment Act, said it was most desirable that England should be perfectly neutral in all foreign wars, selling munitions of war neither to one side nor to the other. But he feared that non-interference to this extent was impossible. He could not see that any beneficial result would follow an alteration of the present law bearing on the question. Coming to the case of the Alabama, he said he thought that so long as the exportation of gunpowder and arms was permitted it would be un-fair to prevent "free trade in ships." No new light is thrown on the Polish question by these arrivals.

abstract: The Provost-Marshal-General established a fact for the enunciation of which few people were prepared, when he showed by statistics that volunteering has been at such a low ebb that since the opening of the year the State of New-York has only, furnished about a thousand recruits a month to the National Army. This was an effect neither of the Emancipation Proclamation nor of the Conscription Act, for volunteering was just as low in the...
lead_paragraph: The Provost-Marshal-General established a fact for the enunciation of which few people were prepared, when he showed by statistics that volunteering has been at such a low ebb that since the opening of the year the State of New-York has only, furnished about a thousand recruits a month to the National Army. This was an effect neither of the Emancipation Proclamation nor of the Conscription Act, for volunteering was just as low in the closing months of last year, before either of these measures became law or were announced. But this is not the only thing that shows the necessity of adopting some more effective means of sustaining the strength of our army until the rebellion shall be crushed. Those who, in the face of facts, are every day proclaiming the efficiency of volunteering as a means of filling up the ranks, and abusing the Government for not still relying on it, carefully overlook its greatest defect, and that which has, perhaps, more than any other, led military men to condemn it.

abstract: The Hibernian brought the news that the great rebel cotton loan had declined on the London market to 35 per cent, discount, in spite of all the efforts of rebel sympathizers to sustain it. One effort of this kind was a letter from a Mr. MCRAE, agent for the loan, who states that the cotton purchased by the Confederate Government is some 500,000 bales, mainly in Georgia and Alabama, but some also in Eastern Mississippi, Northwestern Louisiana and Texas, and is stored on the plantations of planters from whom it was purchased, in warehouses 300 feet from other buildings. We take it, the object of this letter of Mr. MCRAE, was to convince the credulous that the successes of Gen. GRANT and Gen. BANKS should have little or no influence upon the rebel Loan, because but little of the cotton upon which it was based was in the immediate vicinity of that section of the Southwest where they were operating. But we are inclined to think that Mr. MCRAE's statement will be more than overpowered by the effect of a letter from MEMMINGER, the Secretary of the rebel Treasury, which we published a day or two since, stating that the fall of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson exposed to our forces all the cotton purchased by the rebel authorities in Mississippi and Louisiana, and that the rebel Generals should be instructed to destroy all of it which they could not preserve from our hands. Holders of the loan would undoubtedly be pleased to learn that the cotton is stored on the plantations in sheds three hundred feet from other buildings, but when they learn from Mr. MEMMINGER that the planters will probably run away from the plantations, and therefore the rebel officers are instructed to burn all they cannot carry off, they will think there is probably some danger to it from fire. And lest they should console themselves with the thought that this applies only to what is in Mississippi and Louisiana, this letter of Mr. MEMMINGER is accompanied by one from Mr. DEBOW, in Alabama, to the Mobile Advertiser, informing the public in that State that this is the policy of the rebel Government, and that he had ceased to purchase cotton in Mississippi, whether Eastern or Western.

But we are inclined to think that Mr. MCRAE's statement will be more than overpowered by the effect of a letter from MEMMINGER, the Secretary of the rebel Treasury, which we published a day or two since, stating that the fall of Vicksburgh and Port Hudson exposed to our forces all the cotton purchased by the rebel authorities in Mississippi and Louisiana, and that the rebel Generals should be instructed to destroy all of it which they could not preserve from our hands. Holders of the loan would undoubtedly be pleased to learn that the cotton is stored on the plantations in sheds three hundred feet from other buildings, but when they learn from Mr. MEMMINGER that the planters will probably run away from the plantations, and therefore the rebel officers are instructed to burn all they cannot carry off, they will think there is probably some danger to it from fire. And lest they should console themselves with the thought that this applies only to what is in Mississippi and Louisiana, this letter of Mr. MEMMINGER is accompanied by one from Mr. DEBOW, in Alabama, to the Mobile Advertiser, informing the public in that State that this is the policy of the rebel Government, and that he had ceased to purchase cotton in Mississippi, whether Eastern or Western.

abstract: The business at the Coroners' Office, during the last month, has been greater than at any time for many years past; indeed, we may safely say, greater than for any one month since the last cholera season. These officials have been constantly busy every day in the week, all through this hot term, and the duties of their clerk and deputies have been correspondingly arduous.

abstract: ALLEDED MURDER OF A WOMAN BY HER BROTHER.-- A man named JOHN MALLOY [???]residing at New Durham, was yesterday committed to the County Jail by Justice POPE, of Hoboken, on a charge of having caused the death of his sister, wife of PATRICK RAILLY, by violence in May last. It appears that on Friday last MALLOY had a difficulty with RAILLY and a man named HULL, both of whom he threatened to shoot, and also threatened to set fire to the house of the latter. For this he was arrested on Saturday night, and committed to jail by justice POPE in default of $ 400 bail. Subsequently the Justice received intimations of foul play, and proceeded to investigate the matter. It appears that MALLOY his sister had a quarrel on the 14th of May last, and, as is alleged, knocked down and then kicked his sister in the chest and stomach, causing internal hemorrhage, resulting in death two days after. These facts were communicated by deceased to a woman that attended her, but for some reason it never became public until the present time. MELLOY will be held to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The grand concert and pic-nic of the German Saengerbund of this City, held yesterday, at Jones' Wood, was one of the most marked and delightful of the many pleasant festivals with which our Teutonic fellow-citizens have enlivened that favorite resort during the passing Summer. Notwithstanding the inclemant appearance of the morning, at 9 o'clock the members of the various singing clubs that compose the general Saengerbund, or Singers' Union assembled at the Metropolitan Rooms in Hester-street -- the headquarters of the Association -- and were there joined by delegations of the Turners and other societies and military corps who proposed to participate in the fete. The procession, after due deliberation respecting the chances of the weather, finally marched off with flags and martial music, by way of the Bowery, Grand-street, Essex-street and Avenue A and Tenth-street, to the foot of the latter, on the East River, where the steamer Magnolia and the barge Anna, commanded by Capt, SCHNEIDER, afforded the throng conveyance to the place of disembarkation at "the Wood." In the procession marched the twelve clubs composing the Bund, viz.: The Allemanla, the Colonia, the Euphonia, the Germania, the Uhland, the Mozart Verein, the Rheinishe, the Williamsburgh Saengerbund, the Liedertafel, the Lonely and the Schillerbund, headed by Wiegand's Band, with Company D. of the Fifth regiment New-York State National Guard, and Company I, of the Eleventh regiment N.Y. S.V., making in all some 1,200 persons. Col. HILLEBRAND Acting Grand Marshal.

abstract: Military Roads in
lead_paragraph: Gen. BURNSIDE has ordered the impressment of six thousand laborers from the negro population of Kentucky, to be employed in the construction of military roads in that State. From the list of counties named in which the first impressment of laborers is to take place, we infer that the Central Railroad, which extends from Covington (opposite Cincinnati) to a point fourteen miles south of Lexington, is to be continued (crossing the Kentucky River) to Danville, a further distance of twenty-one miles; and that the Lebanon branch of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad is to be continued from Lebanon, a distance of twenty-eight miles, also to Danville. These two important roads -- one reaching from Cincinnati and the other from Louisville to Danville, very nearly the geographical centre of the State -- will then probably be continued southwardly, in the general direction of Knoxville, Tenn., which place it is intended, no doubt, to reach by the proposed military highway.

abstract: RECOVERED. Yesterday morning Coroner BARRETT held an inquest on the body of a boy named CHRISTOPHER MCELLIGOT, five years old, who was drowned some days since at the foot of North-secondstreet, E.D. The body was recovered yesterday in the dock at North Fourth-street, E.D. When the lad was drowned fifteen persons stood by without attempting a rescue.

abstract: A case of some interest was heard to-day before Chief Justice LOWRIE, of the Supreme Court. A writ of habeas corpus was issued on the 5th inst., directed to Capt. WM. B. COULTER, Provost-Marshal of the Twenty-first District, to-produce the body of JOHN T. CARNEY, of Greene Township, Indiana County. The return set out that CARNEY, a drafted man, had been examined by the Board and exempted for disability, and a certificate to that effect given him, but the Board subsequently arrested him and reexamined him and held him as fit for duty. No allegation of fraud was made, but the reason given for the reexamination was that the Board had deemed themselves in error in their first proceeding. The counsel for the relator contended that the Board having once taken up and decided the case, and given the certificate of exemption, their adjudication was final and conclusive and their power over the exempted man was exhausted. On a partial hearing on the 11th. District-Attorney CARNAHAN obtained leave to amend the return in order to put in a plea against the jurisdiction of the Court, contending that the State Courts had no jurisdiction over questions arising under the new Conscription law. On the hearing to-day that plea was abandoned, and the argument was confined to the point above stated. After a full hearing, the Chief Justice ordered the discharge of the soldier, holding that from all that appeared by the return, the Board had exhausted their power when the certificate of exemption was granted, and that they had no further control over the prisoner. The prisoner was represented by Judge SHALER and by JOSEPH M. THOMPSON, Esq., of Indiana.

abstract: The  State of Minnesota, feeling aggrieved by the Government's slow and humanitarian mode of conducting war against the hostile Indians within her borders, has lately adopted some very decisive but questionable measures of her own for getting rid of the "red devils." A proclamation appeared offering a State bounty for every "scalp" of a Sioux that should be brought in by volunteer and amateur hunters.
lead_paragraph: -- The State of Minnesota, feeling aggrieved by the Government's slow and humanitarian mode of conducting war against the hostile Indians within her borders, has lately adopted some very decisive but questionable measures of her own for getting rid of the "red devils." A proclamation appeared offering a State bounty for every "scalp" of a Sioux that should be brought in by volunteer and amateur hunters. The document rested of upon the official authority of Gov. (now United States Senator) RAMSEY, and greatly shocked some of that gentleman's Eastern friends, who made haste (too much haste it seems) to repudiate the proclamation as a forgery and a slander.

abstract: The Brooklyn city authorities having been unable to raise a loan of one million dollars from the banks, and having met with no better success in appealing to the community at large, have come to the conclusion to adopt another course, with the view of "ameliorating the hardships of the draft." As neither plan would work, the Board of Contracts and the Common Council Committee held a meeting in the Mayor's Office, yesterday morning, to consult upon the course to pursue hereafter. The Mayor, it is understood, favors the raising of a sum of, say $300,000, with which to commence opera lions by paying the exemptions of such whose finalizes would be liable to suffer to the absence of the main, or only support; or pay the amount to a substitute. The resolutions adopted by the Common Council are not as definite as they might be, and their meaning can be construed differently by persons of different views. The object now appears to be to frame resolutions so as to secure a unanimous vote, if possible, and then, it is contended, all the money required can he procured without difficulty. The ordinance recently passed by the New-York Aldermen meets with general favor, and resolutions of a similar import will no [???] be adopted by the Brooklyn Aldermen. A special meeting to take the matter into consideration is came for Wednesday evening. The resolutions previously passed will then probably be reconsidered, and others substituted, with the view of accomplishing the desired object of providing substitutes for drafted men who have large families.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone or public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: A good deal of interest is associated with the battle in the Indian Territory, which has been imminent for some weeks past, and which has probably been fought by this time. We publish this morning an interesting account of the prospects of the battle, of the forces arrayed on either side, and of the respective officers in command. The commander of the rebels is one STEELE, a renegade New-Yorker, and the Union commander is Gen. BLUNT, well known for his battles, marches and victories in the Far West. The troops on either side will consist of the most notable mixture of colors and races that have yet fought during the war. There will be negroes, Indians, half-breeds, mulattoes and white men. The rebels are said to have about 10,000 men, of whom three-fourths are Indians, under command of Acting Brigadiers SANDY WALKER, STAND WAITIE, and CHILI MCINTOSH. The remainder of their troops are Texans and nondescripts from Western Arkansas. The Union force consists of a Kansas regiment, a Colorado regiment, a negro regiment, and three Indian regiments, with artillery and cavalry -- or less than 5,000 men. The Choctaws and Creeks are the principal rebel tribes, and the Cherokee is the principal loyal tribe; but it is believed the two Creek regiments will desert in mass to our side as soon as the battle commences. Before the war, the Cherokees were the richest community in the world, being highly civilized, having splendid farms, handsome towns and plenty of silver, and being presided over by that shrewd and loyal man, JOHN ROSS; but since the war began their lands have been desolated, their towns sacked, and the people beggared by the ravages of the rebels of all complexions.

abstract: A conscript just from Wilmington, N.C., reports that within the past few days seventeen large steamers have arrived at that port, having run the blockade, loaded with stores for the rebel army, among which are 96,000 English rifles, 160,000 army blankets, 131,000 ready-made uniforms, 23,000 cases of ready-made army shoes, 11 locomotives, 6 rifle cannon, heavy calibre, five cargoes of railroad iron and skillful men accompanying them.

abstract: WAENING TO THOSE WHO MAKE TOO MUCH HASTE. -- Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest on the body of a ad, aged 13 years, named LEONARD MILLER, residing with his parents in the rear of No. 77 Norfolk-street, who died from injuries received, according to the verdict of the Jury, "from being jammed between the ferry-boat Canada and the bridge at the foot of Grand-street, on Sunday, the 16th of August inst.; and we, the Jury, believe it to have been accidental." The testimony in the case disclosed the fact that the deceased, in company with two other lads of about his own age, were on their return from a visit to the Union Cemetery on Long Island; that as the South Seventh-street ferry-boat Canada was entering the slip foot of Grand-street, on the New-York side, the deceased undertook to jump from the bow of the boat to the bridge. His foot slipped and he fell between the two, and was crushed in a horrible manner, causing death almost instantly. The boat was from four to six feet from the bridge when the deceased made the jump. He was warned by his companions and others to wait until the chains were down and others to wait until the chains were down and the boat was fattened to the bridge before he went off, but in vain. This case should serve as a warning to those who are in the constant practice of entering and leaving ferry-boats before they are made fast, or alter they have left the bridge. Not a week passes in which we are not called upon to report serious accidents caused by persons being too hasty in this respect.

abstract: Of the noble army of martyrs that constitutes the Spring and Summer management of the Winter Garden and much do we owe to that plucky and plucked band Mr. HUMPHRY BLAND, who commenced operations on Monday evening, is probably the last. The theatre, like all others of its class on Broadway, must, in the course of a month or so, drift into the regular Winter campaign, which, we presume,...
lead_paragraph: Of the noble army of martyrs that constitutes the Spring and Summer management of the Winter Garden -- and much do we owe to that plucky and plucked band -- Mr. HUMPHRY BLAND, who commenced operations on Monday evening, is probably the last. The theatre, like all others of its class on Broadway, must, in the course of a month or so, drift into the regular Winter campaign, which, we presume, will be under the direction of Mr. JACKSON. Let us, therefore, as a preliminary to the consideration of the bill offered by the new management hasten to do an act of justice to Mr. BLAND. He has had the theatre brushed out and scrubbed. Slight as this attention may seem it is a very important one in the comfort of the frequenters of the theatre; -- a theatre which, we are sorry to say, amongst its other econotmies has not hesitated to include soap and water.

abstract: The administra  tion of the Conscription law in other States has brought to light many of the deceits and frauds by which it is sought to be evaded, and the officers of the Government should benefit by the knowledge thus gained. It is an unpleasant thing to acknowledge, but, nevertheless, it is true that perjury is not unfrequently committed, not only in regard to the residence.
lead_paragraph: The administration of the Conscription law in other States has brought to light many of the deceits and frauds by which it is sought to be evaded, and the officers of the Government should benefit by the knowledge thus gained. It is an unpleasant thing to acknowledge, but, nevertheless, it is true that perjury is not unfrequently committed, not only in regard to the residence, but physicial condition and domestic relations of the drafted persons who seek exemption. A man can only be drafted in his legal domicile, that is, where he has his residence. Many thousands in New-York have a residence quite as easily in one Ward as another, if anything is to be gained by the change. Inasmuch, therefore, as a man living, and drafted say, in the Sixth Ward, is exempt if he is found really to live or have his residence in the First or Fourth or any other Ward, it will require close watching to fix the domicile of many conscripts. So in regard to other quibbles and tricks. A hopeful youth in Philadelphia gained exemption because he was "the only son of his widowed mother," and her "dependence for support," &c. An investigation showed the mother to be a thrifty and flourishing proprietress of a grocery store, who supported the graceless son in idleness. But his papers were all regular, and the certificate of exemption had been issued. It is proper to state, it was speedily canceled, and the youth at last accounts was hunting a substitute.

abstract: It is a noticeable fact that there is not a single copper smelting establishment in New-York. Noticeable because there is an unlimited business for such, and because with the accession of ore which the development of the California mines is making, there will ere long not be enough of such establishments to do the business required of them. The greater portion of the rich ore of California is being shipped to Swansea, Wales, where extensive works are established. At Boston, Mass., there are a few works, but they were erected for the smelting of the Lake Superior ore, and have monopolized this business, which has proved one of great profit. The works are expensive, but the per centage, where sufficient ore is had to keep engaged, is very great, and all that is required to make New-York a centre for the business, is to satisfy California that the facilities are here; the coppery treasure will then flow thither in abundance. Already some dozen mines are open in California, all of them yielding shipping ore, and many more in process of development. Capitalists there are turning attention to these mines in preference to the gold ones, as permanent investments. Afford the assurances of smelting facilities here, and to a certainty there will be an immense business built up. Boston receives a large quantity of the ore, being the only place, as we have said, where it can be worked. The matter is well worth the examination of capitalists; and there are assurances that investigations of the facts in regard to the copper interest will convince them of its magnitude, and of the advantage of turning their attention to it.

abstract: The naval authorities of the Brooklyn Navyyard have reported the iron-clad Lehigh ready for active service. She burst a gun some time since at Fortress Monroe, and came here for a new one. On her arrival, however, she was taken in hand, and improved in every way. The turret gear, which got out of order in one of the vessels during the first contest, is now rendered inaccessible to projectiles...
lead_paragraph: The naval authorities of the Brooklyn Navy-yard have reported the iron-clad Lehigh ready for active service. She burst a gun some time since at Fortress Monroe, and came here for a new one. On her arrival, however, she was taken in hand, and improved in every way. The turret gear, which got out of order in one of the vessels during the first contest, is now rendered inaccessible to projectiles of any description. A huge iron band, no less than five feet in thickness, surrounds the lower part of the turret, and preserves it from all effect of shot. The armament of the vessel has been also changed. She has now one of the 15-inch Dahlgren guns and a 200-pound Parrott, rifled, one of the extraordinary pieces of ordnance whose advent into the navy we noticed some time since. The machinery of the Legigh has been also overhauled, and she is now in a better condition than when she sailed first from Wilmington. She is to leave this City to-morrow, or the day after, it is supposed, for Charleston, to reinforce the armored fleet doing such good service there. The Lehigh is one of the original nine iron-clads constructed immediately after the Monitor.

abstract: THE MILITIA UNDER ARMS. The different militia regiments comprising the Fifth and Eleventh brigades were ordered to be in readiness for active service yesterday. The different organizations met at their respective armories during the day or evening. The Thirteenth and Twenty-eighth met at the City Armory, corner of Henry and Cranberry streets;...
lead_paragraph: THE MILITIA UNDER ARMS. -- The different militia regiments comprising the Fifth and Eleventh brigades were ordered to be in readiness for active service yesterday. The different organizations met at their respective armories during the day or evening. The Thirteenth and Twenty-eighth met at the City Armory, corner of Henry and Cranberry streets; the Twenty-third and Fifty-second met at the armory corner of Fulton and Orange streets; the Fifty-sixth, at the armory in Raymond-street; the Seventieth, at the arsenal in Portland-avenue; and the Forty-seventh at their armory in the Eastern District. Strong guards were detailed last night at all the armories and places where arms and military acoutrements are stored. The regiments are to report at their respective headquarters daily, and to keep themselves in readiness to act at short notice. Since the return of the militia from Pennsylvania and Maryland, one company of each regiment has been kept on constant duty in guarding different places. Now the entire force will be kept under arms until all apprehension of danger growing out of the enforcement of the draft has ceased. The Police are also held in readiness by order of the General Superintendent until further directions.
