abstract: The draft in the Sixth district will commence this morning at 10 o'clock, at No. 105 Sixth avenue, under direction of Provost-Marshal FARE, and Will be publicly conducted. The first drawings will be from the Ninth ward, and the others will follow in numerical order. Those parties who were drawn on the occasion of the first attempt at drafting, are released from all obligations in consequence, and will again take their chances on the wheel with others.

abstract: About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the Tattersal stables, situated on Sixthavenue near Thirty-ninth-street. The buildings were built of wood, three stories in height, and extended seventy-five feet on Sixth-avenue, and one hundred feet on Thirty-ninth-street. The entire structure was destroyed.
lead_paragraph: About 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the Tattersal stables, situated on Sixth-avenue near Thirty-ninth-street. The buildings were built of wood, three stories in height, and extended seventy-five feet on Sixth-avenue, and one hundred feet on Thirty-ninth-street. The entire structure was destroyed. Twenty-five valuable horses, out of the sixty-five which were in the building at the time the fire broke out, were also burned. These horses were valuable fancy and carriage horses, owned by gentlemen in the immediate neighborhood. Those which were destroyed were valued at $10,000, upon which, it is believed, there is very little insurance. Mr. G. ELASHER lost a span valued at $2,000; Mr. WEST, one worth $800; Mr. CHARTIER's loss on horses is $1,000; Mr. WELLS, $600, and several other gentlemen had very fine animals burned.

abstract: -- Rev. M.D. Conway has addressed the following card to the editor of the Philadelphia Press: "I have just seen a note published in the Press, from Mr. Shirley Brooks, of London, who seems to complain that I should have alluded to him, in one of my letters to the Commonwealth, as one of the Tory writers against us in Punch. The point made in my letter, and to support which his name was used, was precisely that in England not every man opposed to our cause is to be supposed Pro-Slavery. Of course, therefore, Mr. Brooks' complaint is but the result of his having only seen a detached portion of my letter. I quoted the case because it seemed to me a very important one; for, of all the attacks and insinuations against the North and its cause, there are few loyal Americans who will not agree that those in Punch have been the most offensive, and it is certainly a startling fact to learn that the author of them is an Anti-Slavery man."
lead_paragraph: -- Rev. The point made in my letter, and to support which his name was used, was precisely that in England not every man opposed to our cause is to be supposed Pro-Slavery. Of course, therefore, Mr. Brooks' complaint is but the result of his having only seen a detached portion of my letter. abstract: A political gathering took place at Rochester yesterday, attended by delegates from several States, including Kentucky, Missouri, Maryland and Wisconsin about thirty in all being present. The meeting appears to be preliminary to organizing in the different States the old Whig and Belt-Everett elements. A secret conference was held in the afternoon, at which the conclusion...
lead_paragraph: A political gathering took place at Rochester yesterday, attended by delegates from several States, including Kentucky, Missouri, Maryland and Wisconsin -- about thirty in all being present. The meeting appears to be preliminary to organizing in the different States the old Whig and Belt-Everett elements. A secret conference was held in the afternoon, at which the conclusion was arrived at that the restoration or peace and the reestablishment of the Union can only be effected by an organization of the "conservative" elements of the North upon a platform similar to that, of the Union Democracy of Kentucky. The Convention will continue to-day.

abstract: By the steamship Asia, which passed Cape Race on Sunday evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th inst. The London Globe announces, apparently upon authority, that no authentic intelligence has been received giving any assurance to the statement that the American conscription was a menace to England.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Asia, which passed Cape Race on Sunday evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later. She left Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th inst. The London Globe announces, apparently upon authority, that no authentic intelligence has been received giving any assurance to the statement that the American conscription was a menace to England. It says there is no interruption of the general amity between the two countries. This statement was called out by the republication in the London Post of a Washington dispatch which originally appeared in one of the New-York morning dailies. The rebel loan on the 7th was quoted at 27@25 discount, but it subsequently rallied two or three per cent, on the news taken out by the Persia, which was imagined to be more favorable to the rebels. The three Powers, England, France and Austria, the London Times says, have agreed to send a common note to Russia, regarding the Polish question. An iron ram building for Russia, in England, has been hurried off to Russia in an incomplete condition, in anticipation of eventualities. A council of war had been held in St. Petersburgh, at the close of which the Vienna and Warsaw Railway had been seized for the transportation of troops for one week. The Paris Bourse was again excited. The Rentes had declined 3/8 per cent. It is reported that Prussia declines to meet with the German Kings to consent in regard to a reorganization of the German Confederation. Several tenders have been made to the American Telegraph Company for the laying of their new cable. Specimens of cotton grown in Java had been received in England, equal to fair middling American. The Liverpool Cotton market is reported firm, with an upward tendency. Breadstuffs quiet, and Provisions firm. Consols were quoted at 92 3/4@92 7/8.

abstract: We  are glad to be able to give the Governor of the State of New-York the credit of a purpose to secure public order and uphold the execution of the laws. Some may think this rather a questionable sort of praise; but we have fallen upon such times that no man or community can feel secure that those who threaten...
lead_paragraph: We are glad to be able to give the Governor of the State of New-York the credit of a purpose to secure public order and uphold the execution of the laws. Some may think this rather a questionable sort of praise; but we have fallen upon such times that no man or community can feel secure that those who threaten it may not spring the mine under their feet and hurl them to destruction. The organs which claim to be the Governor's, and the faction of which he is a leader, have within the last two months used language so seditious, revolutionary and atrocious -- have made such inflammatory appeals to incite the excitable, and such mendacious statements to deceive the ignorant -- have exhibited such contempt for the laws, the Constitution and the Government, such disregard for the public welfare, public rights and the public peace -- that many people dreaded the result, and feared there was too much truth in the claim put forth by these organs, that the Governor would actively side with their schemes, or else that he would wink at them. But, independently of the threats of his friends, or of his action, there has latterly been a feeling of security, from the knowledge that the Government had determined to put forth its power to execute the laws, and to punish active resistance thereto, which is treason, as well in New-York as in Virginia; and in this direction the proclamation of Gen. DIX has been a great aid.

abstract: The steamship Alabama, in the service of the United States, arrived at Lower Quarantine some ten days ago, and was anchored, and stil remains there. She had been cruising between the West Indies and Charleston, and returned with 134 officers and men, 15 of whom have since died of yellow fever. Dr. GUNN, our efficient and valuable Health Officer, at once transhipped the well men and hospital'd the sick, sealed down the hatches, placing...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Alabama, in the service of the United States, arrived at Lower Quarantine some ten days ago, and was anchored, and stil remains there. She had been cruising between the West Indies and Charleston, and returned with 134 officers and men, 15 of whom have since died of yellow fever. Dr. GUNN, our efficient and valuable Health Officer, at once transhipped the well men and hospital'd the sick, sealed down the hatches, placing six "ship-keepers" on board. Three of these have since been attacked with the fever, and two have died. The vessel was the most infected of any reaching this port, and it is not known whether it was so infected at Havana or Key West. The Health Officer has written to the Navy Department, requesting that she be sent north as soon and as far as possible to catch the earliest frost, as the only way to redeem her from the pest. Not an article either in the way of arms, ammunition or clothing has he allowed to be removed from her by officers or men.

abstract: THE $14,000 ROBBERY?ARREST OF THE ALLEGED PRINCIPAL.?It will be recollected that some four weeks since a Pennsylvanian, who was supposed to have left his State to avoid the Conscription, was robbed at the Erie Railway station in Jersey City, of a carpet-bag containing $14,000 in greenbacks.
lead_paragraph: THE $14,000 ROBBERY -- ARREST OF THE ALLEGED PRINCIPAL. -- It will be recollected that some four weeks since a Pennsylvanian, who was supposed to have left his State to avoid the Conscription, was robbed at the Erie Railway station in Jersey City, of a carpet-bag containing $14,000 in greenbacks. Since that time, Chief of Police REILY and Detective KILCAULEY have been engaged in ferreting out the principal, a notorious thief known as "Deaf NED." They finally got traces of his whereabouts and yesterday morning about 8 o'clock succeeded in taking him into custody at a rendezvous for thieves in Laurens-street, near Bleecker, in New-York. The accused was committed to the Hudson County jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: A meeting of the Commissioners of Health was held at the Mayor's Office yesterday, at which it was reported by Health Officer GUNN that no infected vessels had arrived at the Port during the past week. The health and condition of the City were reported excellent, no contagious diseases existing to any extent. A complaint was made by the citizens of Tompkinsville, S.I., of the dumping of offal along shore, which was referred to the City Inspector with power. This last complaint is one of too frequent occurrence, and now that Inspector BOOLE holds the reins there will be a prompt and effective remedy applied.

abstract: In the record of the "Broadway Squad," or the "Twenty-fifth," it was stated that Capt. N.R. MILLS "was not on hand" during riot week. He was not, because of illness and absence was at Sangersfield Centre, Oneida County. So soon as he heard of the riot, (which was on Wednesday evening,) he telegraphed to Inspector CARPENTER to know its proportions, and whether he should return.
lead_paragraph: In the record of the "Broadway Squad," or the "Twenty-fifth," it was stated that Capt. N.R. MILLS "was not on hand" during riot week. He was not, because of illness and absence -- was at Sangersfield Centre, Oneida County. So soon as he heard of the riot, (which was on Wednesday evening,) he telegraphed to Inspector CARPENTER to know its proportions, and whether he should return. The Inspector, knowing his illness, did not answer; so, after waiting a short but reasonable time for reply, the Captain started for Utica, took the first train and came directly through, reporting at Central Office for duty on Thursday evening. All was over by this time, but he at once took command of his force, until, by representation of Surgeon RANNEY, he was allowed another leave of absence to recuperate. Before this was expired, he saw in the papers the rumored renewal of the draft, and at once returned and reported himself for duty on which he is now.

abstract: There is always  very great danger in trying to conduct any affair of life on "sensation" principles. A sensation once started must be maintained to the full stretch of its original tension, if anything is expected to be made of it. Few men get to understand this. BARNUM is a notable instance of success in the list of showmen.
lead_paragraph: -- There is always very great danger in trying to conduct any affair of life on "sensation" principles. A sensation once started must be maintained to the full stretch of its original tension, if anything is expected to be made of it. Few men get to understand this. BARNUM is a notable instance of success in the list of showmen. He made a sensation with "Joyce Heth"-- a greater one with the "woolly horse" -- a greater one with JENNY LIND -- a greater one with the "What is it?" -- a greater one with MINNE WARREN and Commodore NUTT -- and certainly a greater one, in this torrid temperature, with LIZZIE HARRIS and her 678 pounds of seething human flesh. It is by sustaining his role that BARNUM has succeeded, and that "any other man" must succeed.
headline: {'main': 'A SENSATION CANVASS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A SENSATION CANVASS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Dissatisfaction in with the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: The leaven of dissatisfaction with the rebel Confederacy, if not the leaven of loyalty, continues to work, and lately more actively than ever, in North Carolina. We have marked from time to time the progress of free speech against the rebel Government in the old North State, and drawn moderate encouragement therefrom; but always warned our readers against too sanguine expectations of active help to the Union cause from that source. We continue to do the same thing. But we are free to say that late signs are more hopeful than any that have gone before. The facts are these: The North Carolina Standard, well known as the organ of Gov. VANCE and of the party that elected him, has published an article of great length, and evidently well matured in language and in argument, "denouncing the treachery of the Confederate leaders," showing the "ill success of their efforts," stating that "portions of only five of the original thirteen [seceded] States remain in the hands of the Confederacy," and proposing that North Carolina "in her sovereign capacity" make "immediate overtures to the United States Government for peace." We give the whole of this important document in the columns of the TIMES to-day.

abstract: Considerable interest is felt in regard to the position of His Honor the Mayor, on the ordinance bearing upon the draft, which has been passed by the Common Council. While we know nothing positively of the views of His Honor, we understand from reliable sources that in his interview with those framing the ordinance he suggested amendments, making it more consistent with the interests of the Government.
lead_paragraph: Considerable interest is felt in regard to the position of His Honor the Mayor, on the ordinance bearing upon the draft, which has been passed by the Common Council. While we know nothing positively of the views of His Honor, we understand from reliable sources that in his interview with those framing the ordinance he suggested amendments, making it more consistent with the interests of the Government, and at the same time not a whit less liberal to those drafted whom it is intended to benefit. When His Honor was consulted in regard to the ordinance -- and that he was consulted is a matter of publicity -- he suggested that in the second section should be incorporated a provision to the effect that the parties drafted, and to whom the $300 were to be paid, should not receive the money until they had been mustered into the service of the United States, and were sent to a rendezvous. That this provision is eminently proper and absolutely necessary, is proven by the suggestive fact that the late Comptroller estimated of the half million appropriated for bounties by the City, four-fifths or four hundred thousand dollars were paid to parties who evaded service after receipt, either by skedaddling or skulkage! His Honor the Mayor requested that the provision referred to should be incorporated in the second section. The consultation of His Honor with those drawing the ordinance, and his concurrence in its general provisions, has created the impression that, as it exists, he approves of it. But this essential provision, on which he was most tenacious, has, from a misapprehension of his views, been omitted from the second section, where it should most apply, and been incorporated in the fifth, where it is only applicable to volunteers. A caucus of the Common Council will be held this morning, whereat, it is supposed, this and other suggestions of His Honor will be semi-officially considered. That, characterized as they are by sagacity and prudence, and sustained as they will be by the public, they will receive courteous and approving attention, we have no doubt. In that event, there will be but a brief delay before the formal adoption of the amendments, and the ordinance will become a fixed fact, with His Honor's approval.

abstract: Among the recent arrivals at New-York from Europe we observe the name of Count AULICH, who comes as Minister Plenipotentiary of Austria, to succeed the Chevalier HULSEMANN, who recently returned home after a residence in our country in the same capacity of twenty-five years -- a service not more distinguished by its unusual duration, than it was by the signal propriety and urbanity with which its delicate and sometimes difficult duties were discharged, or the esteem which the worthy gentleman commanded by his personal deportment, his intelligence, and his amiability. -- Washington Intelligencer.

abstract: The commander of this post, Gen. CANBY, has issued a circular defining the duties of the United States troops now stationed in this City and harbor. "Their duties," he says, "are limited to the defence of the forts and the protection of public (Government) property and of the officers of the General...
lead_paragraph: The commander of this post, Gen. CANBY, has issued a circular defining the duties of the United States troops now stationed in this City and harbor. "Their duties," he says, "are limited to the defence of the forts and the protection of public (Government) property and of the officers of the General Government in the performance of their legal duties. The duty of maintaining order and protecting the property and rights of private individuals, devolves upon the Municipal and State authorities." But if these authorities are unable to maintain order, or if they call for the aid of the United States troops, such aid will be promptly rendered.

abstract: In the budget of late  foreign news are two items side by side, of singular contradiction, in regard to the Bread prospects in Paris. One paragraph says: "Some excitement was produced in the Paris Corn market by the report that the Czar had prohibited the export of corn and flour from the Russian Empire."
lead_paragraph: -- In the budget of late foreign news are two items side by side, of singular contradiction, in regard to the Bread prospects in Paris. One paragraph says: "Some excitement was produced in the Paris Corn market by the report that the Czar had prohibited the export of corn and flour from the Russian Empire." The immediately succeeding and reassuring sentence is: "The prospect of the French harvest is so good that there is a probability wheat may be exported from France, rather than a necessity exist for its importation."

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR'S Proclamation regarding the draft, alluded to yesterday, is published this morning. The Governor still clings to the idea that the constitutionality of the draft should have been tested before putting it in force, but is explicit enough in warning his "friends" against any riotous opposition to it. The draft will certainly commence this forenoon at 10 o'clock, as previously announced.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO A PROVOST. -- On Monday evening last the employes of Provost-Marshal SAMUEL T. MADDOX, of the Eleventh Congressional District, of Kings County, presented him with a gold hunting case watch, chain and seal. The presentation took place at the residence of Mr. JOHN E. DAVIDSON, in Second-street, Brooklyn, E.D. A speech was made by Mr. S.H. MELLIS, to which the recipient feelingly responded. The value of the gift is about $300, a very appropriate recognition of the efficiency, impartiality, and courtesy with which Marshal MADDOX has performed his duties in the preliminaries of conscription.

abstract: The Insurrection and American Opinion
lead_paragraph: We warn our readers against the English statement of the facts of the present Polish revolution. Without Russian journals, and with very few other means of learning the Russian version of affairs, we are obliged to depend almost entirely upon the London Times, and other British prints, for our current information. Their dominant spirit is anti-Russian. This, in itself, would not vitiate their testimony; but it happens that nearly all of them, and the Times especially, have an inveterate habit of lying without scruple whenever their inclinations prompt.

abstract: This new State, formed of that portion of Old Virginia which lies within the Alleghany Mountains, and contributes its waters to the Mississippi Basin, has, by act of Congress, been admitted into the Union. This diminution in area of an ancient Atlantic State, occurring simultaneously with a radical change in the geographical distribution of population on our Continent, draws attention to facts of more profound significance than have hitherto attracted notice.

abstract: Capt. F.C. SPEIGHT, East Twenty-ninth-street, near Fourth-avenue. Except when detailed in squads, the Twenty-ninth was always under the immediate command of the Captain. Saturday, before the riot, Sergt. VAN ORDEN, with fifteen men, took charge of the Seventh-avenue Arsenal, remaining until Monday afternoon. Many manifestations were made against the building, but the force determined to defend it to the last. Early on Monday Capt. SPEIGHT, with 20 men. reported at the Marshal's Office, No. 1,190 Broadway, where the drafting proceeded quietly until adjournment at noon. Capt. SPEIGHT withdrew his men at 4 P.M., having, during his stay, dispersed, several crowds and reported at Central Office. Ten minutes after he left, the mob reassembled, and the Marshal's Office was in flames. The entire block, from Twenty-eighth to Twenty-ninth-street, was destroyed. During the morning word was received that Superintendent KENNEDY had been killed, and Capt. SPEIGHT, without waiting for orders, sent off Sergt, YOUNG with a force to the Nineteenth Ward to recover him; meantime he had been rescued. On Monday evening the entire command was with Inspector CARPENTER in the Park, and were active participants in the battle there with, those who had attempted to fire the Tribune buildings. Subsequently were with Inspector CARPENTEE in the tour through the Fourth Ward and in the several engagements; in this section houses occupied by colored people bad been fired from below, driving the inmates up stairs, whose only escape was by jumping into the street; some of them were clinging to window sills, some to the eaves, and the clothes of some, while thus suspended, had caught fire. The Police did all in their power to rescue them, but in many instances for want of ladders were unable to. A number were in falling seriously injured, and one killed. Thence Capt. SPEIGHT and command were ordered to Inspector LEONARD's command at City Hall, and were constantly on the different expeditions of the night. Officer O'BYRN[???] was attacked in Chatham-street, near the Park, his club wrenched from him and he badly beaten with it; he recovered the locust, caught his men and succeeded in bringing one into the Twenty-sixth Precinct Station-house, who was in a condition which, required immediate attention of the surgeon. This fellow's name was MODERMOTT; he Was afterward sent to the City Hospital, but escaped on Wednesday.

abstract: Recommenced in New-York
lead_paragraph: In conformity with the notice given in the TIMES the renewal of the Draft was commenced yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock. It was generally known in the community that the National, State and Municpal authorities had made every possible preparation which could insure quiet and order, and prevent disturbance of any nature. Nevertheless, in consequence of the deep interest felt in the procedure by every man, woman and child in the City, a grea excitement was evidently pervading the people, and an anxiety in no degree feigned rested upon every mind. The Provost-Marshal-General, with admirable sagacity, selected the quiet Sixth District in which to commence the renewal, a District which is noted for its good order. At an early hour the Sixth-avenue, in the immediate neighborhood of Capt. FARR's Headquarters, was crowded with people of every grade of life. All sorts and conditions of men were there, and although perfect order reigned, arguments pro and con the Draft were liberally entered into.

abstract: Every Northern man ought to read the article from the Raleigh Standard, which we published yesterday. We do not hesitate to say that it is, by all odds, the most important publication since this war commenced. It reveals, as nothing else has, the electricity with which the whole South is becoming charged, and which is destined ere long to blow "the Confederacy" into atoms, and to consume Copperheadism from the face of the land forever.

abstract: His Probable Movements
lead_paragraph: The report we had a few days ago of a movement by the Army of the Cumberland, in two columns, on Chattanooga, has not been confirmed, and was not in itself very probable. The fact is, the further progress of the army of Gen. ROSECRANS is not conditioned so much on the movements of the enemy in front, for we believe it is able to whip BRAGG at any time, but on circumstances of another nature, of which people generally take small cognizance. Glance at the position of his army from Tullahoma to Bridgeport, on the Tennessee, and then run the eye northward, to Louisville and Cincinnati, on the Ohio, and consider that every pound of food for man and beast has to be transported over the intervening distance, through a country infested by guerrillas and exposed to constant cavalry raids, and some idea may be formed of the enormous task Gen. ROSECRANS has in keeping up his line of communications.

abstract: Correspondence between E??? and American representatives on shipping ar???
snippet: Correspondence between E??? and American representatives on shipping ar???
lead_paragraph: A letter fron Hond Kong which we gave yesterday contained a curious report current there, that there had been some sharp correspondence between the American Representative and the British Charge d' Affaires in Japan, in reference to large importations of arms and ammunition which American merchants were reported to be making into the latter country. The Hong Kond writer doubted whether any large importations had been made; but added that there was no question that all munitions of war had found a ready sale in Japan, and this it was not in the power of our Representative to prevent. It may be, as news is a very great while in reaching Japan, that Her Majesty's Charge there has not yet heard what has been the policy of the British Government for the last two years and a half in regard to neutral nations supplying belligerents with arms and military munitions, for he certainly would not dare to dispute the binding force of a principle which has been so frequently and authoritatively stated, and so faithfully carried out practically, in the matter of the so- called Southern Confederacy.

abstract: The French folly in
lead_paragraph: The constant pretence of Gen. FOREY in his addresses to the Mexican people, on the advance to the City of Mexico, was that his mission was one of peace and independence to Mexicans. As soon as he should succeed in breaking the power of the Juarez Government -- which was denounced as a usurpation of tyrants -- he intended to turn over to the Mexican people the administration of their own affairs and secure them in the free and peaceable selection of their own rulers.

abstract: The tidings from Charleston indicate that after the preliminary manoeuvres and practice of last week, the grand attack on Fort Sumter was positively down on the programme for Monday last. If nothing has intervened to postpone it, therefore, we ought to hear the result by to-day or to-morrow, either by a dispatch-boat or through the Richmond papers. In the full of military operations East and West, public attention is concentrated with redoubled interest on our army and fleet on the coast of South Carolina.

headline: {'main': 'OFFICIAL REPORTS FROM CHARLESTON.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OFFICIAL REPORTS FROM CHARLESTON.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The arrival of the steamer Fulton, from Charleston Bar on Sunday evening last, puts us in possession of our own accounts of the progress of operations against Charleston to that time. The idea of the rebels, as published yesterday, that the grand bombardment had commenced on Saturday last, appears to have been erroneous. Notwithstanding its "awful" character, there was something still more "awful " to follow it. Gen. GILLMORE and Admiral DAHLGREN were then only getting the range of their guns, and the grand combined attack was set down for Monday. Some damage had already been inflicted upon Sumter by Gen. GILLMORE's long-range guns, and one of them it is reported, on the authority of a Government dispatch, had succeeded in throwing shell into the city. There is nothing improbable in the report. On the contrary, we have the best authority for believing the feat entirely within the range of possibility. There were indications that the rebels, despairing of being able to hold Sumter, were preparing to evacuate it at short notice. In fact, a considerable number of heavy guns had already been removed from the fort and mounted in earthworks on James Island, on which the rebels have been for some time busily engaged. Meantime, reinforcements for Gen. GILLMORE continued to arrive, and it appears certain that the capture of Sumter will be immediately followed by other operations of an equally important character, looking to the speedy reduction of the city itself.

The London Times gives currency to a report that, in view of the recent menacing news from America, the British Government intended sending additional troops to Canada. The latest news vi[???] , Queenstown states that it is generally asserted that MAXIMILIAN will accept the Mexican crown. abstract: Miss Flora Hotchkiss, aged seventeen, the daughter of a prominent professional gentleman residing at Glenallan, Canada, recently eloped with her father's servant-man, who was of the staid age of fifty-five.
lead_paragraph: -- Miss Flora Hotchkiss, aged seventeen, the daughter of a prominent professional gentleman residing at Glenallan, Canada, recently eloped with her father's servant-man, who was of the staid age of fifty-five. The love-sick swain, Darwin by name, is described as a thorough-bred English gentleman, who, for some cause. has been reduced in circumstances, and came to Dr. Hotchkiss' house for a home last Winter as a man of all work. The couple had a full day's start of the exasperated father in the chase, which he instituted as soon as his daughter's folly was discovered; but he seems to have over- taken the runaways at Toronto, and the young woman was induced to go home. Darwin was taken. before a Police Court on a charge of stealing a gold watch belonging to the mother of the girl; but the evidence showed that he was guilt[???]ess of the theft, and he was discharged.

abstract: Advices from New-Orleans to the 11th inst., received up the Mississippi, state that the health of the city is only fair, and that there are numerous cases of yellow fever at Quarantine.
lead_paragraph: Advices from New-Orleans to the 11th inst., received up the Mississippi, state that the health of the city is only fair, and that there are numerous cases of yellow fever at Quarantine. Our advices by the ocean route are to the 13th, two days later, and they make no mention of any extraordinary sickness there. Our correspondent "Galway," who was in New-Orleans on the 10th, states that "the city is remarkable for its cleanliness, quietness and healthy ness." At Vicksburgh, however, numerous cases of typhoid are reported, many of which prove fatal. This is the result of the state of nastiness in which the place was found by our troops when they entered it, though vigorous efforts have been made to put it in an inhabitable condition.

abstract: As it appears from Gov. SEYMOUR'S language, as well as that of his supporters in the Press, that his section of the Democratic  party are about to incorporate in their political creed a new article, making it the duty of ...
lead_paragraph: As it appears from Gov. SEYMOUR's language, as well as that of his supporters in the Press, that his section of the Democratic party are about to incorporate in their political creed a new article, making it the duty of the Government to delay the execution of all new laws until the Courts have pronounced them constitutional, whenever anybody expresses any doubt about it, we wish respectfully to suggest that they should at the same time define the precise amount of doubt which they will consider sufficient. Nothing could be more inconvenient than to leave this point in uncertainty. The whole doctrine is novel. The honor of inventing it belongs to that great political luminary, FERNANDO WOOD, when Mayor of this City six years ago. Up to that time the nation had got along tolerably well with the time-honored presumption, sanctioned not only by judicial decisions but by common sense, that a law not only might be but was constitutional until the Courts had, on the application of a private individual, who felt himself aggrieved by it, pronounced it the contrary. FERANANDO in one of those happy fits of inspiration to which he owes all the glories of his career, discovered that this was a mistake, and that if anybody affected by the operation of an act expressed doubts of its validity, this at once raised the presumption that it was invalid, and deprived it of all force and authority until the question was decided. Moreover, what rendered this contrivance still more curious and valuable was, that, under it, the doubter was not under any sort of obligation to submit his doubts to any test whatever. He was not to be obliged to go to Court to have them either confirmed or set aside. His part was simply to doubt and refuse obedience, and upon those who approved of the law fell the burden of trying the question of its constitutionality.

abstract: Forey's tyranny and ferocity
lead_paragraph: atrocities that are being committed upon the Mexicans by FOREY and his army of invasion must secure for him and his tools the disgust and contempt of the whole world. We published a short time ago a decree of confis[???]ation -- confis[???]ation of the real and personal property of every respectable and patriotic citizen of Mexico -- which had been issued at the dictation, and which is being enforced by the bayonets, of the invaders. We have given some of the details of the ludicrous and fraudulent action connected with the appointment of the Junta of Notables, and their attempt to establish an imperial and foreign tyranny over Mexico. We have given publicity to other of the acts of FOREY -- though the fact that nearly all the native and republican journals of Mexico have been suppressed, and that most of our news comes through French channels, prevents us from obtaining a correct version of all that is transpiring in that unfortunate country.

abstract: years ago, the Common Councils of this City and Brooklyn made large appropriations from the municipal funds for the benefit of the families of volunteers, not a voice was raised to object.
lead_paragraph: years ago, the Common Councils of this City and Brooklyn made large appropriations from the municipal funds for the benefit of the families of volunteers, not a voice was raised to object. Every one felt that the Government needed soldiers, and that there was no way more sure to get them than to provide for the families which those who volunteered left behind. The spirit in which the present municipal appropriations have been made, and the object they are intended to effect, does not seem to be precisely the same. We look in vain through the provisions of the ordinance passed by our Common Council, or the resolutions adopted in the Brooklyn Board, for any provision which operates so as to stimulate recruiting. It is not too late for either of them to make a change in this respect. In Brooklyn the sum of $500,000 is proposed to be raised, and a Committee of seven is appointed to "hear and inquire into all applications for relief" by persons drafted, and to report the amount of relief estimated by them. This Committee, as it seems to us, should so act as to encourage drafted men to enlist. They should refuse to pay anything to relieve those who could go to the war without great hardship. They should in all cases where the drafted man cannot go, encourage the sending a substitute instead, and they should see to it most earnestly that the course which Mayor OPDYKE urges should be adopted, viz.: -- of paying money to no man until he is actually in the service.

abstract: ARREST OF ANOTHER RIOTER. JAMES KELLY was arraigned yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with rioting and attempting to extort money by threats from MARY JACKSON, the complainant, of No. 464 Eleventh-avenue, where she keeps a fancy store.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF ANOTHER RIOTER. -- JAMES KELLY was arraigned yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with rioting and attempting to extort money by threats from MARY JACKSON, the complainant, of No. 464 Eleventh-avenue, where she keeps a fancy store. On Wednesday the accused entered her place of business, and in a threatening and boisterous manner, demanded money of a young son of Mrs. JACKSON's, who was in the store at the time. He declared that unless his demand was instantly complied with, he would call around him a crowd and burn down the house. At this stage of the proceedings, some person who overheard the threats called in Officer TIERNEY, who was close at hand, and the offender was taken into custody. Justice KELLY committed him for examination.

abstract: Capt. A.S. WILSON, Fort Washington. The Captain and his force reported at Central Office on Tuesday morning, with Sergts. HUFF, WHITEMAN and CASTLE, coming down by Hudson River Railroad; were soon after en route, with Inspector DILKS' command, to Twenty-second-street and Second-avenue, ...
lead_paragraph: Capt. A.S. WILSON, Fort Washington. The Captain and his force reported at Central Office on Tuesday morning, with Sergts. HUFF, WHITEMAN and CASTLE, coming down by Hudson River Railroad; were soon after en route, with Inspector DILKS' command, to Twenty-second-street and Second-avenue, where the mob was driven off, the building in which stolen arms were secreted, entered, and a general clubbing given to the lawless outside and in the building. The "Thirty-second" were active and gallant in this affair, and seemed to relish infantry duty after their uninterrupted duty as mounted Police. Returning to headquarters, there was but a brief respite ere again under inspector DILKS they marched to same v[???]nity, engaged in another conflict, where their command was again conspicuous, and were parties to another victory. It was at this time that Capt. HELME's command was being hemmed in from all quarters, and the rescue, bravely as his men would have fought, was the result of the opportune arrival of Inspector DILKS. The hazardous return march, and the stubborn persistence of the mob in their assaults, have already been fully described. On reaching headquarters, Capt. WILSON and his command were sent through the infected districts of the Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards, and on return reported to Inspector LEONARD at the City Hall; from here, aside of the day duties, were sent at night to the Western Hotel, and had a hand in the dispersion of the mob which had threatened it, several of the parties being cracked on the head some what severely; thence to Cedar-Street, to the Government Stores to the Twenty-seventh Precinct, and a march through it, and 4 A.M. Wednesday, after nearly twenty hours of continuous march, interrupted only to give battle, returned to the City Hall and stretching out on the marble floor the members were allowed a brief rest. On Tuesday night the men were exceedingly hungry and the Captain found for them a genuine friend in Mr. CROOK, of Chatham-street. On hearing that they had been nearly all day without food, he aroused his servants, opened his establishment and had the force brought in, furnishing them with an excellent, substantial and, of course, most welcome repast. They resolve him to be a whole-souled man.

abstract: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, in pursuance of an order from Provost-Marshal Farr, the draft in the Sixth District, Fifteenth Ward, was continued at the official Headquarters, No. 185 Sixth-avenue.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock, in pursuance of an order from Provost-Marshal Farr, the draft in the Sixth District, Fifteenth Ward, was continued at the official Headquarters, No. 185 Sixth-avenue. A very large crowd assembled at the doors hours before the time specified, but there was not the slightest manifestation of disorder, or even disquiet. The soldier still occupy the house, with the exception of the upper story, and the police in full force garrison and watch the premises. The doors were opened at a little after 10 o'clock, when a great rush was made to secure places.

abstract: MOVEMENT TO RAISE THE QUOTA IN HOBOKEN.  A public meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall on Wednesday evening, for the purpose of hearing the report of the Committee of fifteen in reference to raising funds, with which to pay bounties to volunteers for filling the quota of the city.
lead_paragraph: MOVEMENT TO RAISE THE QUOTA IN HOBOKEN. -- A public meeting of the citizens of Hoboken was held at Odd Fellows' Hall on Wednesday evening, for the purpose of hearing the report of the Committee of fifteen in reference to raising funds, with which to pay bounties to volunteers for filling the quota of the city. Gen HATFIELD presided and stated the object of the meeting. He said that Hoboken was placed under peculiar circumstances. The Common Council could not expend any more money than was voted by the people, without becoming personally responsible.

abstract: A deplorable accident occurred at Hamiltonavenue bridge shortly after 10 o'clock on Wednesday night, which resulted in the death of two persons and to the injury of several others.
lead_paragraph: A deplorable accident occurred at Hamilton-avenue bridge shortly after 10 o'clock on Wednesday night, which resulted in the death of two persons and to the injury of several others. It appears that the draw of the bridge was open for the purpose of passing a boat through the canal, and this being unperceived by the driver of car No. 119, which was coming from Greenwood to the city, the horses were driver overboard, dragging the car with them into the creek. The passengers in the car were Rev. WM.C. SHANNON, a blind Clergyman, who was on his return from Fort Hamilton, where he had conducted religious exercises during the early part of the evening. He was accompanied by a lad named THOMAS STEWART, aged 14 years. They were in the rear of the car, and both were drowned. Mr. SHANNON's family, consisting of wife and sister, reside at No. 119 Degraw-street; he has no children. The other passenger was Mr. HENRY C. HUDSON, residing in Ninth-street, near Third-avenue; he was standing near the driver, on the front platform; both were precipitated into the creek. Mr. HUDSON wag severely injured about the head and face, and sustained a dangerous cut on the arm, by which an artery was severed. The conductor was inside the car, and as it went over the bridge he was thrown with great force through one of the windows, by which means he was enabled to escape, although badly cut about the hands and face. The driver, JOHN FERRIL, was slightly injured by falling head-long into the creek, but succeeded in making his way to shore una[???]ded. One of the horses attached to the car was drowned -- the other was saved; the car was shattered to pieces. The creek, at the place where the accident occurred, is about 150 feet wide, and the water about 20 feet deep at high tide. The water at the spot where the car fell is a out 7 feet in depth. The bodies of the unfortunate victims were recovered and given in charge of their friend. The cause of the accident is said to be the absence of [???]ight -- there being no lamp on the G[???]wan[???]s side of the bridge.

abstract: Why We Want
lead_paragraph: The time is approaching when the Union armies will no longer be called on to confront great armies in the field. With the defeat of LEE and the breaking up of his army as the armies of JOHNSTON and BRAGG have been broken up, the only foes we shall have to settle accounts with will be minor bodies of rebels and bands of guerrillas, varying in number from one to ten thousand, and seldom mounted, from the simple fact, that even with unrestrained impressment, they will not be able to get horses. To meet and hunt out these bands our men will not march in large armies, but will sweep from point to point in flying columns. This mode of warfare will bring forth the real fighting talent of subordinate officers, and it will be in such warfare that mounted men will have immense advantage, whether they be regular cavalry or mounted infantry, and whether it be upon the pursuit or in actual meeting. The history of this arm of the service shows that when properly wielded, infantry bodies are powerless before it. For all purposes of scouting, reconnoissance, or passing through an enemy's country, its value is computed by military authorities as three to one. In battle, it is not that cavalry are expected to come to an actual crossing of swords, any more than infantry are to mingle bayonets -- a thing which has seldom occurred -- but they carry a moral force that cannot be equaled by any unmounted men. ROEMER, in his History of Cavalry, gives, in a few words, an admirable description of the use of cavalry in battle.
headline: {'main': 'Why We Want Cavalry.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Why We Want Cavalry.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ing to the six, or seven new men-of-war in course of construction, vessels have to be equipped at the shortest possible notice, and dispatched to sea in perfect trim, although the time sometimes given for the execution of the work renders it perfectly impossible to do it as it should be done. There were, until yesterday, the iron-clad Lehigh, the steamer Home, the Mary Sandford, the Schooner Alethea, the steamship Relief, the steamer Ariel, and the new steamtug Ajax -- all at the very same time employing a large number of hands, and requiring incessant and unremitting toil. The United States steamer Mackinaw was also fitted out and dispatched within the last three days, and sailed yesterday for Baltimore, ie tow of the steamtug Governor, to receive her machinery. The clerical department is also worked to a great extent beyond the usual business, although no additional hands have been given by the Government. The copying, registering, and issuing of general orders daily, copying of requisitions for every ship at the station, as the case may be, and a variety of other writing to be done, is so heavy, that the clerks have sometimes, within the last week, become exhausted with work. Col. WILLETT, Secretary of the Admiral, Mr. CHARLES MORSE, and Mr. WILLETT, Jr., are the only employes provided for the execution of the arduous duties in the Commandant's office.

abstract: Slaves command  a higher price in Kentucky, taking gold as the standard of value, than in any other of the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: -- Slaves command a higher price in Kentucky, taking gold as the standard of value, than in any other of the Southern States. In Missouri they are sold at from forty dollars to four hundred, according to age, quality, and especially according to place. In Tennessee they cannot be said to be sold at all. In Maryland the negroes upon an estate were lately sold, and fetched an average price of $18 a head. In the farther States of the Southern Confederacy we frequently see reports of negro sales, and we occasionally see boasts from rebel newspapers as to the high prices the slaves bring, notwithstanding the war and the collapse of Southern industry. We notice in the Savannah Republican of the 5th, a report of a negro sale in that city, at which, we are told, high prices prevailed, and at which two girls of 18 years of age were sold for about $2,500 apiece, two matured boys for about the same price, a man of 45 for $1,850, and at woman of 23, with her child of 5, for $3,950. Twenty-five hundred dollars, then, may be taken as the standard price of first-class slaves in the Confederacy; but when it is remembered that this is in Confederate money, which is worth less than one-twelfth its face in gold, it will be seen that the real price, by this standard, is only about $200. In Kentucky, on the other hand, though there is but little buying or selling of slave stock going on, we understand that negroes are still held at from seven to twelve hundred dollars apiece.
headline: {'main': 'MARKET PRICE OF SLAVES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'MARKET PRICE OF SLAVES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sergt. Y.S. COPELAND, whose services as Drill Officer to the force have been of the utmost value, was one of the most efficient of the Officers during ...
lead_paragraph: Sergt. Y.S. COPELAND, whose services as Drill Officer to the force have been of the utmost value, was one of the most efficient of the Officers during riot week. His first duty was organizing the command of Inspector CARPENTER, which on Monday afternoon met the mob at Broadway and Amity-street, and he had the second blow in what was a gallant fight, and a quick and complete victory. It was here that the Police by their bravery extorted from the citizens gathered at the spot cheer on cheer of approval -- something unusual for the force to hear given them, but which will be nothing novel hereafter. This mob was the one which had been doing so much damage in the upper part of the City, and they came down ladened with plunder. In the evening Sergt. COPELAND formed another command of 250 men, which, under Inspector CARPENTER, marched to the Park, and gave the rioters fleeing from the Tribune Building a reception with clubs such as they little expected, and largely suffered from. The Sergeant was here also amongst the most conspicuous and foremost. Thence he was on the march through the Fourth Ward. Here were witnessed shocking scenes; the sacking of houses occupied by negroes, the piling up and burning of their furniture, the forcing of their dwellings, and in some cases the actual burning alive of the inmates. In one instance a dwelling was fired where seven negroes had taken refuge; they escaped by jumping from the windows, a distance of twenty feet; one broke his leg, another his arm, and it was only by the prompt and decisive action of the Police that any of them escaped death, the mob standing ready, like so many wolves, to jump upon them the moment they reached the ground. In this march, the various mobs were met and dispersed, the greater portion fleeing back into their dens. At midnight the force returned to the Park in time to receive the large mob coming down Broadway to finish the interrupted work at the Tribune Building. It was here that Inspector CARPENTER exhibited strategy and generalship, massing his force to the east side of the Park, and, covered by the darkness, coolly awaiting the mob, which came on, singing "We'll hang old GREELEY to a sour apple tree," and rushed into the grasp of the force ere their presence was suspected. Exemplary, sudden, thorough was their punishment after the force sprang upon them. "Up, Guards, and at them," was the word; the songs ceased, and the ringing of the locusts and cries for mercy of the renegades supplied their place. Here, too, was Sergt. COPELAND brave and efficient. Returning to Headquarters, but a brief respite was had, for at 2 A.M., Tuesday, Sergt. C. formed a battalion of 100 men, and proceeded to Clarkson-street, to recover the body of the negro hung there. It was recovered and brought to the Central office. On Tuesday the Sergeant formed a battalion of some two hundred men, which, under Inspector CARPENTER, visited Second-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, where the severe battle, heretofore described, was held. The force used their revolvers to clear the tops of the houses of their assailants, but ultimately had to charge the houses, take and "clean" them. The rioters most of them boldly met the assault, others were found secreted in beds, boxes, closets, &c., &c., but were hunted out, receiving lessons which those of them who can remember anything, are not likely to forget. The force returned to Headquarters at noon, and during the balance of the day the military knowledge of the Sergeant was in constant requisition in the organizing of the different commands constantly being required and sent off. In the evening he was with the command which, under Inspector CARPENTER, marched to BROOKS BROS.' clothing-store, and subsequently through the infected districts thereabouts, dispersing all mobs and administering, on several occasions, severe punishment; thence to the Fifth Ward, where valuable service was done and quiet restored, and thence to Headquarters. During the balance of the week, until Saturday, Sergt. COPELAND was occupied in organizing companies, as they were required, for special service.

abstract: The  President has appointed Hon. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, of this City, as the representative of the United States in the "International Statistical Congress," which commences its session at Berlin (Prussia) on the 6th of September ...
lead_paragraph: -- The President has appointed Hon. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, of this City, as the representative of the United States in the "International Statistical Congress," which commences its session at Berlin (Prussia) on the 6th of September. This is the fifth of the series of triennial Statistical Congresses which have been held in Europe -- the previous sessions having been at Paris, at London, at Brussels, and at Vienna. This Congress is purely a governmental body, or rather the delegates to it are appointed by their respective Governments, and are not the representatives of societies or conventions. Most of the civilized Powers are represented by their delegates, and some of the most distinguished statisticians and economists of the present day have taken part in the previous, and will take part in the coming, deliberations. The discussions take a wide and practical range, and may be said, in a word, to embrace all the material interests and resources of the various nations of the world, as they affect human progress and civilization.

abstract: SERIOUS AFFRAY -- ATTEMPT TO MURDER AN OFFICER. -- A serious affray occurred in Hoboken on Thursday, in which a man named BRADY was seriously, if not dangerously, injured. It appears that about 6 o'clock Constable WHITNEY went to BRADY's house, in Meadow street, to arrest Mrs. BRADY, on a warrant issued by Justice WHITE. After entering the house and making his business known, BRADY locked the door and said, "We have got you now, you son of a _____, and will murder you before you get out of here." BRADY then seized an ax and attacked the officer, attempting to strike him, but the latter evaded his blows, and finally wrenched the axe away, and dealt BRADY two blows on the head, inflicting very severe scalp wounds. Mrs. BRADY also assisted her husband, and the officer came off with black eyes. Subsequently Mrs. BRADY was taken into custody, but her husband was too seriously injured to be removed.

abstract: A telegram has been received from Major-Gen. HALLECK, ordering the suspension of the proposed harbor defences, and directing another plan to be adopted. Instead of erecting works on Yerba and Buena Islands, and Rincon Point, two large batteries of ten guns each, to be constructed on Angel Island, and a heavy battery on San Jose or Black Point.

abstract: Now that the draft is taking place in this City, it has been asked whether the conscripts will be allowed the privilege of joining organizations of their own choice, or compelled to enter those assigned by the War Department. Many of the drafted have friends or relatives in the army, and they would, therefore, prefer to be attached to the regiments where their friends or relatives are, in preference to going among strangers.

abstract: The, and its Originators
lead_paragraph: The difficulties of writing history could hardly be better exemplified than by a comparison of the versions of the origin of the war, given by Mr. DONNELL, the Speaker of the North Carolina House of Commons, and published in our columns on Wednesday, and that which is daily put forward by the rebel sympathizers at the North. According to Mr. DONNELL, who had personal cognizance of most of the steps taken "to precipitate the South into revolution," the secession movement was due to a determination of certain Southern leaders that the South should be independent at any cost, grievance or no grievance; that they tried to convert the tariff into a pretext for separation, and, failing, fixed on Slavery as "the only question on which the South is likely to unite;" that they then agitated and intrigued in such manner as to make Mr. LINCOLN's election a certainty; and as soon as he was elected, dragged the Southern people into a revolution upon a series of pretences, which the progress of events have all proved false, and foremost among them was the depreciation of Northern courage and tenacity. He denies, from first to last, that the North had any share in bringing about the war, beyond the fact that it existed and furnished something to separate from, and something to fight with.
headline: {'main': 'The War and Its Originators.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The War and Its Originators.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FELONIOUS ASSAULT WITH A KNIFE. -- ADAM DECKHOLD, of Moore-street, between Graham-avenue and Smith-street, was arrested Thursday, on complaint of JACOB EBEHARDT, who resides in Graham-avenue, for feloniously assaulting him with a knife, and inflicting a serious wound on his head. He was arraigned before Justice WALTERS, and committed to a wait examination.

abstract: The 3d inst. was the last examination and discharge sitting in the case of WILLIAM JOSHUA GRAZEBROOK, before Mr. Commissioner PERRY. at Liverpool. The bankrupt carried on business in Liverpool as a merchant and commission agent. His statement of accounts shows debts unsecured to the amount of £23,443 8s. 9d., and secured debts to the amount of £12,610 8s. 4d.; liabilities on bills discounted. £2,477 9s. 4d.; liabilities on accommodation bills, £600; and debts to be paid in full, £328. The credit side of the account shows a surplus of £14,363 12s. 10d.; the assets being debts due to the estate, £16,160; property given up to the assignees, £13,513 16s. 9d.; and do, in the hands of creditors, £24,149 8s. 2d. The bankrupt has been for some years past extensively engaged in business, and latterly with the ports of the Southern States of America, and attributes his present position to the capture, detention and confiscation of the steamers Nicolai I. and Dolphin by the Federal States. The circumstances connected with the capture and detention of the latter vessel have been brought under the notice of Lord RUSSELL, and have been the subject of communication between the two Governments an appeal against the decision of the Court at Key West having been lodged with the authorities at Washington. There was no opposition on the part of the assignees or creditors, and the bankrupt passed his examination, and was allowed an unconditional order of discharge.

abstract: We do not know whether or not it is the purpose of the military authorities to permit our conscripts to have any choice as to the regiments which they shall enter when they arrive in the army. Thus far, the conscripts from any given State say Pennsylvania, ...
lead_paragraph: We do not know whether or not it is the purpose of the military authorities to permit our conscripts to have any choice as to the regiments which they shall enter when they arrive in the army. Thus far, the conscripts from any given State -- say Pennsylvania, Massachusetts or New-York -- have been assigned to the regiments in the field that were originally raised in those States, and this system, we suppose, will be kept up. But we do not see why men who have preferences for service in any given division, brigade or regiment should not be allowed the exercise of their choice. Many of the substitutes, at all events, have formerly served in regiments to which they would like to return, and again join their old comrades; and other drafted men have acquaintances or friends in certain regiments whom they would much prefer to join, feeling assured that, in case of sickness or accident, they would find attentions otherwise beyond their reach, or their families would be informed of that of which they might otherwise remain ignorant. A man entering a regiment feels much more at home where he has an acquaintance or friend than where he is an entire stranger to all. Others would prefer to join a regiment or brigade because of their estimate of its prowess, or of the glory and honor it has achieved, of which they at once assume a share.

abstract: On her way returning from her tour through the mountains of New-England, Mrs. LINCOLN has been passing three or four days in our City -- so quietly, however, that only a few personal friends have been aware of her presence. On Thursday, she paid a friendly visit to the French frigate Guerriere, lying at anchor in the North River, and was received with distinguished courtesy by the commandant, who, attended by his officers, conducted his guest and her companions over the vessel with the utmost measure of refined French hospitality. Mrs. LINCOLN spent a most agreeable hour, and returned highly delighted with her excursion.
lead_paragraph: On her way returning from her tour through the mountains of New-England, Mrs. LINCOLN has been passing three or four days in our City -- so quietly, however, that only a few personal friends have been aware of her presence. abstract: We have rebel news from Charleston, by way of Richmond and Norfolk, to the 20th inst.  Thursday last which indicates anything but a belief on the part of the rebels that they will be ...
lead_paragraph: We have rebel news from Charleston, by way of Richmond and Norfolk, to the 20th inst. -- Thursday last -- which indicates anything but a belief on the part of the rebels that they will be able to hold the city. The operations of our forces for the preceding twenty-four hours are said to have been mostly confined to a steady and continuous bombardment of Fort Sumter -- from which we judge that the grand attack on that stronghold did not commence on Monday as anticipated. Our fire had begun to tell on the fort, which replied only at long intervals; and the rebel dispatch confesses that Gen. GILLMORE's 200-pound Parrotts were too much for it. The dispatch states, however, that even should Sumter fall, the harbor may still be held; but that the rebels despair of being able to held it is evidenced by the fact that Gen. BONHAM has issued a proclamation urging the removal of all non-combatants from the city as soon as possible. The dispatch closes with the old bombast, that the city will be defended street by street, and house by house.

abstract: His Honor the Mayor still adheres to the opinion that a consideration should be had by the City from the drafted, ere they receive the $300. He thinks that the "free and easy" disbursement of the public moneys without consideration, as contemplated and designed by the ordinance, will neither meet the approval of tax-payers nor subserve the interests of the Government. He is sustained by the community. In regard to the Fire Department, it was Mayor OPDYKE who suggested the clause for their exemption, and it was wholly due to his suggestions and to his arguments thereon, that it was incorporated in the ordinance. It was never even thought of until proposed by him. This those who framed the ordinance know and will say. He has even proposed that the ordinance, so far as it relates to firemen, be made a special matter for the meeting of the Board on Monday or Tuesday, and is ready to at once give it his approval. In common with every citizen, he recognizes the justice of their claim to exemption, and has thus put on record his recognition. The firemen of New-York owe to Mayor OPDYKE, and to him alone, the clause in the ordinance relieving them. This they can inform themselves in regard to by asking any one of the Committee with whom he was in consultation ere the ordinance took its form. Each of them are too honorable to deny the fact. An attempt has been made to induce the Department to believe that His Honor is inimical to them, and ignores their interest in refusing to approve the ordinance. Here is a proposed test; let a clean, clear, honest ordinance, embracing the clause of exemption in regard to the firemen of New-York, not hampered by the other objectionable provisions, be presented to the Common Council at its meeting Monday. Let it pass, honestly free from all tricky appendages, and the Mayor, who first proposed their exemption, and had it incorporated in the ordinance, will at once, we doubt not, approve it. Unfortunately, a "clean thing" seems impossible; and an honest, well-meant provision, must be smothered because of its profligate connections. Come, gentlemen of the Common Council, make a clean, unembarrassed ordinance for the firemen, and see how promptly the Mayor will sign it.

abstract: Since the attack on Charleston commenced, the number of vessels dispatched from our Navyyards with ammunition, stores and provisions, has been almost as great as that sent to all the other squadrons together, during the same time.
lead_paragraph: Since the attack on Charleston commenced, the number of vessels dispatched from our Navyyards with ammunition, stores and provisions, has been almost as great as that sent to all the other squadrons together, during the same time. In addition to the ships reported as having left within the last week, three more left yesterday at 1 o'clock. The United States steamer Aries, filled with stores, provisions and necessaries for a cruise on active service; the Adams Express Company steamer Mary sandford, the schooner Alethea; the two last named were loaded with ice. lemons, potatoes and other delicacies for the sailors of the fleet. The Mary Sandford had no less than 250 tons of ice and the schooner about fifty tons more. Besides, another vessel left a few days ago with another large cargo of the same valuable commodity, and in a few days more still another is to depart similarly loaded. The care of the Navy Department for the crews of the ships now engaged in the attack, is such that even the scuttlebutts in which water for ordinary drinking is kept, are provided with a fair share of ice -- a circumstance unparalleled in the history of the Navy of the United States.

abstract: Rungest Singh, the widow of, in London
snippet: Rungest Singh, the widow of, in London
lead_paragraph: "Died, on the 1st inst., at Abingdon House, Kensington, the widow of the late Maharajah RUNJEET SINGH, of the Sikhs, and mother of the present Maharajah DHULEE[???] SINGH." In these few and formal words the death of a Princess has been chronicled whose words once shook kingdoms and made war or peace. CHUNDA KOUR, although the wife of the Maharajah of the Punjrb, was not, if report speaks true, very nobly born. One version of her birth makes her father a dog-keeper in the service of RUNJEET; but at any rate she was selected as one of his harem, and came to be its mistress. From that time, if she could have written the history of her marvelous life, blood, and not ink, would have been the fitting medium to have used. KURRUCK SINGH succeeded RUNJEET, and he was dispatched with acetate of lead and corrosive sublimate mingled in a curry. NAO MEHAL SINGH followed KURRUCK on the throne; but as he passed upon his elephant under an arch, after his corronation, it was contrived that the masonry should fall and crush him. The widow of KURRUCK still stood in the way, and her chamber-women were bribed to beat her brains out with a stone as they stood behind her, braiding and perfuming her hair. SHERE SINGH, a son of the murdered Princess, yet blocked the path to the throne against CHUNDA KOUR's child, and he, too, was dispatched by an adroit treachery. An English rifle was shown to him as be safe upon the "gadi," and when its muzzle was turned to his breast in the course of examining it, the trigger was pressed, and four slugs were discharged into his heart. Thus at last the crown of the Punjaub was won, and placed upon the infant head of DHULEEP SINGH; his mother, the Princess now dead, employing the influence thus obtained to revel in license. Sometimes, however, she was obliged to be the spectatress of murder, and not its accomplice, as when the troops at Lahore bayoneted her brother, the Prince JEWAHIR, as he reviewed them, sprinkling her robe and that of her son with his blood. But she replaced her brother with a lover, LALL SINGH, and in conjunction with him, declared war upon the British by matching her Sikhs across the Sutlej, Moodker, Aliwal, and Ferozeshah ended the first Sikh war, and reduced her to the mere guardianship of a protected Prince. Then she commenced the net-work of intrigue with MOOLRAJ, of Mooltan. GOLAB SINGH, of Cashmere, and DOST MAHOMED. of Affghanistan, which led to the murder of the English officers at the first-named place, and to the second Sikh war. Her emissaries, under pretence of fetching drugs from various cities, carried on correspondence for her with all the discontented in India. Confined to fortresses, she bribed the guards with costly necklaces of pearl and gold; her money and messages circulated in every Sikh barrack and village. So well was she served, too, that when one of her messengers was executed at Lahore, his wife begged his armlet as a relic of love at the scaffold, and instantly took out of it one of the Maharanee's letters, tore it into a hundred pieces, and swallowed them to save detection. She was removed to Benares too late to avert the war which she had fomented. Far away from the Punjab, pacing her prison in the "holy city" liked a caged tigress, she heard the echoes of the cannon of GOOGERAT, which deposed RUNJEET SINGH's dynasty forever, and made the Five Waters a province of the victorious English. Thenceforward she passed from the eyes of men, a pensioner of the British Power -- her hundred lovers dead or degraded -- her influence gone with her beauty and her youth -- the son, for whom she had sinned and plotted, dethroned, an exile and a renegade from the grand and conquering creed of Khalsa. Before her swimming eyes, as she lately sank in death in the country whither she had followed her son, these scenes, and a thousand as full of Eastern splendor and crime, must have passed.

abstract: Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday afternoon, at No. 11 Worth-street, on the body of ANN DERICKSON, a native of Ireland, aged 29 years, who died from injuries received during the riot. The testimony in the case shows that the poor woman was beaten almost to death by a gang of lawless men and boys while she was trying to protect her son from being burned and hung. A notice of her death and a statement of the circumstances under which she received her injuries were published in the TIMES of yesterday. The testimony given below tells the entire story.

abstract: On the War path
lead_paragraph: We have private advices from the Army of the Cumberland that make it positively certain that ROSECRANS is again on the war-path. It might not be prudent, at this moment, to mention such details as we have; but this much we may say, that the advance is under such circumstances and with such combinations as look toward the most important results.

abstract: It is a matter of surprise that there is so little real manifested in this city and the surrounding country, in making preparations for our own immediate defence, and especially by those who have the most at stake. To be sure we have frequently met and passed very patriotic and self-sacrificing resolutions, but where are the fruits of them? The army has not been increased, and we are to-day as defenceless as we were before any meeting was called. Have we lost our spirit, or did the valiant young men and old who volunteered at the beginning of this unholy war take all the honor, chivalry and manhood with them? Neither speeches, resolutions, nor unending talk can do us any good without action. What we must have is a thorough organization; and every man capable of bearing arms should join it. There are now a few companies here half filled up, or perhaps with a full quota of names, but who do not muster more than a respectable sized equal, while there should be in this city at least a regiment, and they should turn out at every drill. If our soldiers can devote their whole time to the service, we certainly ought to spare a few hours of each week in preparing to defend our own homes. Montgomery is one of the wealthiest cities in the Confederacy in proportion to the number of inhabitants, and it certainly seems to be the most defenceless.

abstract: Peaceful Progress of the
lead_paragraph: Well, the draft in the Sixth District is completed, and without the slightest tremor in the pulse of the mildest family man of that region. There has been neither insurrection, riot, row, nor shindy; not even so much as a quarrel or a tiff. Indeed, we never had more charming tranquillity. It quite carries back the mind to the sweet calm of the pastoral age.

lead_paragraph: THE RAILROAD ACCIDENT AT HAMILTON-AVENUE BRIDGE -- CONCLUSION OF THE CORONER's INVESTIGATION, AND VERDICT OF THE JURY. -- The investigation relating to the circumstances connected with the deplorable accident on Wednesday night, upon which occasion car No. 119 of the Greenwood and Fulton Ferry line was precipitated into Gowanus Creek, in consequence of the opening of the draw of Hamilton-avenue Bridge, was concluded before Coroner BENNETT and a jury, yesterday afternoon.

abstract: Our latest advices from Charleston are under date of Thursday, and are from the rebels themselves. Gen. GILLMORE, by his siege guns planted on Morris Island, was carrying on a steady and continuous bombardment of Fort Sumter; and the rebels confess that our fire was beginning to tell on this stronghold -- that our 200-pounder guns were proving too much for its walls, and that at date the fort was able to reply only at long intervals. They seem to anticipate its speedy reduction with even greater certainty than we have done. One of the paragraphs sets forth the rebel prospect in case of Sumter's fall, by asserting that it is not the main defence of the harbor, and even, if battered down, the latter may still be held. Another of their paragraphs sets forth their programme after Sumter and all the other works are reduced, by saying that it has been "determined to defend the city, street by street and house by house, as long as a foot of earth is left." The inference to be drawn from all this is, that whether or no Charleston is to be at once reduced, rebel confidence has been wonderfully reduced. As for the rebel gammon about fighting from street to street and house to house, we have already expressed the opinion that Gen. GILLMORE will give them a chance to do no such thing. When once Sumter and the other works in the harbor are reduced, and half a dozen monitors steam up the Ashley and Cooper Rivers, and plant themselves opposite each side of the old town, the rebels will be compelled to evacuate the streets and houses pretty quickly.

abstract: its Relations to the Army
lead_paragraph: We are occasionally afforded some very amusing illustrations of the mental confusion which exists on the subject of the relations of the State and National Governments. The leading Copperhead organ in this City informed us gravely a few days ago, in the latest finding of its constituents on this subject, "that the United States, in their relations with one another, were a confederation, but in their relations with foreign Powers, a nation." We remarked upon this theory at the time that it was propounded, that it looked well on paper, and its realization had long been the dream of statesmen and of political philosophers, but that it was impossible, in the present condition of human nature, to put it into practice; that if the idea of independence and separate sovereignty be allowed to prevail in the relations of the States with one another, it will inevitably prevail also in the relations of the States with foreign Powers. Strange as it may seem, Copperhead politicians are furnishing proofs of this every day themselves, and often in the same breath in which they pronounce their interpretation of the Constitution to be the very perfection of human ingenuity and wisdom.
