abstract: Never, since  the first record of the world, has a nation stood in a more false business and financial light before her peers than does England. She holds the unmerited reputation of a ...
lead_paragraph: -- Never, since the first record of the world, has a nation stood in a more false business and financial light before her peers than does England. She holds the unmerited reputation of a sturdy old business plodder, making money by industry alone, and looking with a wary and suspicious eye on everything approaching to speculative knavery. On the first appearance of any movement in another land, savoring of financial scheming, she commences a homily upon the wickedness of tempting fortune, and warns the unwary to keep their pockets tightly closed. Having satisfied her conscience on this point, the next is to look about that she may see some opening, be it ever so small, into which she can creep, and with her superabundant moneybags feed the flame, and rake out the monkey's share of the roasted chesnuts.

abstract: THE PRIZE STEAMER CHARLESTON. -- Judge CADWALLADER has ordered a sale of the prize steamer Charleston, which will take place on the 31st inst. When first sold the steamer brought but $6,000, though appraised at $11,000. The sale was set aside and a new appraisement ordered, which put the value of the steamer $8,[???]00. The former purchaser expressed a willingness to give that amount for her, and he would have got her for that sum, but a gentleman from New-York, who was unable to attend the first sale, offered, through his counsel, $8,500 for [???], and upon this the resale was ordered. At the [???] there were but two bidders, and little or no [???]. It is believed that, under such compe[???] should be at auction sales, the steamer [???] not quite, the amount of the [???]ent. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 21.

lead_paragraph: The diplomats of the coalition may rest from their labors. Whether they have agreed on identical notes, or a joint note, matters not. The Russian Government, and people as well, have chosen war before concession, and it only remains now for the Western Powers to retire baffled from the arena of controversy, or to take up arms, and espouse the cause of the insurgents.

abstract: We have looked with curiosity to see into what corner of refuge the English secession Press would creep to escape from the effect of the crushing blows which the cause they sustain has recently received. It was perhaps to be expected that they would lay hold ...
lead_paragraph: We have looked with curiosity to see into what corner of refuge the English secession Press would creep to escape from the effect of the crushing blows which the cause they sustain has recently received. It was perhaps to be expected that they would lay hold of the desperate "last ditch" utterances of some of the Southern leaders and insist that the Southern people were not cast down or discouraged or disunited by the victorious progress of our arms, but that they "rallied with the sterner resolution the more gloomy their prospects became." They had not yet heard of the crowds of deserters from the rebel armies which fill the mountains; the admissions of Southern papers that the rebel troops which crossed the Mississippi were lost to the Confederacy; or their lamentations over the state of things in Mississippi, where the people are anxious to give up the struggle. They had not heard the cry for peace from North Carolina, nor seen scathing review of the abundant promise and scant performance of Secession. Probably it would not have made much difference with them if they had, for the determination to see all things by rebel lights and through Pro-Slavery spectacles, would inevitably prevent them from giving any weight to these multifarious signs of dissolution.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF A SHOOTING AFFRAY IN THE SIXTH WARD. Corner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of BRIDGET GILROY, a girl aged about 13 years, who died at the New-York Hospital from the effects of injuries received at the hands of ...
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF A SHOOTING AFFRAY IN THE SIXTH WARD. -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of BRIDGET GILROY, a girl aged about 13 years, who died at the New-York Hospital from the effects of injuries received at the hands of FRANCIS FITZPATRICK, on the 30th of July last, at No. 100 Worth-street. The building in which the trouble took place is a large tenement-house, occupied by a great number of families and single persons, among whom were the deceased and FITZPATRICK. The latter was engaged in using all manner of vile and offensive epithets toward the girls, and they, becoming provoked by his conduct, retorted in somewhat the same style. This had the effect to exasperate FITZPATRICK, who was much the worse for liquor, and he drew a pistol and fired. The shot took effect in the head of BRIDGET, from the effects of which she died. The offender way arrested the same night by Officer WILKINSON, of the Sixth Precinct, and confined in the Tombs. Upon the rendition of the verdict the prisoner was arraigned, and in answer to the usual questions put to him by the Coroner, he stated that he was 58 years of age, a native of Ireland, resided at No. 100 Worth-street, and was a laborer. He further stated that he had never fired a gun or a pistol in his life, but that a man by the name of FITZGIBBONS fired it. The testimony in the case, however, is very conclusive as to the identity of the prisoner. There were a large number of witnesses examined, and the case has been thoroughly investigated by Coroner WILDEY.

abstract: BONAPARTE characterized war as "a game of blunders." This Southern insurrection is a long series of blunders. The first blunder of the South was at Charleston in 1860. The Democracy had a clear majority of votes in ...
lead_paragraph: BONAPARTE characterized war as "a game of blunders." This Southern insurrection is a long series of blunders. The first blunder of the South was at Charleston in 1860. The Democracy had a clear majority of votes in the country, as the election that Fall showed. The united vote of BRECKINRIDGE and DOUGLASS was 356,658 greater than the vote for LINCOLN. They knew this fact, and that they had a perfect party drill which had done them veteran service for thirty years. They deliberately, and with a full consciousness of the act, broke their party machinery into fragments, and flung away the advantages of their position. They determined to overthrow a Government in which no law favorable to Slavery could be passed which a Supreme Court, carefully selected from men of Southern proclivities, would not uphold as strictly constitutional; a Government in which they had the whole executive power of the land -- the President and all the civil and military and naval offices, as well as a majority in both Houses of Congress.
headline: {'main': 'Who has Blundered Most?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Who has Blundered Most?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The destruction of Lawrence, Kansas, by QUANTRELL and his guerrillas, appears to have been very complete only a few houses being left standing in the place. The list of killed and wounded citizens is said to number some one hundred and eighty, the majority of whom were ...
lead_paragraph: The destruction of Lawrence, Kansas, by QUANTRELL and his guerrillas, appears to have been very complete -- only a few houses being left standing in the place. The list of killed and wounded citizens is said to number some one hundred and eighty, the majority of whom were killed outright. Among those killed were the Mayor and his son, and a number of other prominent citizens -- all shot down in their own houses, in the midst of their families. Pillage and murder has not before during the war been carried to such a fearful extent even by the miscreants who compose QUANTRELL's band. Gen. JIM LANE, it now appears, succeeded in making his escape from the town on horseback, and rallied some twenty men, with whom he pursued the murderers, though with no success. It is doubtful whether they can be overtaken before they will have disposed of their plunder and dispersed. The loss at Lawrence, it is estimated, will amount to about two millions, which will fall heavily on New-York as well as Lawrence merchants.

abstract: London Times on Our Bravery in a Bad Cause
snippet: London Times on Our Bravery in a Bad Cause
lead_paragraph: -- We saw, with great surprise, in reading a discourse of the London Times upon our affairs, that we had carried on the war with "dogged perseverance." We were disposed at first to grieve that we had received praise from such a quarter, but on reading further we found that even that sweet drop was not without its atrabilious accompaniment, for it was said to be a "dogged perseverance, worthy of a better cause," and, on reflection, the bitter entirely overpowered the sweet. We cannot accept a compliment to our perseverance, at the expense of the cause for which we have fought. A better cause! where will one be found? Our cause is the cause of the Union against disintegration; of order against anarchy; of representative government against despotism; of civilization against barbarism; of the Future against the Past. It is the cause of the people against the aristocracy; and that is what makes the Times hate us so virulently. It is the great cause of the world.

abstract: The Kaiser's Plans
lead_paragraph: The Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH is evidently disgusted with the arrogance of the Western Powers, and determined to abate it. In order to accomplish this, he is laboring to bring about a more perfect federal union between the German States. Divided, those States are utterly incapable of resisting the aggression of any of the great Powers; united, they would control the destinies of Europe.

abstract: Rodgers, Capt. G. W., of the Monitor Catskill; the Massacre at by Quantrell; the Victims; Quantrell's Massacres at Lawrence
snippet: Rodgers, Capt. G. W., of the Monitor Catskill; the Massacre at by Quantrell; the Victims; Quantrell's Massacres at Lawrence
lead_paragraph: The steamers Arkansas, which arrived at Philadelphia, and the Star of the South, which arrived here yesterday, put us in possession of our own advices from Charleston to the 20th instant as late as the rebel advices published by us on Saturday. The rebel accounts of the damage done to Fort Sumter are of course more than confirmed. It appears that the attack upon the Fort by Gen. GILLMORE's batteries and by the naval battery on shore, commenced at daybreak on Monday morning, and that at 6 o'clock Admiral DAHLGREN attacked batteries Wagner and Gregg (the Cummings Point battery) with the Ironsides and the Monitors. The wooden gunboats also joined effectively in the assault. Wagner was soon completely silenced, and Battery Gregg nearly so -- thus enabling Gen. GILLMORE to prosecute his attack upon Sumter almost without annoyance from the enemy's guns. At 10 o'clock, the Admiral, with two Monitors, joined in the attack on Sumter at a distance of 1,400 yards, and rendered effective service for about an hour without damage to the vessels. During the attack on Wagner, Fieet-Capt. RODGERS took command of his old vessel, Monitor Catskill, and went within 150 yards of the beach point. Then, after firing a number of shots, the Catskill turret was struck by a shot which detached a piece of the interior lining, which, striking Capt. RODGERS in the head, killed him instantly. The same piece also killed Paymaster WOODBURY, who was standing at his side. No other persons were injured on land or water during the engagement, which lasted six hours. The damage done by Gen. GILLMORE's batteries to the works of Sumter was quite visible to the naked eye. The false wall, ten feet thick, built by the rebels outside the main wall, was reduced to a heap of ruins, and the main wall was bored full of deep holes, the parapet crushed, and the northwest corner cracked almost to the Water's edge. And all this the result of only one day's work! On Tuesday the batteries were kept steadily engaged, while two of the Monitors kept batteries Wagner and Gregg silent. This course was continued, with slight variation, through Wednesday and Thursday, when Sumter was so far silenced as to throw only an occasional shot. When the Star of the South left, on the 20th, Gen. GILLMORE was mounting his 300-pound parrott, with which Charleston itself was to be shelled. No doubt was entertained that the efforts of our land and naval forces would be crowned with triumphant success.

abstract: The honorable record would be left incomplete without reference to three gentlemen, D.B. HASBROUCK, First Deputy Clerk; GEORGE HOPCRAFT, Clerk to Superintendent; and HORACE A. BLISS, Clerk to Inspectors.
lead_paragraph: The honorable record would be left incomplete without reference to three gentlemen, D.B. HASBROUCK, First Deputy Clerk; GEORGE HOPCRAFT, Clerk to Superintendent; and HORACE A. BLISS, Clerk to Inspectors. The two former during Riot Week were occupied day and night, unceasingly, in the performance of varied duties, neither of them making note of hours or weariness, but lending their whole time and energies to the intelligent and valuable services they were called upon to perform. When the immense amount of business centralizing at headquarters, and the responsible character of what devolved on them to do, is remembered, that they were the right men in the right place will be promptly and cheerfully conceded. Mr. BLISS, was temporarily absent at the burial of a brother, but returned in time to make available to the Department the intelligence and energy which he is so well known to possess.

Provost-Marshal ERHARDT had made excellent arrangements, and with his assistants hurried the drawings rapidly along.
lead_paragraph: The drafting in the Fourth District passed off quietly yesterday, there being not an approach even to any demonstration of dissatisfaction. Inspector DILKS had carge of the Police, and a body of military was posted in the building. Provost-Marshal ERHARDT had made excellent arrangements, and with his assistants hurried the drawings rapidly along. Mr. B. LEVISON, a blind man -- a Prussian, who has been blind five years -- drew the names from the wheel. The first name drawn was that of PATRICK MAGUIRE, Pier No. 1, North River. The following is the result. The Fourth Ward has been completed. The Fifth will be commenced this morning at 9 o'clock.

abstract: And the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: Our most important news this morning is from the splendid army of Gen. ROSECRANS -- being as late as the afternoon of the 23d. Gen ROSECRANS' advance appeared before Chattanooga on the 21st, and opened fire on the rebel works at 10 o'clock A.M., with good effect. The rebels replied, but generally with small guns, which did very little damage. The works were found to be very strong. Two steamers were moored at the wharf, one of which was sunk and the other disabled by our fire. There was also a pontoon bridge across the river, protected by rebel sharpshooters. It was ascertained that there were two divisions of rebel troops at Chattanooga, while HILL's corps (late HARDEE's) were disposed along the railroad in the direction of Bridgeport -- Gen. JOE JOHNSTON being in command of the whole, he having superseded BRAGG. On the night of the 22d, Gen. WILDER crossed the Tennessee River, and burned a small railroad bridge near Shellmound, thus severing communication between the right and left wings of the rebel army, and recrossed the river in safety. Deserters and citizens confirm the repeated reports of great demoralization among the rebel troops, not only at Chattanooga but everywhere in the Southwest. Our dispatches lead us to expect the immediate occurrence of important events.

abstract: THE QUOTA OF JERSEY CITY FILLED. -- The liberal bounty offered in Jersey City, together with the county bounty and State pay, has enabled the authorities to raise their quota (which was completed yesterday) of 595 men within the required time, and two days to spare. The quota for Hudson City was completed several days since. Hoboken will probably raise the number of men required this week.

lead_paragraph: Some days since we took occasion to say that in our judgment the reconstruction of the Union would be accomplished by the voluntary return of the several rebellious States, through the action of their people in deposing the rebel authorities, repudiating the rebel Confederate Government, reorganizing their State Legislatures and Executives, renewing their allegiance to the Constitution of the United States, and sending members to represent them in both Houses of the National Congress. We endeavored also, though briefly, to answer some of the objections that are likely to be urged to such a view of the case.
headline: {'main': 'Reconstruction of the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reconstruction of the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SUPPOSED INCENDIARY ATTEMPT TO DESTROY A LIQUOR STORE. -- About 10 o'clock yesterday morning a pipe of brandy exploded, without apparent cause, in the establishment of MILTON WOOLEY, Nos. 75 and 77 South Seventh-street, Brooklyn, E.D. The clerk and porter were prostrated, and the building set on fire. A stream of water from a hydrant immediately turned on saved the premises, with a loss of only about $400 on the stock, which is covered by insurance. A man was in the store just a moment before the accident, and it is believed by the proprietor that it was intended to burn him out because he persists in keening a colored porter, after having been repeatedly warned to discharge him. He thinks a lighted cigar must have been dropped into the bunghole of the pipe. The man escaped.

abstract: the Reckoning with
lead_paragraph: CARLYLE somewhere speaks of Justice putting on her terrible garments -- "her robes of hell-fire." It is in just this aspect she is to-day approaching Charleston. There is something fearfully imposing in the manner in which that sheet of flame works its resistless way toward the devoted city. Yet men rejoice. And well may they. Not for revenge. Revenge is a passion fit for savages only. But because there is a deep instinct in the human breast that finds pleasure in righteous retribution. This visitation upon the chief city of South Carolina causes peculiar satisfaction, for the reason that South Carolina is the guiltiest of all the rebel States. It gave birth to the master-traitor, CALHOUN -- idolized him living and canonized him when dead. It plotted disunion for thirty years; twice made a desperate effort to compass it by open resistance, and was the head and front of the present, yet more formidable, movement. It was South Carolina that first began the war; that first shut up the Federal Courts; that first withdrew her members from Congress; that first passed an ordinance of secession; that first laid hands upon the Federal property; that first fired upon the National flag, and opened the war. Had it not been for South Carolina, in all earthly probability, this impious rebellion would not have existed at all. As it is said of Satan that he "drew" one-third of the angels after him in foul revolt, so may it be said of this arch-apostate in the family of American States -- she drew a third of them away by her own original and infernal wickedness.
headline: {'main': 'The Reckoning with South Carolina.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Reckoning with South Carolina.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: hattan was an island; never since New-York was a City; never under Indian rule, nor Dutch rule, nor English rule, nor the rule of the Union -- was there such a large body of soldiers concentrated here as at the present moment. The rioters are reported to have information that there are over forty Federal regiments on this island and the isles immediately adjacent; and it is possible that their information is not very erroneous. Every park and square, and every vacant spot where a soldier can pitch his tent, is occupied. The reveille and tattoo are heard all over the city. There are artillery, cavalry, and infantry. There are bronzed, battle-worn, and begrimed veterans from Virginia -- regiments which have carried our banner in a score of fierce fights and have routed the rebels on many a field; and they seem to be all ready for any duty. Beside these there are not a few of our brave militia regiments constantly under arms. Their faces are whiter, their clothes newer and cleaner, and their general appearance more spruce than those of the others. Both classes are soldierly-looking men -- to use a much misused term; but the characteristic has a very different development in each, as may be seen by comparing them on parade, or on general duty, or when off duty. Beside all these forces there are sprightly little gunboats darting to and fro in the harbor, and up and down both rivers, with clean, tasteful, " all-ready" marines, quite prepared for action. Our garrison, on the whole, is a very powerful one, and seems to enjoy a visit to the Metropolis very much. The Metropolis is well pleased to see them.

abstract: The performance of the excellent drama of the "Duke's Motto " has been brought to such a state of perfection at this house that it is hardly possible to speak of it in terms of moderation. During the long period of its career, it has gone through all the small complaints of dramahood, and survived the later and sterner afflictions of professional "gaggery." It is now one of the quickest plays in action, and best in performance, that we have had on the City stage for many years. This result is due mainly to Mr. WHEATLEY, not only for the liberal way in which the work has been placed upon the stage, but also for his fine and manly impersonation of the leading character. He was assisted, last night, by a new member of his already powerful company. The lady, Miss Ross EYTINGE, impersonated the somewhat faint and embarassing role of Blanche -- hitherto played -- and played very nicely by Mrs. ALLEN. It is not in such a part that we shall seek the materials of a criticism on, or a just approximation to a knowledge of the lady's powers. It is sufficient that gracefully seizing the few opportunities of the character -- as in the love passages of the first act -- she interpreted them with naturalness, ease and elegance, conveying at the same time a very unmistakable indication of ability that will lead to higher regions of the art, where there wards, if more difficult of obtainment, are also more worthy of effort. Miss EYTINGE is no novice, but she is comparatively new to our stage, and we think Mr. WHEATLEY is to be congratulated on having added her to his company. Her voice and her appearance are eminently in her power, and intellectually she will, we are sure, prove a very desirable addition to the small total of educated artists in our midst.

abstract: Two of our armies--that of ROSEGRANS in the Alleghany Mountains, and that of GILLMORE on the Atlantic seaboard--are now activity engaged with the rebels.
lead_paragraph: Two of our armies -- that of ROSECRANS in the Alleghany Mountains, and that of GILLMORE on the Atlantic seaboard -- are now activity engaged with the rebels. Our dates from Charleston are to Thursday last, at which time, according to the telegraph, the guns of Fort Sumter had been silenced and several breaches made in its walls, and its speedy capitulation or reduction were looked for. On Friday last the advance of Gen. ROSECRANS' army appeared before Chattanooga, and on the morning of the same day our guns opened fire upon the stronghold. The rebels replied to our bombardment, but the report is that we disabled every one of their batteries which opened upon us. The works were found to be very strong. It has long been known that they were so. The rebel force holding Chattanooga is said to consist of two army corps; and it is further reported that Gen. JOHNSTON had arrived on the ground with two trains filled with reinforcements, and also that this ill-starred general had superseded the worse-starred Gen. BRAGG. If it be really true that "the demoralization of the rebel army is complete," and that thousand after thousand is deserting from it, we should think its total defeat and the speedy capture or Chattanooga would be an easy matter.

abstract: A Tour of INSPECTION.--Gen. CANBY and Staff, Surgeon-General WM. A. HAMMOND, Medical Director Surgeon C. McDOUGALL, and Major STEWART VAN VLEIT, Quartermaster U.S.A. at this point, were on a tour of inspection of the hospitals and defences in the harbor on Friday and Saturday last.
lead_paragraph: A TOUR OF INSPECTION. -- Gen. CANBY and Staff, Surgeon-General WM.A. HAMMOND, Medical Director Surgeon C. MCDOUGALL, and Major STEWART VAN VLEIT, Quartermaster U.S.A. at this point, were on a tour of inspection of the hospitals and defences in the harbor on Friday and Saturday last. Brig.-Gen. HARVEY BROWN, now in command at Fort Schuyler, joined the party also at that point. Gen. CANBY and Surgeon-General HAMMOND expressed themselves as well satisfied with the condition and management of the hospitals, both for our own men and for the rebels on David's Island. The Surgeon-General has certainly been fortunate in the selection of a Medical Director for this Department. Dr. MCDOUGALL is peculiarly qualified for this position, both by long experience in the army, and in possessing those other qualities of kindness and sympathy, which render him at all times accessible. The several military Departments work harmoniously and satisfactorily to all parties concerned.

abstract: The ship Francis B. Cutting, Capt. JAMES T. MALONEY, arrived at this port yesterday from Liverpool, and reports as follows: Sailed from Liverpool July 20. Nothing of note occurred until Aug. 6, when, in lat. 41° 10', lon. 44° 20', a strange and suspicious-looking sail appeared to windward, it then blowing strong from the north-northwest, with a rough sea. This sail soon bore down for us, fired a shot across our bow, and hoisted the American ensign at the mizzen peak; at this time she was very near us, and we saw that she was an armed steamer, bark-rigged. We then showed our colors, and prepared to heave to; while doing so he fired a second shot, which passed between our fore and mainmasts. We then hove to: he also hove to, (distance then one quarter of a mile to windward,) and sent an armed boat's crew alongside, containing two Lieutenants and eight men. As soon as the Lieutenant in command came on board he asked for the Captain, then pointing to the vessel to windward said: "That ship to windward of vou, Sir, is the Confederate sloop-of-war Florida. Your ship is a prize. I will put one of my men at your wheel, if you please, Sir," and ordered one of his armed men to haul down my flag. All this time the vessel to windward was flying the American flag. He then asked to see my papers, which I showed him. He examined all my bills of lading, and also broke open the package of certified British invoices, asking particularly for boiler iron, and how many passengers I had on board. I told him 230. He asked for my signal-book and code of signals, which I gave him. He then had a long conversation with his ship by telegraph. He asked me if I would like to have my ship burned. I replied I would not. He then said I would have to go on board the Florida with him. I declined doing so. I would not leave my ship, as my passengers were British subjects, and I would not trust their lives in another person's bands. He telegraphed to his ship again, and said he would probably have to run my ship for [???]ayal, put the passengers out, and burn the ship. Otherwise, if Capt. MAFFIT approved of it, he would bond the ship for $60,660. I told him the ship was worth no such money, and I would not sign a bond to that effect. After a consultation of two or three hours, he agreed to take $40,000, for which I signed a bond, under the conditions of Capt. MAFFIT's approval, and sent my chief mate on board with them to witness my signature. He then telegraphed to me that the bond was accepted, and returned the mate. After detaining us five hours, we proceeded on our course. The Florida immediately gave chase to a large ship to windward, which I took to be an American. I understood from the Lieutenant of the Florida, who came on board, that the Florida had burned two American ships, and bonded two others, but would not give their names.

abstract: The steamship City of Baltimore arrived at this port late last night, with advices from Europe one day later. She left Liverpool on the 12th, and Queenstown on the 13th inst. There is no confirmation of the London Times' report that additional British troops were to be sent to Canada.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Baltimore arrived at this port late last night, with advices from Europe one day later. She left Liverpool on the 12th, and Queenstown on the 13th inst. There is no confirmation of the London Times' report that additional British troops were to be sent to Canada. There are no new developments regarding the Polish question. It is asserted in various quarters that the Archduke MAXIMILIAN will accept the throne of Mexico. Cotton in the Liverpool, market had an upward tendency.

abstract: has been a deal of indignant outcry among our people, ever since the rebellion broke out, against those who were taking advantage of the necessities of the Government, and the confusion and hurry of such an immense amount of business as was suddenly thrown upon it, to gain unfair and extortionate profits for themselves. Not a whit too much outcry, however. It is impossible to mark with too deep obloquy those who take advantage of such an emergency to plunder right and left, and to get their country's money into their pockets without giving an equivalent to their country for it. There is one class of these knaves who are doing a lively business now-a-days, to our great loss and disgrace. We mean those who offer themselves as substitutes in the intention of deserting.

abstract: -- The London Times says that "any protests from the United States [in regard to French policy in Mexico] are likely to be received with little regard -- "Since for years past the leading organ of the present Washington Cabinet, the NEW-YORK TIMES, has reiterated the declaration that it was the policy and intention of America to make Mexico drink the cup of anarchy to the very dregs, and there can be no sympathy in any part of the civilized world with the disappointment that may now be felt at Washington at the frustration of the project."

abstract: We have intelligence from Charleston to Sunday last, through rebel dispatches published in the Richmond papers. It is of a highly important character. Fort Sumter is, no doubt, by this time in our possession it having, according to the rebel accounts, been reduced to a ruin.
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from Charleston to Sunday last, through rebel dispatches published in the Richmond papers. It is of a highly important character. Fort Sumter is, no doubt, by this time in our possession -- it having, according to the rebel accounts, been reduced to a ruin. On Saturday six hundred and four shots are said to have been fired at it, of which four hundred and nineteen struck inside and outside. On Sunday the land batteries opened from South to North, and the Monitors from East to West, going close to the fort, and the consequences were most ruinous to the enemy. Gen. GILLMORE had previously demanded the surrender of the fort, and of the works on Morris Island, accompanied by a threat to shell Charleston; and on Sunday at 11 O'clock he gave notice that on Monday at 11 he would open on the city, and that in the meantime non-combatants could leave. Our own reports, by arrivals at this port, are only to midnight of Friday. They, of course, more than confirm the rebel reports of the damage done to Fort Sumter up to that time.

abstract: The Captain of the brig South Boston, which araivid at Philadelphia on the 23d Inst., reports that on the evening of the 22d, in latitude 37°, longitude 74°, he picked up a boat belonging to the U.S. brig Bainbridge, which was full of water and contained a colored man named SMITH, who stated that on the 21st during a violent gale, the brig foundered, with al hands on board, except himself and the cook. The latter went crazy after being five hours in the boat, and jumped overboard.

abstract: In obedience to official orders from B.F. MANIERRE, Marshal of the Eighth District, which comprises the Eighteenth and Twenty-first Wards, the Draft commenced for that section of the City at 8 A.M. yesterday, in the building No. 1,303 Broadway, near 36th-street. At a very early hour a large but orderly crowd of working men and others lined the adjacent sidewalks. A strong body of Police, commanded by Capt. SPEIGHT of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, was stationed both outside and inside of the building, assisted by a detachment of military who occupied the lower floor. On the tower of the Seventh-Avenue Arsenal in the vicinity were sentinels and lookouts, who scanned the neighborhood with field glasses, the Union flag indicating the military occupancy of the structure as a strong point of vantage in case of attempted insurrection. The opposition which made the scene so memorable on the 13th of July, was not renewed, and, at 8 o'clock precisely, a thousand and twenty-six were counted out, and after the deduction of 216 drawn on the former occasion, Marshal MANIERRE announced the formal opening of the proceedings.

abstract: Before Chattanooga
lead_paragraph: Those who take an intelligent view of the military situation will not, amid the brilliancy of our operations on the coast of South Carolina, lose sight of the supreme importance of the work at which the army of Gen. ROSECRANS is now engaged. Superb though the reduction of Sumter be as a piece of engineering, and valuable though its practical results must be, it is a conquest on the outer rim of the rebellion. ROSECRANS menaces its very centre and heart. With the possession of Chattanooga, the whole complexion of the war, the distribution of all our forces in the field, and the lines and combinations of military operations undergo a fundamental change. ROSECRANS drives a wedge into the centre of the Confederacy, seizes interior lines, forces the rebels to fall back on exterior lines, and puts the military power of the rebellion at the mercy of a few vigorous blows.
headline: {'main': 'Rosecrans Before Chattanooga.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rosecrans Before Chattanooga.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- They are having a great deal of trouble in Providence with "bounty jumpers" and substitute swindlers from this City. The Journal of Wednesday says: "Capt. HANLIN developed another precious trio of scamps yesterday. The first was a young man calling himself WM. H. ONDERDONK, who said he was selected by one of the others, who claimed to be an officer of the Executive Department of the State of New-York, to 'spot' deserters. He wore spectacles of entirely plain glass, evidently put on to disguise a rather wicked face. Upon investigation he was himself 'spotted' as a deserter from the Eleventh New-York regiment, by the name of HENRY MYERS, who had been to Taunton, and attempted to pass the Board, but was rejected. Then came the second person of the trio, one RICHARD BARBOUR, who it was known had been discharged from the Provost-Marshal's department, but who now pretended to be here on special private business for the Executive Department of the State of New-York. Unfortunately he had no papers to show his mission, and his companionship with a deserter, and his association with the substitutes and agents afforded very poor credentials, so that no one was surprised when a dispatch was received from the Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal- General in New-York that the fellow was an imposter. He was also committed. The third of this gay copartnership was one FLURY, from Taunton, who claimed to be accidentally in the ring. He had brought on a German to sell here as a substitute, but the thieves had stolen him on the steamboat, so that on the whole he was the losing partner. He was discharged.

abstract: -- Gen. GRANT has issued an order in reference to guerrillas analogous in intent and aim to that issued by Gen. ROSECRANS. He announces that as all regularly organized bodies of rebels have been driven from those parts of Kentucky and Tennessee west of the Tennessee River, and from all of Mississippi west of the Central Railroad, the most rigorous penalties will be inflicted upon all irregular bodies of cavalry not mustered and paid by the Confederate authorities -- upon all conscript officers and all those who aid them -- and upon all persons detected in firing upon unarmed transports. It is not contemplated that this order shall affect the treatment due to prisoners of war captured within the districts named, when they are members of legally organized companies, and when their acts are in accordance with the usages of civilized warfare. It is evident that a line of policy similar to this of ROSECRANS and GRANT will soon have to be applied to very large districts of the rebellious States.
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. GRANT has issued an order in reference to guerrillas analogous in intent and aim to that issued by Gen. ROSECRANS. It is not contemplated that this order shall affect the treatment due to prisoners of war captured within the districts named, when they are members of legally organized companies, and when their acts are in accordance with the usages of civilized warfare. It is evident that a line of policy similar to this of ROSECRANS and GRANT will soon have to be applied to very large districts of the rebellious States.

abstract: It is gratifying to record the completion of the Draft in the Seventh District. On Monday the proceedings were begun, and at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the whole quota was enrolled. The Provost-Marshal, Capt. WAGNER, is entitled to great praise for the quiet and efficient manner in which the proceedings were carried out. The arrangements were perfect, the work rapid, the order complete. Commissioner BALDWIN alternated with Capt. WAGNER in announcing the names, which was done so distinctly as to render the labor of the reporters comparatively light. The Police force present was under charge of Capt. BROWER, of the Seventeenth Precinct. A large military force was under arms, in charge of Capt. CORNELIUS KING. The Recorders were Lieut.-Col. RUTHERFORD and Messrs. B.P. WOODS and S.S. WANDELL.

abstract: -- At the meeting of the Councilmen yesterday afternoon, the Mayor sent in a communication vetoing the exemption ordinance. It is published in another column. The main point of objection made by his Honor is, that the effect of the ordinance, as it reads, is to nullify the object of the act of Congress by depriving the army of men. He thinks the ordinance loosely drawn in regard to the payment of the $300, and as affording opportunity for gross misappropriation of the public moneys. He proposes that the firemen, militia and police should be exempted, past experience having proven the necessity of their presence.

abstract: The U.S. steamer Alabama, an account of which was some time since given, is still infected with yellow fever, and no hopes exist of relieving her of the plague until she is sent North, where the early frost will purify her. At the last meeting of the Board of Commissioners of Health, the Mayor was requested to address the Secretary of the Navy on the subject. The Alabama is the worst infected vessel arriving here since 1857. After her arrival and the removal of the crew, Health Officer GUNN placed on board three ship-keepers; two of them were taken with the fever and died, and the other was ordered from the vessel. Subsequently several of the crew of the Alabama who were taken from her ill with the fever and recovered, volunteered to act as ship-keepers. But a few days ago one of them was again attacked with the lever, in its most malignant form, and has ere this probably died. No better evidence is needed of how badly the vessel, is infected than this. She is a plague-spot, a constant source of danger and anxiety, and should be moved forthwith to where there are hopes of redeeming her. Every case of fever taken from her has been characterized by a very unusual malignity, and nearly all cases have proved speedily fatal. Dr. WALSER, Deputy Health Officer, states that in his many years of experience at Quarantine, he has never witnessed anything like the infected condition of this vessel, or the terrible nature of the disease she disseminates. Dr. GUNN has been anxiously endeavoring to induce her removal North, and the attempts should prove successful.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamer Alabama, an account of which was some time since given, is still infected with yellow fever, and no hopes exist of relieving her of the plague until she is sent North, where the early frost will purify her. The Alabama is the worst infected vessel arriving here since 1857. After her arrival and the removal of the crew, Health Officer GUNN placed on board three ship-keepers; two of them were taken with the fever and died, and the other was ordered from the vessel. Subsequently several of the crew of the Alabama who were taken from her ill with the fever and recovered, volunteered to act as ship-keepers. But a few days ago one of them was again attacked with the lever, in its most malignant form, and has ere this probably died. No better evidence is needed of how badly the vessel, is infected than this. She is a plague-spot, a constant source of danger and anxiety, and should be moved forthwith to where there are hopes of redeeming her. Every case of fever taken from her has been characterized by a very unusual malignity, and nearly all cases have proved speedily fatal. Dr. WALSER, Deputy Health Officer, states that in his many years of experience at Quarantine, he has never witnessed anything like the infected condition of this vessel, or the terrible nature of the disease she disseminates. Dr. GUNN has been anxiously endeavoring to induce her removal North, and the attempts should prove successful.

abstract: The following is said to be something like a correct statement of the contents of the reform project proposed by Austria: An Assembly of delegates from all the German Diets, with right of voting, and to be convoked periodically. An Upper House, composed of the representatives of the Sovereigns. This Assembly is to include the former Princes of the German Empire. The direction of Federal affairs to be administered by seven Governors of German States under the Presidency of Austria. The present Federal Diet to be dissolved. A reform of the military organization of the Confederation. Abolition of the article of the German Federal Constitution by which unanimity of the members of the Diet is required for the adoption of measures of general utility to the establishment of organic Federal institutions.
lead_paragraph: The following is said to be something like a correct statement of the contents of the reform project proposed by Austria: An Assembly of delegates from all the German Diets, with right of voting, and to be convoked periodically. An Upper House, composed of the representatives of the Sovereigns. This Assembly is to include the former Princes of the German Empire. The direction of Federal affairs to be administered by seven Governors of German States under the Presidency of Austria. The present Federal Diet to be dissolved. A reform of the military organization of the Confederation. Abolition of the article of the German Federal Constitution by which unanimity of the members of the Diet is required for the adoption of measures of general utility to the establishment of organic Federal institutions.

abstract: And the Union
lead_paragraph: Prior to the rebellion the old North State had been second to none in dignity, patriotism, steadiness and good sense. She was not in the habit of blowing her trumpet and proclaiming to the world her matchless bravery; and even when she fell into the folly of rebellion, she did not, like her brethren of the Southern Gascony, wax red in the face in windy announcements that one of her soldiers could whip ten Yankees, and that her whole population was ready to "die in the last ditch," &c. There had been no ill blood between her people and the people of the North, but much of mutual respect and good will, and friendly intercourse. Her business men -- the producing whites, the "plain people" -- had no interest, general or local, which was not in harmony with the Union; and her obedience to the South Carolina decree was as discreditable and suicidal as such obedience would have been for Pennsylvania or New-York.

abstract: Instead of the reports of QUANTRELL's massacre at Lawrence growing less as the truth in regard to it reaches us, they grow greater and more horrible. The details which we publish this morning make the blood run cold; and, alas! they can no longer be discredited -- they cannot be characterized as exaggerations. Two hundred citizens, some say 300 -- nearly all the more respectable people of the place -- butchered at their own hearthstones in the early dawn of the morning. Two hundred houses -- nearly all the better houses of the town -- fired and reduced to ruins. Nearly a hundred wives made widows in an hour, and two hundred and fifty children made orphans forever. Most of these are now houseless, penniless and friendless, mourning for their dead amid the ruins of their homes, far out on the wild plains west of the Missouri. It is a case for our deepest sympathy, for our promptest charity.
lead_paragraph: Instead of the reports of QUANTRELL's massacre at Lawrence growing less as the truth in regard to it reaches us, they grow greater and more horrible. Two hundred houses -- nearly all the better houses of the town -- fired and reduced to ruins. Nearly a hundred wives made widows in an hour, and two hundred and fifty children made orphans forever. Most of these are now houseless, penniless and friendless, mourning for their dead amid the ruins of their homes, far out on the wild plains west of the Missouri. It is a case for our deepest sympathy, for our promptest charity.

abstract: Another blockade-runner left Queenstown yesterday, the long, rakish-looking, two-funneled steamer which has been lying in the harbor for the past week, and which came here from the Clyde, on which, it appears, she had been employed in the ordinary river traffic. She looks less able to stand a heavy sea than one of the steamers of our Citizens' River Steamers Company, but is modelled as it possessed of great swiftness. She called into Queenstown nominally for coals.

abstract: The additional news from Charleston, which we publish to-day, is no later, but is confirmatory of that published yesterday. Sumter, on Saturday morning, was an immense ruin.
lead_paragraph: The additional news from Charleston, which we publish to-day, is no later, but is confirmatory of that published yesterday. Sumter, on Saturday morning, was an immense ruin. The rear wall was battered down, disclosing to view the interior of the fort, and the front was very badly shattered by shot striking it on the inside. Rebel deserters, captured last week, reported that it was the intention of the rebels to abandon the fort and blow it up. We have no later reports via Richmond than those published yesterday.

abstract: Yesterday we briefly announced the loss of the United States brig Bainbridge, in the gale off Hatteras, on the 21st, she having foundered with all on board except one person. This vessel left New-York on Monday, the 17th, for Port Royal, was caught in the storm of the 21st and foundered, turning bottom upward. The following particulars were got from the person who was saved -- a colored seaman -- the only person known to be saved out of eighty persons.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday we briefly announced the loss of the United States brig Bainbridge, in the gale off Hatteras, on the 21st, she having foundered with all on board except one person. abstract: The following is the report of Capt. COFFIN, of bring W.E. Nash, destroyed by the Florida: "Sailed from New-York, July 3. July 8, latitude 40째, longitude 70째, at 3 P.M., made a steamer to the eastward, standing to the westward, apparently under full head of steam; passed us about five miles off; she had four smoke-pipes, and was a side-wheel boat -- the Ericsson chased by the Florida. Soon afterward made another steamer to the eastward, which came along and passed us; soon after she bore up for us, and came alongside, with the stars and stripes flying; hailed us to heave to, as they wished to send a boat aboard, and as the boat boarded us they ran up the Confederate flag on the steamer, and the officer of the boat pronounced us a prize to the Confederate flag; ordered myself and part of my crew to take part of our clothes and my papers and go on board the steamer, which proved to be the Florida. My charts and instruments were confiscated, the brig sacked and then set on fire. They then steered for a schooner in sight, which they found abandoned; she was a whaling schooner, bailed from Provincetown, and was set on fire. They then steered off the coast as fast as possible, under steam and canvas, and landed myself and crew in Bermuda on the 16th of July. The Florida is armed with six broadside guns and two pivots; is not as fast as has been represented, and her machinery is getting out of repair; she does not steam over 8 1/2 knots; the discipline on board is bad. She, together with a number of blockade runners, were in port. The Florida has transferred a portion of her valuable spoils on board the Robert E. Lee, to be taken to Wilmington."
lead_paragraph: The following is the report of Capt. COFFIN, of bring W.E. Nash, destroyed by the Florida: "Sailed from New-York, July 3. Soon afterward made another steamer to the eastward, which came along and passed us; soon after she bore up for us, and came alongside, with the stars and stripes flying; hailed us to heave to, as they wished to send a boat aboard, and as the boat boarded us they ran up the Confederate flag on the steamer, and the officer of the boat pronounced us a prize to the Confederate flag; ordered myself and part of my crew to take part of our clothes and my papers and go on board the steamer, which proved to be the Florida. My charts and instruments were confiscated, the brig sacked and then set on fire. They then steered for a schooner in sight, which they found abandoned; she was a whaling schooner, bailed from Provincetown, and was set on fire. They then steered off the coast as fast as possible, under steam and canvas, and landed myself and crew in Bermuda on the 16th of July. The Florida is armed with six broadside guns and two pivots; is not as fast as has been represented, and her machinery is getting out of repair; she does not steam over 8 1/2 knots; the discipline on board is bad. She, together with a number of blockade runners, were in port. The Florida has transferred a portion of her valuable spoils on board the Robert E. Lee, to be taken to Wilmington."

abstract: Steamer Charles Martell, from Vera Cruz, was ordered in Quarantine by Health Officer GUNN, July 13. She has been thoroughly cleaned and the ballast discharged at the Lower Bay. Being considered perfectly safe now, she has been allowed to go to the Atlantic Docks and receive cargo. No cases of yellow fever occurred among the crew, nor among the Quarantine employes on her, after the removal of some decayed hides on board a month since.
lead_paragraph: Steamer Charles Martell, from Vera Cruz, was ordered in Quarantine by Health Officer GUNN, July 13. She has been thoroughly cleaned and the ballast discharged at the Lower Bay. Being considered perfectly safe now, she has been allowed to go to the Atlantic Docks and receive cargo. No cases of yellow fever occurred among the crew, nor among the Quarantine employes on her, after the removal of some decayed hides on board a month since.

abstract: The Paris Constitutionnel announces positively that the French reply to the Russian note had been the first of the answers of the three Powers dispatched to St. Petersubrgh; those of Austria and
lead_paragraph: The Paris Constitutionnel announces positively that the French reply to the Russian note had been the first of the answers of the three Powers dispatched to St. Petersubrgh; those of Austria and England were only forwarded on the 11th inst. Each Cabinet has replied specially on the arguments addressed particularly to itself, but the three notes terminate with an identical paragraph once more testifying the unity of the views of the three Powers.

abstract: There is now lying at the shipbuilding yard of the Cork Steamship Company, a curious looking craft. She is named the Alliance, and was originally designed for a pleasure steamer to ply on the Mersey, between Liverpool and a place called Eastham. When plying on the Mersey she had a division along the centre from stem to stern, as completely as if her two parts were two separate ships lying side by side. In this space she had a single paddle-wheel, by which alone she was propelled, and this had so much power, added to the lightness of her build, that she had a speed of 20 knots an hour. She had been purchased by a Liverpool firm for the purpose of running the blockade of the Southern ports of America, and to fit her out for this purpose considerable alterations have been made, both in her structure and machinery. The paddle-wheel which was in the centre has been removed; in the space occupied by it a hold has been made, thus filling up the division, and she has been furnished with a pair of paddles, making her appear like the ordinary paddle steamers. She has three funnels placed in the line across between the paddle-boxes. With the view of resisting the rough salutations which are generally dealt out to blockade-runners by the Yankee squadrons, she has been fitted with an outer shell, or coat of timber below the waterline. The space between this and the vessel herself can be filled with cotton which, it is considered, will effectually resist the Yankee missiles. To obviate the danger of ignition, this space can be filled with water immediately without in the least disturbing the crew or injuring the cargo. The upper portion of the vessel is unprotected; but although this may endanger the lives of the crew and admit of injury to the interior of the vessel, yet there can be very little danger of her going down. The Alliance was on her way to Nassau, but had to put in here on Thursday evening to get some repairs to her machinery.
lead_paragraph: There is now lying at the shipbuilding yard of the Cork Steamship Company, a curious looking craft. She had been purchased by a Liverpool firm for the purpose of running the blockade of the Southern ports of America, and to fit her out for this purpose considerable alterations have been made, both in her structure and machinery. The paddle-wheel which was in the centre has been removed; in the space occupied by it a hold has been made, thus filling up the division, and she has been furnished with a pair of paddles, making her appear like the ordinary paddle steamers. With the view of resisting the rough salutations which are generally dealt out to blockade-runners by the Yankee squadrons, she has been fitted with an outer shell, or coat of timber below the waterline. abstract: BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second night of Mr. BONIFACE's brief season at the Brooklyn Academy crew forth the largest audience we have ever seen at a dramatic performance in the City of Churches. The farce which precedes the fearful drama was capitally given, and literally "screamed the house." The "Ghost" was all the fancy of the audience had painted it, and exacted the usual tribute of shiverings, tears and screams from the gaping throngs. To-morrow night the bill will be repeated for the last time.

abstract: -- The Toronto Leader is anxious to gain notoriety by its discovery of a fearful conspiracy in Canada. The Provincial conspirators have actually invited the “Federal Government to invade the Province, overthrow British supremacy, and bring it under subjection to the LINCOLN dynasty.” Our Government at once, of course, accepted this inviting invitation, and has already concentrated forty thousand troops in this City to carry out the programme. What will the Canucks do? Elect Tories to Parliament, of course. How will the Bluenoes feel? Bluer than ever. Alas! poor habitans! As the Leader says, they would be “justly incensed at this attempt to place on their necks a yoke of despotism more intolerable than that of Turkey or Russia.” The best advice under the circumstances that we can give to the Provincial Tories is to enter into an alliance, offensive and defensive, with the Southern Confederacy, and put themselves “under subjection to the JEFF. DAVIS dynasty,” which they so furiously admire. They will find that a mild, cheerful, and altogether beatific form of Government; and if JEFF. DAVIS should drive them all like negroes to the field to be slaughtered, why, even that might be better than to spend a long life in Canada.
lead_paragraph: -- The Toronto Leader is anxious to gain notoriety by its discovery of a fearful conspiracy in Canada. abstract: The military events which have occurred since last May are a curious commentary upon the proceedings of the peace meetings, and above all of the peace "Convention," which was held in that month in this City,...
lead_paragraph: The military events which have occurred since last May are a curious commentary upon the proceedings of the peace meetings, and above all of the peace "Convention," which was held in that month in this City, and which in its address to its constituents informed them that amongst many weighty reasons for putting an end to this cruel war was the very weighty one that we were beaten, and that there was no use in denying it. People had hardly ceased talking about the Convention, however, and its leading spirit, had hardly returned from his mission to Washington to induce Mr. LINCOLN, if he wished to save the nation, to place himself and it under the able guidance of the New-York Copperheads, when the tide began to turn; and we have in the ninety days which have since elapsed had the most extraordinary series of successes, and the South the most extraordinary series of disasters, according to the London Times, to be found in military history.

abstract: The hearing of claims for exemption is now progressing before the Board of Enrollment of the Sixth District, consisting of Capt. FARR, Provost Marshal; CHAS. A. LAMONT, Esq., Commissioner, and Dr. POWELL, Surgeon. Claimants crowd the Headquarters in Sixth-avenue, anxiously awaiting their...
lead_paragraph: The hearing of claims for exemption is now progressing before the Board of Enrollment of the Sixth District, consisting of Capt. FARR, Provost-Marshal; CHAS. A. LAMONT, Esq., Commissioner, and Dr. POWELL, Surgeon. Claimants crowd the Headquarters in Sixth-avenue, anxiously awaiting their turns to be heard, most with substantial excuses, many with such as will not be accepted. A large number of aliens appear to have been drawn and, of course, they are not subject to the draft. Very many over the specified age, very many because of physical disability, have also been exempted, and nearly all the excuses provided for by the act have been represented. Quite a number of claims have been rejected. Two days grace is given those ordered into the ranks to prepare for, or with the money evade it.

abstract: The London Saturday Review is vexed and fretful over the discovery that England stands almost friendless in the world, and indeed is held in detestation or contempt by all other great nations. Not only is there a “furious hatred” of her in the United States, but the French indulge in “habitual declamations against English perfidy and selfishness,” the Russians are “bitterly offended at the interference of England,” the Poles are even now “unable to express their hatred for England,” the Prussians “regard English policy with suspicion and dislike,” the “former hatred of the Austrian Government to England is perhaps recently relaxed, but the antagonism may at any moment revive,” the Italian sentiment is very dubious; and the only two Powers of the globe that are suspected of entertaining friendship for England are -- not Japan or Brazil, for both these Powers are at sword’s points with her at this moment -- but, Greece and Turkey! How England has secured the friendship of two contiguous peoples which so cordially detest each other, it is not easy to say, and the saying is not true, for the hatred of an average Turk to an Englishman is only less than that of an Ionian Islander to his British masters. So after scouring the whole world to find a respectable friend of England, the Saturday Review gives up the search in despair.
lead_paragraph: The London Saturday Review is vexed and fretful over the discovery that England stands almost friendless in the world, and indeed is held in detestation or contempt by all other great nations. Not only is there a furious hatred of her in the United States, but the French indulge in habitual declamations against English perfidy and selfishness, the Russians are bitterly offended at the interference of England, the Poles are even now unable to express their hatred for England, the Prussians regard English policy with suspicion and dislike, the former hatred of the Austrian Government to England is perhaps recently relaxed, but the antagonism may at any moment revive, the Italian sentiment is very dubious; and the only two Powers of the globe that are suspected of entertaining friendship for England are -- not Japan or Brazil, for both these Powers are at swords points with her at this moment -- but, Greece and Turkey! How England has secured the friendship of two contiguous peoples which so cordially detest each other, it is not easy to say, and the saying is not true, for the hatred of an average Turk to an Englishman is only less than that of an Ionian Islander to his British masters. So after scouring the whole world to find a respectable friend of England, the Saturday Review gives up the search in despair.

abstract: The drawing of names for the United States service recommenced in the Fifth District yesterday morning. At 9 o’clock, the hour previously fixed for the opening of the Draft, there was much less interest and excitement manifested than on the preceding day, and the throng in and around No. 413 Broome-street was thinner. The same force of police and military that had guarded the premises under the charge of Inspector LEONARD, of the Metropolitans, Capts. JORDAN and BRYANT, of the United States Infantry, were on duty, and will continue at their post during the draft in the Fifth District. Their arrangements for the preservation of order were admirable, and quiet and good humor seemed general.
lead_paragraph: The drawing of names for the United States service recommenced in the Fifth District yesterday morning. abstract: Rebel Chances of Hopeless
lead_paragraph: It is fast becoming an accepted fact that there is no possible chance for the so-called "Confederacy" but in foreign succor, secured at any price. The crushing force of the National Government has now proceeded so far that it is senseless to doubt what the end must be, unless something outside is interposed. The rebel Government cannot help feeling that its power of resistance and endurance is fast giving way, and that its last extremity is approaching. One of the papers in their Capital, the Richmond Whig, has just said, We want the aid of France. We are able to pay for it. Let us do it. But we need no such outgivings to substantiate that this last alternative is now daily and nightly occupying the thoughts of the rebel leaders. The same supreme selfishness which impelled them to precipitate this rebellion against the will of the Southern people, must also impel them to save themselves if possible, at whatever cost to that people. If once taken by the National Government, they may be tried for treason and lose their lives, or be sent into perpetual exile. At all events, the overthrow of their rule would cast them forever into the dust, politically and socially. The Southern people would turn upon them with fiercest hate for all of their false promises and high-handed tyranny, while the people of the North, with all their magnanimity, never could and never would have any other feeling toward them than detestation and contempt. They would be the pariahs of the land. To save themselves from this fate, there is nothing these men would hesitate to do. And the aid of France being the only possible resource left, we may count it certain that they will do their best to obtain it at any sacrifice.

abstract: -- We see by an advertisement that the Board of Supervisors are examining claims for all sums less than $500, at the rate of twenty per day. As there are said, on good authority, to be nearly 2,000 poor white claimants and over 1,000 colored sufferers, making 3,000 altogether, it follows that the Board will be six months before they will be through with claims of this class.

abstract: The arrrival of the steamer Arago at this port puts us in possession of our dispatches and correspondence from Charleston to the 25th inst. Fort Sumter had not yet formally surrendered, but it was a heap of ruins and of no further use to the enemy.
lead_paragraph: The arrrival of the steamer Arago at this port puts us in possession of our dispatches and correspondence from Charleston to the 25th inst. Fort Sumter had not yet formally surrendered, but it was a heap of ruins and of no further use to the enemy. It was expected that on the 24th a combined land and naval effort to drive the rebels off Morris Island would be made, but it does not appear that the programme was carried out. The report of the shelling of Charleston is fully confirmed. On Friday night Gen. GILLMORE threw fifteen shell charged with Greek fire into the city. This called out a protest, under flag of trace, from BEAUREGARD, and also one from the foreign Consuls, asking for more time than had been given to remove the non-combatants. On Sunday Gen. GILLMORE renewed his demand for a surrender of the forts and public property. BEAUREGARD asked for a truce of forty hours, but Gen. GILLMORE refused to give any time or to accept any terms but unconditional surrender, and at 12 oclock on Sunday night the shelling with Greek fire was renewed. Its effects we shall probahly learn from the rebels.

abstract: A dispatch received from Fortress Monroe yesterday, announced the reception of news there that Forts Sumter and Wagner were occupied by our forces on Monday last, the 24th.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch received from Fortress Monroe yesterday, announced the reception of news there that Forts Sumter and Wagner were occupied by our forces on Monday last, the 24th. To show that the news is unreliable, it is only necessary to refer to the fact that the Arago, whose advices we published yesterday, did not leave Charleston bar until the 25th -- the day after its alleged occupation -- at which time the rebels still had possession. We also have this morning an official dispatch from Gen. GILLMORE, dated the 24th, announcing the practical demolition of Sumter, and the establishment of batteries on his left, with which he had succeeded in reaching the heart of Charleston and throwing missiles which BEAUREGARD had designated the most destructive ever used in war. Gen. GILLMORE's dispatch it accompanied by the report of his Chief of Artillery, Col. TURNER.

abstract: As a Candidate for Governor of Ohio
snippet: As a Candidate for Governor of Ohio
lead_paragraph: The canvass for VALLANDIGHAM in Ohio drags pitifully. The mass of the people stubbornly refuse to give "the martyr" any sympathy. All of the efforts of the party leaders to kindle passion against, "the persecutors" utterly fail. The flashiest clap-trap about the eternal sanctity of free speech vanishes with the flash, and that is the end of it. All the red-hot indignation against the "worst despotism of the age," is received with the most absolute coolness. Nothing answers. The people of Ohio are as firm as flint in their purpose not to make VALLANDIGHAM their Governor; and even his most ardent champions are giving up all hope.

abstract: The conclusion of the Hibernia's news, shut off from us yesterday morning by an interruption of the telegraph is given to-day. The London Times, referring to French operations in Mexico, thinks the French Emperor has done a great service to the world in extinguishing the Monroe doctrine, and in restoring commercial intercourse with a nation of such importance of territory. A British war vessel from Rio Janeiro reports having passed the wreck of a ship just destroyed by the Alabama, an the 2d of July. There had been to change in the Polish question.

abstract: The; The People and The Laws
snippet: The; The People and The Laws
lead_paragraph: When Mr. LINCOLN announced that he would enforce the draft without waiting to have the constitutionality of the act tested in the Courts, the Copperheads of this City lifted up their hands in holy horror, and their organ broadly hinted that the supreme moment was at hand, and that Democrats would probably have to count up their strength and -- see what they had better do within a few days. By the time Gen. DIX issued his proclamation, however, they had apparently passed through the agonies of deliberation and reached the high and holy resolve of doing nothing whatever. But the organ nevertheless "improved the occasion" by severely reprimanding Major-Gen. DIX for having ventured, in his address to his fellow-citizens, to express his solemn conviction of the justice and expediency of the law which he had undertaken to carry out, if need were, at the point of the bayonet. He ought, it appears, to have preached obedience to the law, but not to have hurt the feelings of "the people" of Mackerelville, by saying that he thought it a good law. After a man has solemnly testified his disapproval of it as FLYNN, who is now in jail awaiting his trial, has done, by publicly dashing out a negro's brains and crushing in his ribs with a big stone, it certainly does seem a little indelicate to tell him to his face that the enrollment act is worthy of obedience on higher grounds than mere constitutional ones. But then Gen. DIX is a soldier, and we think he ought to be excused if, coming fresh from the camp, his language displayed a little of a soldier's bluntness. Gentlemen like the July rioters, who have themselves, in the exercise of their calling, frequently to express their feelings in homely and energetic phrases, and without much attention to the possible shocks which they may inflict on the nerves of their hearers, will not be so ready to condemn Gen. DIX on this point as their newspapers are.

abstract: PREPARATIONS FOR THE DRAFT IN BROOKLYN -- ARRIVAL OF UNITED STATES TROOPS. -- The arrangements for commencing the draft in tills city on Monday morning are completed. The Provost-Marshal of the Second District expects to complete the drawing in three days, and the Provost-Marshal of the Third District intends to finish two Wards each day, and more if possible. It is probable that the entire week will be consumed before the drawing is completed. A number of regiments arrived in the city, last evening, from New-York, and encamped in different localities. The Eighth Ohio and First Indiana pitched their tents on Fort Greene Park. The Fourteenth Indiana and Seventh Michigan encamped on the parade-ground at East New-York. The One Hundred and Tenth Ohio and another regiment is encamped on the Base Ball Ground bounded by Union, Sacket[???], Smith and Hoyt streets. The Fourth Ohio proceeded to Jamaica. Several of the militia regiments were ordered to Jamaica, but the orders were subsequently countermanded. The officers of the Forty-ninth Police Precinct raised their flag, and fired a national salute with a ten-pounder in their possession, in honor of the veterans who passed their Station-house on the march to East New-York.

abstract: York City was concluded yesterday. It took just seven days for its enforcement. As everybody knows, and as everybody is rejoiced to know, everything has passed off quietly. Neither the rioters, nor their leaders, nor their newspaper organs, are to be thanked for this, but only the National and State authorities and our gallant soldiers. We are pleased, however, to be able to say that the presence of the troops here seemed to have an excellent tonic effect upon the rioters' newspapers and the rioters' leaders. They have been much less furious and revolutionary, much less inflammatory and bloodthirsty in August than the were in July -- though this has been the hotter month by the thermometer. If the presence of twenty or thirty thousand troops here has such an excellent effect in improving the manners, morals, logic and republicanism of the Express, World and Daily News, we think it would be economical and wholesome to station them here permanently.

abstract: Lieut.-Col. LOCKWOOD, commanding the Seventh Virginia Union regiment, reports a series of robberies of the mails of the Third division Second army corps, running from the 8th to the 25th of August. Several thousands of dollars in Government and private drafts, checks and funds have been purloined, and the letters covering them found along the route. The mail carriers are under arrest.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Board of Supervisors held a special meeting, and passed, with but one vote, Mr. ELY's, in the negative, an ordinance appropriating two millions of dollars for the exemption of the military of this City, active firemen, and exempt firemen ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Board of Supervisors held a special meeting, and passed, with but one vote, Mr. ELY's, in the negative, an ordinance appropriating two millions of dollars for the exemption of the military of this City, active firemen, and exempt firemen doing active duty, and the police resident of and doing service in this City. It also provides for exempting in certain cases of indigence, where the drafted has a family depending on him for support, and also for peculiar cases of hardships in the draft lot.

abstract: American Relations with
lead_paragraph: Our Government ought at once to make preparations for a war with France. It would be foolish to say that such a war is certain to come; -- but it would be dangerous as well as foolish to act as if it were impossible. All precaution, especially in national affairs, rests upon the apprehension, the suspicion of coming danger. If we were always to wait until the peril is upon us before making any preparation to meet it, we should always be too late. Absolute certainty in regard to the hostile movements and intentions of foreign Powers, it is impossible to attain. We must act upon indications and tendencies, and the conjectures which they warrant. The seaman guides his vessel by the barometer, though he never expects to find it an infallible prophet of the coming storm.

lead_paragraph: Rebel news from Charleston to the 28th inst. has been received by way of Richmond and Fortress Monroe. A dispatch dated the 27th, announces an "overwhelming" attack on the rebel riflepits on Wednesday evening about 7 o'clock. No explanation is given as to the location of the rifle-pits, or the actual results of the attack, but from the fact that the latter is denominated "overwhelming," we judge it to have been successful. A dispatch dated the 28th, announces that the bombardment of Sumter and Wagner proceeded sluggishly, and that our forces were working hard in the trenches in front of Wagner. No further attempt had been made to shell the city.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ENGLISH LORD.--On the arrival of the British steamer Corsica at Jersey City, Friday, a complaint was preferred by I.D. HARRIS against FREDERICK AINSLIE, charging him with having stolen...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ENGLISH LORD. -- On the arrival of the British steamer Corsica at Jersey City, Friday, a complaint was preferred by I.D. HARRIS against FREDERICK AINSLIE, charging him with having stolen during the passage, a draft on the Bank of England, amounting to 300. The accused, who is reported to be a Lord, denied the charge, and appeared to be very much surprised when taken into custody; but upon examining his trunk the draft was discovered at the bottom among a number of other papers. The proof being conclusive against the Lord, he sent for his friend HARRIS, and after asking forgiveness and promising to make the matter satisfactory, the parties appeared before Recorder MARTINDALE, and the complaint was withdrawn. They both occupied the same stateroom on the passage to this port, and appeared to be on the most intimate terms until HARRIS discovered his loss, when he ordered the accused to procure another berth. It is furthermore alleged that no less than twenty-five persons came in this steamer from Havana, who, for the past eighteen months have been engaged in the blockading business, and having made considerable money, are now on their way to England.
