lead_paragraph: The Enrollmentt Board of the Sixth District, continued their session on Friday for hearing claims of exemption from drafted men. The Board sits from 9 A.M. to 12 M., and from 2 to 4 P.M. Yesterday was the fourth day of the session, and the number of persons who thronged the office to present their various claims for exemption was larger than on either of the previous days. The claims for exemption on account of alienage are very numerous, and the probabilities of fraud in these cases are so great that the Board have decided to postpone giving certificates until each case can be inquired into, and the proof of alienage clearly established. Thus far only one certificate of exemption on this ground has been granted. The applicant for exemption on account of alienage is obliged to swear that he is a subject of a foreign Government, that he has never declared his intention to become a citizen of the United States, and that he has never exercised the right of suffrage in this country. It is the opinion of Commissioner LAMONT and Surgeon POWELL, a majority of the Enrolling Board, that an examination of the records of naturalization and of the poll-lists would disprove the affidavits of many who have applied for exemption on the above grounds, and they insist that these should be examined. Provost-Marshall FARR, it is understood, does not agree in this view. In the case of the alien to whom a certificate of exemption was given, it was noticed that within an hour thereafter four other applicants made their appearance with papers prepared by the same person who made out the first papers. On Thursday a man presented his affidavits of alienage properly vouched and sworn to, and was told, as all of them are, to call again on a certain day for his certificate. Thinking his case was all right, he went outside the office, where he met another alien friend, to whom he boasted that he had voted often in this City, but said that made no difference, and offered to procure the exemption of his friend for $2. The name of this foreigner is withheld for the present, but when he applies for his certificate of exemption, his case will be attended to.

abstract: Stevenson, Alabama, which Gen. ROSECRANS holds as the base of operations against Chattanooga, was founded by Col. V.K. STEVENSON, President of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, who laid out this depot in 1852.
lead_paragraph: Stevenson, Alabama, which Gen. ROSECRANS holds as the base of operations against Chattanooga, was founded by Col. V.K. STEVENSON, President of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, who laid out this depot in 1852. Five miles distant is Coon Island, the site of Coon Town, an ancient Cherokee rendezvous. Stevenson is located at the base of a spur of Cumberland mountains, two and a half miles from Tennessee river, and contains three hundred of a population. The surrounding country is a clay soil, rather broken; climate tolerably healthy, and the principal agricultural products are cotton, some-grain, horses, cattle, mules, and smaller stock. There is one steam circular saw and grist mill, four dry goods houses, one drug store, and two hotels. Stevenson is the intersecting point of the Memphis and Charleston and the Nashville and Chattanooga railroads. Among the natural curiosities in the vicinity is "Nickajack Cave," at which a bloody encounter is said to have occurred between the whites and Cherokees. It has been explored for several miles, and abounds in matters interesting to visitors.

abstract: The smack Pacific, Capt. APPLEMAN, from Bermuda in five days, to P.T. BARNUM, arrived yesterday. She passed, going in to Bermuda, the Confederate steamer Gladiator, from Wilmington, N.C. The Confederate steamer Robert Lee, from Wilmington, N.C., arrived Aug. 23.
lead_paragraph: The smack Pacific, Capt. APPLEMAN, from Bermuda in five days, to P.T. BARNUM, arrived yesterday. She passed, going in to Bermuda, the Confederate steamer Gladiator, from Wilmington, N.C. The Confederate steamer Robert Lee, from Wilmington, N.C., arrived Aug. 23. She had been chased for nine hours by a United States gunboat; had thrown overboard 300 bales of cotton to escape. Aug. 26, lat. 35, long. 67, passed a steamer steering cast, having a ship in tow; supposed her to be the privateer Florida, with a prize ship in tow. The cook of the smack had been on board of the Florida for fifteen days, and is certain she was the Florida, as she passed close to the smack. The Pacific brings a number of rare fish for BARNUM's Aquarium.

abstract: some English speculators are much exercised in spirit, and sorely moved in their bowels of compassion, on account of what they very complacently, and no less absurdly, call our "fearful" war debt. They profess to feel quite sure that taxation here has reached its extreme limit. Like the man in the fable, they carry two wallets; the one containing their own faults and sins they carry behind their backs, -- that which contains those of their neighbors they have constantly beneath their censorious eyes. Considering that the English National debt amounts to upward of eight hundred millions sterling, or four thousand millions of dollars, their anxiety seems to less philanthropically nervous people to partake more than a little of both the premature and the superfluous. However, as there are not a few uninformed persons among us who take a similarly fearful view as to a debt which, as compared with our resources, developed and undeveloped, is really quite insignificant, it may be well to direct the attention of Secretary CHASE to a splendid source of income which is as yet comparatively untouched, and which may, with great moral justice, as well as with advantage to the National income, be used with respect to the great venders of luxuries, instead of being confined, as at present, to the smaller and poorer ones. The war has already given, and must necessarily continue to give, enormous fortunes to people who till recently were poor enough. Such suddenly enriched folks alway outvie in luxury, as vulgar as it is costly, those who have never known poverty. A very heavy license duty on the venders of such luxuries would produce a heavy revenue, could not interfere a jot with production, or the wages of labor, and would not even interfere one tittle with the profuse outlay of our mushroom nabobs. Women who consider the most brilliant diamonds that even Broadway exhibits, not expensive or flashy enough for them, and who readily pay their $500 each for gaudy sham cachemires, would be none the less customers to jewelers and drygoods importers, if those venders, paying license tax varying from five to ten thousand dollars per annum, were to reimburse themselves by laying ten per cent. extra upon their goods -- thus pocketing a hundred per cent. upon their cost of license. The peddler who carries his heavy pack of huckaback and cheap calicoes, is specially taxed for permission to carry on his trade; why should not, why would not, the same rule apply to those who clear their hundreds by the sale of a couple of shawls or a set of diamonds?

abstract: found with the library of JEFF. DAVIS are becoming widely distributed. We have seen two of them which were sent to Bridgewater, Mass., by an officer in the Massachusetts Twenty-ninth. They simply contain invitations to speak, dated in 1852, and are only interesting in showing that JEFF. DAVIS was in the habit of preserving his letters, even though not important. The stupidity of the officer who made the seizure in allowing these letters to be scattered deserves the severest condemnation. With the letters came a pamphlet embracing "Facts and Incidents" connected with the surrender of Fort Donelson, which appear to be a defence of Gen. PILLOW. It was taken from the desk of JEFF. DAVIS. -- Boston J[???].

abstract: Delacroix, a celebrated French Painter
lead_paragraph: The death of this distinguished French artist is announced, after an illness of several months, at the age of 66. His father was Minister of Foreign Affairs under the Directory. At 18 young Delacroix entered the studio of Guerin; who had already as pupils Gericault and Ary Scheffer. In 1822 he exhibited his first picture, the subject being "Dante and Virgil," and since then down to 1859, scarcely a year passed without some fine work of his pencil being offered to the public. Among them are best known "The Death of Marino Fallero;" "Milton dictating his Paradise Lost;" "Charles the Vth at the Monastery of St. Just;" "Hamlet and Horatio contemplating the skull of Yorick;" "The Doge Foscaro presiding at the condemnation of his Son:" "Our Saviour at the Tombs;" "Ovid in Exile;" "Rebecca carried off," &c. M. Delacroix also executed decorative paintings in one of the rooms of the Chamber of Deputies, in one of the Chamber of Peers and the cerlings of the Galcrie-d'Apollon at the Louvre, Salle du Trone and Library, Paris. The deceased was Commander of the Legion of Honor and Member of the Institute.

abstract: -- Since last December a Court-martial has held daily sessions at the Navy-yard, in the room adjoining the one occupied by the Commander of the Yard. The members composing the Court are appointed by the Secretary of the Navy, and are relieved from time to time. Seven, nine, or thirteen members compose a full Court, which usually convenes at noon and closes at three o'clock in the afternoon. The sittings are open, and the jurisdiction of the Court-martial extends over all cases of complaint preferred against any officer or seaman in the navy who may be brought to this port. While in existence, the present Court has tried several important cases. The most prominent one was the case of the sailors who deserted the gunboat Mercedita, during her engagement with the rebel iron-clads off Charleston harbor. While the conflict was raging, and the vessel was wrapped in a cloud of smoke, thirteen men took one of the boats and escaped in the confusion. Their names and ratings were as follows:

abstract: What Napoleon wants in Mexico
lead_paragraph: ready been announced that among the reforms inaugurated by the Cavalry Bureau, the system of buying horses without contract is prominent; in other words, no more especial contracts will be made, but every person having twenty-five or more horses to offer, can take them to a designated spot, where they will be examined, and if found good, bought. This is an important point reached, as by the contract system the treasury has already been swindled out of hundreds of thousands of dollars for horseflesh, the refuse of the whole country -- nags that could not have been thrust on any farmer for drudge work. Instances have been known in mounting our Western cavalry, where the entire horses of the regiment have been condemned and sent away, and when the new mount came, they were actually worse than those just condemned. A case of this kind occurred with the Ninth Kentucky cavalry, where they were forced by circumstances to accept these hacks, and with scarce time to fit saddles, they rode into action. Horses have been taken fresh from the plow, or the cart, sometimes even unshodden, and sent instantly upon forced marches, or into battle. Is it to be wondered at that, in many instances, our cavalry has not met with the success that should attend well-mounted men and well-trained horses? The Press has continually been disposed to exalt the rebel cavalry; but this praise is only deserved by comparison, and the comparison is instituted against an arm of the service which up to this time has struggled against enormous odds.

abstract: The Rensselaer Club of Troy, N.Y., has sent down a delegation of their members to play a series of matches during the week against the St. George's Club and New-York Club of New-York, and the Newark and Union Clubs of Newark, N. J.
lead_paragraph: The Rensselaer Club of Troy, N.Y., has sent down a delegation of their members to play a series of matches during the week against the St. George's Club and New-York Club of New-York, and the Newark and Union Clubs of Newark, N.J. The first match took place on Wednesday, between the Trojans and a second eleven selected by the New-York Club, who were beaten by the Trojans, with seven wickets to spare, after some remarkably good cricket on the part of the victors. The bowling of CORPSE (slow) and CROW (fast) both of them underhand, was very effective; and the wicket keeping and generalship of WYNN, the Captain, and long-stopping of JACKSON was excellent. The New-York Eleven consisted of members of the New-York, Queens County, Willow, Manhattan, and East New-York Clubs; whilst the Troy Eleven belonged to the Rensselaer Club alone, and therefore the greater eclat and merit attends their victory.

abstract: -- Five persons were executed in the presence of nearly the whole Army of the Potomac on Saturday last for desertion. They were men who had offered themselves as substitutes for conscripts, had taken the price for services to be rendered, had then swindled the conscripts and the Government by desertion, and were caught only to meet their fate. It is a terrible warning to this class of scoundrels, but it is probably not the last they will need and receive. Since the enforcement of the conscription was begun, the crime has been very common, and it has been committed under circumstances of such audacity and such traitorous confederation of action, that it is evident only the relentless enforcement of military law will put a stop to it. Some of those "bounty jumpers," as they are called, have become substitutes for conscripts, and received their money half-a dozen times, and have deserted as often -- accumulating in this way quite a little fortune for themselves. This example will show them the peril of their course, and the worthlessness of their accumulations. There can be no sympathy for them in the country, as there is none in the army. They have earned the highest penalty of military law, and their only service to the State is as a warning to others.
lead_paragraph: -- Five persons were executed in the presence of nearly the whole Army of the Potomac on Saturday last for desertion. They were men who had offered themselves as substitutes for conscripts, had taken the price for services to be rendered, had then swindled the conscripts and the Government by desertion, and were caught only to meet their fate. It is a terrible warning to this class of scoundrels, but it is probably not the last they will need and receive. Since the enforcement of the conscription was begun, the crime has been very common, and it has been committed under circumstances of such audacity and such traitorous confederation of action, that it is evident only the relentless enforcement of military law will put a stop to it. Some of those "bounty jumpers," as they are called, have become substitutes for conscripts, and received their money half-a dozen times, and have deserted as often -- accumulating in this way quite a little fortune for themselves. This example will show them the peril of their course, and the worthlessness of their accumulations. There can be no sympathy for them in the country, as there is none in the army. They have earned the highest penalty of military law, and their only service to the State is as a warning to others.

abstract: On Sunday morning, about 2 o'clock, an attack was made upon a house in Steward's Alley, occupied by colored people, by several persons connected with Engine No. 1-among them the ex-foreman of the company. It seems that some of the members had a ...
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, about 2 o'clock, an attack was made upon a house in Steward's Alley, occupied by colored people, by several persons connected with Engine No. 1-among them the ex-foreman of the company. It seems that some of the members had a grudge against a Spanish negro named RICH, and decided to bombard his premises. They assaulted the house with stones, and an unfortunate colored man named DANIEL JOHNSON, coming to the door to see what the matter was, was struck in the head and had his skull fractured. His injuries are of such a character that it is doubtful whether he can survive. The injured man was taken to the City Hospital, where he lies in a precarious condition. Coroner NORRIS being notified held an ante-mortem examination, and elicited the testimony annexed, upon which he ordered the arrest of PATRICK LAHEY, OLIVER LOCKWOOD and MICHAEL MCWILLIAMS:

abstract: The United States and the French invasion
snippet: The United States and the French invasion
lead_paragraph: When the French Emperor's memorable letter to Gen. FOREY in Mexico was published, six months ago, the London Times declared that " it might rouse to anger a less excitable people than that of the United states," and that "the Federals will probably show their resentment at the Emperor's proposal to limit their power." Like most of the prophecies from the same source, this has not been verified. "The Federals" received that letter with entire composure. What is yet more, they have maintained that composure ever since, notwithstanding the fact that the only mitigating assurances in the letter have since been violated and turned into a mockery -- particularly the assurance that "the Provisional Government will submit to the Mexican people the question of the political regime which is to be definitively established." The American people have seen, in the face of that assurance, the Mexican Republic transformed into an Empire, an Austrian Archduke designated for the sceptre, without any submission of the question to "the Mexican people;" and yet they remain as calm as ever. Word comes by the last steamer that the Austrian magnate accepts the throne. This may be, or may not be; it is all the same; the pulse of this people beats evenly on.

There are conclusive reasons, extrinsic and intrinsic, for disbelieving it.

abstract: Stevenson, Alabama, which Gen. ROSECRANS holds as the base of operations against Chattanooga, was founded by Col. V.K. STEVENSON, President of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, who laid out this depot in 1852. Five miles distant is Coon Island, the site of Coon Town, an ancient Cherokee rendezvous.
lead_paragraph: Stevenson, Alabama, which Gen. ROSECRANS holds as the base of operations against Chattanooga, was founded by Col. V.K. STEVENSON, President of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, who laid out this depot in 1852. Five miles distant is Coon Island, the site of Coon Town, an ancient Cherokee rendezvous. Stevenson is located at the base of a spur of Cumberland mountains, two and a half miles from Tennessee river, and contains three hundred of a population. The surrounding country is a clay soil, rather broken; climate tolerably healthy, and the principal agricultural products are cotton, some-grain, horses, cattle, mules, and smaller stock. There is one steam circular saw and grist mill, four dry goods houses, one drug store, and two hotels. Stevenson is the intersecting point of the Memphis and Charleston and the Nashville and Chattanooga railroads. Among the natural curiosities in the vicinity is "Nickajack Cave," at which a bloody encounter is said to have occurred between the whites and Cherokees. It has been explored for several miles, and abounds in matters interesting to visitors.

abstract: Campaign, Progress of
lead_paragraph: The dispatches which have been reaching us with regard to the advance of the Army of the Cumberland, have been of a nature to cause public anticipation to outrun the actuality of operations, and even the possibility of operations. The bombardment of Chattanooga, of which we had intelligence a week ago, turns out to have been no more than a few shell thrown across the river by Col. WILDER, whose light-moving column of mounted infantry and battery of horse-artillery had made a flying visit to the neighborhood of Chattanooga. But the movements of the adventurous leader of the flying brigade, who has no heed for supplies, roads, trains or communications, are no criterion for the movements of the main body of the army which is strictly dependent on these conditions. Gen. ROSECRANS is now operating in a region of country the difficulties of which are almost inconceivable. The front of operations which he gained in his last advance, when he turned the rebel position at Tullahoma, and compelled BRAGG's retreat to Chattanooga, brought him just to the base of the mountains. Thence to Chattanooga, eighty or a hundred miles, is through an Alpine region, which presents every imaginable obstacle to military operations or military movements, where there are few or no roads, while such as there are are scarcely passable. To those who glibly talk of "throwing" troops here, or "throwing" troops there, a fortnight or three weeks will doubtless seem an unpardonably long period to occupy in a journey of three or four score miles; but should they go to ROSECRANS' field of operations and find that roads had to be made before they could "throw" even themselves, they would probably acquire and beget a little of that "temperance" that would give them "patience." It is in this arduous but indispensable work that Gen. ROSECRANS has been engaged for the past fifteen or twenty days. Details of whole divisions have been out road-making, hauling trains, &c.; and the result is that he has at length succeeded in transferring his whole army across the Tennessee River.

abstract: The British Quarterlies for the present term (republished in New-York by LEONARD, SCOTT  Co.) are out, with their usual assortment of solid and instructive matter. The Westminster leads off with a characteristic article on "The Growth of Christianity," from the rationalistic standpoint ...
lead_paragraph: The British Quarterlies for the present term (republished in New-York by LEONARD, SCOTT & CO.) are out, with their usual assortment of solid and instructive matter. The Westminster leads off with a characteristic article on "The Growth of Christianity," from the rationalistic standpoint, its avowed object being less to discover the "essence" of Christianity than to show how what is usually called Christianity, whether dogma or sentiment, grew up, to indicate the natural preparation for its reception, the causes that favored its extension, and its historical antecedents and accompaniments. Mr. JOHN STUART MILL's latest lucubration, the tractate on "Utilitarianism," (which the Boston republishers of the same author's "Liberty" would do well to bring out,) forms the theme of the next article of mark. "Marriages of Consanguinity" treats of this interesting yet obscure question of physiology in opposition to the current opinion that marriages of blood relations produce degeneracy or deterioration in the offspring. It contains some special points that are well taken, but his foundation of fact is quite too narrow for the superstructure of theory built upon it. "Saint Simon and his Disciples" is an extremely interesting view of this remarkable French philosopher, theosophist and socialist, and his equally remarkable school. Papers on "Gamesters and Gaming-houses," "The Rival Races," (review of EUGENE SUE's romance,) "The Naturalist on the River Amazon," "M. Louis Blanc's History of the French Revolution," "Poland," "Lancashire "and the carefully done review of Cotemporary Literature complete the number.

abstract: SUNDAY AMONG THE SOLDIERS. -- Religious services were held among the regiments in the parks yesterday by the Army Committee of the New-York Young Men's Christian Association. In Washington Parade Ground and Madison Park the Vermont regiments were marched out by companies to shady spots on the grounds, and the day being a fine one, and most of our churches being closed, citizens also attended. The meetings at Washington Parade Ground and at the Soldier's Rest, in Howard-street, were conducted by VINCENT COLVER, Esq., and at Madison Park by Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, Jr. HORACE WINANS, Esq., led the singing.

abstract: Although it is currently believed that the City was never so empty of New-Yorkers as at the present time, the deficiency has been so amply made up by the influx of strangers that the various places of amusement have done, and are still doing, a large and profitable business.
lead_paragraph: Although it is currently believed that the City was never so empty of New-Yorkers as at the present time, the deficiency has been so amply made up by the influx of strangers that the various places of amusement have done, and are still doing, a large and profitable business. There has not been much in the way of novelty to notice, but the country people do not object to a well-tried and well-kept play. If it has been talked about for a season or two so much the better. It takes, indeed, several months for the ever-widening circles of fame to reach the outside leiges of the Union. The sensation play of the "Duke's Motto" has, during the entire Summer, enjoyed the advantages of its wide-spread reputation. Every one has felt the necessity of seeing it, and so Mr. WHEATLEY has reaped his reward. And the reward should be a large one, for the physical and mental powers are sorely taxed in such a character as that which was for so many months impersonated by Mr. WHEATLEY in this piece. We doubt if there is another part on the stage so wearing as Capt. Lagardere. In the mere matter of lines it is of inordinate length, demanding great powers of voice, memory and mimicry. The action is ceaseless and for much of the time the Captain has to impersonate a deformed hunchback -- doubling himself up in an exceedingly inconvenient position for speech. It is not remarkable under these circumstances that Mr. WHEATLEY has twice succumbed to the strain on his system, having suspended the performances in July and August, owing to a throat complaint. There were no performances at NIBLO's from Monday until Saturday, when Mr. BANDMAN opened the Fall season with his clever impersonation, of SHAKESPEARE's Shylock. To-night Mr. FORREST commences his regular engagement, and will play Richelieu in BULWER's play of that name. Mr. FORREST plays on Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, Mr. BANDMAN fills up the remaining nights.
